--July Release Game--      Graphics are well done!!! There is a lot of stuff to craft. My Ideal Game!!! There is going to be update every month. It's worth it to invest to the game!!!--August Update--      I currently have 6 Bases around the backyard. 7 tall Tower for sightseeing. I really love the view from my tower. I can see the whole backyard. Since these only early access only i can do right now is Building multiple base for the future UPDATE. My plan is Build a lot of Tower in different places. So that i can focus on the New Content Every Month without making a new base nearby. I cant wait for the ZIPLINE. I will put them at the top of my towers. Making a new base is not easy. It took me 10 hours to make a normal Base that have all the utilities inside. Grinding Materials is really hard and tedious job. Chopping weed steam and grass plank is really easy because of the new Mutation perk. Carrying it to the base area is the hard part. You going need atleast 300+ grass planks or weed steam. I want the base 2 floors minimum for utilities and a lot of storage chest. This game going to have a lot of Items. I want to organize my items nicely. also preparing for the new Items coming for the future update.--SEPTEMBER UPDATE-- The zipline is amazing!!! i connect my towers using ziplines. the new Hedge environment is garbage but its alright. the only good thing in this update is just the zipline.

Despite the lack of content but this game is gonna be an amazing sandbox game in the future for sure. It has a lots of potential.

Buy it if you like adventure, survival, crafting, building and exploring etc., yall gonna love it I can assure and it's worth every penny even on this state.

This game is best played with friends. I know this because I've logged almost 30 hours into the Xbox version of this game on a file that I have exclusively played co-op with two to three friends at any given time. I liked the game so much that I bought a second copy of it for my PC. Of the 9.8 hours recorded I have spent ZERO of them actually playing the game. Instead I have spent every grueling hour of that time trying workaround after workaround, upending every anti-virus setting, firewall setting,  and privacy setting, and fresh installing the game three different times, trying to get multiplayer to work on PC... I give up... Even in single player this game runs at like 55 fps at 1440p on my RTX 2080 super. I have heard many cute stories of other players having similar issues and fixing them with "these 14 easy steps." I've tried all 14 of them... and then another 6 or 7 that I thought of myself... It's not worth it... I'm gonna give this game some time to mature, but after receiving two major content additions to the game without any successful patches to even the most basic core functions, I'm beginning to lose hope that the developers are even interested in prioritizing basic functionality over trying to use content updates to push their sales numbers. I loved this game for a time. But now even my 30 hour Xbox save file has been lost as my Xbox is telling me I don't own the game anymore, and the cross save feature (surprise surprise) doesn't work either. I'll update my review when they update the game I paid for... twice.

This game even though its still in early access is amazing. So you start out as 1 of 4 kids (there are 2 boys and 2 girls to choose from) and you are shrunked down to the size of an ant. You also play the game in your backyard with a ton of things to do and find, like building your base or finding pre-made bases around the backyard. I have built a couple bases in different areas and at the moment my latest base that I'm working on is a pyramid base. Also there are a ton of enemies to fight like Ants (worker ants & soldier ants), Lady Bugs, Stink Bugs, Mites, Infected Mites, Infected Weevils, Gnats, Bombardier Beetles, Larvae, Tay-Z (enemy robot), Spiderlings, Orb Weaver Spiders & last but also the most terrifying the Wolf Spider. I give this game a 10 out of 10 and the developers usually have a update out every month. The most recent update added a huge hedge base (pre-made) and zip lines so you can get around the backyard a lot faster and much easier. There is also a friendly robot named Burg-l, who gives you missions to do. You also can find science parts that can upgrade tools, weapons, armor and bases. Anyways definitely check out this game I promise you will feel satisfied and wanting to keep playing the game all night long and maybe even into the day.

The quest could use markers on the map, riddles are nice and all but I played ten hours and still haven't found the first thing for the robot. When it's all said and done though, I'm actually growing bored at the ten hour mark. Maybe because I can't find what the robot sent me to look for. Something at the end of a red tunnel and down a hole? And something in a jungle ruin? The whole yard is a jungle. . .

*edit*
After over 15 hours I found the three chips currently in the game. Some tool upgrades that worked would have been nice, but oh well. 

I look forward to the updates and improvements.

Currently, the game is not worth $30. I am sure it will be. It has a lot going for it. And I will change my review when they fix the issues (I know it is early access). 

THE GOOD: As an early access title, it already looks and feels pretty good. Combat is not innovative but it works. Survival mechanics like food water and stamina are not impossible to manage like some survival games. The actual world is super neat looking especially when you get high enough up to get a good look at the yard. The bugs seem a little unbalanced but that is to be expected in early access and so far the patches have been consistent and useful.

THE BAD: The building mechanics are currently god awful and completely pointless. Considering the lack of much to do in the game, I would imagine the base building would be a highlight. Instead, it's an afterthought. You just need a few boxes and a label so you know where to come back and get your items since the bugs do not actually do anything to the boxes when left alone (even on the hardest difficulty). Placing walls, floors, and scaffolding is not intuitive. Parts rarely snap together and your base will ultimately look like a ramshackle mess. Many placed items do not seem to want you on top of them and make your character do a weird falling/floating/slide on top until you slide off (if you know what I mean great, if not i'm sorry I cannot explain it better). Co-op bases are even more useless. If you are not the host, every placed item vanishes... or at least becomes invisible. The box is still THERE... you just cannot see it... so you need to be well aware of where things were initially placed. If you build a tent or bed (respawn point) you must build it outside of your home because if it is INSIDE your building then respawning often glitches you into the ground where you fall into oblivion.

The game has some stability issues but that isn't surprising for such a functional early access with a lot going on. Once I turned off DX12 it has gotten much more stable too. Definitely recommended for anyone who has some money to spend on an incomplete game, for everyone else I would recommend adding to your wishlist and keeping an eye on development.

The game is fun, and the take on the genre is new. However, it is not SO new that it blows all the other games in the Genre out of the water.
My biggest point of critique right now: The Updates.
The game was released as EA and that is fine. Approx. 20% of the story and 2 Tiers out of 5 regarding weapons and armor were implemented.
Right now we are at approx. 30-40% of the story, which will be laughable if the scope keeps. And we have 2 of 5 Tiers of weapons and armor.
The updates included Fixes (which he had to wait 4 weeks for, as the DevTeam coulnd't be arsed to release faster). And... bird feathers. Yes. In 4 whole weeks, while speculations went for Kois, Mosquitos and Bees, all they accomplished was a bird flying across the yard (it's only rendered, mind you, you can't interact with it) which drops feathers. 
BOOM! BIG THING! THAT'S THE UPDATE!
I am not kidding. 
The second update which dropped just now is even less noteworthy.

All in all, I wouldn't hold my breath for this one.
Treat it like an X release. Wishlist it, forget about it for a year or two. Then check back. Difference is, with X we KNOW it will be better. This one...? I'd refund if I could.

First-off, I'll say that, because this is an early-access game, know that it's buggy, so crashing out of the game, and experiencing other problems can be common. But the devs are a very dedicated team that read the bug reports people post, and are working on fixing these problems, as well as introducing new game content that make the game more exciting. 
In spite of the fact that this game can be buggy, I still recommend Grounded, because there's not so many bugs that it prevents you from having fun; it is an absolutely fantastic game. I've played survival games before, like Subnautica and Ark Survival, but wasn't really into them that much. I looked for other survival games, but never really found any to my taste, so kinda lost interest in the survival game genre for a while. Then I decided to try looking at good reviews my friends had made on games, and found Grounded:

A survival game that, upon looking at the videos and pictures on the store page, immediately caught my attention. because, it was unlike any survival game I had ever seen or experienced, flipping your normal perception of things on its head - instead of being a normal, human-sized character fighting to survive against normal-sized (ish?) opponents, and building normal-sized buildings, this game, Grounded, has you playing as characters that are downsized to the size of an ant, where everything that would seem normal sized and harmless to us is now monstrously huge, or poses a threat - from garden equipment like rakes, weed killer canisters, discarded juice boxes and toys (even food, like an oreo, eww :P), puddles, leaves, human footprints on the ground, feathers (which comes from a crow that flies around in the garden, that, compared to you, is bigger than a T-Rex), down to the plants and grass on the ground. And, of course, the insects, like ants, stinkbugs, larva, spiders, etc. To give you an example, compared to you, grass looks like a forest, spiders are roundabout the same size as Shelob (a spider from the movie Lord-of the Rings, maybe slightly smaller), ants are big enough that they could be ridden, outside ground lights in the garden look like towers, and swimming in the pond feels like you're swimming in a lake.
Because of this, the game can be very scary at times; if you specifically have a phobia of spiders, there's a setting you can adjust to do with arachnophobia, that allows you to change the spiders' appearance - raising the bar/having it at the highest setting, makes them look more scary/keeps them at their original spider-like appearance, while lowering it makes the spider look less like a spider, and, well...comical, to be honest ^_^

Going about collecting resources for multiple things like weapons, armour, tools, and buildings is lots of fun, too:
Tools - You can craft handy tools like axes, hammers, shovels, to help with collecting building materials, or just simply finding small critters that you can hunt for food - the shovel, for instance, is used to unearth grubs in the ground, you can spot their location as a dirt trail moving around on the ground. Axes are used to chop down grass stalks and dandelion weed stems for building materials. 
Building - You can chop down grass stalks and dandelion stems to collect grass planks and weed stems, used to build bases that are made out of grass floors, walls, windows, stairs and ceilings, with frames. New building content, I am absolutely certain, will be introduced in the future with upcoming updates. 
Weapons and armour - You can hunt insects to craft weapons and armour, which each have their own perks. For instance, hunting ants will give you ant armour, which, when worn, will allow you to carry more heavy items at a time (such as grass planks and weed stems); crafting aphid slippers or spider armour will make you run faster; wearing a gas mask will allow you to explore the weed killer area, which is coated in deadly gas; trying to explore it without the mask will cause you to suffocate. 
Utilities - You can craft things like dew collectors (a spider web that produces water droplets over-time for you to drink), a spit where you can roast food (which you can get from hunting little critters like aphids, grubs, gnats, etc.), a jerky stand where you can hang raw meat that, overtime, will turn into meat jerkies that will never spoil and will replenish a very large amount of hunger.
Or simple things like canteens that allow you to scoop up liquid to carry them with you either to drink at the moment or later; or healing items like smoothies (which, when consumed, replenishes your health) or healing bandages, that, when applied also replenishes your health. Very handy to have when you're fighting insects, and are low on health. 

Also, something that makes the game exciting, there's a certain someone you can visit, at any time, to obtain and complete quests, which require you to do a range of things, from hunting certain insects, to crafting a specific weapon, armour, or tool, to collecting little chips (the electronic kind) or building trail marks on recognizable landmarks in the garden, that, when built, will  place a beacon on that landmark that will show up on your map, so you know where to find it again. The chips are something you can give to the one you can get the quests from, which will then unlock upgrades for purchase that will make your gameplay easier and better - for instance, one of them allows torches to burn for longer, another one unlocks new building items, another allows you to scoop a bigger amount of water into your canteen, and - a really good one - one that enables your scanner to be able to detect any raw science in the vicinity when exploring the garden, whenever you come in close range to it. Raw science is something you receive upon completing quests, or from collecting them when exploring in the garden; they look like floating hot pink, glowing orbs. You use this raw science as a currency to purchase the upgrades from the one you get the quests from. Quests, 3 at a time, refresh daily, with every single in-game day, so there's always something different to accomplish, regarding the quests.

It can be hard to find out what to do when you're starting the game, but there's plenty of information on the internet that covers what you need to know in Grounded. And this game is constantly being updated with patch fixes and exciting upcoming game content that improve the game (this game starts with a bit of a story, where you have to find the shrinking equipment. It comes to a halt at some point, but there's hints that it will continue on in coming updates), it's a great game to consider getting! :)

I absolutely love this game! The building is really easy to figure out even when going in with no knowledge of the game whatsoever, the bugs are all really cute even when the aggressive ones are trying to murder you, and the graphics are beautiful.

One thing I really like is the arachnophobia mode in settings, which lets you turn down how spidery the spiders are. At max, they look like floating bubbles with eyes. It's really funny to watch them move around and attack when they have no legs.

If you're considering getting this game, DO IT! It's so worth the money, and they update regularly. You'll have a great time exploring the backyard and building, and if you have friends who play it, it's even better because then you have more help building and dealing with the aggressive enemies.

The atmosphere in this game is amazing and reminds me of being a kid playing in the backyard again. The enemies are all intimidating at their least and can be terrifying at their most. But for those worried about creepy crawlies you can turn on arachnophobia mode to lessen the scare factor. The story, although short, is very interesting and immersive. The challenges help you explore and memorize the map. The combat is strategic but pretty simplistic, And the progression system for survival is almost solely based on how much you explore the map to find rare resources and items. I look forward to seeing a longer finished story, new enemies, new weapons and tools, and increased map size/ variety.

Obsidian knocked it out of the park with this one. Even though it's in early access, it runs and feels great! Of course they have a lot of adding to the game, but I've enjoyed it quite a bit. I love this game so much. I'm not usually one to get attached to things, but this is the first game that's got me hooked. I'm not a Minecraft fan, nor have I ever played "The Forest". Despite that, this game is my favorite of all time! Its gorgeous, even when the game is running at its lowest setting. The characters are so cute and quirky (Except Hoops I hate her lmao) And the bugs are ridiculously hard to battle, but entertaining, and keep me on my toes! I love that you can go out and risk your life to get those hard earned ladybug parts, or stay in the safety of the huge base you've built high up off the ground. Also, I forget to mention that I've never seen "Honey, I shrunk the kids", but since its referred to in a lot of previous reviews, I'm assuming the game is nostalgic for some, which is also good. I love the exploration factor, and the suspense of "what's gonna eat me if i go this direction??" i cant wait to see what they do with the unfinished part of the yard as well! I'm not a huge fan of the spiders, but then again, they weren't created to be your friend.

A "Honey, I shrunk the kids" reference kind of game with unique gameplay. Basically an open world survival game being small in your own backyard garden living what it would be like as an insect but being a tiny person. If your afraid of spiders you can disable what real spiders look and sound like. The game has only just come out so some bugs here and there but it is a great game. Good word of advice, never build your base on the ground, always build high up, the baseball is a good start. Great game and is a lot of fun, I highly recommend!

I incorrectly assumed that the game would be closer to full release and that their early access was something like a late stage open Beta just before the full release...because they aren't an indie developer that literally needs the support just to get their game out of beta.

Don't get me wrong it's a fantastic concept that has a lot of potential...but that remains to be seen.  By the looks of it, the game is only just out of alpha.  The full release is years away...

EDIT: We tried the 'public test branch'... Crash...crash...crash...crash...crash...etc.  It is incredibly stupid to call it a "test branch"...the game is pre version 1.0 so the whole thing is a public test branch...  DON'T GIVE THEM MONEY FOR THIS GAME, at least not yet...

Updated review:

Shrinking down life-sized humans down to ant-sized figures is an innovative idea that has only been seen in movies until a company that was known for classic games like Age of Empire brought it to life. This new genre brings in excitement like never before, and I thought I have seen all that the survival games had to offer.

This tiny game packs a big punch with daily tasks to complete, as well as plenty of nightmarish creatures to kill or most likely, run away from. You can play it together with a group of trusty friends or you can go in solo, like myself, hardcore style. Things get more tense and creepy when you are getting chased down by a bazillion amounts of ants army in complete darkness, but it won't last too long as you will quickly find yourself at the respawn point if you are out-geared, nothing like being mowed down to death by red trap-jaw ants AKA soldier ants in-game. 

Nothing like spending all day scavenging for food and materials only to come back to your base at night facing a giant cluster of ants stealing your goodies right in front of you. Apparently a thin layer of wall made of grass will not stop the ants from taking your valuables so don't build a storage box right next to the walls! 

Ladybugs in this game is very OP, one ladybug can fend off more than a dozen ants, and it's easy to bring the aggro on to the ladybug, as it will auto attack once it takes a hit. Riding on the ladybug and watch it kill off all the ants is a great experience. 

Whether you decide to play this with friends, and use them as insect baits, or if you want to enjoy this solo-style, it can provide hours of fun and excitement.

Omg it is SO good. I love running around as a small person in a giant world. Plus things are that it ISN'T procedurally generated but it is this giant garden that always looks the same. It feels incredibly immersive, finding little (ok huge!) things the family has dropped in the grass. It has tons of secrets! I LOVE the secrets. I so hope and wish and almost pray that one day we get to come into the house! The enemies are incredible but I have to use the arachnaphobia mode because the spiders looks SO good! It is in pre-release and moving from Xbox to steam version I lost my first version but I started again! I think this is the third time I have started and so far I spent 57 hours in the game and I will spend at least double that in the end in this amazing game.

I love this game, fun to play and doesn't get boring even when grinding for materials, the creatures in the garden are challenging to battle which keeps it exciting when hunting for bug parts during the night and day! The building is the only issue as some pieces won't snap into place but that can be fixed by future updates. As long as they keep adding new content I'll keep playing!

dont play if you want to do multiplayer. there are loads of issues that make it not playable in mulitplayer. from glitches like falling through the map to dying and not respawning to the lean to you saved at. Not to mention it's extremely taxing apparently on my 2080 ti which is on a custom water loop and still hits 55c under load. Until the fix those issues i would only suggest playing in single player.

When i bought this game, i bought it with the knowledge that this game is EA. I stepped into this game with an open mind... And that's what everyone should do. 
I [b]do[/b] love the game [b]but[/b] there is still a lot of work to be done by the developers.

The game feels very solid in single player mode, apart from the infrequent crashes sometimes. This changes quite a lot (in my experience) when going multiplayer. To name a few:
[list]
[*] Desyncs (items/players/npc's not on same place in everyone's game)
[*] Drinking juice producing gigantic lag
[*] a (kind of) duplication glitch with the weapon rack
[*] walking on grass planks makes your screen go all jumpy
[/list]
The game feels unpolished at these points, but also [i]because[/i] of these bugs i've had a lot of fun with friends in this game. Aim for someone's head with grass planks, miss because of desync, and discover that everyone in game sees you missing because you are the one desynced...

However, I do still recommend it. Why? Because i have high hopes for this game. I think they've shown a lot of content already, and content-wise this game is pretty solid to me. They need to work out all the kinks and bugs [i](badum tsss)[/i], and i'm pretty confident they will do that. The only thing i will say to you before buying is: [b]Step into it with an open mind.[/b]

[h2]Edit 2020/09/23:[/h2]
I no longer recommend it. Update 0.2.2 made my experience way more buggy than my last playthrough. In one hour i experienced the following:
[list]
[*] 2 Disconnects without any reason
[*] 1 crash
[*] Spawning through floor and falling
[*] ... to force leave, only to come back and see your backpack still falling
[*] ... while your friend sees your backpack right in front of him
[*] Items that are suddenly gone from inverntory
[*] Chests or other placeables that are in another place when returning from exploring
[*] Getting stuck in walls or other non-obvious small boundaries
[*] [spoiler]Crawling into the mint box doesn't work anymore, it used to work just fine[/spoiler]
[*] Server desyncs and rubberbanding, or complete skipping of parts of your exploration
[/list]

Yes, i know this is still EA. But i expected bugs to be fixed, especially since we are now a whole minor update further since my last review (0.1.2 -> 0.2.2). 
Instead, it has become way worse. I'm staying away from this game for now. It's ashame that the execution of this game is so bad.

If you ever wanted "Honey I've Shrunk the Kids" in real life as a kid, this is your game. Fulfilling one of my childhood dreams, I forgot i had.

In its current state, I recommend Grounded if it's on sale.

My boyfriend brought this game up to me last week and the "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" vibes really piqued my interest. I love games like The Forest, Green Hell, and Raft, so this seemed like a no-brainer to me. The only regret I have is not reading a lot of the reviews because I think I would have waited had I known I was spending $30 on something that I can't quite pinpoint if it's in its pre-Alpha or Alpha stage. There's not much content here yet, so keep that in mind if you're itching to buy.

What [i]is[/i] here, however, shows a lot of promise and I'm very hopeful. The atmosphere in Grounded is awesome and charming, and it reminds me a lot of the "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" playground that used to be at Disney World's MGM/Hollywood Studios.

Building is my favorite aspect in these survival games, and I feel like the developers took the mechanics found in vanilla ARK, learned from the mistakes, and polished them up. There's not a lot of customization just yet, but there's lots of potential with what's there when they have things like basketball hoops and bounce webs.

Combat is smooth and has more variety than I expected. Different armor sets have different buffs which is a nice touch. For example, the ant set lets you carry an extra plank or log per piece you're wearing. Spiders are outright terrifying, but you can toggle the games arachnophobia mode if you feel like it's something you can't handle. We thought we were safe in the lab by the oak tree until a Wolf Spider kind of glitched through the wall and chased us down the ramp. They can go pretty much anywhere which is odd, but hysterical.

I'd say there's probably about 10-15 hours of learning, building, and exploring you can do here depending on how diligent you are. Obsidian is responsible for making one of my favorite games (South Park: The Stick of Truth) and the wildly popular The Outer Worlds (which I have yet to play), and their good track record makes me optimistic. If you want to watch this game grow and you're a fan of the developers, this is a game worth keeping your eye on. I'd still recommend getting it on sale or waiting until there's more content if you're going to pay full price.

Let me start this by saying, I loved this game. I'm going to sum up this with a couple sentences. The combat is really nice and is still lacking a bit. The world is semi lack luster as of now and that's to be expected with early access. The missions as of now are  great and keep you wanting to come back and check the logs to see if anything new was added. 

Now that that's out of the way here's to all of you who want to know a bit more in depth on my opinion. -SPOILERS AHEAD-

Combat - The combat in this game while being rather amazing is a tad lack luster. I'm seriously enjoying how powerful I am with just lady bug gear and a mint mallet but that also leaves me wondering how things are going to get balanced out and how difficult its going to be for new players when the game gets balance checked. As some may know currently the mint mallet is the strongest weapon in the game CURRENTLY I say currently because it is only tier 3 and ive seen weapons in the files and on youtube from data mining that suggest there will be weapons tier 5 and beyond. Mind you im killing wolf spiders in close combat without worrying about dying with a hammer and a few smoothies and obviously some armour. How is the game going to fare when we have these newer tier V and beyond weapons compared to old ones. Am i going to be one shotting all of these enemies I once found terrifying and impossible to beat?? The other thing im concerned of is if they do either reduce the damage of weapons or increase the health and damage of the bigger badder bugs is it going to be a pain to adapt as im now struggling where my base is situated just to leave my base. I understand in the change logs they've stated they're all subject to change and i'm excited for it and im sure we will get further confirmation when the game is updated further on future changes of the insects. 

Survival - The survival aspect is very well rounded and i'm loving it thus far. There is really nothing to touch on other than the juice being overpowered and eliminating the need for some other food source but im not too worried about that.

The Map - The map is very strong and highly impressive though it feels empty at times and can be a bit buggy (no pun intended) it feels very well rounded for being early access.  I do hope to see some more areas in the map and maybe an expansion outside of the backyard is possible in the future. Maybe some sort of traveling system between back yards via saddled insects????? The map does seem lacking in resources and thats understandable considering the state of the game currently. I also hope there are more landmarks as after you've collected a decent stockpile of underground resources theres very little reason to travel underground. Im sure that will change in the near future though. 

Creatures - The game in this state has a decent amount of creatures to find and each with their own unique properties. As stated in the dev vlogs there will be a plethora more in the future and as of now im satisfied with what i have to work with. The spiders are always fun to scream my head off about and the aphids are always a joy to hear when im scared. The aphids are absolutely adorable and i love them. The crow which was recently added has also been a joy to work with and also terrifying wondering if ill be eaten on sight. Its nice to see more creatures other than insects around the back yard.


Overall this game is easily a 7/10 for me but i guarantee when more creatures and landmarks are added that will shoot up drastically.

For the most part I can suggest the game, if you are going to play online with a group. It is enjoyable, the yard is pretty big, it is fairly polished for an early access game, it's not bad. That said I feel like the balance of the game is way off. You get hungry very quickly, food spoils even quicker (even cooked), there are only a couple of bugs you can eat, and you'll probably only see one of those for every 4000 spiders you come across. That combined with the collectible science resource with associated trade in costs (you get far less science for the number and price of purchases you have to get) makes me feel like this is really balanced for a group of players and the solo play is always going to be an uphill battle.

The music mixed with the spiders gave me anxiety (arachnophobe) so I just turned it down and listened to the amazing nature ambiance, It seriously felt like youre in a backyard. It was beautiful. Shooting a spider with my lil bow made me scream and fall off my chair...more than once, and lose my voice for 2 days, as I didnt think they would make that noise or move that fast at me....

If you're looking for a casual game, or casual fun with friends, and crave an adventure, hybrid action/puzzle game along with beautiful graphics, this is the game!

Note that this is an ALPHA stage build. They are still adding new features and content at a great pace. There are bugs, and yes there isn't much story YET. With that said, this is pretty fantastic. The ambiance, the writing, the voice acting, and the game play all come together and create an amazing experience. 

The graphics are amazing, everything is so pretty and pops off the screen. Often times, I feel like I'm running around a pixar movie. A Bug's Life is strong in my mind when I climb my way up blades of grass, and finally crest the top of a juice box to survey the yard. It really is a gorgeous sight.

The crafting and survival loop are engaging, but not overbearing. building bases are now a joy, and really easy to do. Food is plentiful, and newer players seem to have a hard time finding good water, which is the dew that forms on the blades of grass. #lookup Just hit the grass with a tool or fists, and the water falls to the ground. You can find mushrooms, and kill bugs to eat their meat. There are several types of armor and weapons to make, most of the recipes are locked behind very difficult bugs. This isn't a bad thing, with a team of 2, it made killing a lady bug easy, I'm sure with 3 or 4, you can make short work of the strongest bugs in the game. 

Moving on to the real threats, the bugs can vary from cute to terrifying. All of them are able to be taken down, but do so at your own risk. Some will actively run from you, most will ignore you unless you attack, and some will hunt you. I'm still unable to take down a lady bug reliably solo, so I've a while to go before end game content. If you have arachnophobia, don't play this game. Spiders are the size of cars or trucks. They are mean and vicious, but if you can time your blocks and dodges, they aren't that bad.

Co-op is good when you're in the game, but the way saves and servers are set up, p2p, it can be frustrating if you or your friends don't have good internet. Or if you wanted to work on the base, but it's your friend's save, so you can't. I think this will need to be addressed soon. (If they need to be paid for monthly, that is understandable, but pricing needs to be reasonable. *conjecture!)

Overall, I definitely would suggest this game, but if you aren't the type to love building and exploring an often terrifying and unforgiving wilderness, this may not be for you. Definitely better with friends!

To begin with I would like to say that my wife and I have played a great deal of survival based games. Out of all of them nothing quite compares to this game. This is why.

Unlike many other games in the survival genre the amount of optimization & content is surprisingly more involved and interesting than games such as ARK: Survival Evolved (which has been out of early access for some time with massive bugs) & Conan Exiles with horrible net coding. Of course Grounded comes with a share of bugs in it's state of early access yet if you visit their site directly there is an issue tracker that allows the community to be actively involved in the communication of what is known and to be fixed.

With an in-game feedback system much alike Subnautica's— which inevitably was a large part of that game's success whether we like to admit it or not, that actually allows players to give their feedback alongside their coordinates for specific locations that might tie into their feedback given. This game over all has an extreme amount of awesome potential and the devs unlike many other early access games seem to be VERY dedicated in fully utilizing if not exceeding their potentials.

It's like if the Movie "Honey I Shrunk The Kids" was made into a survival game.

This game is a fantastic show of Passion on Obsidians part, i absolutely love the way the game feels and I'm eager for its completion. This is the kind of fun i miss in video games lately. I find just about all of it so interesting, the story, the gameplay, and the setting and themes are so fun! Even encountering or hearing the spiders wandering around is fast and intense, I don't think I've been as scared of other creatures in other games as much as this in a long while. Bravo! Although once you find where they sleep and spawn and wall them in its not so bad, and in my opinion the spiders should definitely be allowed to just climb over things so they don't look like chumps behind a half buried stem wall getting plunked by arrows. So far the only issue i have had with the game is being unable to load a save file for awhile, although after a couple of days or perhaps because i joined a multiplayer, the game successfully loaded my 42 day save. The only actual gripe i have is the method needed to obtain ant eggs, although really it's a great way to make that resource more precious.

And if the devs see this, I really hope we get to pet the ant workers in the finished game. It would melt my heart! They're adorable, i love them! 

Also, there's a water flea that swims in the air above the Spade Gulch leaf sometimes, not sure if that's intentional.

Best small scale indie type game I've ever played without a doubt (pardon the pun), the concept is fun and original, not many games out there where you're the size of an ant. Me and 3 friends have put atleast 11 hours into the game already and love it. As expected with a preview  there are a few bugs mainly towards the mutiplayer side of the game but that aside its truly amazing. The scenery and art style is cartoonish yet detailed, the combat is definalty tough but once you get the hang of it you'll survive, the building mechanic is clever and helpful (ark developers take note) and I never thought I would scream at the sight of a spider till now. It does lack a lengthy story but as expressed by the developers they are working on it and what it lacks here it truly makes up for in exploration. There's already at least 5 new water creatures theyll be adding next to inhabit that pond, not including the bees and glow bugs you may have seen. Please keep up the good work and id love to see crickets, centipede, earwigs, woodlice, wasps, potentially black ants that could fight the reds and it would be amazing going into the house and shed. Truly recommend the purchase.

If you like Honey I Shrunk the Kids, The Littles and Subnautica, then boy are you in luck!The gameplay is open-world exploration as a child shrunk down to roughly 1cm. The yard you explore is vast and dangerous, with vicious spiders and bugs lurking in the dense grass or under rocks, around every corner really...There's a crafting and base building system, so you can carve out your own little corner of paradise while you search the yard for materials to make armor and weapons. The game is in early access, but there's quite a lot of polish on it at the moment- new content is being added all the time, however I've so far managed to get a good deal of playtime out of the existing content.Multiplayer at the time of writing seemed more geared toward console gamers, with integration to Microsoft Xbox but nothing for Steam, so connecting with friends can be very fiddly and will require a Microsoft account.

For now, I'm going to have to say no... However, I do see a LOT of potential with this game, so please read everything before purchasing
Pros
- Extremely good concept
- Beautiful graphics
- One of the most realistic games I've ever seen (given the story behind it)
- Extremely fun for the first few hours playing the game
- Background and map layout is just fantastic

Cons
- Depth of field is headache inducing 
- Gravity and physics are... interesting...
      - For example, if you set a stack of dandelion leaf things down and walk over it, 90% of the time, the entire stack will fly all over the place
- CURRENTLY not enough to do in the game from what I've played. I felt like I got stuck right after the quests stopped, and got into a place where I didn't know what to do or how to progress
- I got killed by ants a LOT for absolutely no reason. I would come back home, a horde of ants would be at my base, and then a soldier ant would appear for NO reason and kill me. This process repeated about 6 times in my singleplayer world that I spent 2 hours in.
- Some bugs were... Too difficult? 

FOR NOW, I wouldn't recommend it. Too little to do for too much money. However, to the devs, please keep it up. The game has so much potential and you're almost to one of the best games I've ever played.
buy it

This game is AMAZING! I have always loved survival games, only problem, the good ones are far and few between. I remember the last Survival game I had this much fun in was The Forest. Now I will Admit at the time being (Sept. 2020) there are bugs to be worked out and story that needs to be added but the bug fixes have come fast and the Story updates plus other content is already in the works. I can't wait to see where this game goes!

I want to like this game for what it can be, but I must remain fair and review it for what it IS currently. 

This game like many other in its genre does a good job balancing survival, exploration, base building and a hierarchy to armor/weapons and enemies. What small amount of "questing" and storyline  that is present is fun and well thought out, to the point where it borderlines an rpg at times. That being said there just isn't enough of this element which is a shame but understandable as it is in early development. 

I have been playing roughly 2 and a half days off and on and already have defeated seemingly every enemy in the game and made best in slot armor sets and weapons for most everything other than a few items that involves more grinding of the same enemy. This is playing on medium difficulty so I'm sure this can take more time as the toughest enemies took over 60 arrows to kill. I had also been able to explore about 75% of the overall map from what I can tell landmark wise. Once again, early development but if you're going to put 30 dollars into something just know what you're getting. 

Overall the graphics and performance were really great and pretty well polished for an early release. I played with my wife the entire time and she (non-host player) more so than me encountered issues with object permanence in game; built items moving around or unusable for her, ect. Restarting the server or having her join / rejoin fixed about 90% of the issues but hopefully this will be remedied as this game develops. I'd say for a prelease and for its concept and potential alone this is a solid 8/10 addictive distraction from the world right now! As stated I really only wish (and/or hope) there is a lot more to follow to round this out into one of the greats!

Do I regret buying this? Not at all, and I really recommend it if you have 30 dollars and don't know what to buy.

Such an incredibly well put together game! I love Obsidian, they never disappoint! Most survival games seem to be worlds and building mechanics without much thought put in to merging the two or balancing combat or even the games making sense. This is the best balanced survival game I have ever played. The setting is super interesting and unique and the experience is fun! It is co-op without being MMO, which is always a win from me.

Honestly it would be a fantastic game, I loved it but as soon as I found out you need Xbox live to play multiplayer that ruined it, I don't want to have to pay for Xbox live just for this game, I have no other Xbox games. It would make more sense that if you buy the game on steam you should be able to play online with your steam account, to need another one is just ridiculous.

If this changes in the future then I will play it again, this game has enormous potential to be amazing and to be my favorite but right now its not worth it. I always wanted to be shrunk in my backyard just like the movie Honey I Shrunk The Kids and this game has that chance if it allows users to play on their normal Steam account with their friends.

I've only played a little of Grounded so far but even with the few hours I've put into this game, I can immediately tell this game is headed in a great direction. Yes, this is an early access title and yes the price is a little bit high but Obsidian didn't release some half baked product, what they have out right now is a very solid framework to build upon and the game's first update, while small, was still substantial. Obsidian came out swinging into the survival genre with this game and it really shows. Not only is the gameplay loop fun but the game world is enthralling despite being a very familiar concept that's never really been explored too deeply. I highly suggest getting the game even in it's current state as it shows promising signs of being a very strong competitor to other survival titles like The Forest or Subnautica. I look forward to seeing how this game evolves until it's full release.

I recently got this game, and wow. I love it! 

The graphics are beautiful. Highly immersive. You really feel like you're in a bugs world. 

Game play is great, especially for early access. Farming for resources, completing quests, and upgrading your gear is very satisfying. Combat can be tough, but  rewards. Once you get some experience in battling those terrifying giant spiders, and hordes of angry ants, you're well on your way to becoming a master insect slayer. Just don't get too cocky!

For all the architects out there, you can get very creative with building. Construct grass outposts, clay mansions and much more I have yet to discover. 

Thanks for this awesome game Obsidian. Can't wait to see what else you have in store for us!

I absolutely LOVE this game. It's early access so there are still some bugs (pun intended) that I wish they'd fix. I'd like to see them change the build mechanic to allow for users to move objects once built. There is a glitch that happens when you decide to remove a potential building piece and it recycles all the stiff attached to it that you already built which is super annoying. And the collision mechanic is glitchy. if you try to jump over something, it often throws you back and the grass pieces make you glitch out when walking around. But that's literally all the bad stuff. They're constantly fixing the glitches and it's a really fun game to play. I can't wait for the bees! And I'm super hoping they let us ride the bugs at some point! Once I saw it was Obsidian, I knew I had to own it. They don't half ass anything.

12 Sep: Found a crow feather. Analyzed it. Now I can make another plain arrow but with feathers. Yippee (sarc) 
As of the last 2 updates, we can now open save files and they load properly. (You know..something that should already happen in any game) But we can't do anything actually new story line-wise. Some map aspects have changed. That's about it. 
Let us burn webs with torches. Add a chem light that we can drop down dark areas or we could throw and enemies would be attracted to them. Or a chem light arrow that lights or way. 
I changed to a thumbs up only because IF it' ever finished, it'll be amazing, Right now..it's a demo. 
Older reviews
17Aug updates: Over time, the loads for new saves has gotten longer and looonger and loooooonger. a 5min waiting for the save file to load, I have given up. Obsidian claims long loads are due to antivirus of firewalls stopping it. I disabled both and it still loads FOREVEEEERRRRRR. It seems like the more I build...the longer it takes to render the save file. As of today..it won't load..it just hangs. But the last time it worked..It stopped crashing. So there's that.  
3 Aug Updated: Consistent crashes every time I try to walk more than 3 min at a time have stopped me from playing all together. It appears it will constantly crash every time you try to pass through specific areas. I've found 3 specific spots on my map where I can't go near or it crashes EVERY time. A few times, the game loads some weird save file that doesn't even exist in my saves. I saved near the water/tree and when I load that save file, it plops me down in the middle of the dry grass area with zero health and I die within seconds.  
The help screens on the Obsidian page are useless unless you create an account. That means you can't even read the FAQ's they default you to when you try to submit a bug. Losing faith quickly.  
The inventory system forces you to still count armor items in your pack even after you wear them (mistake). So helmets, chest and leg/feet armor ALL count against your inventory. As of the late July updates, the chest armors no longer sync with your clothes properly. I see my regular shirt with sort of shoulder pads sticking out. 
A much smaller complaint is, if you drink dirty pond water, it makes your hunger go down? Not very realistic and maybe it should make your vision blurry or maybe affect your walking for a while (staggering) but not make your hunger go down. Old soda or juice is OK to drink? They are considered clean for some reason but should be energy boosters (in my opinion).  Water drops are your best source of clean water. 
One of the quests are to analyze a ant egg. They NEVER SPAWN inside the nest.Someone said, if you killed the worker ants around the ant hill, the eggs won't spawn inside the cave/nest? That's according to one guy online. So you have to go kill other ants outside the cave (further away) so they respawn back at the cave? THEN the eggs appear? This hasn't worked for me since the game crashes every time I try to walk ANYWHERE near the cave these days. Edit: I finally got inside. I read that you have to kill all the soldier ants. I did it. Went back later..no eggs. I killed every ant in the area (worker and soldier)...went back days later, no eggs. I killed NO ants. Ran past them. No eggs. Dropped the quest. 
Pro tip: Apparently the devs don't care about physics. You can build off of a thistle leaf that's like head level or off of a rock and your house will be JUST off the ground..the bugs won't attack it unless you built RIGHT on top of their spawn point. People complained about their homes being wrecked and they built around the bug's homes...I'm shocked...well not that shocked. Build in better locations numb nuts.   
Other perks: Fire works under water!! WOW!!! Using a lit torch underwater somehow stays lit. Handy.
10/10 Creative, Terrifying, and Bold

*Update: Patches to the game seem to have either optimized a bit or fixed bugs causing lag, the game runs smoothly now!

TL;DR : This game is very short, almost no story has been implemented as of release (about 30 minutes.) This is understandable as it is an Early Access title. If you want to buy this game for the story, I would say to hold off until further updates. This game as it stands right now is not optimized so if you have a low tier - mid range PC, be mindful that you might have frame rate issues. Also be mindful that as of right now, if you want to engage in COOP play, you have to go through your Xbox Online Services and add your friends on your Xbox Account.

**Edit, Edit: I'm disabling comments, they are not constructive in the slightest, I am also changing from Not Recommended to Recommended because while the game itself is fine, the issues I'm experiencing are ultimately what causes me to not recommend it. Adding a TL:DR.

*Edit: I am in fact aware that this game is in Early Access and that it is subject to future updates and fixes, the goal with this review was to point out some problems I had with the game, the game itself is fine, however, due to the technical difficulties I have with this game [b]currently[/b], I cannot personally recommend this game. I am more than happy to change this review to a positive one if the frame rate issues get resolved. I've seen people with RTX 2080 cards getting terrible performance so I believe there's some kind of an issue there. As for the Xbox log-in, sure, it's a mild annoyance, but an annoyance that is not disclosed on the steam store. (Usually, titles that require 3rd party logins have a little warning on the store page.) I am not critiquing the content of the game, this was not the goal of the review, my hope was to inform buyers of potential problems I had with the game.

[b]This game has a lot of potential.[/b]
However, in this current form, I cannot recommend it.
I know this game is in Early Access so I am hopeful the devs will fix these annoyances.

Firstly, the game is poorly optimised, I play on a GTX 1060, 16GB RAM, AMD FX-8320, SSD and I can barely get over 40 FPS on the lowest graphical setting @1080p.

Secondly, the graphical settings aren't customizable, this means you're stuck with the pre-made settings (Low, High, Epic, etc..). I would love to be able to tweak manually every detail, especially since the game runs so poorly on my end.

Thirdly, to play in COOP, you need to log into an Xbox account, it would be fine if it required you to log into your Xbox account if you wanted to play cross-platform with Xbox but right now, if you want to play with your steam friends, you still have to go through your Xbox account which is not optimal, I would love to see the devs using Steam's online services for Steam-Steam COOP.

This is my pre-release review:
I love survival games. I play all of the good ones on Steam and some of the bad ones as well.
Grounded is different. It has all the common survival game tropes but coming from the perspective of a child that has been shrunk down, like the movie Honey, I Shrunk the Kids, which is very nostalgic for me.
The crafting is fun and it doesn't seem like a chore. You are able to repair your gear rather than have to constantly build new items like other survival games. The items you need to repair your gear is common enough that you won't be feeling like you have to constantly farm the items to keep your gear repaired, which gives you more time to build your home.
The graphics and animations are beautiful. I love just climbing up to high points and looking at the environments. Although the map is small, the vertical aspect of some of the zones make it seem bigger.
This game already has a lot of content although the story does come to an abrupt end since it's still pre-release.
I am excitedly waiting for further content.

This game is extremely fun and keeps giving me more and more reasons to play, I strongly suggest this game to anyone who loves survival games, It is worth every penny, and I promise won't let you down. I originally wanted to play this game because of the "Honey I shrunk the kids" movie, and it went past my expectations. This game still has it's problems, one thing that I have found is the lack of graphical settings, that is my main problem, since a large choice in graphics is best for a gaming expirience.

Being a novice programmer and a big fan of crafting/survival games I have a few cents to add to what others have already said, that I mostly agree with. The game adds a very fresh feel to the genre.

Things I love.
- One (or more) players can design a base and everyone can build it. This is a wonderful feature for collaborative building.
- More than one player can be in a storage chest or crafting station at a time.

A lot of work has been put into the base details and general playabilty of the game. Overall even in pre-release I find it a smooth experience.
Yes there are a few bugs, But I have seen fully released games with alot more. Nothing so far has been game breaking.

Things I would Like to see more of.
-Voice acting, cutscenes and commentary at the beginning. I agree that a tutorial kind of spoils the learning curve. But a bit more "how the hell are we gonna do that ?"  from the characters in the beginning as they adapt to their circumstances. With the player finding the answer on their own.
- unknown or random milestones that key bigger bug battles. (when players build x, a big spider that does less damage then normal attacks the camp) that kind of thing. It could be great way to introduce bug parts that would be harder to acquire at a beginners level. as well as custom commentary of the characters without it feeling repetitive every time they have to fight a spider.
- Custom difficulty settings, One of 7D2D's and a few others best features was the ability to micromanage the difficulty to your desired play style and game experience.

Highly Recommend to any Crafting/Survival fans.

After reading other reviews and A LOT OF people complaining about the content of this game I decided to expand review.


I definitely think this game is a high price as an early access game. I would not pay full price if you aren't enthusiastic about the concept, art or content of the game. 

However the common thread that the storyline is short is because most who have played have yet done enough exploration. There is a lot to discover and unlock in this game and it is up to the player to do so. You can stop at the quests and such but this game requires curiousity for it to be fun and extend play time. One hour in the game and most feel like they have finished the game but in reality there is so much to do an unlock in the game. This game is similar to other games that require creativity and the want to build/explore. It took me about 30 hours to finally feel like I'm a spot where its up to my mood if I want to keep playing or not. I play solo and built a base and a sky bridge. I still have yet to unlock everything and explore everything.

This is a really fresh take on the survival genre.  Everything feels pretty new and the way it makes mundane things exotic is really impressive.  Building structures from grass, fighting with spiders and beetles, exploring the backyard are all very exciting when viewed through the lens the game presents.  A lot of work is still being done to constantly update the game and provide new content, but as it stands there is tons to keep you and some buddies busy for a while. The sense of humor and campy attitude that was present in the early 90s movies of the same trope shine through as well. Definitely recommend!

Although it is not close to being fully launched, this game is exploding with character. So much fun to have, especially with friends. Still so much to discover even after the 15-20 hours spent. From what the developers have said it seems more good updates are coming as well. I recommend to anyone who likes survival games and wants something a little bit different.
yes

First of all, I love the game. I love the exploration, the detail, the story-telling from the environment alone. Yes, it is early access and as such, the available "story" can be completed in about 15 minutes if you know what you're doing. However, the backyard is surprisingly huge. There are secrets EVERYWHERE. Some that can be accessed now, some that remain locked for future updates. 

The team working on this is SMALL (about 15 people) but they're trying to do major updates every month. They are hoping for a full release in 2021 but that is obviously subject to change. 

I recommend the game readily as it's great fun. 

But there are negatives. It's still early access so bugs (aside from the insect kind) are plenty and not everything works the way it should/will in the final game. While there are many secrets, the ones that you can access aren't fully fleshed out and end up being quick pit stops. Then there's the price. Yes, it's pricey for an early access game. The devs haven't fully stated the final price but I expect it to be more in the $50-$60 range like other Obsidian titles. However, they did state that those who bought the early access pay that price and will get the full game when it releases without paying anything more. It is stated on this store page. So I would definitely argue that buying now and enjoying the content as it is gradually released is the better option because you will eventually get a full game at a discounted price. 

I love the game and I love the team behind it. I'm a fan of Obsidian titles already. But I truly appreciate how transparent the dev team is. They are being upfront about most topics, but realistic. That in a dev team is rare and I think is worth supporting. Of course, when they make an A+ game, it makes supporting them even easier!

I downloaded this game on Labor Day weekend, which coincidentally lined up just after the August update and patch 0.2.1, which alleged to have some fixes. Cool. Got into playing it with my girlfriend, managed to get us used to the game and established with a chunk of the story done and a base built up, only to have the whole thing fall apart with a gamebreaking bug causing save files to crash the game when you try to load them. 

We were told by the community at the time to just try making a new world, might have just been our save getting broken by the update. No big deal. Fine, it's early access. So we did it all again. Got farther, even got a lucky kill against a Wolf Spider we found fighting a bunch of stink bugs! Crazy cool for us! Then, after playing for most of a day, I had a power flicker and had to reload the game session. And again, the bug occurred, all saves and autosaves completely corrupt. Game crashes on load.

Community has been trying to sort fixes, but we're ultimately waiting on the devs.

It's early access. These things happen.

That said, the game is amazing. The world feels huge and wonderful and expansive, the bugs have personality and fascinate us, the spiders are horrifying and really make the atmosphere, and oh so much more to come.

I strongly recommend it to anyone and everyone, but maybe wait a little while into the development cycle to allow glitches like these to be worked out first.

I've been a fan of the concept of shrinking down and exploring a miniature world ever since I first saw A Bug's Life and Ant Man. Now, many people reference this to "Honey, I Shrunk The Kids"... Of which I've never seen. However, just speaking of the game itself: It is such a fun concept for a survival game. Many-a-game, I have played that were survival-based and this one stands as a jewel among them all for mere uniqueness alone.

Here's my first couple days in the game:
-------------------------------
"I awake in a small tunnel wondering how I got there, I wander a while and find an aphid. I squash it for meat with a pebblet I found along the way. A few more minutes of random resource getting, and I find a machine that turns out to be an analyzing tent of sorts. it gave me blueprints for structures, tools, and so on from the stuff I collected.
Making a lean-to from lily pad...pads, I go to sleep and wake the next day to find ants roaming through my small camp. I didn't think anything of it first off, and then I saw one with big mandibles. It got red eyes upon seeing me. Then, the whole horde of 7 worker ants ganged up with the soldier ant to swiftly make me kick the thimble.
I cautiously respawned and walked to the edges of my camp and notice they were gone, and got my stuff. I wandered a ways and found the story of the game(which I will only describe as that). After a few tasks and stuff, I activated a thing and it went poof then sparks flied and I had to go to a tree... WHERE THERE WERE SPIDERS GALORE!!
Good God, I thought I was scared of Spiders before, even my girlfriend was just terrified of looking at them. I made my way to the place filled with story and stuff happened that was cool. As I was done with the cool stuff I had to drink and eat, but it was night, so I left the doorway to get back to camp... Only to be met with an Orb Weaver spider that leaped at the entrance to the place. I thought I was fine and relaxed for a second, until it leaped again and clipped through the structure and was now inside. I decided to scream and run whichever way was opposite of the eight-legged scare. I made a lean-to from some leftovers in my inventory, several rooms and closed doors away from the main entrance, and slept the night away.

Next day, I checked on the spider and happily found it clipped in place where it could no longer move. With one swift couple hundred thousand pokes from my pebblet spear, the beast was finally slain and I went back to camp; at which point I saved, put away some forgotten loot and closed the game. The next couple of minutes was followed by deep breathing and a few animal photos to calm down my heart...
-------------------------------

First going into the game, I was amazed by everything. Being shrunken down, surviving against the insectal world of your front lawn, unsure of how you got to that size in the first place, makes for honestly one of the funnest experiences I've had the chance of getting, right alongside Ark, where you can walk among the Dinosaurs.

A 9/10 would be my current rating for this game, just because it's still in early access at the time of my writing this. So, my recommendation? Yes, play it. Even if survival games aren't your thing, giving it a try is worth it, in my mind.

[b]This feeling is a pain.[/b]

I want this game to be cheaper, because it's Early Access and it costs as much as a finished and revamped game [strike](State of Decay 2 Juggernaut Edition e.g.).[/strike] And they said in their Discord that when finished, [b]the game will cost EVEN MORE[/b], "giving a benefit" to the currents Early Access buyers. 

I know that they included a story mode in a Survival game, something not seen often in this kind of games. I know that doing that costs a lot of money and time because of voice actors dialogue lines, etc. I understand that they kind of have a product that no one else has, something not explored before in survival games. So they kinda took an advantage of that and decided to set that 30 dollar price (or even more in a future).
And I accept it, I think 30 bucks it's a fair price. But more than 30?
 
Think about the small team behind Grounded (12 devs and 1 animator), you know it's gonna cost them a lot to develop the game in just a year and a half. And is well known that players can finish in just a matter of minutes/hours something the developers were putting together in a lot of months/years of their valued time. So if you know that almost every grounded player is struggling to pay $30, or doesn't recommend to pay $30 because they know is not worth to pay that much for only a few hours of entertainment, you have a few options to choose.
Or you lower the price (won't happen) or you focus your developers to work in the most requested features that the game doesn't have yet. Features and immersive time-consuming content to grind for. Like achievements, new crafting combinations with new bugs parts, different ways to get those parts, re-balancing, etc.
 
And I'm okay waiting, but at the same time I'm not. Because it happened when we asked them about local co-op/shared split-screen. They told us in discord that the feature was coming to the game, but in a future. I [url=https://imgur.com/a/QcFgCOv]screenshotted[/url] it and saved it. And yesterday when I decided to search for the message again in the server I found out that the message was deleted/edited. Is like they've accepted they can't do that not even in a future.

When you're under pressure and you know you need to finish your game in a year and a half, you end up realizing that sadly you won't be able to include in your game every single idea that you had since the beginning. And if you're not careful enough and you let out of the picture ideas that are important for your consumers, it's probably gonna be reflected in sells/critics.


Basically, this game is a must have if they correct everything and they add a lot of content, but not recommended right now. Sometimes, the co-op with your friends is a very frustrating thing if you're not the host and you're not used to be lagged. Also I hate the motion blur, it has to be disabled messing with the game files, you can't in game.

A potentially good game.   It is visually stunning, has great sound and the larger bugs are terrifying.  The crafting system is good and the way recipes work is quite well designed.  There are a few recipes that are ridiculously costly for what you get but all that most likely will be tweaked throughout the early access process.  There is basically no story content right now and you run out of things to do very quickly.  
 
There are a few aspects I really don't like however:

Insta-healing bugs during a fight.  Nothing is worse than fighting a big bug, putting your last expensive arrow into them and watching them retreat 10 ft, heal back to full strength and come back for more.  Simply put, a Lame mechanic.

Many of the things you craft are totally unnecessary and don't do anything.  I realize this is early access, but most of what you can build has no function at all.  chairs, tables, lights, fences, etc all look good but do nothing in game.  There is currently no reason at all to build a fancy base as once you're off the ground, nothing can touch you.  bugs can't climb and there's no air based enemies currently.  No roof, walls or doors required.  Just stick a floor up high, a few necessary crafting and storage items and you have a base.  Literally nothing else is needed.  Unless you find building giant elaborate homes filled with items that do absolutely nothing to benefit your playthrough, base building right now is pretty pointless.

Some of the current crafting recipes are way too costly for what you get.  Repairing most of the better armor takes more expensive and rare resources than building it in the first place.  Venom arrows are pretty useless because before the poison works, the bug runs away and insta-heals. 
The new crow feather is literally as big as you are in the game but only yields one feather piece which  I believe currently gives you 2 arrows.  Not really worth it.

Weapon throwing is pretty broke too.  It's a very cool concept but when trying to do it from an elevated position, say standing on a rock and throwing down at an enemy, you either hit yourself, doing damage to yourself, or your throw goes wildly in another direction and not hitting your enemy at all.  So in summary, the best situation to want to throw your weapon does not currently work at all.

Enough beating up on this.  It is early access after all and a work in progress.  It does appear to have the makings of a quality gaming experience.
I do however think this could be a great game with some tweaking that will no doubt take place as it gets better and better.  There is a lot of potential here but the game still needs a lot of love.


Overall recommend for any fans of the genre.  Lets hope it doesn't stay in early access for 7+ years like many of these survival/crafting type games.

My only dislike, if you can call it that, is the lack of being able to tell your direction, like North, West, South, East. I would love a compass but I won't complain if there isn't one in the future. I can still get around pretty well. I would also love to have multiple save files as my brother plays this as well. I'm hope that will come in the future. My only other dislike is the need for Xbox Live for multiplayer. 

But overall, I love this game.

I highly recommend this game to people who love survival games.

[h1] The Undeniable Truth [/h1]
The truth behind this game is that it is fun.  It is very fun.  It has a similar vibe to The Forest but it's also different enough that I can still get different experiences.  Below I will go more in more depth.
[b] Story/Goals [/b]
If you are looking for a game that tells you what you need to do next, this game is not for you.  Right now the campaign is relatively short (as in 30 minutes to an hour).  As the game continues to update, more and more will be added, but in terms of the game telling you what to do it is very limited (as of right now).  If you are a person who can establish your own goals, you will be able to play this game just fine.
[b] Difficulty [/b]
The game can be on the harder side, but nothing like Dark Souls.  It tells you some things, but for the most part you might find yourself looking up info on the internet or experimenting through trial and error.  When you start out the only thing you can take on are mites and gnats.  But as the game goes on you will be able to take on harder bugs, but that requires better equipment.  This game does reward exploration as there are resources only available in certain parts of the map.
[b] Map [/b]
The map is not randomized, meaning that you will start to memorize it as you play.  This is both a good and bad thing.  It's good because you will eventually get to the point where you will no longer be lost and will know where you are.  It's bad because you will most likely find a spot you like and will always build a base there and will learn the cheap spots of the map.
[b] Resources [/b]
From what I can tell, some resources respawn while others do not.  Basic resources such as grass and dandelions will respawn with time.  Granted you need to destroy the stub (otherwise it won't grow back).  But other resources such as mints (used for a weapon) do not.  Instead they give you a lot and you need to use it wisely.  I cannot tell if quartzite respawns (the material used for repairing).  However, even if it doesn't you get a lot of it so I wouldn't worry about it for now.  One thing to note is that this game does have a hunger system.  I have personally gotten by without building dew catchers and all of that as water droplets do respawn every morning after you sleep, but it is something to keep in mind as you play.  It isn't one of those things where water is stressful.  On normal you only have to refill your water 1 1/2 to 2 times a day which isn't that bad.
[b] Enemies [/b]
The enemies in this game are diverse in appearance, however how their attacks are somewhat the same.  Most enemies will do some form of a lunch forward to attack.  Makes sense because how else are bugs going to attack you?  STAY THE F*** AWAY FROM LADY BUGS!  THEY HIT AS HARD AS A WOLF SPIDER AND ARE EVEN MORE TANKY WHY ARE THEY SO DANGEROUS?!  Also I am not afraid of spiders, but turning around to see a giant spider just staring into your soul is one of the most horrifying things I've ever experience, and this is coming from someone who has genuinely pissed off their fiance.
[b] Skill Tree [/b]
Believe it or not this game does have a (glorified) skill tree.  It is not a traditional one, as there is no leveling up in the game.  Instead, you unlock perks (called mutations) by doing something over and over again.  Each mutation can be leveled up a total of three times.  But, you can only have three mutations active at once.  Some mutations include Natural Explorer (which increases running speed), Ant-nihilator (more dammage to ants), Grass Master (cut down grass faster) and so on.
[b] Verdict [/b]
As the game stands I would give it a 85/100.  It definitely has a lot of potential and is a lot more fun with friends.  That's not to say you can't have fun by yourself, it's just more fun with friends.  There are some things that needs work.  For starters, all saves are located in the same menu.  Meaning if you have a single player and multiplayer world, you will have to remember where they are as there are no slave slots.  A little annoying.  Another thing is that worker ants are a little bugged (hehe) right now.  They can rummage through baskets and take things.  But their reach is really long and can go through walls.  So you have two solutions: build a wall around your house to keep them out or use chests since they can't get in those.  I use both just to be sure.  There aren't really any noticeable bugs that I have ran into so far besides that ant one.  I've gotten stuck once but was able to get free by spamming jump and the game has only crashed once but then they updated it and patched it.  If you have the money, or your friends have the game then I would definitely check it out, but I wouldn't say it is a "must have" as of right now.
[h1] EDIT [/h1]
After playing the game for a while longer I've decided to update the verdict.  I would now give this game a 90/100.  I've noticed that there are varieties among the attacks though they are hard to notice.  Lady bugs, for example, have two types of attacks.  One is a basic headbutt while the other is a charge.  Stinkbugs have two as well: an AOE gas attack and a headbutt.  Bombardier Beetle can spit acid and, you guessed it, headbutt.  The game had more to offer than I thought and quartzite does indeed respawn.

This is a really cool take on survival games - definitely would recommend it, despite the lack of story content right now, because I think this game will be insane once complete.

Are you not afraid of bugs but really want to be? Do you love getting so scared you pee your pants a little? Are jump scares an awful awful thing that you want in a game? If you answered yes to any of these then Grounded is the game for you! 

I absolutely adore this game but man I think it may give me a heart attack! It's a really fun mini survival game with so much to explore and a really good tiering of bugs to fight. From aphids, that just try to run, to giant wolf spider, who will kick your butt in .2 seconds if you don't prepare yourself. And really well thought out enemies in between to make it hard but not too hard to advance your skills to eventually kill the wolf spiders (not with ease for me yet, but it's doable!) 

I was not afraid of bugs and spiders before this game but now whenever I see a freaking ladybug now I get a jolt of adrenaline which is a weird and fun thing to experience from such a mundane bug. Gorgeous! I commend the Devs for such a brilliantly executed game! 

HOPES:

I do hope the story line gets fleshed out more and the parts that are under construction get cool, new, and exciting bugs and items that I haven't seen yet (tier 3+ tools???). But surviving in the world as is, is terrifyingly fun! All in all a great game that I will spend too much time on! 

(Should mention I think it's a little steep on price atm but I think it'll be worth it 100% when finished)
