I'm making this review based on what I think of the game potential, rather than the current state. 

Grounded is similar to other survival games, such as Raft, Green Hell with it's own twist. It feels like a different game nevertheless. 

The food and water aspect of the game feels balanced. You have to make sure you have enough of them but it won't be time consuming. That allows you to focus on the fun part of the game.

The base building was a nice surprise for me. Not only do you have a lot of main parts for base building, such as stairs, walls, windows but also decorative parts. You can build stuffed ants, different kinds of lamps. Those are small things but can make your base look very nice.

The map is very large, along with the variety of different creatures. It will take a while until you beat the early access version of the game, which is a good thing. Grounded has rich content.

Currently, I was playing with my friend, who was the host. In the span of two days, my character reset twice. Meaning after logging in, I started a brand new character. Lost all the items I had right before and all the perks and there was no way to get back the progress.

We built our base on top of water, which was buggy for me. From time to time, all the items from the base were "teleported" near the entrance, while those items were still existing in the base. I could interact with the invisible items, where they actually were but they appeared elsewhere (hope this makes sense).

All in all, my experience was good and bad but it's an early access game. I can't wait until the character progress bug will be fixed so that I could play again.
The graphics are amazing! love the concept. I feel like the game has potential. Keep it up obsidian!

I don't often leave reviews on games unless they are really really good and this fits the bill perfectly for me.
It is beautiful to look at, beautiful to play and great great fun.  The crafting is bang on, the way to unlock recipes is, in my humble opinion, very unique and it isn't just thrown at you so you can make everything straight away.  
It also forces you to kill some of the bigger insects to progress along the crafting menus and if you play solo, like me, then it sets a big challenge for each of the high end things.  
The overall play of the game is just great.  It constantly has you needing to do something else to get further on in the game and the way they have spread the map out makes you have to trek to places far away, passing dangers you wouldn't want to go to unless you had no choice.
I have tried multiplayer with a mate a few days ago and that was even better fun but we didn't get on long enough to go as far into the game as I would have liked.  There is still time ....
not bad

My family enjoys grounded quite a bit. I play with both my 7 year old boy and 12 year old girl.  They also play together.  You can tell the makers really studied the survival horror genre and tried to instill the good parts in a package that wasn't too intense for children (of course that doesn't keep my 7 year old from freaking out about the spiders)  There is no doubt in my mind that they've played games such as The Forest and the like.  My son bugs me to play this and minecraft every day with him.  In his world, there is no higher accolade.  I enjoy the game as well.  Right now it's pretty much a framework.  There is no revealed plot other than what you can surmise by the setting: That you are children that have been shrunken by scientists that have set up shop in the miniaturized expanded vastness of a back yard and all that entails.  Honey I shrunk the kids meets Hatchet and Call it Courage.  I feel as though this game might actually increase my 7 year old's courage as he is forced to face his fears.  There is no final story to beat yet.  I can only imagine that this is forthcoming.  I must admit, like others indicated when Burgl (sp?) told us we had finished what they had so far in the game I was a little  disappointed after paying for two licenses for the game.  The game has so much visual polish that it was quite a surprise they had released it on steam xbox, etc without much more to the plot to the game present in gameplay (don't get me wrong what they have done is quite an accomplishment)... It seems like they screwed the pooch somewhat.  I do anticipate this being remedied in the near future but with consumers that does tend to burn bridges.

I really like the look and gameplay of this game.  I honestly get sick of the look of minecraft and it's blocky gimmick and don't even get me started on the ugliness of Roblox visuals so it's great that my kids now have
something so visually appealing that I can join them in.  We also like the characters and their different personalities, although we kinda wish there were a few more kids/options.  For example, for my son his choice was either the cool kid or the nerd...for him that meant there wasn't really a choice at all.  As an adult I enjoy this game.  Even though the main characters are children I could totally play this on my own and enjoy it.

Now on to the bad:

One thing that they need to fix RIGHT AWAY is their save and connection system.  One of us gets booted off our multiplayer pretty often.  and oftentimes when that happens you can't rejoin the game no matter what you do Unless the person hosting saves and quits and starts the multiplayer all over.  This needs to be worked out because many might not figure out the workaround and it's annoying and tedious even if you do figure that out and infuriating if  you can't.

Another thing that needs to be addressed is that the save system needs to be improved.  I have 2 accounts and I had saves on one, but as soon as I joined a multplayer on another account it wiped out my original saves, all of them.  I tried hosting again on the original account and they were nowhere to be seen.  This is a serious problem in a mutliplayer game and it just makes people not even want to use that aspect if it risks their data.  If you can't play on another server without losing your own saves the programmers haven't thought things out.  Nothing is more frustrating than having hours of work just magically whisked away.  


Overall I believe the game will eventually be worth what I paid for it.  Right now it is a little frustrating and I hope the devs work out these issues.  Since a lot of kids move at a slower pace it might not even care that the game isn't in final form.  Certainly there are lots of kids and adults that play games like minecraft and the forest not even to reach the ending.  The basebuilding and crafting alone in Grounded is enough for one hell of an experience.  I feel that the saving and server issues are the priorities that need to be addressed immediately by the devs.

Right now I give the game a 6/10.  When these issues are addressed I'll revise this.

I can't wait to come back to this review and change it, honestly I can see this game could be great. Right now though it has many game breaking bugs. My family playing this enjoyed it until the crashing started, and characters reload with no equipment or perks like brand new characters when this happens. Placed items appearing to be in places they are not for some players. It seems to be very badly synced for multiplayer.
The road map of what is to come is exciting but it needs some serious bug bashing.

I don't typically like survival games. 
I don't typically purchase early access.
However this game has enough polish, charm, content, fear, exploration, risk & reward, nostalgia for Honey I Shrunk I Kids... and new content being dropped, improvements being made, that I am well impressed with this title despite survival early access. 
Great with friends, although we have the high ping bug... which is a little irritating. Not game breaking, but almost impossible to time the perfect blocks. Early access.
Who knew so many garden insects could be so terrfying.
Looking forward to all the crazy ideas they can dream up.

Worst part of the game (Aug 2020) is the sound design for the emerging grub. It's too loud! All the expletives! I damn well nearly no 1 and no 2 myself every time I run by one of those damn things and they make a noise like an Arrakis Sand Worm about to engulf me. Clean near jump out of my skin. And its not just me, all my friends are quiet for minutes, busy with all the tasks, until one of them suddenly vomits up 14 expletives at a high volume clearly startled. "grub?" someone asks. "&!#^@ yes." is the reply.

I will not lie- I've screamed out loud more than once and I don't care. 

TONS of fun, especially with a friend or two! There's lots to do and explore, tons of mystery they've yet to apply in game (you can tell there's more coming when you begin to really explore- locked doors, creepy ant-totem cave, places labelled "under construction" etc... can't wait to see what comes next!) The characters are amusing and polished, and when together in the game with others, they respond to each other's statements at times.

 The game itself runs fairly smoothly, with a few hitches, but knowing it's still in development, my friends and I are dealing with the few annoying issues as they've appeared- relog when the leantos and chests disappear, host restarts game if players are booted repeatedly, and using a different voice chat system because it doesn't seem to work quite the way it should yet. (only host, or only guest/s get to use it until it randomly begins to work, IF that happens) Also, you can't see your own chat typed out at first, but it does seem to randomly start working in the color of the toon you chose after a while... not sure how long, but just randomly starts showing up.

 So yes, if you can't stand any "bugs" in your game, this one is probably not for you- YET, (but then if I were you, I'd stop shopping the Early Access pages, as that's what you'll likely find.) You should however, consider adding it to follow or on your wishlist, because it'll be one helluva game when it's in the final stage! :)
 On the other hand, if you like to help developers stay paid and creating, and play games before they're *quite* finished, YES, this a GREAT game.  I am looking forward to the future of Grounded, as I can TELL there's a lot more of some exciting content en route. 


--also, a side note-- some people have REALLY big issues with bugs (spiders to be specific) so there is a setting adjuster you can use to help with possible arachnophobia issues. I think I'm going to turn it all the way on and look at white blobs instead of the spiders for a bit- landing on that wolf spider last time was my last straw, and I hope my heart won't give out the next time my kids scare the crap out of me while I'm playing............ pests. :D

I was hesitant to buy Grounded so early on in its development stage, but something about it and watching other gamers play it made me want it even more – I’d describe it as nostalgia even though there haven’t been any games like it!

One of the best things about Grounded, while on Early Access, is the availability and openness of the developers. As part of the community you feel listened to, your ideas matter and when you report a bug (I know, this pun got overplayed fast) it gets proper attention from the team.

However, and this is something you must understand before buying it, this IS an Early Access Game. Bugs (not the fun kind), crashes, lost saved games, bases being destroyed by updates that change the in-game world, multi-player connection issues, and much more is common occurrence and to be expected. It’s what you sign-up on when purchasing a title in Early Access.

That said, the developers do listen to the community and if an issue or suggestion gets enough track, they’ll do their best to fix it/implement it. They’ve also given us a roadmap of future updates - https://grounded.obsidian.net/feature-board - in case you want to wait for more content and patches before you buy it. Because right now, as far as story goes (which is the most compelling thing about Grounded), you can breeze through it in under 45 minutes. The rest comes down to building and gathering resources or exploring.

If common Early Access issues and all that entails make you rage quit or get frustrated with a game, I’d advise waiting for next year when I expect this game to be fully completed. But if you want to jump in this amazing game and contribute your ideas and suggestions, then go ahead!

(if you have a fear of spiders, there IS a setting that changes their looks to make them less like spiders, but still act the same)
If you like minecraft, you'll like this. the crafting menu is is a bit wonky, but overall the game has promise. Have not played online yet, so i am to see the merits of that.

Broken multiplayer is still a problem for almost two months now. Not worth it until the devs get the led out, and actually fix it. Till then, have fun sitting in the "joining game" screen, praying that you actually get to connect. 

Steam invites don't work, Windows Live invites don't work, and the in game lobby joining doesn't work. 

It's a shame that modern day games can't launch with a solid network, meanwhile games like TF2 that came out almost 14 years ago have flawless group systems, and multiplayer. (We don't talk about the auto-rebalance system.)

So I am really only saying "not recommend" basically because you can find better survival games that are complete or close to and are cheaper than this one. I like the setting and the concept even though the kids being players seems weird to me. Like "a kid is about to be eaten by a spider" personally doesn't sit well with me however that is just my opinion. There isn't really much out there in the game world to justify that price tag after you craft most of everything. Seems like this was rushed to early access with the price its planning to be without actually finishing it.

Scores (at its current state):
Atmosphere: 10/10 - Higher number better
It really grips you and takes you down the rabbit hole, a honey I shrunk the kids rabbit hole. Atmosphere at night is truly terrifying if you don't turn up the gamma you coward!

Glitches: 10/10 - Higher number worse
This is the most glitchy piece of junk I have played in awhile. How the heck is that hard to put a wall up, just have them connect. Goodness gracious what pain in the A! Water not responding when I first started playing, now it is but other things are still god awful horrible. This more pre-alpha with these kind of game breaking mechanics. Way too much money for an early access with this type of conflicts. I find it funny how developers charge people half the games price to play game breaking glitches that we help find that they prosper from. Should be the other way around? Maybe it's just me, but 30 bucks for hardly any story and these glitches. Not cool developers not cool. 
Graphics: 8/10 - Higher number better
Better than the average game, nothing wrong with average. But it has a wonderful pallet of color. Truly brilliant and breathtaking on different spots and locations. The ability to go way up and look over the entire yard like its the grand canyon. Goodness I love it. Give me more.
Content: 1/10 - Lower number worse
How can a world be this big and this empty? Where is the dialogue, where is the notes. The small side stories, anything other than a few lines of dialogue? Really? A kid could have come up with more depth in an hour. I know it looks like I'm complaining alot, but honestly the story is really. Well. Not much. I am used to deep story, so maybe this is more of the norm? I don't care for no depth, I like breaking bad complexity and mechanics. It's science! But without any explanation of hardly anything and empty like my wallet in this pandemic.
Replayability: 2/10 - Lower number worse
I can't believe I got bored after about 10 hours of not knowing where stuff is. 10 hours figured out where the majority of stuff is. I mean. Alright, now what. That's about it. The quest is to scan a grub. You mean to tell me the quest is to dig up a grub, then have to walk all the way back and scan the grub. Boom. That's the quest? Again no complexity, no depth, a kid in an hour could have came up with something more.
Sound - 9/10 - Higher number better
Good god the sound is amazing! So scary at times. Those grubs made me jump to high hell. I called them a ton of curse words and still they get me. I just hate them, but the sound is so good. The spiders chasing you down through the grass. Oh my heart attack is a knocking. This thing raised my blood pressure by 20 points, thank you. I mean it, the sound really immerses you this wonderful empty no dialogue world. It has very nice calming effect of sound at some points and then quickly turns to scary blood curdling jump fest that sends you back to momma crying.

Voice Acting 5/10 - Higher number better

Could it have killed you to given him a few more lines of dialogue. I mean if I have to hear Brussels sprouts one more time I'm gonna stuff them down Peter's throat till chokes and dies on them. Shut the hell up about Brussels sprouts or I will drowned you in the pond you little picky eating white boy.

Mechanics 1/10 - Lower number worse

This is the most clumsy wack a mole of mess I ever saw. Chests next to the workbench, you have to go through you 8 chests to find the dang piece of junk your trying to use. Why the heck wont the game just take from my inventory, and to find out what is not researched I have to go to the workbench to find out which items need to be researched and then remember from my 8 chests of stuff what to research and then walk half way across the map with those items to scan them but can only scan three items and then have to do the whole thing over again until it recharges. What the actual F? Why are walls so hard to place, why am I constantly getting stuck on grass, why does it take 50 arrows to kill a spider for 1 venom that gets you 5 arrows but then they disappear but the regular arrows don't. I get it, early access. So here developers, here is 10 bucks. This what you gave me. Now give me my 20 bucks back lol.

Conclusion 5/10


In conclusion. While the first hours are amazing and so good. It's like Mcdonalds food, it's really good but then later you feel sick and ate something that wasn't real food. This isn't a real game, it's like a piece of piece of piece of game. And you know it's missing so much. But to charge that much for this, is like a scam. But at least they gave you something, that something is 20 less bucks out of my pocket. For 10 bucks I would agree for this game missing so much. But 30? The developer must have been dehydrated from running back forth from the research tent to think of charging that amount of money. Here have some water droplets as they just recently started respawning lol.

Scariest game i have ever played... maybe fighting giant spiders wasn't my best idea.

While the game is still in development and definitely has major bugs that can be frustrating and sometimes even gamebreaking (moreso in multiplayer than singleplayer), there's easily 10x more good than bad.

I downloaded the game based on vague memories of early trailers and gameplay clips, one friend's recommendation for a game in the survival genre, and 90% based on one word: Obsidian. Knowing Obsidian stole Bethesda's thunder with New Vegas was all the extra push I needed to hit the buy button, and so far I have not been disappointed at all.

The world is vibrant and beautiful, the perspective of being a tiny person in a big world is done very well, the dangers of the yard feel genuinely threatening even on mild mode (you spend a LOT more time running than fighting from the big stuff until you get good equipment). The building system has had some flaws but I've already seen a lot of them fixed with just one patch, and ultimately the base-building system is everything Fallout4 ever wished it was, so once again thank you Obsidian for putting those AAA-game-ruining sponsor-pandering toolboxes at Bethesda in their place.

The quests that already exist are compelling enough but I'm excited for what's to come -- the intrigue is high but the content just isn't there yet to back it up. That being said, it's still an excellent game.

Early Access Review for 0.1.3 (will try to keep it brief and will edit my review with each update if the update is sizeable and if I am able to) 

As many other reviews stated this a "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" survival game that feels like a mix of The Forest and Subnautica. The graphics are beautiful, the game has a pretty solid foundation but currently doesn't have a lot of content (Early Access so I'm not complaining too much). The main part of the game is doing repetitive BURG-L quest to farm raw science at the moment. That aside, there is still plenty to explore and you can make some nice bases. Personally the footprints ruined the spot I liked building at near the mysterious machine. I've only put a few hours into this patch so I haven't encountered any new bugs yet.
its a fun game but still cant host or join a game with friends

As far as the story goes, it's somewhat interesting. Maybe it'll improve as it develops. The gameplay isn't bad per se. There's just a ton of annoying, quality of life things that they have decided to go with and I don't know why.
1. Inventory space isn't upgradeable, the only option you have is to make chests. When you're out adventuring, you have 30 slots.
2. For whatever reason, they decided to make your equipped items stay in your inventory bag instead of just taking space up on the body. 
3. The menus are cumbersome and annoying to navigate.
4. The building has some cool features like ghost builds, so you can see what it'll look like before you build and the snap to grid works well. Unfortunately, they don't have a builder mode or easy way to get to the build menu to easily change what you want to build and that got really annoying. 
5. The spiders are terrifying, good job there.

This game has a lot of potential and I'd be excited to see what full release is like, but as of now, i'm about 10 hours in and fairly bored.
Should I Buy This Game? 99% yes, 1% no for poor single person.

This game has great potential IMO.

I'm not going to go into graphics and gameplay too much, plenty of reviews for that. I'll only say that the game looks pretty good and plays pretty well on my upper middle tier rig. 

I am mostly writing this for those thinking about getting this game. If you like games like Rust or Ark you will certainly enjoy this twist on the survival/building genre. Currently the game has a very good base to be built on from what I've seen so far. I haven't encountered too much as far as game breaking bugs personally. A few graphical issues but certainly things I would assume will be patched and fixed up at some point. For an Early Access game it has a lot of features already and I would fully expect loads more to be added. 

I would love to see this game go in an Ark like direction. It would be cool to see it become larger and have more variety in the critters you encounter. Although there are currently quite a few. It would be cool if you could somehow tame some things and ride them around and what not. I would also like to see the building functions expand like Ark. For me these kinds of games are great for equal parts survival and building, that's what I like to play. So far it's on a good track and I can't wait to see how they flesh out stuff as the game grows. 

The main thing I would like to mention is that this game is currently essentially single player. You would only be able to play with a friend on your steam list at this time it seems. The server browser only searches your friends games but it does say a global server search is coming eventually. If you have a friend to play with this shouldn't be a problem. A looking for group thing in the xbox live companion or discord may help here, i haven't tried that yet. So far playing alone has been fun. [ NOTE: A random person on my friends list was playing and I joined their game. I can confirm it does work.]

Lastly,.... SPIDERS ARE SCARY AF YO! LOL. I got killed by one but otherwise I just run away like a scared little girl when I see one. I wouldn't even consider fighting one yet but maybe one day I will have the strength to take on this mighty beast! Hopefully there is a day when you can catch and ride one.... You will be the king of the backyard! 

Anyway, in conclusion it's well worth it to buy at this point if you enjoy this genre. There is enough to keep you busy for now and I'm sure more will come soon.  Just stay away from spiders!

As it is still in early access, there are still plenty of problems but I'll say that it is still fun to play.

The problems I mentioned? I get SO irritated with the system for placing down items/building material. There is an issue with the pathing where sometimes the "block" just won't sit down even when it has the room. And there is a bit of trouble with the elevation of items as well, sometimes you have to place a block at a higher or lower elevation and they act as hard barriers that you have to jump over. Even though you can simply walk over natural terrain features that are more severe, i.e. rocks and sticks. 

Then there's the fact that during updates the world shifts in drastic fashions that can screw up what you have built. Like grass suddenly growing through your support beams, floors, and roof. Or that suddenly the area you built in is suddenly a swamp. Though, once again, this is early access so you have to expect changes to the game like this.

Still, I see plenty of room for this game to grow and become seriously fun over the course of it's development. I can't wait to see what the devs come up with! Just... please don't have the crow be the final boss. That thing scares me.

This game is well polished with most what you would expect for a survival game. Here's the kicker.. it's from Obsidian and it's only just got into early access. With a reputable company and an already solid game, the future for Grounded is looking good.

Ground puts you in the backyard as one of four children all resembling each other on a functional standpoint. You must(as far as the story goes) fix the beams in order to grow large again. Through your travels you will uncover tidbits about the Ominent company. There is many more to be added and you can see some such locations that invite the idea of something to come.

As for game play.. It is exactly what you would expect. The fighting feels good, the spiders get your heart pumping, chopping grass and weed provide good audio/video effects(more leaning towards the audio), harvesting feels like harvesting. The different biomes separate themselves seamlessly, never giving way to the backyard feel. Everything feels natural. Everything except one thing...

The only negative points I have to make is that the arrows are too tedious to pick up and the decision for the server being created on the client... 

Not only is creating arrows one of the biggest grinds, but you must collect them by individually clicking each arrow while hovering your cursor over them... When you take 20-30 arrows per target often times you end up being spawned on as your taking back your arrows. It would be much better if arrows were pickup on collide...

Now when one of the clients become the master(i.e. the client that creates/loads the game) it means that all the other players playing a)only play when the master is on, b)have stability limited by the masters setup, c)does not have a choice to save their progress, and d)become nothing more than harvesters for the master client. Solutions are hard because of the open world and small server sizes. With more players in one lobby, dedicated servers could be justified, sadly the game is directed towards groups of friends that already know each other and all have Microsoft accounts.

Not a lot of story content yet, but the setting, crafting system, and gameplay feel is pretty great so far.  Even if the game isn't telling you what to do, there's enough there that you can pretty easily give yourself interesting tasks based on exploration or needing things for building or crafting.  I'm a bit of a ho for good single player story, and I've got faith that Obsidian will get us there eventually.

The game-play is lightly flawed, but boy is it spectacular! I never expected anything like it! The water, of course, is a big thing for me, since I'm absolutely terrified of areas I'm not comfortable with. ESPECIALLY if it's underwater. Yet, when you figure out the behaviors of everything and the functions, even I can go under the water! It's nice to feel that as of now, it's safe to go under! I'm excited to see the fish update (if there will be one (I'm absolutely positive there will be one!)!)! The birds are new, and terrifying! Please don't let them eat us! >~< The functionality of the AI is impressive in the new update! Orb Weavers, Wolf Spiders, and Stinkbugs are far less predictable! It made me smile to see that! A good challenge is always welcome in my books!
Looking forward to seeing what they've got in store!

Interesting early access game. Definitely if survival early access is your thing, this is going to be a compelling offer. In it's current form you're getting a compelling and unique world, solid crafting mechanics and great character movement (which is usually rare for early access games). Places that need work: the campaign is only 15 minute long filler, the combat is passable but weak and the bugs are numerous. Expect 6-7 hours of gameplay right now. Obsidian Entertainment is a reputable game developer and look forward to seeing where this game goes given it doesn't die before the development cycle finishes. You just never know with early access games. I made a totalbiscuit style first impression on this game, check it out if you'd like to see more before buying.

Updated :

Having originally said it cannot be recommended for a few notable bugs, these have now been significantly improved.

The respawns that were broken and resulted in a significant grind are now plentiful and investing time in building structures is mostly working now.  Although this has resulted in a much better experience, there are still some really annoying pinch points ...

  1) Host/Client desync is a serious problem.  Pretty much every time I host a game with friends, we are unable to see each others blueprints and stepping on "finished" locations results in disappearing from others visibility, or they end up falling through the world.  Various structures are also "kinked" so that platforms appear in different locations on different players sessions.

  2) Random crashes ... no apparent reason, sometimes moving, sometimes building, sometimes combat.

Things are improving so kudos to the developers pushing out fixes over content at the moment and I dare say this will continue to improve in the following months.  This still feels like it was released a month or two too early, assuming you can put up with the bugs (code not in game) then the game is actually a lot of fun.

Some more stability improvements and this will be a solid recommendation.

My friends and I are loving our grounded experience and are anxiously awaiting any and all updates to this game. I have gifted this to 5 other people that were on the fence and now we have all combined forces to build an extremely complex set of bases all connected by enclosed elevated pathways. It has given us all an incredible experience with a simple survival game with an interesting and unique new take. I highly recommend this game to all. The only negative word i have about Grounded is due to connectivity issues. When we first started our base we had a few issues with disconnects even though many of us including our server host have gigabit internet and huge download and upload speeds and more than efficient gpu's and ram. However, after 500+ man-hours and countless grass planks among thousands of other resources our server is almost completely unplayable. Falling through terrain and structures on spawn and disconnects that appear to happen randomly and so frequently that it makes accomplishing any task impossible. Structures will render for some players and not for others and construction blueprints act erratically often appearing in 4 different places for 4 different players. Please support this game so that Obsidian can make the proper changes and upgrades to fix these issues and continue to add new features to Grounded. Thank you to the Obsidian team for this terrific game and i hope to play much more in the future. If i can ever get back into the server I will take screenshots and videos of our massive complex and post them in the Grounded Discord Channel. Thank you and I hope you enjoy this game as much as we do.

I played this game for two hours and then refunded it due to it being early access. I really like this game. Controls are good, graphics are great, and I absolutely love the concept (I have been wishing they would make a game like this for years). My issue is that I don't want this game to be another No Man's Sky, where the game you purchase today looks almost like a completely different game in two years due to all the updates and changes. I want to be able to fully immerse myself in this game and everything it has to offer, and while it brings a lot to the table already, I feel like this is going to be another multi-year incrementally updated game stuck in development limbo, and only years from now will we see something that resembles a complete and polished game. So I stopped playing after taking a peek at the actual storyline and decided to refund. It looks like a great game, but I'd rather wait and experience this game completed, rather than feed off updates like a garden mite.

"A fun, unique, and easy-to-learn experience for all gamers new and experienced to the survival/crafting genre." 

It has been a long time since a game has encapsulated me in the same way that Grounded has, and I want to personally thank the team for putting together such a unique and fun to play game! 

If you're on the fence about purchasing grounded, just know that the videos you may or may not have watched on it don't do it justice at all. Once you're placed into the expanding world that is "The Backyard" you'll see what I mean. 

-MN <3

Despite what this review has listed I have played 50+ hours of grounded however had to play in offline mode due to all the earlier bugs such as login crashes during the first few weeks. and steam does not record time played in offline mode for some reason. 

In Grounded's current state I would NOT recommend playing this game regardless of the fact that it is "EARLY ACCESS" there are still issues with multiplayer which prevent many players playing with friends through hosting and joining which for many is a deal breaker. I don't believe early access as a label gives a studio the right to push out a game with very little content or depth. The whole game experience can be completed in 3  hours which, building is very limited so you don't have much variety, which is a shame. 

I am an avid fan of this game however I would strongly recommend other to wait for a few months or wait until release and allow the existing community to help drive the game forward and improve the game in terms of content and story, I really do hope this succeeds but I cannot recommend this title at the moment.

Gameplay is your typical survival, with the player needing to craft weapons, shelters and resources but its all on a mini scale. The environment is fun to explore and running into huge Ladybirds and beetles is a cool experience. The game has a day/night cycle and you definitely don't want to be caught running around at night or you'll run into giant Wolf and Orb weaving Spiders who are pretty difficult to kill. With the game still in early access I'm excited to see what developments are made in the future.

A beautiful game with an 80's theme and a unique take on the survival genre. In Grounded you are a kid who's been shrunken down to the size of an ant and has to survive in a dangerous backyard while discovering the secrets of the scientists who (probably) brought you here by exploring the world and the various labs & research stations around the backyard. Grounded is an early access game so, everything is a work in progress and there's more content to be expected over the course of its time in early access however, it's been a truly impressive & promising launch in early access. I've quite enjoyed the time I've spent playing so far and can't wait to see what they'll be bringing to table in the future of Grounded. Beware if you're scared of spiders, they run quite rampant in the backyard and can be very terrifying but, there is an arachnophobia setting that can scale down the realism of the spiders all the way to floating balls of clay.

I absolutely love this game.  I've been playing a lot with friends and the adventure of hunting spiders and building our base has been the best.  The game is beautiful, fun characters, and so much potential.  I'm excited to see what the full game will be like.

This game is officially my favorite thing since I discovered survival games. If you like survival and a have a childlike sense of wonder, this is definitely the game for you. This brings me back to my childhood when Disney still had that Honey I Shrunk the Kids playground. 

Graphically, the game is amazing. I love the detail of the environment and insects. It is still early access, so there are some bugs. The biggest thing I have seen was already fixed in the last patch. Currently, the only issue I have is some of the Esc buttons in various menus have to be clicked (hitting Esc doesn't work), but honestly that's not gonna kill my experience. I haven't experienced crashes like some have reported. 

My laptop is an Asus that's probably around 6-7 years old, but it runs the game just fine on several settings so far. I do have a bit of lag at my base when I put lighting everywhere, but it hasn't interfered with combat near the base so far.

All in all, I really want to see how far this game is going to go. I would love more building options because I'm loving the base building a lot. Is this game only confined to this backyard? Do we get to go inside the house? Outside the yard? I'm excited to find out and find all these mysterious bases and unlock some background story :) 

Keep it up Devs!

While Grounded may have some potential right down the line, in it's current state its one of those games you used to hate the Early Access title for. Like, it's meant to be a survival game, but its not even remotely one. Its one where you wander around and never even remotely struggle to find food and water, but then get murdered in one shot by half of the incredibly poorly designed (for combat and balance purposes) enemies that occupy like 70% of the yard you're in. 
Build a base? Nah, the game will just spawn a wolf spider outside your base while you sleep so it destroys everything you placed. Just stay in side and not sleep? Nah, itll spawn Larva INSIDE your base causing a wolf spider to come running over and destroy your base. Just build a camp or something? Nah, one of the spiders will aggro onto you from approximately half a (relative) mile away and kill you on the way to your camp or the instant you awaken. Want to explore? Well half the map is just a spider's nest, water, or a fungal cloud. 

Right now Grounded is an Early Access title just as bland and boring as every other fucking wannabe survival game that pops up on steam EA. 

It ain't worth your time at all for now. Keep an eye on it in the future, though.

As somebody who has had quite poor experiences with other survival genre games, Grounded has completely set aside every doubt I've had with them.

Now firstly, I will say I find this EXCEPTIONALLY more enjoyable with friends rather than solo, the world is so vast it feels eerily creepy without them, as you seriously can't grasp how small you are.
However, with friends? This is perfect, it's a addiction like no other - and whilst it may be somewhat ruthless of a world, it never gets old - you never know exactly what is around every corner.. (warning, it's probably a spider. Run.)

They seem to be adding things at a great pace for the size of their company and everything the world is going through right now - and yeah sure, some things are still somewhat clanky (I.e... building flooring ontop of walls can cause some issues such as getting stuck etc etc, nothing a jump can't fix!) it is still is an Early access game.

Basically, get it. It's really good, and they even have an arachnophobia option which I found sweet!

I have to admit a predisposition and bias toward this one. I generally love Obsidian and consider most of what they release to be rather good. If you agree with that or not may impact if you agree with the review.

I think grounded is great. With my preword there, that probably goes without saying, but I really think the folks at Obsidian have really managed to capture something... Yet again. Perhaps I'm overthinking things, but this appears to be tentative steps toward emergent storytelling first hinted at in Outer Worlds, the company branching into more diverse storytelling methods to enrich the ways their obviously extremely talented team can portray these fantastic worlds that exist within their creative minds, capturing the nostalgic imaginations of the old and the bright-eyed imagination of the youth. I hope to see more of their growth as true artists of the medium. Anyway, all that artsy stuff aside and with the forgoing of any more sucking of Obsidian's girthy meat, the game.

Grounded behaves like one would expect a survival game to work. You gather materials, make workbenches, build bases, make storage (MORE STORAGE), progress through tech and make new things. It shows an impressive amount of content for an early access title and has plenty of unlocks, locations to discover, recipes to learn and gear to craft. The building feels satisfying although slightly lacks customisation options in terms of the pieces themselves, there are sufficient decoration structures and decor to make your own creation. The crafting is crafting and the gear feels varied, and better tools feel like better tools in almost every way.

The combat feels tight and is reliant on two fairly important things, those being stats granted to you by items and occasional buffs like smoothies, as well as the block and perfect block mechanics. Tougher enemies like Wolf Spiders might require mastery of the Perfect Block Technique to go toe-to-toe with them, and others like the Bombadier Beetle will require more subtle tactics, as their acid gloop and shotgun spray will keep you from facetanking encounters with them with perfect block. It all feels interesting to master and forces you into using different tactics and sometimes different gear for certain enemies. A stink bug while wearing a gas mask is a relatively trivial encounter, as another example of the systems at play working together.

The story is largely emergent, and as you continue to play you'll get a better idea of exactly what's going on. There is a light exposition dump from a NPC and it's so on the nose it feels like a self referential joke of itself and some notes and audio logs scattered around that fill in blanks as you play, but the observant player will pick up plenty from the environment. It feels like a saturday morning cartoon in the 90's that has menus and flashing arrows and points and objectives for the kids and then subtle references for the parents in the background... Like a Battletoads figuine sitting in a puddle somewhere in the backyard.

Ultimately, a lot of fun and I'm still yet to experience anything but the single player. I'm positive with a few friends, it could be an experience of fun and adventure quite unlike any other and I'm absolutely looking forward to what comes out of this title as it moves from early access to full release and perhaps beyond.

90 hours... It feels like yesterday I started playing Grounded. I guess it's true, "Time flies when your being chased by spiders." This game has been an absolute blast to play with my friends. This was the game I didn't know I needed in my life, until I played the demo. For me it was the nostalgic 90's vibe and the memories of Honey I Shrunk the Kids. Plus the pricing is just right, this could have easily been a standard $60 game and at only half that price you are getting a solid base game with a whole lot of future content and potential. 

Now keep in mind, the game is in early access and is said to be around 20% completed. Even at a 5th of it's completion and at 90 hours in, I'm still finding new things in the backyard, so don't let the talks of the current short campaign scare you away. They are building the story with each content update, but exploring this tiny world and base building is where the real fun is. The game is pretty fair with it's resources too, so it's not to much of a grind to building bases or weapons and armor. There is a nice mix of familiar bugs you can currently interact with and while some are tanks starting out, with a little time, you'll be the king of the backyard. 

As for the game overview, the graphic are beautiful, the music puts you at ease... well until your life is at risk of being somethings next meal. The controls to me felt better on a controller than keyboard, but that's the beauty of having that option. There is a lot of flexibility when it comes to base building, I just wish we could build into the environment to make cleaner builds. The whole time playing I never felt like I was under/over powered throughout my character progression. Everything I still do feels rewarding and the grind is still enjoyable. If anything you've seen or read has peaked your interest a little about this game, it won't disappoint. So, come explore this tiny world with us, you won't regret it!

(So much fun when you play with your friends on this one) This is a game you can literally get lost in and the hours of game time played just fly by.  Very addictive game because it's so much fun to play.  Can't wait to see what else they are adding to the game in the future.

i love this game even tho it has a few game breaking like every other game out. it reminds  me of bugs life, ant bully, honey i shrunk the kids. there was couple of thing i didn't like which was you cant change difficulty and  the background blur but you can remove it by editing the game file if you want to do the same just follow these step 

1. go to %appdata%
2. go local 
3. go into the folder name Maine
4.  go into the folder name Saved
5. go into the folder name config
6. go into the folder name WindowsNoEditor
7. click edit on the txt file name GameUserSettings
8. find the line with (sg.PostProcessQuality=3)
9. change the 3 to a 0 and save txt file and run the game
10. have fun playing

Okay, so I have been thinking for a while about how I would LOVE a game where people are shrunken down and then turned it into a survival game. This game is still early access, but still pretty fun to play...the biggest thing lacking in that sense is the story is not very far along.
So, in the meantime it does have several options for difficulty in regular play as well as a creative mode if you just want to see what you can build.  I have started over several times just to see what areas worked best for starting up my bases and such (almost anywhere is good if done right though). My first base was by the baseball and built on scaffolding with my leanto on top of the baseball until I was ready but my favorite spot is near the Oak Base on top of the edgers.

Despite being Early Access, this game has a lot of potential. It has a few things to work out, and the good thing is the Dev's seem to be reactive to community feedback and are already going to be implementing some fixes that have been suggested.

My only gripes with the game so far are: 

1) Inventory Management - Your armor is part of your inventory, as is your hot bar. That shouldn't be. But again, this looks to be something that will change so it probably won't be a gripe for long.

2) Enemy AI - They're a bit too predictable for my liking. But this is a minor gripe. Still, it should not be that you can completely own an Orb Weaver spider the size of a car while taking next to no damage just because you have "the best club" in the game. The fights need to be more intense for the larger enemies. Otherwise, where's the challenge and the heart thumping in your chest feeling supposed to come from?

3) Building - Overall it's better than some games I've played like ARK Survival Evolved. But there are still I'm a little irritated by some of the placement issues that plague you when you try to build on a semi-flat surface and encounter clipping issues on the second wall you try to put down just because the tiniest bit of the corner is touching the ground. That tiny bit shouldn't prevent the placement. Ya know?

Overall though, the gameplay itself is great. The graphics are great for the art style. The lighting is great. All your items and tools have a purpose, and different types of armor give you different strategic uses. A great first impression. Just needs some polish!

This game is so unique I have never experienced anything like it. Reminds me of the days when 'Honey I Shrunk the Kids' was on VHS, for those of you who lived back in the day. In saying that I am slightly upset I have not found a giant oreo cookie yet (devs add the easter egg!) or maybe it's out there and I haven't quite found it!? But I have found many other landmarks that this yard seems to have in it. 

There are certain aspects of this game that just put a smile on my face because they are simply so unique and fresh. For example, blueberries. Some are on the ground, some are in trees, take your bow and knock em down, hit them to get the flesh or convert the flesh into berry leather to help make armor. The true sandbox nature of this game, if you see it, and there's access to that location right now, you will be able to get as far as you can on it that logically makes sense. For example I wanted to get on top of the bird feeder under the blueberry bush, I ran up the branches of the blueberry bush, across leaves, killed spiders in the bush along the way and ended up in the glorious bird bath, took a screen shot to share with all. 

This game is a ton of fun, and I play it single player so far. If you have friends, I am sure this is a blast with others. 

Optimization - it runs extremely smooth on my system. I am maxed on graphics, maxed on all else, FOV maxed, on 4K resolution and it is running extremely smooth, more smooth than some AAA releases, and this is a beta! The controls are easy to use, fluid and you master them quickly. The landscape is lush with detail, lots going on, but it runs very well, nearly flawlessly. Saves are quick and don't stutter the game, and loading a save game is nearly instant. 

Look forward to seeing more content. So far it has been very enjoyable.

**Edit: Want to add that I do not particularly like spiders. And Wolf Spiders where I live are much larger than these Wolf Spiders, thank God you haven't made them the size they are in the mid west! But though I find spiders to be a gross creature, I left the spiders on fully, and I think it adds that much more to the game. Though I will comment it's funny to me that the wolf spider growls and snores like a wolf.

The game still has some bugs, yes, and it needs some polishing in terms of inventory management and multiplayer experience, but the reason I recommend it at this price is because I think content-wise it's pretty good, even at this early stage, and I haven't experienced any bugs that screwed up time I have put in the time which would be utterly frustrating :) The developers also have shown that they truly want to build this game with the community and they have said that new content will arrive every month with bug fixes shipped every week or so. It's true that the current campaign ends after a couple of minutes but there is SO much more to explore, craft, insects to fight against... I have played for 8 hours and there are still many items I have to check in the list of stuff to do. I definitely recommend it, although I urge Obsidian to consider a mode that allows the game to run as a dedicated server. Peer-to-peer really ruins the experience when you have friends across the country and the world.

This is definitely in an early access state so beware. It has all the early access pitfalls.

Oh and there are spiders which somehow make people cry. Side note: Our fathers and grandfathers stormed Normandy beach, faced the Pacific Theater, North Africa and Polio, but this generation curls up and demands trigger warnings if they see a spider. We may be doomed.

 Anyway, the gameplay is good, but nothing special. The tiny size vs big is a fun gimmick, but the mechanics will need to grow tremendously to make this one to return to often. The guided missions are done well, it gives you an idea of your goals, although there is a lot of trial and error of course.  I have never been so frustrated just trying to build base walls that butt up against each other. I finally gave up on them. The bugs definitely have individual personalities, which is fun to figure out and respond to. Ladybugs will kick your ass if you aren't polite.

It is also nagware that forces you to say no to an xbox account every time you start.

Push Button, Check Lazer, Push Button, Check Tree and Done with current story.   

 * 20 hrs -------Not rly much to do at the moment, other than explore. I would warn against building to big or collecting to many resources when you complete the current story.  When companies work on these maps and implement new features often the saves become corrupted or do not have the new layers added by patches. So keep in mind you may not be securing your future, but spoiling it.

Addicting, fun, and im definitely looking forward to more future contents ! The early-access itself was fun enough for me. This game brought you to a different perspective, which is quite a cool aesthetic for my liking. Everything is huge, and you're not the one to be squishing them with ease, but they do. Graphics wise, this game is awesome, especially the lighting, making everything looks as immersive as possible, cartoon style. Gameplay wise, it's fun. How weak you are is definitely a big challenge, but as soon as you get to the good stuff, everything will definitely go easier. Overall, this game is worth every money spent.
i bought this played it for an hour not that fun but it was ok for sure wait for when this game is on sale to buy it..

This is the best survival game I've played. I have over 2000 hours in Ark (across xbox and Steam) and this blows it away. The graphics are great, the game hardly glitches (even though it's early access), and the building is pretty good. And it's only 20% complete so far. That's quite an achievement. The multiplayer works great with only a few issues. I love Ark and this is way more polished even this early in development.

I like the game a lot, but some early access glitches are pretty annoying for example: The all kinds of bugs and enemies are getting very often stuck under or in the rock (especially aphids) what makes the game easier with killings spiders but harder, when you appear to have a common glitch when there is only one ladybug on your backyard and she is stuck and hidden in the rock. Box clearly recommends buying it now just to try it out. In this state of early access we can only sip a little bit of story mode, nearly nothing but I think the game isn't much about the story mode but about a survival. The survival is hard for beginners but soon enough it's easy, the perfect blocks, armor and using the environment are the most important things to know if you want to win a battle against spiders and other enemies.

I would not recommend this game in its current state. only 10 hours of good content available. after that there's nothing to do, and i mean nothing. The map is small, extremely repetitive and bland to explore. There is story, and its very compelling but it finishes in 2 hours and then you're forced to do repetitive quests to grind party hat. The biggest attraction, the house, is a black void when you enter it. The AI gets bugged 5 seconds into fighting and sits still. Also the lights that produce smoke absolutely tank fps. I'm on a 2060 and can run the game fine on highest settings but when i place a few of those i chug down to 50-40 frames. The game has potential, i recommend following its progress and waiting. It is not worth the money in its current state.

This game is beautiful. It is still in early access with some areas cordoned off, but there is so much to do!

This game has a very much "I Shrunk The Kids" vibe. There is a different backstory developing for it, but it still seems to be the father's fault that you play as a shrunken kid. The crafting system is well thought out, though it seems rather hard to step up from first tier items to second. However, it still scares the lights out of me to see one of the Orb Weavers or Wolf Spiders appear...and I know that there is more to expect in the near future.
If you like survival...and you don't mind the wit and cynicism of pre-teens, this'll be a game you enjoy.

So to get the elephant out of the room yes the story is uber short with it in early access right now.
Otherwise the crafting system and survival aspects are pretty good.  If you have ever heard of The Forest you will find a lot of similarities to this game.  Besides the obvious.  The game doesn't hold your hand or tell you what to do but instead is entirely open sandbox.

There are many different biomes that you won't notice until you get into them and can't see them from afar unless you are up high.  This adds a lot of variety to the game play.  Night time has yet to be anything worthwhile and not hard to avoid.  I haven't found a reason to go and explore during the night rather than the day.  

I've yet to play with anyone.  Single player is enough of a challenge but still possible without assistance.  So don't let that deter you.

My thoughts and opinions so far on this amazing new survival game "Grounded" 

It has quite a beautiful shader on the game and all the in game scenery and object/mobs look great, there's not too much to do besides beat up bugs and insects at the moment. i do like the streamlined building/crafting system. 

Pros:
.It's quite stunning with it's shaders and a decent day/night cycle.
.Has quite a few things to do and beat up for a very early access game.
.Requires thought and planning in to what you wanna build and set up and where
.Good amount of drops per item and NPC drop
.Ok combat, and my biggest winner, It HAS A BOW!
. Gathering systems are in place to gather water and sap easier


Cons:
.Lack of mobs and materials and items at the moment
.Not friendly to newcomers of survival games
.Water droplets are usually well out of reach unless you build up to grab them, or scout the floor in hopes of finding anything to drink
. Bigger Mobs (lady bugs and stink bugs i've beaten) can be easily killed as they get stuck on certain plants and cant move. (Developers please look into this as it may be an unintentional bug)

it's a relatively good game for early access, it's not really worth the $40 at the moment, but as they add more to the game it will go up in price. So best to get in now and pick it up!!!
It's like 'Honey I shrunk the Kids' combined with a little Minecraft. Love it!

I've only had the chance to play Solo for roughly 5hours at the time of writing. If you have a fear of spiders, please avoid this title. They are scattered through out and will just give you a hard time. 
If you have ever played The Forest, and seen the classic movie "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids", Just kinda blend the two. I have not found a way to put a saddle on an ant, and this saddens me, though.

I see amazing potential, and if the developers read these reviews, can I recommend a praying mantis as a boss encounter? 

Pro tip: Lady bugs are chill. Unless you hit them.
I also tried to jump on ones back. Do. not. Do. This.


EDIT: I've now been able to play with a group of 2 others. (3 total). and this changes the game. Sure, taking on spiders, and other pests is easier. But food and water becomes a much higher priority. It really is a team effort to survive in this back yard. I'm hooked. I've never been a huge fan of survival games, but somehow, Grounded has given it a new light to me. 
I'm excited to see how they progress the game in the future.

I was looking for a survival game that had a bugs life feel. This game far exceeds what I was looking for but there are a few problems and suggestions I have about the gameplay.

1. Torches stay light underwater
2. Sometimes water drops don't move or fall when you hit the blade of grass
3. Thirst and hunger shouldn't refill when you sleep
4. Think about adding seasonal weather
5. Maybe add mosquito at night
6. Add types of sickness
7. Add different storms
8. Be able to tame bugs
9. Add Stat training

Just for starters. I will keep updating as I find issues

I don't know how to rate the game. first: I hate survival games and I hate early access, but Grounded seems to be an exception for me. I have a lot of fun, the world is incredibly beautiful and rich in detail. The humor is also really worth mentioning. But here is the big but: The story is far too short. It currently lasts 20 minutes. Yes, it's an early access game, but at the same time the developers said that the story is already 20% in the game: So my concern is that the game will quickly lose its appeal if the story is far too short. After all, the survival game offers neither PvP nor such a mass of variety as comparable titles, which is also not needed if the story is long and captivating, so that we finally have a worthy co-op game again. However I'm concerned that Grounded will be a disappointment in the long run. 
So Unfortunately, at this point in time, $ 30 is too much. I'm sorry

Main thoughts: This game is great and i am having a great time playing it. it is just like hunny i shrunk the kids made into a video game. you're a child trying to survive in a person's yard while you are the size of an ant. you have to find sources of food and water as well as defend yourself from the many insects that lurk in the grass. you can build a base or multiple bases if you choose to do so and learn new crafting ideas as you gain new materials to craft with. everything that you find seems to have a use. while this game is still early access and is by no means a complete game, there is still a lot to do and explore in what they have made so far. 

Pros: 
-a nice crafting system that will surely grow as more gets released
-various insects with different behaviors
-a unique game idea that was implemented well
-multiple difficulty levels to choose from to suit your play style
-an "arachnophobia mode" that allows you to make spiders look less spider like if you are afraid of spiders
-even though it is in early access it still feels like a full survival game (not including story)
-not everything is trying to kill you. 

Cons:
-because it is early access there are bound to be bugs (not the insect kind). if you want to store food be aware that it will attract ants and they will be bale to reach it seemingly regardless of where you put it. i had my food stored in a container 3 stories off the ground and in a secluded room. ants were still able to break into the container and steal food even while they were on the ground and the container was behind a wall. 
-SO MANY SPIDERS. spiders are one of the more difficult things to kill (at least they were for me) and they are way too common in my opinion. 
-while you can craft different armors from all of the creatures you kill, it didn't seem to me like one was better than another one, at least not by a significant amount. they do allow for different abilities though
-at the moment there does not seem to be a way to increase your personal inventory (that i found) which fills up rather quickly and equipped items occupy inventory slots as well
-though i am not sure the game really needs one, there is no fast travel system. i think it would be cool to add the ability to fast travel between the different science stations that you find

Final thoughts:
This game is definitely fun and i look forward to what will be added and how the world might change. even though i finished the "story" of the early access game rather quickly, the game did not feel finished. if you like survival games where you can build and craft and you don't mind insects then i would suggest getting this game.

The buggiest game I've ever played. 10/10

-Early access, so far from feature complete as of this writing. Features are changing and being tweaked as development progresses.

-Written for console apparently, but absolutely PC friendly, top to bottom. Feels like a PC game.

-Beautiful, fun and light graphical style. Distant objects blurred on my system with no setting to modify that, but what I [i]can[/i] see is spectacular.

-Decently graduated combat complexity. Winning strategies for different play styles so far. Many simplistic foes, a few truly terrifying ones. All manageable with multiple strategies. Some rather complex, but simpler strategies can be made to work as well. Currently has a foe health reset function that is annoying as all getout if you're trying to plink big-bads, but as I've said, there's more than one way to skin a bombardier beetle.

-Crafting and resource gathering galore. Kinda the meat and potatoes of the game. Virtually everything in the game is a resource of some description, with very few exceptions. *cough* I'm looking at you tree bark roof tiles and wood stump splinters. (neither exist)

-Epic base building. At this point simplistic in ways compared to some of my favs but definitely serviceable. You can build a nice home with a variety of structural materials at least. There are enough furnishings to clog it up a little at this point, but hoping for more, and more material variety in furnishings. 

-Looks like it's going to be best with friends but I've had a blast solo so far.  Multiplayer is in progress, but available. Keep your ear to the ground on that one, it appears to be priority one.

-Plagued by bugs. Swarms, HORDES. This title is literally infested with bugs. Squish them until your heart is content. (I have actually hit a precious few software bugs in singleplayer, we'll see how these are handled as development progresses. It's Obsidian, I have a great deal of faith.)

Join the bug hunt, grab your EA copy today.

Over all very good and I can't wait to see what else is to come!

Combat can be a bit janky, with bugs getting stuck on terrain, but on reading interviews with the devs, they have plans later to work on combat and pathing for insects. But on the whole it's fine for an early build of the game. 
Grounded is a great foundation to what will, I'm sure will be, an amazing game. 

Just be aware, this is early access, so my advice, if you can't handle the fact there may be bugs (not just the insect kind) and there may issues, even the occasional game breaking problem, DO NOT buy an early access game. 

Remember this is not how the game is always going to be. Devs probably already know the majority of your issues within a couple hours of a patch going live, and will be trying to fix them. Screaming in the patch notes that the "game is unplayable" and "I am minorly inconvenienced by this temporary issue, I want my money back, instead of waiting a few days for a fix to get implemented" is not going to do anyone any good.

This game, at the time of writing this review, has been released for less than a month. And the quality of this early access release is amazing.
The atmosphere is soothing and relaxing, as long as spiders aren't trying to eat your bum.
It is easy to get immersed and lose hours just cutting down grass to build a makeshift home to protect yourself from the ants and larva that wander around.
And it's not overly difficult and grindy like other survival games (Yes, I am looking at you, ARK).
Even the great menacing Wolf Spider can be beat with relative ease once you get fully used to the mechanics.
There are only a few cons that I have, and they may or may not be patched in the future.
1. The inventory space is heckin small, and it isn't fully optimized. 
    A. Stack sizes goes from 10 for most items, to 20 for smaller items like arrows. And armor and weapons that are equipped to you or your hotbar takes up an inventory slot. This means your inventory gets really full, really fast. And you'll spend a lot of time shuffling things around trying to haul the best loot without leaving anything behind.
    B. Currently, you cannot transfer or drop a full stack at once. At least, not with a hot key. To transfer a full stack between inventories, you can drag the full stack,, but, as I said, there is no hotkey. 
2. Building bases is a bit wonky. When things like walls or scaffolding is trying to snap, it ends up snapping rapidly to different snap points and can get a bit disorienting.

As of this current moment, I can't really think of any other cons. This game has serious potential! Give it a shot!

So with the game being early access the amount of available content is limited and I find that this is the main reason for most of the negative reviews. To me however, there's a quite a few reasons this game is worth the $30 price tag even though its in early development.

1. The Game is solid. I haven't encountered any bugs (hehe no pun intended) 
2. When the game does finally come to a full release they will most likely hike the price. 
3. Its a nice spin on the survival genre.  I enjoy the cartoony graphics, shrunken world and characters and overall concept.
4. Finally, The big issue I found in most negative reviews is that the content is limited and when you finish the hour or so story content that's available you're left with a shell of a game. This is TRUE. You can do small random missions for an NPC and continue building and crafting but that's it.  For some this is a deal breaker but for me it's a reason to keep coming back and working through the fresh content as its released.

Final thoughts: I believe its worth the $30 because I think it will only increase in price upon full release. They nailed the survival aspect and its nice to fight something other than a zombie.

Fantastic game! Haven't been sucked into a world like this for many moons.

PROS:
- Detailed and immersive world to explore. The map is full of fun surprises to encounter and lots of lore and currency collectables to find. Usually tucked away in some hidden area or accessible through a "jump puzzle."
- Graphics are pretty and it runs on high settings on my non-gaming, potato pc so it's very well optimised. Also less than 4gb filesize, how?
- The survival aspects are easy to live by once you work out where to find certain resources, adding just enough pressure to ensure you're watching your hunger/thirst meters but not constantly scavenging to stay alive. There's heaps of clever quality of life options that make things a lot easier once you learn them. (Trail markers are your friend and the smoothie station is awesome!)
- The combat is basic but fun. Melee fighting is satisfying and the weapons have a nice weight to their swings and allow you to block most attacks. Ranged fighting (bow, throwables) is less viable as it does very little damage (haven't got the Spider Bow yet which looks much more powerful) but still fun. Ranged is basically used to lure large enemies out or to "cheese" them from unreachable heights. There are status effects like stun, poison etc on more advanced weapons too. Overall it's much better than most survival games in this aspect.
- Crafting is simple and operates on an analysis system where you bring mats to a computer to unlock associated crafting recipes. It works and gives you an incentive to take on the more challenging bugs for access to higher tier recipes.

CONS:
- The story adds a lot of flavour to the world and is genuinely intriguing but there's next to none of it at this stage of development. What is there will leave you hanging for more story content badly so I can understand other reviewers taking a dark view of this. 
- Building is a bit of a mess at this stage. Objects can be placed as transparent blue "place holder" structures which lets you map out your base before you have the mats to actually construct it all (much like The Forest, it's great for being able to visualise your goals) but the placements of walls and floors etc is extremely hit and miss with where it will allow you to build and snap pieces together. Needs work but we still managed to make a pretty badass tree fort!

IS IT WORTH THE ASKING PRICE AT THIS STAGE OF EA?
If you're playing purely for the story content: No. The story seems like it will be awesome but at this stage it's just a tease of future content. Excited to see more.
If you're playing for the sandbox experience of most survival games: Yes, definitely. There's heaps of map to explore, items to find, crafting recipes to unlock and challenging bugs to conquer. If you're playing with a friend it's even better. The co-op is seamless and makes base building and tackling spiders etc a lot less daunting. There's also a bunch of character banter you'll miss if playing alone which gives the characters a bit more personality.

Hopefully that helps!

Grounded is a very pretty and very well made survival/exploration game.

It ticks all the boxes:

Nice graphics
Base building
Crafting
Hunting/Gathering
Progression (on things you can craft and build anyway)
Exploration

If you have ever played any of the really good survival crafting games on Steam (The Forest, Subnautica) then there's nothing really new here for you other than the setting.

I'd say as it is, it doesn't offer any more or any less than the existing survival crafting games already out, there's no new gameplay to be had here.

It is early access so I'm hoping obsidian can bring something new to the genre (other than the setting)

Maybe the ability to tame some of the bugs and ride them, maybe find a remote control car you can drive, maybe humans walking around the backyard mowing the lawn, maybe a decent storyline that is more than an hour or so long?

We will see, for now, I wouldn't recommend unless you haven't played The Forest or Subnautica.

Honey I Shrunk the Kids meets Survival-Crafting game. You can play alone or co-op with 3 other friends, select one of 4 unique characters, and set out on an miniaturized adventure in your own back yard, encountering all kinds of common insects such as worker ants, ladybugs, stinkbugs, spiders and more. Create home-bases using blades of grass and weeds, handcraft armor and weapons using the parts of that last bug you squashed, as you try to survive in the wilderness of your yard and uncover the truth of how you got there.

This game is early-access and is not complete, but there is enough content in-game to keep you interested for multiple hours. There is unlimited potential with how the developer can steer this game, the map is still being worked on, and new creatures and content are expected to be released by the end of August. 

The base building is similar to "The Forest" where, when you chop down a blade of grass, it will break into individual pieces for you to haul off to your base. You can craft a variety of different stations and utilities to help you along your way, such as a spider web rain catcher to help you catch water droplets, or lanterns made out of sprigs and sap. You can create unique armor sets and weapons that come with passive set bonuses using bug parts and other resources, forcing you to venture deeper into the yard to fight more difficult creatures. 

The story is incomplete at this time, but allows daily missions that reward a resource that allows you to research new blueprints and schematics. The resource can be found while exploring the map, or by analyzing resources in many of the research sites that have been left around the yard.

Pro's: gorgeous graphics, creatures are great, their AI makes it so you can react around them, still play if your not looking to fight (spiders), but not so simple that it makes the game boring; theirs a good portion of crafting, building, fighting which offers a great diversity for different types of survivalist gamers. The game is diverse enough that if you do want to grind, you can put in the time, but can be casual enough, you can do small sessions and still have fun. I do recommend having a friend or two to play with, trying to have a nice base AND do the exploring can be a bit taxing solo. 

Cons: I've had a couple small bugs, nothing game breaking but required a server restart a couple times (enemy creature empty health bar gets stuck on my screen), (an Ant appeared to steal from chests, and seemed to give the items back too me, when I went to put them back in chests, some of the items became invisible (we're still there, but couldn't see them).  However a quick exit and relaunch of the hosting multiplayer fixed it. 

Wishes: have ways to make players a little more sustainable against the bigger creatures (spiders, beetles), perhaps stuff like "Acorn armor gives a boost against spider bites because they're not designed to bite thru an acorn shell" or stuff of the like; otherwise it's a gorgeous game, well made, excited to see what's to come.

Grounded basically takes the "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" movie and turns it into an adventure survival game.  The campaign is ridiculously short.  Once the campaign is complete, you can continue to gather, build, and upgrade your gear ... but there is no compelling reason to continue building or upgrading.  

The game is beautiful!  Gameplay is fun, and becomes even more fun with a friend or two.  Also, survival becomes more likely when there are folks who can revive you after you fall.  

I recommend giving Grounded a shot.  Each update has offered noticeable improvements, and the game will be a steal if the price stays the same once it leaves early access or once the early access version is updated with some more story or quests.
