This is my first review so be gentle in the comments, please!

First off I have to admit that the $29.99 price tag for an EA game on its first day of release nearly made me pass it up. However, that being said. I honestly think that it's the best ~$30 I have spent on a game for a very, [b]very[/b] long time. Take that with some context, on Steam alone I have 279 games with 404 DLC's. On top of that I have Epic Store, EA Games Store, Bethesda Store and Blizzard Store games plus at least a hundred other titles that don't fit into any of those. So [i]Grounded[/i] has a [u]lot[/u] of competition to earn that statement.

Now it is true that the game has limited [u]storyline[/u] content at the moment, which for having been out for less than 3 weeks (18 days since it's first availability as an EA game) it is still way more than I have seen with some other titles in a close price range. Heck, there are quite a few games out there of the same vein that have been years in EA development, cost as much and still have less storyline. [b]But[/b] here's the thing, [u]everything[/u] else about the game is well fleshed out and well polished already! It can only get better from here. (Which by the way they already have their first couple of patches out. already!)

And a great thing that I have never seen before in an EA title (at least not done this well) is when you reach the end of the into storyline there is an NPC that has daily quests and objectives as well as blueprints you can unlock from the the science earned in those quest, so there is still a lot more gaming to do before the next storyline update!

With the high quality they put out on literally day 1, being superior to a lot of multi-year EA games in the same price range I definitely expect huge things from this very tiny game! 

[b][u]TLDR:[/u][/b] Within the top 5 of the 279 Steam games I own. [b][u]Well[/u][/b] worth the mildly high entry for an EA game. I will be buying copies for my friends. Well up to 3 of them, the rest can be eaten by spiders. 6/5 stars! Now if you will excuse me, I need to play more of this game. (I already finished the current storyline but the game is so worth playing on after it!)
Lots of surprises and secrets, also allot of fun crafting metheds and even if the story line is not finished it leaves u wanting to play the game more.

The game has the potential to be very good.  However, the game as it is now has a very VERY LONG list of bugs.  A good portion of these bugs are even game breaking.  

If you are going to play this game with friends, I would suggest you hold off until the devs fix the multiplayer issue.  Right now, you may not even be able to join your friends session as it will not show up in the multiplayer directory.  

Next, there is a point where the day/night cycle will break, leaving you at the same exact time of the day indefinitely.  This can be problematic if you're playing in the night time, as it will be permanently dark.

Now the Larva Swarms.  After a good amount of time passes, your base will start getting attacked by larvae.  As time passes, the swarms get bigger.  It gets to the point where there are too many larvae and your fps gets killed.

The game is good concept is good.  It's just really REALLY buggy.  I don't recommend playing it now.  As I have heard, the devs will only update this game monthly.  That may even include fixes for the bugs stated above.  This does not give me confidence that these issues will be resolved quickly.  I would suggest that you wait a year before picking this game up, unless you intend to work with the devs on identifying the bugs.

As the game improves, I may change my review to "recommended".  As of now, I do not recommend picking up this game.

UPDATE:  It seems the devs have listened and made some fixes!  So far, the only thing I'm having issue with are the crashes mid-game and time stopping.  I'll be happy to revise my review once these are fixed.

UPDATE 8/14/20:  It seems they fixed some of the respawning bugs.  However at the moment, Whenever you harvest something, the grass/mushroom/etc the model still remains intact.  That means that after cutting down grass, you'll still see the model as if it hasn't been cut in the first place.  The game is slowly improving, but still not worth the 30 dollars because that's too high for something released on its early stages.  I'll still say not recommended, but I'll definitely change my review once further improvements have been made.
Buggy, but a lot of promise! Very fun game with friends, cool twist on classic survival genre.

Gorunded is by far one of the best survival games that I have ever played. The entire concept of the game is very well done. The character choices are great although i would like to see light customization, maybe something like a hair color change or t shirt change. The story is still progressing so it is very short at the moment but i would love to have maybe a journal that shows what ur currently doing with maybe a tip on where to go or a short explanation to look at. The builiding aspect of the game is really cool but i will say i do wish that resources especially weeds themselves would respawn faster so that base building and expanding is more worth the grind to do. Also  being able to place things is a bit glitchy and should be looked at. I would also like to see more decoration items that are craftable like tables, rugs, a real bed or hammock, ways to connect multiple floor like elevators or bridges, etc.. just to give us more options of things to build for us creative people. Now onto the map! The map is giant and there is still areas that are incomplete and I cant wait for that but i really am hoping that there is some type of transportation with something like mounts. being able to ride a lady bug or wolf spider and tame them would just make the travel time and maybe even material hauling alot better. With mounts and maybe taming animals i would then want to see more base building options so that the bugs will have a space of their own so like new fences that hold bugs or maybe a fence that tame bugs don't attack something along those lines. i know the other labs are inaccessible right now but ppl are glitching into them and creating their own lore so i would love for those to be opened up so that we can experience that without having to glitch into them. with the logs i think that there should be a 1 out of 11 or how ever many there are that way we know there is more story that we haven't collected yet.  i also know that the ant eggs are glitched so if we could make those spawn more or maybe have to do something to trigger them that would be great because currently i've looked 10 times and haven't found a single one. i could probably go on for hours with things i love from the game and things that i want to see from the game! the game is fantastic and is still in its very early stages and i just cant wait for more things to come out so that i might waste many more hours of my life on it :) if ur sketchy on survival games or just this game in general go over to xbox game pass and grab the game for free then if its something you love come on over to steam or xbox which ever and purchase the game that way ur supporting the amazing people who are developing this game! thank you for taking the time to read this and GL on ur gaming experience!!!!

Bear in mind, this is at a very early stage of early access when you are purchasing this.

Having said that, it's pretty well fleshed out for the stage it's in of development, and I have only run into one bug regarding the physics of plants launching me.

Not a lot of story to it at the moment, gives you a taste, but ends early.  Not a hugely diverse ecosystem of plants, bugs, consumables, tools nor armor, but what's there is functional, and even at this stage (being that its in alpha 0.1.2) has given me a few hours of enjoyment, which is more than I can say for most early access survival games.  

This is Obsidian we're talking about here.  They turned the shitty engine that bethesda built and made the best game in the fallout series (Yeah yeah, 1 and 2 purists, we get it.  You're old, and nostalgia is a powerful thing).  Its probably going to be pretty good later down the line.  I'm willing to take the risk in buying it now, and see where it goes.  At least they're a reliable studio.

Im being forced to speak, so instead i will just copy and paste an epic poem.

He came a far road, was weary, found peace,
and set all his labors on a tablet of stone.
He built the rampart of Uruk-the-Sheepfold,
of holy Eanna, the sacred storehouse.

See its wall like a strand of wool,
view its parapet that none could copy!
Take the stairway of a bygone era,
draw near to Eanna, seat of Ishtar the goddess,
that no later king could ever copy!

Climb Uruk’s wall and walk back and forth!
Survey its foundations, examine the brickwork!
Were its bricks not fired in an oven?
Did the Seven Sages not lay its foundation?

[A square mile is] city, [a square mile [date-grove, a square mile is
clay-pit, half a quarter mile the temple of Ishtar:
[three square miles] and a half is Uruk’s expanse.

[See] the tablet-box of cedar,
[release] its clasp of bronze!
[Lift] the lid of its secret,
[pick] up the tablet of lapis lazuli and read out
the travels of Gilgamesh, all that he went through.

Surpassing all other kings, heroic in stature,
brave scion of Uruk, wild bull on the rampage!
Going at the force he was the vanguard,
going at the rear, one his comrades could trust!

A mighty bank, protecting his warriors,
a violent flood-wave, smashing a stone wall!
Wild bull of Lugalbanda, Gilgamesh, the perfect in strength,
suckling of the august Wild Cow, the goddess Ninsun!

Gilgamesh the tall, magnificent and terrible,
who opened passes in the mountains,
who dug wells on the slopes of the uplands,
and crossed the ocean, the wide sea to the sunrise;

who scoured the world ever searching for life,
and reached through sheer force Uta-napishti the Distant;
who restored the cult-centers destroyed by the Deluge,
and set in place for the people the rites of the cosmos.

Who is there can rival his kingly standing,
and say like Gilgamesh, ‘It is I am the king’?
Gilgamesh was his name from the day he was born,
two-thirds of him god and one third human.

It was the Lady of the Gods drew the form of his figure,
While his build was perfected by divine Nudimmud.

* * *

A triple cubit was his foot, half a rod his leg.
Six cubits was his stride,
… cubits the front part of his …

His cheeks were bearded like those of …,
the hair of his head grew thickly [as barley.]
When he grew tall his beauty was consummate,
by earthly standards he was most handsome.

In Uruk-the-Sheepfold he walks [back and forth,]
like a wild bull lording it, head held aloft.
He has no equal when his weapons are brandished,
his companions are kept on their feet by his contests.
The young men of Uruk he harries without warrant,
Gilgamesh lets no son go free to his father.
By day and by night his tyranny grows harsher,
Gilgamesh, [the guide of the teeming people!]

It is he who is shepherd of Uruk-the-Sheepfold,
[but Gilgamesh] lets no [daughter go free to her] mother.
[The women voiced] their [troubles to the goddesses,]
[they brought their] complaint before [them:]

‘[Though powerful, pre-eminent,] expert [and mighty,]
[Gilgamesh] lets [no] girl go free to [her bridegroom.]’
The warrior’s daughter, the young man’s bride,
to their complaint the goddess paid heed.

The gods of haven, the lords of initiative,
[to the god Anu they spoke] …:
‘A savage wild bull you have bred in Uruk-the-Sheepfold,
he has no equal when his weapons are brandished.

‘His companions are kept on their feet by his contests,
[the young men of Uruk] he harries without warrant.
Gilgamesh lets no son go free to his father,
by day and by [night his tyranny grows] harsher.

‘Yet he is the shepherd of Uruk-the-Sheepfold,
Gilgamesh, [the guide of the] teeming [people]
Though he their shepherd and their [protector,]
powerful, pre-eminent, expert [and mighty,]
Gilgamesh lets no girl go free to her bride[groom.]’

The warrior’s daughter, the young man’s bride:
To their complaint the [Anu] paid heed.

They summoned Aruru, the great one:
‘You, Aruru, created [mankind:]
now fashion what Anu has thought of!

‘Let him be a match for the storm of his heart,
let them vie with each other, so Uruk may be rested’
The goddess Aruru heard these words,
What Anu had thought of she fashioned within her.

The goddess Aruru, she washed her hands,
took a pinch of clay, threw it down in the wild.
In the wild she created Enkidu, the hero,
offspring of silence, knit strong by Ninurta.

All his body is matted with hair,
he bears long tresses like those of a woman:
the hair of his head grows thickly as barley,
he knows not a people, nor even a country.

Coated in hair like the god of animals,
with the gazelles he grazes on grasses,
joining the throng with the game at the water-hole,
his heart delighting with the beasts in the water.

A hunter, a trapper-man,
did come upon him by the water-hole.
One day, a second and then a third,
he came upon him by the water-hole.
When the hunter saw him, his expression froze,
but he with his herds — he went back to his lair.

[The hunter was] troubled, subdued and silent,
his mood [was despondent,] his features gloomy.
In his heart there was sorrow,
his face resembled [one come from] afar.

The hunter opened [his mouth] to speak, saying [to his father:]
‘My father, there was a man came [by the water-hole.]
Mightiest in the land, strength [he possesses,]
[his strength] is as mighty [as a rock] from the sky.

‘Over the hills he [roams all day,]
[always] with the herd [he grazes on grasses,]
[always] his tracks [are found] by the water-hole,
[I am afraid and] I dare not approach him.

‘[He fills in the] pits that I [myself] dig,
[he pulls up] the snares that I lay.
[He sets free from my grasp] all the beasts of the field,
[he stops] me doing the work of the wild.’

[His father opened his mouth to] speak, saying to the hunter:
‘[My son, in the city of] Uruk [go seek out] Gilgamesh!
……… in his presence,
his strength is as mighty [as a rock from the sky.]

‘[Take the road,] set your face [toward Uruk,]
[do not rely on] the strength of a man!
[Go, my son, and] fetch [Shamhat the harlot,]
[her allure is a match] for even the mighty!

‘[When the herd comes] down [to] the water-hole,
[she should strip off] her [raiment to reveal] her charms.
[He will] see her, and he will approach her,
his herd will spurn him, [though he grew up ] amongst it.’

[Paying heed] to the advice of his father,
the hunter went off, [set out on the journey.]
He took the road, set [his face] toward Uruk,
Before Gilgamesh the king [he spoke these words:]

‘There was a man [came by the water-hole,]
mightiest in the land, strength [he possesses,]
[his strength] is as mighty as a rock from the sky.

‘Over the hills he roams all [day,]
always with the herd [he grazes on grasses,]
always his tracks [are found] by the water-[hole,]
I am afraid and I dare not approach [him.]

‘He fills in the pits that I [myself] dig,
he pulls up the snares [that I lay.]
He sets free from my grasp all the beasts of the field,
he stops me doing the work of the wild.’

Said Gilgamesh to him, to the hunter:
‘Go, hunter, take with you Shamhat the harlot!

‘When the herd comes down to the water-hole,
she should strip off her raiment to reveal her charms.
He will see her, and will approach her,
His herd will spurn him, though he grew up amongst it.’

Off went the hunter, taking Shamhat the harlot,
they set out on the road, they started the journey.
On the third day they came to their destination,
hunter and harlot sat down there to wait.

One day and a second they waited by the water-hole.
then the herd came down to drink the water.
The game arrived, their hearts delighted in water,
and Enkidu also, born in the uplands.

With the gazelles he grazed on grasses,
joining the throng with the game at the water-hole,
his heart delighting with the beasts in the water:
then Shamhat saw him, the child of nature,
the savage man from the midst of the wild.

‘This is he, Shamhat! Uncradle your bosom,
bare your sex, let him take in your charms!
Do not recoil, but take in his scent:
he will see you, and will approach you.

Look, this game is amazing. Visually stunning. Polished. Interesting. And all the components that a fantastic survival game could need, except that it is extremely lacking in content. The developers themselves (Microsoft) have admitted that its only 20% finished....

When did it become OK for one of the world's largest companies to start selling products that are effectively only 20% complete for full retail price? "Early Access" has become the world's biggest scam.

Apart from that, I would give this game a 9.9/10. It's hopefully going to be incredible. But why should the general public foot the bill for the development when it's owned by one of the world's largest companies.

I played this solo and it was still very fun. Some games make co-op almost required for a good time, but I thoroughly enjoyed myself, and am continuing to!

Finding new things to analyze for new crafting recipes is always exciting. The game really isn't super grindy, which I love because that gets old to me. The enemies are interesting and there are a pretty good amount, definitely would love to see even more. There's so much more content than I was expecting walking into the game, though you can get to "the end"
 so far, fairly easily, but even after that, there's still more progressing you can do. I like that you still have to be careful, even with the best gear, just gets easier to deal with enemies but never too op.

The only quirks I have is that I have a texture bug in my armor, it all looks like acorn armor now for some reason, probably a simple fix. The enemies are typically very easy to outsmart by being up high enough to be out of their reach but keep them close enough that they think they can get you, but can't (AKA if you've ever hunted Giants in Skyrim at an early level, you know exactly what to do). Also some of the normal, smaller insects spawn in rocks sometimes and it's just a very, very insignificant bug, but i thought i'd mention it.

Also a side note, I personally find it a little annoying that as soon as an enemy de-aggros, it's health instantly replenishes. I was taking on a wolf spider and it healed 3 times. Same deal with a lady big I took on early on, you might laugh but they're tanky lil sons of guns. Just a personal minor annoyance, most of the time it's not a problem.

Very polished for an early access game. Still, there are some bugs, no game breaking things, but minor things that don't really impact the gaming experience too much. It is getting updated fairly often so I wouldn't be surprised if all of the things that I noticed are gone by the next update. The game is clearly not finished as there are certain areas that are blocked off to the player, but there is lots to do in the areas that you can access. The only complaint that I remotely had would be that a few bits of climbing and parkour are several orders of magnitude harder than the other parts. For example,[spoiler]the hole to enter the hedge lab was very difficult and I fell all of the way to the bottom multiple times losing about 7-10 minutes of progress each time. This could easily be fixed by adding another mushroom to walk along or by making the hole larger. [/spoiler]Other than this small thing, the game is very fun and I would recommend it.

11 hours into early access and I have to say there is so much potential for this game as long as the story updates come and some adjustment is made to enemy AI. (Multiple times when fighting a ladybug) small little fixes to overall AI and small audio glitches and this game is sure to be a hit success and has potential to be a long running IP. Great time solo and even more so with friends the survival aspect of being so small in such a large open backyard makes this an enjoyable time and at the time of writing I still haven't even explored the entirety of the map.
Lots of fun and it seems more will be added each month. I look forward to all they could add to the game. There are some bugs, but it's early access so it's to be expected.

Unfortunately - once the novelty of the setting wears off - Grounded is little more than a grindy, boring mess. Even allowing for significant leeway as an early access title, the core mechanics and gameplay loops simply have nowhere to go. The only content we can expect to see released for this title going forward are more things to farm for a gear grind that's simply not worth the effort.

We'll see how things develop over the months (or even years) but it seems likely to me that Grounded will go down as a game that had a great premise with a lot of potential that was squandered by a lack of coherent vision and direction, ending up little more than an underwhelming and forgettable sandbox.

I absolutely love playing this game. I am addicted to it. I've never had so much fun playing a game before and I enjoy it so much. I like the vibe of the game and how it reminds me a bit of old-school science fiction flicks with all the secret labs and the overall story. I haven't finished the main story and I've been expanding my base. I just have so much fun exploring the vast world and seeing all the different insects and crafting items. I'm so satisfied with my purchase and would recommend if you like a survival game that allows you to craft, build and explore. I also like that you can avoid conflict by running away or you can engage in it and killing insects and other predators gives you crafting materials.

In it's infancy, this is still a great game.  I was a little disappointed with the initial lack of content that came with the beta release, but playing it for a bit past that first quest completion completely removed all of my woes with the game.  The environment is impressive.  The insects can be brutal but with strategy, can be overcome.  I love the building and this game is only in beta, which makes me excited for whatever the future holds.  I am very excited to continue to explore this amazing concept.  I am also impressed with how quickly the developers are fixing issues that the community finds.  I would completely recommend this game to people that enjoy the base building survival genre.  It does this VERY well.

As the game is not fully released but in early access, I will give a shorter review. Games in early access are likely to change during development, due to the interaction between devs and players with player feedback.

First and most importantly, Game play. 9/10
If you do not look up how to do everything and explore the world yourself as games were meant to be enjoyed, there is plenty of hours of content to be had here, even in it's early state. Base building is wonderful, with only a few stressful issues, that are likely to be ironed out. Resource gathering is fun, but some things are currently broken. Fighting feels great, a variety of enemies all with their own fighting patterns. Exploration is amazing. So much to discover on your own, especially if you do not look it up before hand. 

Secondly, Sounds and Music. 9/10
Adding depth and substance to the visuals, the sounds are really immersive. The music is both soothing at times, and sets the mood for other situations. The sound effects are also appealing. Walking along peacefully, then hearing the chilling call of the wolf spider that found prey can be pleasantly unsettling, causing me to jump more than once. Also B.U.R.G. L with his friendly robo-voice is cute.

Third, Multiplayer. 7/10
Honestly the rating on this one left me unhappy as I did not get to test the multiplayer out as much as I would've liked. What I did get, was easy use of voice chat, and fairly lag free game play, and pretty quick fun. The biggest issue I had was trying to connect at first, and having to open xbox live on pc, which I had never needed so never did before.

Fourth, and least important, but many would argue the opposite, Graphics. 10/10
While I care least of graphics in a game, Grounded has made me bug out over the different visuals that are offered. The floating particulates in the air, the depth of view haze, the lighting and shadows, all phenomenal. While not going in a realistic view, and leaning more towards a cartoonish style. I find it pleasing to look at, easy to differentiate, and perfect for the vibe the game gives off as a whole.

Overall, this game has great potential. Currently as of writing this there are some bugs that make it difficult to do certain things, but not really game breaking. Even in it's early access state, it does have a ton of content available right now. Not comparable to a full game yet, but still plenty to do, and prepare for future updates. I have over 100 hours in game, and still going. Anyone who says this game does not have more than a few hours content likely just looks up everything first. I do not recommend playing this game, or any other game that way. You get more out of it if you experience it yourself. I do recommend this game as a great source of survival/building/exploration fun.

This game exceeds every expectation I had. Even for early access very unfinished game, it's extremely fun,but not without its quirks and hiccups. 
First off, the building isn't the worst I've seen, but could be improved greatly. 
When I log out and log back in,the walls on my base are clipping through the doorway where they were previously not.
Also, somehow after putting walls up, those pesky ants always find a way through them and to my storage crates as if there's no wall there at all.
The dew collector only collects water when first built, after that good luck.
Dandelions grow very sparingly, I would have liked to have seen them respawn a bit faster considering almost everything is built with them.
Some of the Bugs IE: Bombardier Beetle and Wolf Spider are a bit OP even with the tier 2 weapons and acorn armor IMO.
The story mode as is literally lasts 45 minutes tops, so if you're looking for an engaging story right now this isn't it.
But what it lacks in story for the moment, It makes up for it with fun scavenging of Science points and resources.
Also, I like that the Devs included a nice 3 quests a day of various tasks to keep us busy until full release.
Overall I give this game 3.5 stars as is already,I cant wait until full release to really dig into this gem.

For an early access game, Grounded has surprisingly few bugs and issues. Gameplay is solid and fun. There's always something to build, farm or kill and the insects are a real threat on higher difficulties. 

Positive:
- Polished Graphics & Interface
- Easy to learn
- Base Building (build a complete base layout, add the building materials later)
- Nighttime is spooky as hell
- Fast paced dodge/block combat (with tougher insects)
- Cool armor with set bonusses
- Big Spiders

Negative:
- At some points building materials will drop through the floor if you put it down
- You can build a base floating in the sky
- Hard to see which savegames are mine (they all have the same icon, especially if multiple players use the same avatar/kid)
- Gnats are VERY annoying (I guess that's a bug [i]and[/i] a feature)
- Big Spiders

Too bad a lot of players don't understand what early access means and write negative reviews complaining about lack of content. Obsidian has revealed it will update the game monthly (with content, not only bug fixes), so I'm very curious what they have in store for us. Bees and Mosquitos are confirmed tho..

I am a HUGE fan of survival games. Ever since my introduction to the genre with ARK, I have played as many as I can, as well as supported them with purchasing the early access. Games like The Forest, SCUM, 7DTD, all have been...ok games that all need some love from the developers to really shine. Grounded, however, is absolutely amazing. It is GORGEOUS, and the game play is very enjoyable. With some exploring, you can get a sense of where the story will be going for your characters. There are many hidden treats that will answer some questions and leave you asking more. 

Does the game have more to work on? Absolutely. However, the "lack" of content will still keep you busy for hours, exploring, gathering the goodies, etc. Does it have some bugs?  Yep. The little ones are annoying, but so far I've seen next to no "game breakers". And the big ones try to eat you. 

I am happy with the purchase, and would most certainly recommend this to anyone seeking a game with great potential!

If you plan to get this for Early Access, be prepared to restart with any update. There's always the potential that patches are *not* backwards compatible. It's a game *in development*, not a *full game with all the kinks worked out*. If you are upset because something broke between patches, you were warned from the start.

The game is beautiful, the gameplay is fun, but the content is severely lacking. 'Early Access' has become an excuse to release a MVP (minimum viable product) while charging the intended full price. You get an hour of story content and then are abruptly stopped with promises of upcoming content. How is that acceptable for any game? This is a glorified demo as others have said. I absolutely love Obsidian to the point of being a fanboy but these type of sales tactics shouldn't be accepted no matter who the developer is. I'd give this game a few months to release the actual story and then give it a shot but there's no way I can recommend this game in this state.

I'd say don't buy this console port.  
Do buy this game claiming to be a multiplayer coop.  It requires (nope) an Xbox Subscription to play coop.  (IT doesn't actually.. It only requires a Microsoft Account login, which you will have if you have windows installed. It just looks like it's demanding the xbox sub.)
It requires a Subscription just to send feedback ingame. (No you don't)

The UI is horrible.   There are some glitchy bugs.  

That said, the core gameplay in singleplayer on medium difficulty, is fun.  The atmosphere, sound effects and general horror level is exceptional, even if spiders don't scare you irl.. they will in this game.

This is an Xbox Console Port.. being sold on Steam Pc.. where you can only play Single player unless you take out a monthly subscription to access the multiplayer coop.  The game is £25.. $40.. it has about 20-30 minutes of story driven content.

And maybe 10-15 hours of make your own story content.  Completionist stuff etc.   If they release a steam mp coop version I'll change my review to a recommendation, until then.  I'd say no.  Unless you have an xbox sub.. in which case.. play it on your console.

Changing this to a Yes Review.  Turns out I was wrong about the multiplayer coop.  

Now I just need to find some friends.. what are those anyway??

Nearly 100 hours played so far.. still loving it. Your choice, but this is going to be the most Awarded Game in 2020/2021.

Dear God! This game is REALLY good! There is a certain allure to a game that involves survival, crafting, and miniaturization and this game has all three. If you loved Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, you are going to love this. Currently the game is only $29 which isn't bad. Once they finish everything, they may increase the price to a understandable $60. For me, the game is worth every penny as is, and is only going to be improved as time goes on. Overall, this game is brilliant yet unfinished.

Pros:
- The crafting system is really polished for an unfinished game. The unlock system for new blueprints and schematics is directly connected to what you can find. This pushes you to explore rather than hole up in a safe place and get stagnant. 
- The current "enemies" (bugs) you encounter can range from the tiny aphids to big (to you) ladybugs. There is a definite adorability in seeing these bumbling ladybugs walk through your world yet it goes a long way to show your relative scale in the game when you see the grass (which are basically the size of trees relatively speaking) shift and BREAK as the bugs approach reminiscent of a dinosaur in Jurassic Park.
- The game does an amazing job of setting the mood and the *FEEL* of the game. There is an extreme element of sheer terror as your are running through the world exploring and come face to face with a MASSIVE wolf spider. If you are afraid of spiders, this game could EASILY be placed in the horror genre for you. To elaborate a bit more though, it's everything about the game that helps set the mood and pace. Even the landmarks in the game (such as the massive baseball which you see in the video along with the frog toy) seem to lend a since of credibility and a believable circumstance in an utterly syfy idea of being a child who is miniaturized in their back yard.
- Grounded is a BEAUTIFUL game! It's interesting that even when I'm running through the mud puddles that for the player may as well be a swamp, you still can't help but appreciate the details in the game world. Nothing extraneous or too over-the-top, just very well done. Yet the game is still in Early Access at the moment which means it can only get better. It's difficult to improve perfection, but I'm sure looking forward to it.

Cons:
- The game is simply unfinished. The quest line is fairly short (though it does give players a decent idea what they can expect from the game) so it can be finished EASILY in just a few short minutes. This may bother some players who need a structured quest line in order to enjoy a game. There's nothing wrong with that, if you are that type of gamer, but fair warning here. If you're looking for a strong story line game, perhaps wait a bit. There are some, shall we say, busy work (side quests) you can get from BURG.L, the robot from the intro video, but they are just that; they are short side quests. He rewards you with science points which are the in-game currency, but honestly there isn't much to use it for. All in all, the currently finished story line is fun but over too soon. If you have patience and don't mind waiting for updates (which I think is totally worth it) then this con shouldn't be a big deal.
- Currently, the game is a bit buggy (pardon the pun) and glitchy. This is ABSOLUTELY to be expected from a game that is technically still being developed. I have had crashes and glitches but nothing that completely ruins the experience.
- Since the game is unfinished, you will inevitably run across areas where you want to explore but can't until the game is updated a bit more. This can be extremely frustrating when you work hard to climb up somewhere to get into a structure that you saw from far away only to have the door to said structure be locked with no way to open it. However, this (in my opinion) just makes me all the more excited to enjoy the finished product.

All in all, the pros outweigh the cons in my opinion and that's not even factoring in that the "cons" will be corrected by future updates. This puts this game in the MUST BUY box for anyone who enjoys creative, survival, builder, adventure games.

Early game, even on the easiest difficulty setting is a tooth-pulling nightmare with killer bugs at every turn. No safe areas at all, they'll just turn up and annihilate you. Want to build a base? Yup, Bug-Annihilation! Who T.F. tuned this?? So...can't build a base. can't explore, can't take on the enemies and can't survive longer than 15 minutes. The Forest has the challenge just right, if you want a survival building game play that..a full game...that's cheaper than this EA travesty. Oh, and multiplayer is broken and requires a f*&^%$g xbox live account?!? I don't care about cross platform and neither should the developers! Not yet at least. I'd have loved to be at the meeting where that was decided to be a priority..

I'm sure it has potential, but you couldn't wait a bit before releasing to tune some of these crappy aspects out of the game? As it stands this is like an old Alfa Romeo car..very pretty but ultimately useless at it's supposed primary function - to be a playable, enjoyable game.

They've fixed the constant harassment from ants and larvae when building you base!  It's nice to come back to your base and have it still be there when you get back with more resources for the base.

This has lead me on a goal to build the largest structure in the front yard.  So far I have a 20 floor building that is just about even with the front porch of the house!  

Out side of that, I will say that the dew catcher is a waste of materials and time.  Ever since I installed the dew catcher, I've yet to see it catch any dew.  In fact, it's caught me in it's web more times than any dew has thought of being caught by it.  

So, hey Dev team, maybe make the dew catcher actually catch due, or call it something else!

Original Review:After 4 hours of gathering resources, following the very few quests/objectives available in the game. 

I built my beautiful two story base, complete with kitchen, living room, and a sweeeeeet trophy room.  I laid out my spike traps and other traps to prevent insects from bombarding my base for food and other supplies.

Feeling good about the work I had accomplished, I went to bed, and awoke to ants raiding my kitchen, and Larvae attacking me.  

I logged out, uninstalled the game and will await a patch/update.  

I wouldn't recommend this to any of my friends or family, $30 dollars is far too high a price for what you get.

Here's to hoping Obsidian listen's to their community.

For the moment, fellow gamer, I'm not going to recommend you pay 30.00 for this game.

Grounded is a visual triumph with tremendous possibility. At best in its current form, you complete the storyline in an hour or less. One making what should have been an epic breakthrough, you are greeted with a prompt telling you that this is as far as they've gone so far in development, but promises there will be more in the future. 

Grounded is like having the very best pringle ever created with perfect flavor and texture, but there's only one in the can. It succeeds in leaving you wanting more- I would have eve bought new region unlocks it is that immersive- but, the game just ends. You can continue to build, explore and hunt, but this is simply a demo- and prior to playing 30 dollars, be aware it is a demo and that while the experience is an an amazing, albeit short-lived one, it is not a fully developed game in early access for polish, it has the opening chapter of the story, and you're done. It is not worth more than 10 dollars in it's current state. 

I am really frustrated with developers releasing demos at full retail cost. The concept of Early Access has become a fierce cash grab and enables developers to produce minimal content on their own terms, usually very slowly while they harvest money from the hopeful expectations of players. for may gamers, the cost of this game costs two hours of work- and from investment, they get an hour of content. 

 When the game is beyond a demo phase, I wil likely change this review, but I can't in good faith justify 30 dollars for an unfinished game- even leverage the all-to-common "Early Access" excuse often used. However, this is will most certainly be a phenomenal game when finished.

Fantasticly immersive, Grounded is almost a horror game, full of tense Bug Battles and Spider jump scares, (They also have a setting for aracnaphobes to tone down the fright a bit)

Trying not to die can be a sufficient challenge when you're starting out and as you expand a base and your armor, you can seek out bigger baddies and better loot! 

Unfortunately, the storyline feels entirely separate from the sandbox survival, and neither of them are quite fleshed out enough. What I want to see in the future of Grounded is more things to craft and build for Sandbox and a more fleshed out campaign that isn't forced on the player...

Obviously this game is still in early access, and you can't blame them because the game needs to be fleshed out more. What you can blame them for however, is the Price. $30 for an early access game that's barren of content is too much. At this stage of development, it should cost $20 maximum.

Overall, it's fantastic fun, and I expect hundreds of hours played in the months to come!

Really enjoying what the game has to offer so far! The first thing I noticed was that, considering the price, it's quite decent for a brand new early access game. There are plenty of other early access games which are more expensive and have less content than this game, there's a lot here already!

I've put a solid 30 hours in so far and I've seen pretty much everything at least vaguely, I haven't explored in depth some of the harder areas of the garden, and even areas I thought I knew quite well have been hiding secrets from me I only discover later in the game. Exploration is the best and biggest thing in this game, and growing up loving stories like The Borrowers and "Honey I Shrunk the Kids", the perspective is refreshing and exciting. You really feel tiny in this huge garden, where it can take almost full minute to sprint along the length of a rake's pole. 

There are lots of things I'd like to see, such as pet insects and bug mounts (would love to be able to ride a ladybird!), more resources and materials, more armour designs and weapons, more insects to fight, boats of some kind and water-related enemies maybe... I could go on and on, there is a lot of potential here and what the game already has is very fun and easy to sink time into. 

If you like survival games, insects, or the sort of "fairy" perspective, you'll love this game the way I do! Otherwise, I'd say as a survival game alone it might be a bit easier than others, but then there are difficulty options, so go nuts I guess.

This game does have potential to go on and be great, however right now its nothing special. The game has 2 proper quests, and a few side quests and that's it. With a price tag of $25 I expect more. I do understand that this game is still in development, but there could have been more to it rather than just run around and explore. Not to mention the game has some buggy moments like stuff just randomly disappearing, a spear can randomly just get stuck below the ground and some insects are actually stuck either in the ground or a cave. Like I said this game does have potential but right now there's nothing to do for a game worth $25.

Grounded is a fun little game, a little weak on content as to be expected with Early Access games, but worth the buy and the road through development. With a very "Honey I shrunk the Kids" feeling to it Grounded places you in the backyard, roaming around trying to survive which proves difficult at times as you're the size of an ant. 
In terms of survival, it's pretty simply, and exactly what you would expect from a survival crafting games. You need to eat, find water and shelter for the night. As far as enemies go, your 2 biggest threats are spider and stink bugs. Beyond those to, surviving the backyard is as easy as building a home inside of a soda can. 
I enjoyed the game, but I also had the benefit of playing it with a friend which really adds to the game. I highly recommend Grounded to anyone wanting a fun little survival experience with friends.

It's not even a remote issue because they put multiple places you can research items at all with their own timer, but i'd prefer to just be able to research whenever i have new items. The game itself is pretty cool and it definitely is early access, but honestly if you spend $30 on this right now its not a total waste, because the future this game has is pretty bright.

Wonderful game with tremendous potential! The story mode is super short at the moment, but the team at Obsidian is clearly working very hard at implementing new features and fixing bugs (of which there are many at the moment, unfortunately) that have arisen since the first update. 

The game has a wonderful world filled with adorable and deadly insects to interact with, a setting that very much feels alive, and a nice dose of early 90s nostalgia (ala "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids").  The creative and exploration side of the game keeps me coming back - I honestly can't get enough of this game.

Regarding the bugs: I submitted a bug report and actually got a personal message from one of the devs (read: not a canned response). It's stuff like this that will keep me coming back to an early access game, even despite the current frustrations the patch has brought on. 

The sky is the limit with this game - there is SO much the devs can do, and I'm really looking forward to it.

This game has honestly been a lot of fun to figure out and go through. It's interesting world and creative looking armors and houses is a nice break from the other gritty and usually zombie infested survival games out there. It's bright and fun. Everything I WOULD have said negative about it was fixed in the latest patch and they continue to make improvements to bugs and creation. If you are looking for a game with a complex story and depth then this game isn't there YET. If you are interested in a new survival world feel and don't mind developing as the game is worked on, then this is a good investment. 

A note on the arachnophobia slider: This addition is fantastic for people who really can't stand the sight of spiders. When it is scaled all the way up, the spiders look like colorful balloon creatures. The only draw back is that it can be hard to read their attacks and prepare to block when they are in balloon mode. This feature is amazing but when fighting/defending against them it will take some time to figure out their telecast attacks because there are no legs to look at.

If you like Survival-Craft games this one is a good buy. Only caveat is that in it's current state there is little to do.

The story progression ends after about 15 minutes of play if you focus on it and don't worry about anything else. The story is also incomplete and pretty straight forward—get un-shrunk. What all this entails will only be known as the devs finish the game.

As for actual content that is readily available, there's a few good hours of fun to be had. Especially with friends. Once your base is built and in a pretty solid state, all you have left to do is explore and craft the best equipment you can—currently, not very much to choose from but definitely some potential given information you stumble upon in-game, like bee armor but no bees in game (at least none that I have seen).

There is also not very much to explore. The map is divided into a few different zones and about half of them are developed. Running around all of these developed areas could waste a few hours, but eventually you'll pretty much find everything you need and the drive to explore will diminish.

As of now, my only drive to play this game is meaningless challenges we give each other. Like "kill everything" or "mow the lawn". The game definitely has a lot of potential and this is probably the cheapest you will be able to get it for a long while. Just know before you buy that it IS still being developed, there are plans to expand the content (presumably as updates and not as DLC, but perhaps one day they will have those as well), and that the game has some broken mechanics that the devs have done a quick job fixing.

Known issues after first patch (0.1.1):
- Undeveloped areas have a few spots where you can fall off of the map, did not attempt to fall because I had some valuable items I wasn't willing to risk losing.
- Day/Night/Time progression sometimes stops on multiplayer mode, possibly when sleep is initiated by one player but not all. (Only happened 3 times so far, twice before first patch and once, briefly, after)
- When time stops progressing, some other timed features stop, like the analyser doesn't recharge and cooking never finishes. Torches never diminish.

Revising my review after more time playing. I am mainly only focusing on the bugs/building aspect of the game due to it being early-access and complaining about the lack of a story is just silly.

The game is littered with bugs (no pun intended) that can quite literally ruin any further progression for your game. Simple things such as ants, weevils, and larva no-clipping through your base is one thing, but having items such as acorns, dandelions, and even bugs not spawning can keep you from getting any further in the game.

I have currently spent 9 hours on a singleplayer save (on Medium) and I honestly have been having a blast. However, I am now stagnated when it comes to continually building up my base and getting spare weapons/armor. The reason behind this is all due to acorns not respawning at all. This makes it impossible to store large amounts of materials as I am no longer capable of building chests, but rather the baskets which have half the amount of space alotted to them while also taking up almost the same amount of space. Another problem with continual base building is that I have an insanely hard time gathering weed stems due to the lack of respawning on the side of dandelions- so now I am forced to run across half the map in order to get weed stems, and if I want to pick up more than 5, I have to run back and forth repeatedly until I get them to my base. 

When it comes to content, I think there's a good start here. However, I would like to see MUCH more building options, as currently there isn't even an option for floors/ceilings (not counting the foundation due to that being limited to the ground), which makes two-story or higher buildings impossible.

While the game is really fun and honestly, I never knew I can be afraid of a stink bug, still I can't wholeheartedly recommend it at this point in time. 

I really don't mind that the shortness of the story itself. It's just two quests, but I'm more annoyed by the issues. I've tried to play it with my friend and we discovered that while the host's game is reasonably okay but if you join as a client all hell breaks lose. Starting from holding two bows at the same time and not seeing where you aim, to teleporting bugs and not respawning resources. 

Pros:

- It's an absolute relief to finally play in a survival game where you are not supposed to be a hardcore survivor whos aim is to destroy monsters and/or zombies and stuff. It's really creative.
- Graphics are great, so much so that I got scared of bugs that I usually don't even notice climbing on me in real.
- Great characters, even when we don't know anything about them yet.
- Creative looking building pieces. 
- Wholesome world.

Cons:

- I know it's EA but I think they published it a bit sooner than when they should've. I mean only two quests for story? 
- Building system is really janky right now. When I try to place something it just jumps all over the place. Really hard to control it.
- A ton of bugs ... yeah I said it, ya happy?. Especially when I wasn't hosting. Stuff disappearing in ground, or from your inventory, teleporting enemies etc.
- Resources won't respawn. When we started playing, we saw some water bubbles on weed but after second login we never saw them again. We tried the Dew Collector too but after the first bubble, nothing. It can be worked around of course, but we noticed that some important building materials run out too. 

TL/DR:

While it looks truly awesome, I think the game should've stayed in incubation for a bit longer. I'm all about EA games and I understand there are bugs, but honestly I don't want to be the company's glorified alpha tester. 

I can't wait for the upcoming updates and to change my review, but right now I wouldn't recommend buying it, but keep it on your wishlist.

Survival games may no longer be in vouge, but that hasn't stopped their evolution one bit. Obsidian has delivered in [i] Grounded [/i] a survival experience that is both new and fresh, and also built on the foundations of other excellent survival games. Though the game is in early access, and is unfinished, it is both remarkably playable and remarkably stable.

The game takes the building mechanics from [i] The Forest [/i], with buildable structures and platforms, constructed from stems and blades of grass that you carry over your shoulder. The recipes are not resource-intensive enough to make construction annoying (looking at you ARK), but building a sick base does take a rewarding amount of time. The sound design is excellent, you know what is creeping around that next corner, and it fills you with [b] absolute terror [/b], building towards the moment when the wolf spider jumps out of the grass at you, and you have the best heart attack since you met Sammy from [i] Subnautica [/i]. The music is thematic, and really drives home the sense of wonder, and the whole yard feels alive with clicks, chirps, and footfalls.

The difficulty is just right, the enemies are strong enough that killing one feels like a real accomplishment, and if you miss too many blocks or get cornered you are dead, but the attacks are well-telegraphed and have acceptable hitreg. No bug I have fought yet (so everything but the super secret boss and the wolf spider) has had so much health that the fight was a drag, and the actual melee mechanics are top-notch. Blocks and Parrying are key to most fights, and the lack of block-cancelling adds an element of risk-reward to making one more strike. Melee is also encouraged due to the (albeit funky) pathing, that leads enemies being attacked from an unreachable vantage to flee, forcing either a long kiting battle (suicide against spiders) or a good old scrap. 

The atmosphere and environment is beautiful, and the sense of wonder from staring up into the sky through grass as tall as trees, or climbing inside a soda can, is refreshing and new. You feel like prey, you are afraid to go out at night, but you never feel so powerless you are confined to your base. The spiders are scary, really scary, but if you engage on your terms they feel conquerable, which is a super rewarding balance of predator and prey mentality that always has you on your toes. The lighting is gorgeous especially since many things are translucent, though it still needs a little touch of polish, the sunglow through grass walls is especially beautiful.

Now for the criticisms:
The motion blur is totally goofy, even slow moving objects such as dust particles and viewmodels will sometimes have afterimages.
Lighting also needs a little polish, namely the same translucent effect that I love so much in the game. Some models such as the aphid roast will have 'stepping' in the light transfer from the fireplace. The game can also have some really bad haze issues, which may be an intended feature but looks unnatural.
The armor dummy is currently bugged, and will sometimes 'eat' armor upon reloading a save.

The biggest issues I have experienced are with clipping, pathing, and spawing of insects.
Bugs like to either spawn or clip into rocks or other pieces of terrain, my current save has a wolf spider stuck in a rock that has almost killed me by striking through the rock. For a time there were very few worker ants, with many of them also being stuck in rocks, but they seemed to have been respawned, and now they are everywhere in large numbers. Bugs will get caught on twigs, short trenches, or other natural features, which can make some fights just arrow cheese (still better than ARK). I currently cannot find any ladybugs, I assume that they are all stuck inside rocks as well.

The game is also missing some content, which is to be expected from early access. Many icons are placeholders, there are only two mission types, some landmarks do not have mapmarkers or their mapmarkers aren't revealed by walking up to them. There is a lack of passive and neutral mobs, and the ecosystem in general feels less diverse that other similar titles (*sigh* ARK), we know there are plenty of other mobs in the works, this is just critique at the time of writing. 

In summary, this game is what early access should be: a playable yet unfinished game, giving the community an opportunity to help squash bugs (pun intended) in exchange for a reduced price tag and the assumption of some risk should the project go under. Well done Obsidian, I look forward to this games future.

TLDR: Game good, playable but not finished, worth paying full price for.

I like the gameplay of this game, almost like the forest but have more of a "kid friendly" vibe to it. Pretty good graphics, and good gameplay, lots of jumpscares if you're not ready for it. But to all good games, there are some flaws. If i can recall correctly those are:
- not being able to open box even when no one's opening it
-  when items more than 1 stack are put in the smoothie, it will "disappear" until you put it back into your inventory
- There are no "sort item" options in inventory and chest
- You cannot remove 1 item only from a stack of the same item, you have to remove the entire stack
-When you join a game, the weapons hotbar are sometimes missing the weapons and some items stack another item over (it does not remove the item, you can see your missing items by putting the items in a different hotbar)
- Ants are able to take items from boxes that are 10 cm above them
- Some items/ enemies does not/rarely spawn, like acorns (does not spawn back) or gnats (in 5 hours, i've never seen it once)
- Items on the floor can sometimes block movement
- Constant disconnects from a server  for no reason

I do hope those glitches/bugs are fixed during the early access as they can be annoying

Not sure why people are complaining about the game being short. It's in early access for a reason. Overtime the game will be updated with new content and bug fixes so it's not so short/boring anymore. I personally had a lot of fun playing with friends trying to hunt down spiders, only to end up screaming for our lives. The cartoonish style of this game is really nice and I love the scaling of everything. You really do feel small when you realize you're about the size of an ant, with every blade of grass towering over you. The building system is a pretty cool concept that I like. When it comes to transporting grass planks or weed stems, you have to actually hull it in your hands in small stacks. Then if something threatens you, just go ahead and panic throw all those supplies into the poor soul that ran into you.

The whole recipe researching system doesn't work for stupid gaymers like me. I can't tell you how long it took for us to research a grass plank or a weed stem. It's not the game's fault for us being stupid. It pretty much tells you to research stuff right at the beginning. It seems like food and especially clean water are really hard to come by in the world. Yes you could kill stuff for meat but that goes bad in a day. Also you could make jerky out of them so they don't expire, expect then you'll need to drink more water. Pretty much I just grab a bunch of mushrooms and drink dirty water. When the hunger goes down I just keep eating until my belly explodes from the dirty water and probably dangerous shrooms.

Currently I can't exactly recommend this game to someone in this state of development, due to the game not having much to offer at this moment, but I'm looking forward to what Obsidian have planned in the future.

This game brings on memories of the Honey, I Shrunk the Kids movie though it has it's own unique twist to it. I like most of the game play, the building and crafting is fun, and there is huge potential for the story line moving forward. What I don't like is the fighting system specially against all of the harder enemies. The difficulty reminds me of Dark Souls which is a game that I dislike purely because of those same mechanics. I play most survival games on easy because I don't play games for the challenge. I play games to have fun and relax. I was hoping that with this game looking like it was going to be geared more towards kids that it would be easier on Mild mode than it has turned out to be. I don't want a Passive mode, but, it looks like I might have to beg for one if the developers leave the fighting the way it is.

If you like playing survival games that are more challenging like The Forest in normal mode then you will most likely like this game.

I can't down vote it because I do like the game most of the time. It's just that one element that pisses me off and makes me dislike the game enough to take a break for a day or two.

1st - Multiplayer is Free, but you have to create an XBox Live account but that is no big deal since it's free. You don't need an XBox Live Gold account (the monthly paid subscription service).  As of 8/9 there is no "Global Lobby" for random matchmaking, but you can play multiplayer by inviting friends from your Steam List.

The Game - is a laid back crafting and survival game. Similar in some ways to Ark and Conan. It's really interesting and fun to play as a shrunken teenager and see the whole world from the perspective of an ant. For the most part, the game is laid back however it can prove VERY challenging depending on what you have provoked a fight with and what gear you have.

!!!STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME!!! (for now)
I'm not the type of person to normally leave a review, infact i don't believe i ever have done in the past, however;
I spent the last 9 hours playing this game and its currently 5am in the morning, i was having a relatively good time and everything was going well up until an un expected crash occurred, then when i reload the world my loot and gear is no longer on my character and theres no visible backpack anywhere to be found on the map. Everything was just gone.
Simply put, the crash somehow erased almost all of the progress i had made in the last 9 hours.

Because of this and a handful of other reasons, i simply cannot recommend this game to anybody right now, Save your money and save your time. The game is in an extremely buggy state and you will enjoy it more if you put it off until the issues are fixed and the story is expanded. 

Creatures hitboxes connect when theyre nowhere near you, creatures glitch through walls and terrain, creatures gett stuck under the map for you to then be forced to listen to their sounds over and over, weapons and arrows gett stuck under the map and are unable to be retrieved, my friends couldn't hit any of the blue berries after they had fallen, only the host could do anything with them. The spiders seem to almost always find a way to glitch out and just stand there staring at you while you beat it to death, the sap collectors don't work at all and you cannot even place them most the time, there isn't a reliable way to keep on top of your thirst meter so you are constantly forced to suicide or drink dirty water. The building is glitchy at best and sometimes things just will not place for no reason and if you do manage to place them its never in the right spot because the blueprint keeps jumping around, jumping up against a blade of grass (which is literally everywhere by the way) will launch you backwards into the air enough to take fall damage, acorns are a valuable resource in the game however, now that we have collected all the acorns refuse to respawn even though it says they should every night. Not to mention in the current state the story only lasts 5 minutes.

just save your money and frustration on this one by adding it to your wish list and forgetting about it for awhile. It's a decent game and the concept is there, the execution is just not perfected right now. Given the time to grow and update i have no doubt this game will be outstanding.

I have no idea who put those minimum specs on the store page, but rest assured that the minimum specifications is like an Urban Legend or some sort of creepypasta. This game will run on nothing short of a supercomputer, I've actually entered a contract with Bitmain so that they can act as a VM for this game. According to my calculations, if I use 100% of the mining pools resources, I may be able to run Grounded on min resolution and low graphics setting at 30 fps.

There's also a stupid requirement to have an Xbox Account (Idk if they require you to purchase gold because I already have it and therefore was not prompted to purchase it) to play multiplayer (which doesn't work yet) which makes 0 sense considering I purchased this game on Steam.

This game is the biggest cash grab/SCAM since Ouya, no reason why a game this unfinished and this poorly made should be work $30 just for you to be work as an unpaid beta tester. They say that they really appreciate feedback, but I refuse to give them any since this game should be FREE until it has a half finished beta at bare minimum, even Activi$ion releases free beta's of their games.

And before any of you Early Access Aristocrats come at me with "Yeah but this is an Early Access game bro." Okay, but why is this worth 30 Dollars American? Did I wake up in an alternate Reality where Microsoft and Obsidian are indie companies, and can only afford to keep themselves afloat by selling garbage beta versions for full price? 
Jesus Christ, even Minecraft had a working beta version, and the guy who made that was a neckbeard working on his own with nothing but a trenchcoat on his back and a fedora on his head.

This game is truly pathetic, and Microsoft should be ashamed of their blatant attempt to not only outsource the beta testing to us, but also the fund raising. 

As for the game itself it seems promising and basically a reskin of Fortnite Save the World with a better story premise. Just buy this game when it leaves early access.

Note: as of this review, build 0.1.1 This game has lots of issues.

As of build 0.1.1 The game has a long way to go. This is by no means a finished game. In fact, far from it. There are still many, many bugs in the code. You will often get stuck inside things. (walls, floors) There  are major items for the quest that do now spawn. (ex ant eggs) No clear way to toggle markers. (ex. you can click the map, and they may or may not turn on) Poor AI paths. (AI will get stuck on/in things like walls and floors) No clear map bounds. (ex. they have a large section that says under construction) Tool limits. (ex. some things you can cut, some you can't)

All that being said, the game is playable. You get the feel for the basics. I don't know how I feel for paying for a beta. I hate this is the way games are going. Almost none of the games you buy anymore are finished. If people don't play it, than you bought a beta, if people do than they will keep working on it. 

Again, the game plays. It looks good. With no clear objective, because there the story is not finished in the game; all you can really do is run around and explore the map. Maybe get a feel for where things are. What it does have is ok. The bugs need worked out though.

Grounded throws you into the world with a set of tools for crafting, building and fighting some rather interesting enemies. If you like the movie "Honey I Shrunk The Kids" and survival games this is the game for you, based in a backyard shrunken so small that worker ants are just slightly smaller than you, the enemies present in this game at times can seem overwhelming. If you like games that get frequent updates of new content monthly this is the game for you, it gives you a small bundle of content to go through but like The Forest you do have to wait for new content after playing a few hours. Definitely one of those games best played with friends rather than by yourself, if you got the money lying around and feel like messing around with friends.

Lighting is quite nice, bright and flickers across the walls.    Bug AI actually seem life-like: ants will push food around, I assume back to their mound.   Ants will also dig in your storage for food too.   Spiders are pretty scary and tend to come out at night more often.    Building is a blast, the entire time can see outline of project and they can pitch in resources.   Grass will move when larger bugs move through the grass.   Two wall/roof/flooring types, limited decorations.

Combat is fun, intuitive, and smooth; just left click to do primary attack.  No power attacks.   3 Main weapon types of multiple tiers: Bows, two-handed clubs, fast daggers, tools (axes/hammers).

Lots of platformer-type objectives in the game to acquire collectables.

A few dungeons where you discover story notes.

No levels or skill tree.   Progress is measured through crafting stations and equiped items.   Crafting a dew collector will allow you to collect your water at your base instead of wandering around to find drinkable fluid.  However, each station requires parts from various creatures, so you have to explore and find those before making it.   Like crafting the Dew collector requires webs, so need to go kill spiders before you can make that.

This game has exceeded my expectations! I understand the game is quite new and in early release stages I did expect more for the price point,

Things I wish they had / Fixed 

*Option to upgrade backpack more inventory*
*Fix the bug where wearing equipment still takes up an inventory slot* 
*Have an option to craft materials in bulk instead of clicking it every time* 
*Public join others CO-OP*

As of right now the game nets around a 6/10 for me.
which if a good score for a game so early in developement, and rating any hire would just show a lack of ability to accurately determine a game's current quality. 
If anyone ever gives a game a 10/10 ignore their reviews because 10/10 means it's a perfect game with no flaws or downsides.
And yes, we "ALL" know the game is "early access", but that's no excuse to behave like children with this behavior of "you can't ever say anything bad about a game" mentality people seems to have. 
it's call "constructive criticism"
also Steam has such a lazily designed Review system which appears as just a "love or hate" option. if Steam wanted accurate review scores they'd do a 1-10 rating,
so if someone doesn't recommend the game now, the "thumbs down" to the ignorant children of the internet looks like a "YOU HATE THE GAME!!!" to which i say, Grow Up. enough of the childish, straight from 0 to 100, either with us or against us behavior. 
 
the game looks great, has an interesting approach to survival games, and unlike other survival games, it really offers the ability to change the player's perspective on the world, things like "there's a whole world like this in my own back yard" 
But when you're actually playing there isn't much to the survival aspect. (lack of food items and base building)

visually the game is quite an achievement, but there is a large lack tools, resources, and buildables in the game's current state. plus few to NO options to protect your base from raiding bugs which can just spawn inside your base at times (anyehere from 10-30) and kill you repeatedly, then proceed to destroy the majority of your structures, causing you to have to basically start over again. 
- ants seem to be attracted to food stored in chests, meaning you can't store food AT ALL.
- Spiders seems to be attracted to raw meat, either stored away or left on your person,
- not sure what attracts the larva swarms, heard someone say corpses, but there are none, unless it's insect parts, again meaning you can't store those either if that's true. (basically can't store anything other than rocks and fibers)
all of the above which bee-line from across the map to destroy your base, or just spawn in waves inside your base that you can't defend.
only 1 farming item, a mushroom garden, a lack of building options, and bugs that you can't really defend well against without cheesing the AI.

Now overall it's a great experience that shows a lot of potential. I'm excited to see what farming options they open up, either new plants, resources, or bug farms, bug mounts/pets, new building options, utilities, furnitures, everything.

in it's current state i could only recommend it to people who are very patient with the game's development (sounds like they'll be updating once a month)
but in general, and from an unbiased and critical review standpoint, i wouldn't recommend the game in it's current state as there are a lot of things that need fixing and to be more thought out, so as not to have incidents that ruin players fun with the game, 
again like the constant random bug hordes spawning INSIDE bases, not allowing players the time to learn what or even fix what's causing the issue and you have to sit there and watch your hours of work are destroyed, which is no fun for anyone, as it feels it's punishing you for even playing more than it is teaching you anything. 

still can't recommend it in it's current state since after the players beat the current 15-30 minute story, they will end up exploring around the world and going to areas that the future story will take them and their experience will have been ruined since they'll have already explored and found the secrets months before the story takes them there, meaning there will be little room for "new" experiences and surprises alongside the new story additions.
in the long run this will hurt the game since 
it'll be like recieveing end game Spoilers before getting half way through the game. 

but looking forward to see how this game develops.

One of my favourite game developers + my favourite genre of game, I thought it would be a recipe for awesomeness, alas after 1 and a half hours I just found it to be a huge "meh".

That is, it's a huge "meh" in it's current early access state.

I adore the concept and what I assume it's aiming for, it just seems after 1 and a half hours I had seen and done everything it has to offer; hence the "not recommended" (in it's current early access state). First time writing a public review~
Honey I Shrunk the Kids: The Game™ 

I usually play games through a 3rd-party site before purchasing, through Steam or otherwise- especially those in Early Access because of harsh criticism. 'Money worth your time invested in the game' blah blah. "Grounded" made the list of purchasing in a few hours of playing for many of reasons. As a HUGE fan of survival games, this one made the cut.

Pros

- 9/10 Graphics/Atmosphere – Polished, stylized and overall a joy to look at. Playing on High default settings with a low-end computer setup, it's absolutely beautiful. Lighting, reflections, size scale – day or night – it sinks you into being Ant Man sized. Sound effects and music are fantastic!!

- 8/10 Performance – Through 3rd-party or via Steam, there's been little to no lag hiccups or shuddering. Keep in mind I've played single player only. Only obvious issues of enemies/items clipping through the floor but what game doesn't have those issues?

- 8/10 Combat – Smooth, the sound effects and animations give weight to every blow. Repair system decently balanced along with being punished for not blocking when enemy attacks are choreographed. Overpowered spiders well deserved

- 6/10 Characters – Each teen has a different personality and responds to actions accordingly. I know through watching multiplayer there's interactions between them too. Right off the bat, I enjoy how each has responded to the world they've been sent to. The biggest drawback is not having character specific abilities or stats. Maybe Maxwell having having higher health and Hoops a bigger stamina bar. Perhaps Pete a larger inventory or Willow raised attack. My personal nick-pick side. When playing a game, I wish to be invested in the characters and how their variance in stats can effect the game-play.

BUT. The voice-acting is top notch. And BURG.L is adorable (extra points because I work in a restaurant haha). Most potential rests here for me


- 4/10 Content – The biggest downside. The story is left extremely weak. While curious for what's next, wish there was a LITTLE (hah, small joke) bit more to keep players hooked in for an Early Access. Crafting items have been serviceable, same goes for base building and exportation of the ok sized map. If off the beaten trail of quests and go out, there's some unique bugs to try and beat besides 'OMG NO PLEASE DON'T SPIDERS.' Nothing awesome but nothing to write home about


Overall

For an Early Access game, its clean controls, gorgeous visuals, fun and heart pumping game-play (if spiders scare the sh*t outta you) make it a pleasurable experience. If you're into survival games, I recommend picking this up. A bonus, in this case, is being Early Access. More and more content will trickle into this game as does water droplets into an acorn water container. I'm looking forwarded to each update.

Thank you developers for a great game thus far~

Early Access means that the "Plot" only advances to the first major plot point and then stalls, leaving you with nothing to do but explore, build your base, and work your way up the tech tree.

But I haven't enjoyed exploration this much since Subnautica. The "Shrunken kids in a suburban back yard" proves to be an awesome setting to get lost in. The towering jungles of grass, soda cans you can build a house in, and going Skyrim-style cave diving in anthills.

I don't think a game's enemies have freaked me out as much since Subnautica, either. I don't consider myself to have a fear of spiders, but hearing a skuttling behind you, and turning around to find a two-story tall wolf spider racing at you inflicts a terror I haven't felt since my first Leviathan. Fortunately, there's an option to turn the spiders into something else, because I can't imagine how an arachnophobe would react to getting ganged up on by three orb-weavers while trying to make their way through the rose-garden edging.

The base building is a pain: All of it requires massive planks of grass that your kid can only carry five at a time, meaning you're in for dozens of trips back and forth to get any decent structure constructed. But the 'Grass strapped together with moss strands and twinks' style is excellent. The armor sets you wind up constructing out of clover leaves, acorn shells, and spider bits are weird, but exactly the sort of thing you'd expect half-inch-high kids to pull together.

It might all fall apart when the rest of the storyline's implimented. Ants might be recoded to be able to climb up your walls and chew through your bedroom window and eat all your stuff. They might start spawning spiders out of thin air. They might put fish in the middle of the pond just to make the Subnautica flashbacks complete. But until any of that happens, I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes the Build To Survive genre.
