It hurts my heart to negatively review a game from THE Obsidian Entertainment, but this EA product misses the mark.

It's gorgeous, the music is on point, and they clearly put a lot of effort into the aesthetics.

But the gameplay, tutorial content and pacing need a lot of work (insofar as the pacing is concerned, just adding some would be a good start).  Before I have a second to just take in the aesthetic, this small world made larger, I'm rushing to avoid starving, dehydrating, sent on one badly-explained fools errand of a quest after the next -- and since the tutorial doesn't include anything about the game's internal logic, I have things constantly beeping and booping without any idea why they are. 

Tip: Reel us in early. Have your characters spend a little more time reacting to the world-made-larger, instead of throwaway line after throwaway line of snark, glib commentary and so on. The stitching on the baseball, the us-sized ants fighting weevils. This instead of pulling us in two different directions while we're also trying to just take in the world you created. Experienced players will have time to do that when they're stabilized, but the moment will have been lost by then. 

A shame. I hope it improves. Still love you, Obsidian.

Buyer: To borrow a line from Pete, "Logic dictates that you give this game a pass for now."

At 11 hours in on 3 different files, my own, and 2 others with different friends, the game already has a solid amount of content. Despite having no perks or any sort of leveling the tier of weapons plays a big part in still making for feel progression, starting with spears and axes and using the parts of beaten bugs to upgrade and advance. Each armor has different advantages and disadvantages so even some of the earlier armors have some use here and there. A small but diverse 11 bugs currently reside in the game, from the tiny aphids to the monsterous spiders each having a use and purpose in the game either for food or progression. The tool selection is small at the moment with only 3 hammers, 2 axe, 1 spear, and 2 clubs but I can see that being super easy to expand as the yard gets bigger and more dangerous with the new bugs. The 2 bows are nice but feel a bit lackluster in solo, but can see them great for co-op.

If your ok with bugs, both literal and in game sense, then Grounded is a great buy right now

I'm going to be as honest as possible, while trying to remain polite and constructive. I am fully aware that this game is in early access, so take everything I have to say with a grain of salt.

Firstly, the atmosphere is wonderful. You're tiny, and facing tiny problems. The tiny visuals are a joy, if only you were able to fully appreciate the scale of the things in your yard. Up to this point, the devs have decided that blurring all "huge" things (such as the tree and the house) is a good idea, but all this does is makes it a visual EYE SORE. I feel like I have both put on and removed my glasses, giving me nothing but simulated eyestrain. I WISH I could experience how truly big these things are in comparison to me, but again, they are out of focus and nearly impossible to appreciate. (Just think about it, it's like a normal person looking at a skyscraper and it's just one big blur. Doesn't make sense and hurts the eyes)

Secondly, I feel like there isn't much to do that I haven't done already in nearly every other survival game. While the perspective is different, the feel of the game is all too familiar. I would love to see them change the game right from the beginning. Maybe give you a pet bug from the get go, something to take care of while you figure out what is happening. The experience of being alone in the wild and punching items until you get more useful ones has been done too much.

I have few comments on other aspects including locomotion, which has been executed quite nicely. Everything feels fluid, and rarely did I find geometry hindering my exploration. The UI is easy to understand, and I never felt like I was being walked through a large tutorial.

Unfortunately, I haven't bothered with multiplayer. I already didn't enjoy the game on my own from a technical point of view. Unless the game is tweaked to be more unique, I may not see myself playing much more of this game. 

NOT A BAD GAME, just not for me.

While this game is less than two weeks off of its release as early access at the time of this review, there is a lot of substance to it. Obsidian is already accepting lots of feedback for this new title, and they will likely channel such feedback into improvements for an already outstanding outdoor adventure. Here are my personal thoughts on the game so far:

[b] Graphics [/b]: The game looks amazing. There is loads of detail packed into every inch of the backyard that you explore. It is apparent that the game was meant to feel immersive and look fairly realistic. Unfortunately, that means that you'll need a beefy computer to play Grounded at an optimal graphics level. If you do have an advanced computer rig, then you have access to an array of the visual embellishments the game has to look more realistic, including motion blur and shading (gamma). Even if you don't, the game looks good but a bit blurry at the lowest settings. The one complaint I will share about the game's art is the sprite work, both in the inventory and as models in the world. Some of the sprites work well, but many are unpolished, reused, or simply not done. This especially goes for 3D models in the world, with many item just being brown bags. 

[b] Game Play [/b]: This game is optimized for Xbox, which is apparent with Xbox on the loading screen. Luckily, the keyboard controls have been properly examined and concentrated to the left side of the keyboard around WASD movement. Any buttons that are out of the way, like M for the map, are shortcuts to menus that are already accessible from multiple places. I'm also confident that the keyboard bindings can be edited to personalize the controls and eliminate uncomfortable game play.

As far as the game itself, it is fairly intuitive if you are a survival game veteran, but maybe a bit abstruse for new arrivals to the genre. I think the game could use a little more direction from the start. To do that, the only change I would recommend is for an additional starting quest to craft an axe. That way, players will become familiar with the crafting interface right away and how to navigate through multiple tabs. It will also make the build a lean-to quest much more natural after.

[b] Multiplayer [/b]: Because Xbox is supposed to be the primary platform for this game and not Steam, multiplayer uses Xbox Live in order to connect with other players. This indicates cross-platform compatibility, but also means that Steam users need an Xbox Live subscription to play multiplayer. This is the part that I disagree with. I like the idea of cross-platform compatibility, but I think that purchasing a subscription to a completely different console in order to play online with other computer users should be optional, as well as viewing the message before the main menu screen reminding me of logging in with Xbox Live. That should only be after selecting multiplayer. It should only be mandated if we Steam users want to play with Xbox players online. As with pretty much all other games, multiplayer has its own unique array of bugs, but because I have not played or seen multiplayer, I consider myself inadequate to further comment on bugs in multiplayer.

[b] Bugs (as in the ones with legs) [/b]: [spoiler] The game features a host of legged creatures, with four harmless ones, half a dozen or more moderate threats, and five titans of the lawn that are not easily trifled with. The current ones fit very well in my opinion, but there is still room for more. Personally, I would like to see more flying creatures, namely bees, hornets, crickets, and dragonflies. With that, I would like to see improved aerial combat. The one flying creature (gnat) is difficult to hit even when circling the player. Throwable nets or web traps would be fun to see to fight winged creatures. Also improved gliders and more use for grub armor would compliment such additions. [/spoiler]

Raw Science: [spoiler] This game has a currency system known as Raw Science. You exchange it for recipes from BURG.L. However, the game fails to indicate in any fashion that you need to pick up the small, almost unnoticable item by BURG.L's feet and give it to him before you can exchange Raw Science for anything. Otherwise, this currency has no application. BURG.L (in his exchange tab) or the game should tell you to look around the room before exchanging Raw Science for anything so the currency and side quests have use. [/spoiler]

Building: [spoiler] This game has building features that involve cutting down larger plants and fashioning them into house parts. The game does not tell you that you need clay and access to BURG.L for more intricate house building. The houses are much simpler without these. Windowed walls are, to me, the most infuriating part of house building. They are differently sized than walls and are pickier regarding placement. I think that maybe a movement to find and gather clay at some point would make building a bit better, as well as re-examining windowed walls. [/spoiler]

SCA.B: [spoiler] SCA.B (pronounced "scabby") is the device attached to the player's arm that monitors their overall health. It is the in-game explanation as to why the character can visibly see how hungry or thirsty they are. SCA.B is very obnoxious in practice. The UI for the stat interface is fine, but the noises that SCA.B makes (a mechanical [i] waaah waaaaaaaaah [/i]) to alert the player are relentlessly irritating. There should be an option to change the noise SCA.B makes (maybe a purchasable from BURG.L) and/or a volume setting on it. [/spoiler]

[b] Story [/b]: The story of this game is in the works. You can get the main quests done in just about an hour or two depending on how brave you're feeling. [spoiler] After you activate the machine and go to the lab, there's not much except side quests to run errands. [/spoiler] The story is probably the part of this game that is the most heavily in development or just the least implemented right now.

[b] Conclusion [/b]: If you are interested in survival games, this one makes for a really good option, even in an unfinished state. It is a unique take on a survival game, with many potential avenues to explore. Later down the road, I might follow this up once the game gets more content and fixes.

***FIRST TIME REVIEWER***

What a beautiful game.  The amount of potential this game has is staggering.  I'm just imagining late game being in the pond with a makeshift boat or some sort of diving makeshift suit of some sort to get into a a new biom under water or an island.  Or perhaps, make our way into the house and holy cow the POTENTIAL.  Daddy Long Legs SUPER HUGE crawling all over the place.  I mean, CMON developers this has such a massive chip on its shoulder and I am hungry, just waiting on the dip.

Ok enough with the foreplay.

Atmosphere: 5/5

Really nothing to say about this.  I felt able to go anywhere I wanted in the entire layout of the game so far, no hindrances aside from stuff I assume will be implemented as time goes by.  Done and done.

Story: 2/5

It's still early.  I imagine quite a lot of Subnauticaesque style of quests being implemented along with more quest hubs.  Giving a 2 as of now for that alone, however the quests that are provided give us a pretty good traveling picture book journey across the built landscape.

Graphics: 5/5

Absolutely beautiful.  Atmosphere should have already covered this, but those sounds mmm  mm.  Bravo!

Sound: 4/5

Because why not.  Sound is very, VERY important in my opinion of course.  I will only point to Subnautica in cases like this, simply because of the sound design.  Again game, is super early stages here but so far it is well done.

Crafting: 3/5

Very easy to understand crafting in this game.  Not too much diversity.  Would love for more items, again, still early stages.  But none the less a 3 a 3 a 3 for you sir.

Character: 2/5

Now.  A 2 here, really only shows the minimal amount of detail we have with our characters.  I would like to see each character having certain specialist titles.  One's more sciency and therefor has different craftible options.  Ones super athletic and can run jump climb faster, and on and on.  The little interactions we do have however are on point.  Certain landmarks you discover and the little character quirks are a very good start.

Overall: 3/5

Definitely well worth the money in the games current stage.

cant fully commit a review to this game. It really has its ups/downs due to it being early access game. 
dont know if this just applies to me but for the bugs/glitches:
1. falling tree physics. dont know if game dev did it on purpose but sometimes after cutting down trees, they would be launched away like on a catapult flying off to ridiculous locations - pain to have it be hauled.
2. fallen item physics, there will be times when the ground is littered with your mats (plant fiber, grass, stems ,etc) when you walk/run over them, you trip/stumble/bounce preventing movement temporarily. 
3. when organizing my inventory via storage chests, my items being deposited would disappear completely and my total backpack space would get reduced.. couldnt fix until i restarted game.
4. still rather new to the game so this might be just me being dumb.. but when knocking back an arrow with bow equipped, cant disable animation to cancel shooting the bow..
5. latency issues but this might just be my local internet connections. 

besides those points, the game is fantastic and heavy with content. gives you puzzles to solve, hunt/gather, research, build, craft. endless possibilities! cant wait for more multiplayer functions in the future.

It's an okay game so far. The combat is kind of bland, and the deeper systems of gear mechanics are interesting - I hope to see it fleshed out more with gadgets or something more beyond the 3 pieces of gear you can equip right now.  It's fun for what it is, but I don't think I'll be playing it any more for the following reason:

Unlike games like Subnautica where you mine for ore and non-living materials to create stuff for progression, in Grounded you have to kill bugs. At first I didn't think I would mind that very much, but over time I found the Aphids to be cute, and the Ants to be pretty fun to chill out with. Sadly you gotta kill 'em to build better armor and weapons. Ladybugs are adorable, but you gotta kill 'em if you want better weapons. None of those things ever attack you or are aggressive towards you - they just mind their own business. The ants will even walk up to you, be chill and emote a bit, then wander off - you can even feed them. 

Just couldn't bring myself to keep killing them, so I'm out.

Went and bought this game with 3 friends since its a 4 player game. Immediately we all started senselessly beating poor bugs to death and fought a lady bug and got annihilated. Safe to say that was the funnest we had in a while.

Great theme and concept, a mixture of PIXAR-esque style with a hint of "Honey I shrunk the kids" kind of vibe.

Honestly as interesting as the story was/is my group and I were more so focused on the survival aspect and looking to quickly grind to get the best gear to conquer the garden.

Shortly after a few days of the same thing we kinda started to slow down and eventually started to lose a little interest. The trope gets boring quickly without the content but I am sure more content is coming / going to be added later. A little bit of server issues as sometimes my friends or I would randomly get disconnected, a good bunch of bugs but the dev team seem to be keeping up so that's all well and good.

So long as the updates keep coming and content is being added then this game will net you days and days of fun! BONUS if you have friends to play with but even alone you can really get immersed in the world.

For the moment since its still new I'll give it a 6.5/10. But with the future content coming, the steady amount of bug patches and the fun aspect of playing it with friends I have no doubt it'll be close to an 8 or 9/10.

Whether you like or hate creepy crawlers, you will love this big small world, pact with exploration, jaw dropping discoveries, and intuitive crafting mechanics. This is the survival game you have been looking for.

The immense interactive environment and live ecosystem, will immerse you into a magical insect world beneath our feet, that most of us take for granted. Along the way, you will discover amazing sights and cringing moments, from majestic creatures to terrifying threats and ingenious technology in your expedition for survival and exposition.

Very smooth controls in 3rd and 1st person perspectives. Streamlined crafting and science research, allow for advanced weaponry and base fortification.  Easy and intuitive crafting menus to escape the monotonous duties of batch crafting and base building. Simple and clearly labeled crafting recipes. Modern base building mechanics are a welcome addition, making it a snap to build your fort or cozy cottage as you please.

Overall this is an amazing user friendly survival game to start your survival game expirience or add to your collection for any survival fan.

After the the patch, water drops are bugged so now they don't spawn on collectors and now drops are just permanently stuck floating in air when you try to knock them down. For a game with hungry/thirst mechanics it's kind of a FUNDAMENTAL PROBLEM IF YOU CAN'T DRINK. I honestly want nothing more then a refund on this game but I decided to try to be patient with it until it became unplayable and ended up going over the 2 hour refund policy that steam has and now I'm out my money. Fun game. Honey I Shrunk the Kids, meets The Forest..kind of. Seems nicely optimized, voice acting is pretty good, combat is well done, and most all animations are smooth. I was a bit skeptical, due to a couple of bugs after release, but devs responded directly and quickly, releasing a patch that addressed and fixed those issues, while also tackling some others. 
 The only down side to the game is there arent many story quests yet so its pretty easy to finish all those in less than an hour, however they will be adding more soon, and there are lots of things you can do to stay busy until then. You can truly use your imagination to build any type of home you like. Want to build a spiral home up the side of a tree? Or a lake house that extends out over and across the lake? or a simple ground home inside a hollow tree base that you can fortify with palisades to keep out the spiders and other aggressive bugs? You can do all those and more. Great game, really looking forward to more story releases.

Well I've just finished playing Grounded and I've sunk about 23 hours into the game so far.  Overall I loved it.  The atmosphere and gameplay loop are fun and addicting and any game that lets me kill monsters and make armor from their corpses will get my vote.  However there are a few major issues that make this game hard to play and enjoy.  The inventory issues being the primary offender.  For basically the whole game most of my inventory was tools and armor.  I had maybe 8-10 slots at a time for loot which meant lots pf running home.  I spent more time running back home than I feel I spent doing anything else.  Combat seems to be a heavy focus of the game and while fun actually fighting things makes the game harder.  I spent hours hunting ladybugs for the armor only for it to break after maybe 30 minutes.  (you can repair, but that gets expensive).  The game puts a lot of value on "perfect blocking" and the issue with that is that the block doesn't stop your armor from being destroyed.  I fought one wolf spider and took no damage, but it almost completely destroyed my armor in that one fight.   Plus it took a long time for me to figure out how to fight the enemies because the hit boxes are so broken.  I've died dozens of times to Bombardiers and Spiders that according to the animations never hit me.  I loved the game and I'll be coming back for the updates, but with combat being such a heavy focus I feel like it needs to be a little less frustrating.

It would be nice to have a middle of the road option for games like this.

There is enough content to keep you going for the time being as long as you're looking for a survival/building sort of game, rather than a story. Currently the story is missing in action, but I don't doubt that Obsidian will provide something enjoyable in future as the game develops. :D

This game is early access as of writing this and so obviously, things are expected to change.

Grounded is a game in which you take the form of a shrunken human trying to survive in the...backyard. I personally think the style is adorable, and I think, though opposite, it is a welcome surprise when paired with the combat of the game.

I'll start with the good. The game is beautiful. The lighting is fantastic, and you can't really get away with cheating too much in the dark by boosting the gamma. Problem solving to get food or water is actually very fun and rewarding, and I don't feel rushed to top these bars every few minutes, which is a welcome change from other survival games in which I have to eat or drink frequently - it gives me time to explore, or complete tasks given to me. The game also makes it very clear when you're low on something. The varying insects all have different mechanics, which, even without a tutorial is pretty quick to grasp, for example, some bugs are never hostile (though annoying - gnats), some aren't until attacked, you can get away with sneaking behind some, while others - not so much. Some have routes, which you can pick up on, and others leave their "designated" areas. Progress in terms of getting upgrades also feels rewarding, and though it's not fully released, I have a feeling that the lore will be... interesting, to say the least, based on the potential "easter eggs" throughout the map (unless it turns out to be the whole "but it was all a dream!" shtick). Overall, the progression feels rewarding. There's always multiple ways to get to destinations, even if you choose not to go the "intended" way. I quite enjoyed the base-building, as well - it was relaxing rather than tedious. Also, through my research, the game is supposed to be "reactive", meaning that the resources and actions you take have an effect on the way the "ecosystem" changes, though, I have seen very little of this.
Also, multiplayer is functional, both through steam, and cross-platform (though tedious, but that'll be touched on later). The amount of breath you have while swimming is another pleasant addition to the game, since you can stay underwater for more than two seconds.  The map is fun and, though unneeded in my case, the arachnophobia mode is pretty funny, but useful to some. Jump height, maneuverability, resource gathering - all wonderful. 

For the bad (and again, PLEASE remember, this is early access). Bugs. BUGS! No pun, but game-breaking bugs are very prevalent at the time of reviewing this game, to name a few that I've personally encountered: Crashing, inventory deletion (constantly), forced "/kill" - "Give Up" via getting permanently grappled by non-existent spider webs, smacked through walls, aggro'd on through walls, and getting launched like team rocket any time I jump into any kind of angled structure. Resources and insects getting sucked into impenetrable structures. The hitboxes for hostiles is a bit ridiculous (I can't tell you how many times I was rocketed to the underworld by a spider standing a good 200 feet away from me). The game has essentially zero replayability, and the map is constant - never-changing. At a low difficulty setting, and full ladybug armour, wolf spiders can still two-hit the players. There are tasks in the game which are completely impossible to complete, as what's needed has not yet been implemented into the game. The game is quite clearly not optimized to play on PC yet, basic tasks like dropping items, or stashing stacks are tedious and take extra time for nothing - and the "esc/escape" button is 50/50 with if it decides it wants to work, especially when looking around in the menu, settings, what have you. Though understandable for cross-platform, getting multiplayer to function is a bit annoying, needing an alternative to my steam account (microsoft) set up to play ANY multiplayer, even if it isn't being played crossplatform. Finally, the voices and voicelines of the kids are atrocious. This is purely my opinion, but Willow Branch (seriously why did you do this to me) is the only character worth playing, as she complains the least in her voice lines and isn't literally moaning when she eats. The jokes (ex: "this tastes worse/better than my mom/dad's brussel sprouts" - feat. What is this an 80's Sitcom?) If you're not interested in the story, I highly recommend just turning off the voices and subtitles, while you're at it. Though the least of the issues, the voices and, (but mostly) script for purely the children is the most annoying to me.

In conclusion, I do NOT recommend this game currently, primarily because it's not optimized to be played with anything but a controller, and until that makes stashing all of your inventory before closing the game easier, or until the vanishing inventory bug is patched, I can't in good spirits tell people to purchase this game. I could tolerate everything else.

IF you are careful, don't mind the slight wonkynes due to bugs, are patient with the time it takes to perform basic actions, I think you can play the game confidently without many issues, even with friends. I think with a few tweaks, and with more progression, the game will be great, and I'll be - hopefully - returning to update this review in the future.

As of now I have 16 hours in this game its not much, but I think I'm able to give a steady review. First of all I will say this: I am [b]Terrified[/b] of spiders, I get very stressed out playing this game. The safe mode for this game does not make things any better in my opinion. 

~ The game has a lot to do depending on how you play it.  The farther out you go you'll realize that there's not much out there, but that's when the exploration part comes in. There's lots of areas to explore and you can go out of bounds to see future content. If you decide to stay in bounds the game provides a great amount to do, and for a small game there's a lot of lore that's already placed in. 

~ There's currently single-player, co-op and a creative mode. The single-player and co-op has a choice of three different difficulties, depending on which you play will decide how fast the hunger and thirst bar will drain, and how much damage the insects will deal. 

~ The game has a tier list and as you move through the tiers, you'll realize that it becomes more difficult to play. So far there's [spoiler]3[/spoiler] tiers. This tier list works for the base building and the weapon layout. The further you go, the better the base to build and the more powerful weapons to be built.

Don't give the game and obsidian too much crap, just remember: This is a [u]Early Access Game[/u], there's plenty of glitches and bugs they need to work out and they plan to have a lot of content. They just need time to do so.

Im going to leave a not recommend for good reasons. However you should get this game when it has more. Here was my experience. 
Graphics: Very Good!
Performance: Ran great, host of game had some issues from amount of entities in our area (eg: grass planks, weed stems, etc) I also crashed twice, fell through world on login, bugs would glitch (mostly spiders), desync with server despite very fast internet on both sides.
Content: Beyond lacking. Now let me say that this game has potential, A LOT of potential. We were just brainstorming things we would like to see such as, paper airplane launcher, grappling hooks, different bugs like wasps and mosquitoes, and all the different items they would bring, almost endless. A good story you can follow and learn about.
Spoiler ahead***You basically learn a scientist fails at his project, goes back to his shrink ray, succeeds (obviously) and thats it. I have 12 hours played, my friend and I had to reddit if there was more, watched videos, read what others have done....nothing. We did everything, built everything, got everything....and part of that was relocating our base out of the oak tree bc the spiders always spawn there, and believe me when i say this, no matter what, they spawn there.
NO DEDICATED SERVER! A player has to launch and run server. That person not on, you play on your own. As previously stated, it caused some host lag.

Final thought: This can be a fantastic game, endless possibilities, fun to play. The only thing is, its no $30 game (right now). If you must play it, wait for it to go on sale. I cant wait to see what happens here and will check on it about every 6 months, maybe longer, thats how much content it lacks right now. Good luck to everyone making this game and I hope you listen to your community when building a bigger, better game.

So, if you're like me, you're looking at this game because you're a fan of games like The Forest. So let me relate to you based on the assumption you played that.

Remember when The Forest DIDN'T have the airplane scene and you just woke up in the plane? Like you knew there was maybe a story and that it was clear that the devs were working on a story? Grounded is mechanically like The Forest now and story-wise like The Forest then. 

Despite being almost a clone of The Forest mechanically, there are some huge differences as well. Grounded does not take any mercy on you. Many bugs are hostile and most of the smaller bugs swarm. Spiders will OHKO you and are literally EVERYWHERE. Spiders are like the mid-end game mutants in The Forest. They take a single look at your base and just start blastin'. There are avenues for dealing with them, but as of this review, I haven't tried many of them out yet.

Grounded runs, looks and feels like a AAA titles and suffers from very few FPS issues as far as I can tell. All-in-all, as someone who loved the hell out of the Forest from Alpha to now, Grounded is fun to play for a bit right now.
Do not skip this.

First of all. THIS. GAME. IS. AMAZING!
Hands down would recommend this game to anyone i know immediately, now on to the actual review!

This game is much like a mixture of The Forest and Subnautica. If you like any of those two games consider grabbing this beauty. even with The Forest having mutated flesh eating cannibals and Subnautica being filled with loads of potentially deadly aquatic life this game still make a major impact on the survival game community, now you're probably looking at the game right about now saying "well hey it doesn't look too bad, i might take i peek at the reviews to find out what others experiences are?" well i'm telling you right now. 
GET IT.
This game has so much potential! (and it's only the beginning!) Grounded even 20 hours in is still providing me with unique experiences, landmarks and challenges to face. The developers behind the making of Grounded have focused into making a playable survival game before focusing on the story (in which they have succeeded mind you) and this is 100% fine, no one would want a game with all of the story content released initially and have a broken and playable experience.

Now for the graphics. These graphics are take home to your parents material, secondly the cartoonish nature of this game really brings out all of the little details and really enhances the experience without any frame loss.

The gameplay, yes you've all been waiting for this part!
this game comes out on top for stable gameplay, yes this review was made in the early access of the game as you can see at the top of this review but DAMN never have i ever seen such well polished A.I even spiders slowly stalk you until they get the right opportunity to pounce! meaning you have to be aware of your surroundings at all times! this even means during the day. Grounded tends to get harder the longer you play much like most other survival crafting horror games no matter how hard you try you can only avoid conflict for so long. every so often you'll have waves of enimies sent to your beautifully build base, as you're standing back and admiring it something is sure to sneak up behind you and wage war.

Grounded is a early access masterpiece! so naturally that means it is still subject to change and still has many updates to come! this is only the foundation of the game, imagine what it will be in a few years heck, maybe even months time! don't pass up an opportunity like this.

anyways enough about blabbering on about this review i'm off to play yet again! 
peace out!

disclaimer: yes we do run into glitches and bugs quite a bit, but it's not deterring us from the otherwise pretty fun gameplay.

Grounded caught me and my friends completely off guard with its beautiful artstyle, small-group-centered coop multiplay (4 players max) and generally very enjoyable Gameplay. 

Compared to other titles on the genre, i would tag it more as a survival light, and it does its job decently at that (medium difficulty is our experience) - You have to manage your hunger and thirst, but its not too much of a hassle, and once you know where to look, its one of these things you just do alongside while youre around on any other tasks. 
Enemies range from "cute and smack it dead" with little to no resistance to "oh crap, that wolf spider caught me off guard and now im getting eaten" with a lot of in between. About every of the more meaningful enemies has tricks to get the fight done a bit less stressful, but especially on the bigger guys later, when you think theyre no more than pushovers because of your gear / weapon, they can still getcha if you dont pay attention.

The base building is amazing, you can lay out your base as blueprints and the haul in the materials over time. The material grind isnt overly bothersome and feels okay on the amounts you need. Of course a big supercastle will take some time to bring to life, but its still no ridiculous supergrind to grab the resources. If youre the creative type, you can end up with a very fancy place, the game gives you an ok amount of individual building blocks to play around with. I think more will be added in future updates, if i caught that correctly. 

It's a fun promising experience. It lacks content, the current main quest can be finished in some 10 minutes if you really push it, but so far we have been staying busy just kinda playing the game and didnt get bored yet. 
Experience may vary on that last part, of course.

Bugs can be annoying at times, but just recently a couple important ones got fixed, and im pretty confident theyll eventually get it under control.

Overall, recommended for someone who likes himself some casual survival, best with a handful of friends around, too.

This being in early access obviously means there will be a lack in content and loads of bugs, so I won't, unlike many others, point on those two issues which is totally acceptable at this stage. I will however, regarding bugs, say that the feedback/bug report system could be better. They ask us to give feedback but the way to do it is meaningless. To give a sad smiley when you're stuck in the air due to buggy spiderweb doesn't give the developer a good enough basis to fix bugs. WIth that being said I will get down to the review.

I've played a little over 35 hours and I have to say those hours went by really quickly: this game is addictive. I played with my partner and this is a really fun cooperative experience, fighting spiders, building your base. The addictive part is to always wanting to progress, to let your creativity flow when building a house or a fort.

I really like the concept of being the size of an ant, having to worry about small bugs that normally isn't even a nuisance. The game offers both normal monsters which can be killed with one hand and a little tougher ones that require a little finesse, in the beginning. I feel like spiders should be harder. Maybe they've planned on introducing tougher enemies but after only 35 hours wolf spiders shouldn't be a piece of cake.

The base building is really fun and I love the idea that bugs break in and steal your stuff unless you've secured it properly. This is very obvious when you don't build on a base and build on the ground directly: walls, roof and more don't really connect and before I realized you can build floors and clay bases if you progress the "story" building a base was a hassle.

Fighting system is fairly basic, nothing special about it really: hack'n slash with the possibility of avoiding damage completely if you parry attacks properly. Weapons break which I like, adds a little more to keep track on and that's a positive. Night time can be dangerous unless you utilize torches, you need to eat, drink but the thing I miss is the need to sleep.

Overall this game is a really fun survival game. It has interesting graphics and I look forward to the full release with more content. This game is a lot more fun when playing with friends (you can play with up to 4 people in a lobby mind you) but is enjoyable by yourself aswell.

It's difficult to give a review to an early access game when the common problems like lack of content, bugs, performance, items, features etc, may be added /fixed as we speak but I will try to give it a go anyway to give an idea of the positves and negatives of the game:

+ Fun concept, shrinking down and having a normal garden as a world to explore is really fun.
+ It's the same feeling you get when playing games like Minecraft: gathering materials and building stuff is almost funnier than the rest of the game
+ If you don't like spiders, there's an option for you to make them look less spider-like.
+ Being a survival game you have to keep track of your food and water intake. And night time makes it harder and unless you utilize torches you won't see bugger all.
+ The game has fun little details like using dandelions to glide in the air, you get stuck in spiderwebs, bug-thieves etc. Small stuff really but adds to the fun.
+ The possibility to add countless of items, monsters in the future. At this stage the game doesn't have a great replay value but it really has potential to be a really good game

- The report system has to get better. It's acceptable to encounter bugs but reporting them needs to be more specific. I don't want to report bugs in the steam review page.
- The difficulty should be adjusted. Much can be adjusted with difficulty but I'd like to see something that cannot be defeated, that HAS to be avoided. I would like to not be able to defeat difficult enemies as fast as I can now.
- Needing to avoid spiders in the beginning is really fun, but when they attack your base, destroy your walls and jump over them it's not as fun anymore when you die and they camp your corpse. Maybe not having the difficult, one-hit-kill monsters attacking your base and spawn point would be a good idea.
- A more detailed option menu is never bad. Having more options is desirable.

Is this game worth the 30 bucks? If you don't forget that this isn't a released game yet and there WILL be bugs, crashes, lack of content and in general stuff to improve then YES. Don't buy this if you expect to have a full released game with hours of content and replay value because at the moment it doesn't. Go into this with an open mind of what the game CAN become instead of what the game currently IS and you'll have a great time.

Honey I Shrunk the Kids meets Ark Survival - though I've not played this at ALL on multiplayer, unlike Ark it is a ton of fun to run around on single player and experience the world for what it is. It's very well done, considering it's early access and there's a bunch of things you can do and enjoy. 

There's still some things that need work, obviously, such as the respawn issue I've ran into that if something runs away from you after you shoot it from up high or somewhere "safe", it tends to spawn another one, and the other one walks back. Meaning you could have... oh... 8 wolf spiders instead of 2. There's also some small building errors where things don't "snap" properly to existing structures, some floating wall lamps here and there, and the settings don't stick when you turn the game back on. (Curse you motion blur) the NPC occasionally gives you a daily quest of something not yet released in the game as well (Mosquitos, where art thou?) 

However, these are small complaints. I absolutely love the game, and I've been literally enjoying my time playing it. I love playing with the building mechanics and doing literally almost whatever I want, and really look forward to new stuff being added. It's everything I loved about Ark- the building, the exploration, and the sense of wonder as you find new and exciting sights and places. Crafting is a lot of fun, and does feel rewarding once you get it all together and working. I love that you have to physically carry things back to your base, and the ant armor of all things is what allows you to carry more. The existing lore and NPC  dialogue is very intriguing and I can't wait to learn more about it!

1. Content - Currently total of 30 minutes of "story" - If you're expecting a story-line to follow, expect 30 minutes of it.

2. Open World - Building is easy, has unlockables, and can be built almost anywhere on the map. Best part of the game so far is build several bases, different kinds, and how fun it is to upgrade. The farming in this game is just like any other open world game, but resembles don't starve together, where you require a lot of the basic materials to get started, then move forward with tiers of items.

3. Fighting - Fighting mechanic is easy to pick up, and have a moderate skill gap, with the parry function. There are multiple bugs (monsters/creeps) in this game that require no knowledge of attacking/moving/kiting; There are some bugs that you must attack, move to dodge, and kite to no die, and to sustain HP. 

4. Co-op - Right now there is a max of 4 players, and i believe that is a good number. Hopefully in the future they can add dedicated servers and 6 people so there can be a clown fiesta of people fighting off swarms. 

Summary - 7/10 Game 
The real lack of story for 30$ price tag is what really hurts this game. Do not spend your money now, and wait for the update in Aug27th 2020 to see if its worth the investment.

I've been waiting for a game like this ever since I was a kid and the fact that this is only Early Access blows my mind. I love this game and I hope more and more people support this masterpiece.

The game's a little buggy (not the ones that try to murder you) and there's a handful to brush up on, but for an Early Access game, it runs amazingly. Multiplayer obviously has more issues in terms of gameplay, but I suspect that will improve in time.

If you liked the Forest, you'll love Grounded. 

The attention to detail in the game is incredible and although I don't have the best computer, I am so happy that I am able to play with lowered graphics. Even with the lowered settings, this game still looks absolutely beautiful. 

There's a lot that will be added to the game and I'm excited to see where Grounded ends up. With so much to offer already, this game is only going to get better. Get this game. Support the devs. I would have paid double for this game and still gotten my money's worth.

As of right now, I've completed the game. I've killed every bug, explored every biome, built my base, and crafted every perceivable item the game has to offer. As of my completion of the game, I have 3 things to say.

1. This game's atmosphere and concept are stunning, it's hard to believe that no other game developers have jumped onto the "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" idea, but they haven't and here this game is. With realistic yet slightly cartoony graphics, every time I open the game I feel totally and fully immersed in the world of "Grounded".

2. Now that's not to say this game doesn't have it's flaws. It's a little bit pricey for the current content offered but considering that it only came out about a week or so ago, I'll give it some time to flesh itself out. For the content the game does have it's perfectly polished. It feels fair and like I'm really a shrunken child fighting a regular ol' wolf spider with my scrappily made bow and hammer. 

3. I would say if you're going to buy this game then you should buy it with friends, the solo experience is quite difficult considering that you have a whole world to be explored and many insects and arachnids to battle. Without friends the game can seem a bit lonely, like you're the only person in this vast world. So yeah, get some friends, buy it, play it, and have fun.

This is a breath of fresh air for survival games. It's a beautiful world and a unique experience, running around as someone shrunken down to nearly the size of an ant. It doesn't go out of its way to destroy you at every turn, but you have to watch around you, because spiders and a few other enemies you'll find  are appropriately deadly. I think it's being developed in a pretty smart and balanced way. The story is a good little beginning and you can tell they're going somewhere good with it. The crafting and build systems are simple and intuitive with a generous amount of freedom to build your structures however and wherever you want, pretty much. I hope they'll add things like frogs and fish, mice, rats, or squirrels, maybe also simple vehicles like craftable boats (a large leaf or something as the hull) , underwater buildings perhaps. Looking forward to seeing how this thing evolves, but it's a lot of fun to play already.

This is a "Honey I Shrunk The Kids" shrunk down survival/builder game.  Played from launch on July 28, 2020, plan on updating this review as more content and patches make changes to the core gameplay.

Pros:
-Fun visuals, being tiny is great
-Unlocking new gear feels rewarding.
-Multiplayer/Co-op makes the adventures that much more fantastic.
-Base building can be a lot of fun (but also a time suck!)
-You can get this for free if you're using Xbox GamePass, dont need to buy it on Steam.
-Has an "Arachnophobia" mode to tone down the spiders

Cons:
-If you're on steam, you also will need an Xbox Live account (free works) to connect to others in multiplayer
-Music can be a bit repetitive
-Some noises far too loud on headphones, I had to turn down some sliders to 30-40%
-Large bases make make the game run a little slower
If you are going to play it definitely play it with multiple people

For $30 it's a bit steep right now.

There is a decent bit to do so far concerning sandbox elements, not a ton.

The story is very short so far.

My favorite parts about it is how the map is small but easy to navigate quickly, but also packed with new enemies, items, and biomes. It feels much more fast paced and enjoyable compared to something like ark, and there isn't a ton of grinding either.

Despite its early state, Grounded is easily my favorite survival sandbox game I've played yet.

This game is only in early access. Keeping that in mind, this game is amazing. I'm comparing this game directly to the forest (and its early access). Grounded gives you so much more things so play with, discover and learn. I'm going to list down some of the things I really liked and I disliked about the game (the dislike factor doesn't really matter because it's only in early access):

Pros:
- many things to discover and learn (many items and different areas of the map)
- very cool and individual characters to choose from
- the whole athmosphere of this game is very mysterious (soundtracks and light settings)
- as far as main story goes it's very interesting and makes you wonder what happened
- Beautiful graphics, the insects look disgusting, yet cute :D
- you actually get jumpscares in this game, because some insects sound like they are going to murder you (makes the whole gameplay pretty exciting)
- very creative game in general, especially the details

Cons:
- the design of the characters remind me a little bit of fortnite, which is the only con for me about the graphics, everything else looks stunning
- Some of the insects appear to sometimes bug in a stone (which is actually helpful and not disadvantaging)
- the storyline is very short yet, only about an hour long if you take your time with it and not rush it
- the game crashes sometimes (for me it was 1 time in +10 hours)
- for using mutliplayer you need to create or log into your xbox account and add your friends there. It's not possible playing with your friends over steam only yet.
- the price is a little bit much for an early access game

I'ld say you should buy this game if you are really into survival games and you would like to play a game which is a little bit different than the usual survival games out there and you don't mind playing an early access game with some bugs and a small storyline. If you hate bugs and love jumpscares and playing with your friends, buy it! :D

This is my re-written review for Grounded. Spoilers will not be blocked.

Grounded: The best survival game I have ever played.

The claim I make in the title is quite absurd. I have been playing Minecraft since 2014 and I have had more fun with this game in the past week than I have with that game ever. I of course would never say this is the best game I have ever played, because that would be like marrying someone a week after meeting them.

First I want to break down the pros and cons of this game. I warn that there are not that many HUGE cons, and the pros certainly mean more as the cons are just little issues

Pros:
Very creative concept that is realized to the fullest extent
Monthly updates
Great Visuals

Meh's:
Decent Story

Cons:
No Persistant Servers
Price should be half its cost, but I don't like complaining about price points as they are very circumstantial 
Buggy, but ea so what can you do.

First lets discuss the concept. I can envision a version of this game set in a field or a forest of some sort and not a backyard. But setting this game in a backyard was a stroke of genius. When I first saw the game, I was worried the giant objects would not add to game play. Nope. From a spilled over can of pesticides making a biome toxic requiring a gas mask to explore to juice boxes and soda cans to fill you first, this game is jam packed with 90's inspired environments that you want to just explore every inch of.

The story is a ok. (Spoiler warning)

From what I have gathered the story is what you would think. You are shrunk down by a bad corporation because they are bad, so get big. Also theirs  a mad scientist named Wendall (Who sounds like a rejected Wendys employee) and his robot who also is, you guessed it, crazy. I was some what disappointed because the game is made by Obsidian, so I expected big. I would hope this story is slowly fixed through ea.

On last thing before we wrap up with the cons. I played this game with my mom, and just joining yesterday, my dad. I can confirm its much funner with friends, so find one who has game pass and threaten them with a shrink ray until they want to play.

Please oh please give me persistant servers! I really don't like the hosting system, I want to be able to have a small community we can jump in and out of when we want. The bugs run rampant in more ways then one. I noticed to many too count, but they seem to be patching them on the daily

But who cares get this game, and join the million of us who agree.
This game has a excellent concept that, even at this time, is very well executed. Not only that, but there is so much room for expansion of this world. Exciting stuff...

We have played for about 29 hours now so I thought I would give and updated review. 

The story is short but the survival and adventuring aspect definitely holds its own while they continue creating content. I have had zero problems with multiplayer as well so dont let those reviews hold you back. There is a ton of things to create and build in the game that will actually take you a while to do if you try to do all of it. None of the enemies are OP either, some people will argue the spider is OP but honestly once you make the level 1 bow and level 2 ant weapon all you need to do is shoot, block, run, until its dead, and the lady bug armor makes that even easier. There is also a tun of different OS schemes that change the displays for your inventory and crafting to find around the map, I think i have like 15 so far? Still plenty more to find! 

Definitely one of my new favorite games. My wife and I got it on both PC's and played for about 6 hours straight! It gives you a real sense of nostalgia while also providing a fairly challenging and fun experience for the survival genre. If you like other survival games in my opinion this is a must have. I cannot wait for more of the game to be released over time, the forest did a great job and they had a ROUGH alpha compared to this, and I think this game has the potential to be 100x better than that. Great Job Obsidian!

This game needs some serious second round developing. You go hungry too quickly, the mechanics are funky and the physics will have bugs launching across the map. I spent 4 hours bulding my fortress and putting up defenses. One spider came through and destroyed everything. Tools break faster and weapons do hardly any damage. I'm going back to warzone.

Early Access Review: 

Amazingly absorbing game, I am loving it so far. It is gorgeous, and that fact allows the presentation to fill you with a sense of wonder and curiosity I haven't experienced with a game for a very long time. Its been said that this is someone at Obsidian's passion project, and it shows in the loving detail already present in the game. Base building is simple  and mostly intuitive, and resource availability is generous. 

Early Access issues: 
As of now, it *does* crash regularly, and there are some literally game breaking bugs where you may have to start completely over from scratch. There is a pretty limited amount of content at this time, it's possible to do/get everything available within about 10-20 hours of play. Base building is largely optional, and can add quite a bit of game time if you need something to do. 

But if they fixed the progression blocking issues, and never touched it again, I'd still be happy with the time and money I've spent on this. Highly recommended, and definitely something special to watch.
I really enjoy the details that they put into the game, very excited for what is to come!
Fun game

Grounded is a new open world, multiplayer, survival game from Obsidian Entertainment. It's launching in early access this week. Here's what you need to know. https://grounded.obsidian.net/

In the game,  choose from four unique characters to survive in a backyard. In the game, the player character needs to consume an adequate amount of food and water, or they will lose health due to starvation or dehydration respectively.

The backyard is filled with various bugs and insects, including spiders, Larva, dust mites and ladybugs. Different insects serve different purposes in the game. If you enjoy Fallout or similar games of the nature you will enjoy this.

don't have to dig around and pull items out of containers to craft things. oh and if you don't have plans for one, an actual glider, cause the dandelion tuft while nice for breaking falls has really bad horizontal movement and is only really useful as a type of parachute which while useful makes traversal very limited to just running and some climbing. also for bugs that would be cool to see would be some preying mantis, a termite colony, maybe a second ant type, which you could find competing with the ants already here for food and territory maybe make it a sort of world event where if you kill a species ant queen over time those ants die out and the other species in game takes over the others nest but that may be a bit complex. also something that may be interesting is if the ants corral and protect aphids, as this is something real life ants do to milk them for lack of a better word of their honeydew. also maybe make spiders a bit more aggressive to other insects cause seriously, having a spider just walts into an anthill and have nothing happen makes 0 sense and is a little weird to watch, or have a ladybug just walk up and have a chat with a wolf spider, the only time insects attack other insects is if they get attacked themselves which makes 0 sense as spiders are predatory, why do they not y'know hunt and stuff. so while i pretty much guarantee the devs won't see this, here were a few thoughts on possible future features on grounded, thank you for listening to my ted talk,

TL:DR this game is decent already if you like building and gathering and the beginning process of a survival crafting game, but the end game doesn't really exist atm, you only have like the first 8 ish hours of content and the first 30 minutes of story, Grounded has amazing potential and i gave a few ideas for features :)

Although I haven't spent thousands of hours in Rust, ARK, Subnautica and others, i've played them long enough to say that Grounded is at this stage (Early Access v1.0) - fun in a very short time.

The price of 29.99 EUR is completely unjustified considering the content that comes with it, but having in mind the reputation of Obsidian, it is expected that the price will be higher by 20-50% compared to Indie (unknown) studies that have yet to gain their reputation.

To get right to the point, what doesn’t justify the price and what I personally didn’t like is the EXPLORING feature of the game in an unfinished world! At one point you no longer know if what you EXPLORE exists in the game at all or not !? Is what you are looking for in the game or not? etc.

I understand Obsidian and their MYSTERY system in games, but I don't understand that this system can be applied to an unfinished game whose main feature is EXPLORING. What should I look for and explore if I'm not sure that they even added it to the game, and let's just say it's realistic that it's in some places!
When they add to the game things that are "realistic" to be there and that they will most likely add in later updates, then the game should show all its potential, I guess!

On the other hand, the base building, combat system, crafting are pretty well done so there aren't too many objections really, maybe some "combo punches" in the combat would further improve the game and break the monotony of the BLOCK / HIT system but I think they should be taken seriously first have filling out the EXPLORING piece that is more than necessary for such a unique world that I have been waiting to be a part of since “Honey, I Shrunk the Kids” a movie I was a big fan of when I was a boy.

This game is really awesome but broken for PC multiplayer right now. The issue is everyone who is not the host gets disconnected repeatedly and there are some major crashes that will happen even for the host sometimes when performing certain actions like cooking. I've seen a lot of people playing multiplayer just fine but they are almost always on console.

The disconnects get to be pretty unbearable and unplayable with people disconnecting within seconds to minutes of getting in the game. The longest runs we had are off fresh saves but then it starts happening after about an hour.

We were so desperate we tried changing hosts which means you have to start over with a new save. It kept happening to all four of us. People in our twitch chat told us that apparently the PC version of the game was broken for multiplayer and that they had similar experiences.

Great game otherwise, I really want to play it but I can't recommend it right now. I will update this to recommended when PC multiplayer gets fixed.

This game wasn't quite ready for paid release.
tl;dr It has a lot of promise and I'll revisit it later to see how it's improved, but for now it's a pass.

It's looks fantastic, and exploring a good sized backyard is a lot of fun. 
The problems arise when you are exploring and get ganked by a spider through a barrier or just because you didn't see it coming up on you. Until you're well-geared, all the spiders will one-shot you. Then you respawn and there's 3 larvae hanging out there who immediately kill you, and then just wait for you to respawn and kill you over and over. You could build a base, but alas while you were out the game spawned 5 soldier ants in it.  So instead you respawn in a tiny killbox full of murderous ants.
The base building handles like it does in The Forest, but not as robust yet. I had an ant destroy a wall because he got partially caught in the geometry of it and dug his way out.
I only got to play it single-player, and I'm sure multi will make the whole ordeal less painful, but for now it's just not that good.


Edit:
I've watched several livestreams with 2-4 people playing together and it completely alters the flow and feel of the game. You have friends to play with, it looks like a ton of fun. I would say it's worth it in that case, even though the story content only covers the first 20ish minutes of gameplay right now. There's a lot of yard to explore and dangers to face. Also you can revive in multi, so even if it's a surprise ganking it's not just an unexpected corpse run.
Fun, Cant wait for more content to release (theres lots now but there will be more)
This game is so beautiful! NEED MORE CONTENT!

So I've supported a Very few Early Access titles ever since one (I won't name names, don't wanna start flaming people etc) didn't pan out or even finish their game and I never did find out why; but this?  This I'm impressed with!  I watched a bunch of youtubers play it, and despite the screaming from spiders at first, I got right into it.  The game may feel like it "lacks content", but so far I've been spending hours just building bases to expand and get out there to explore my own backyard.  It may not have an actual "sandbox" mode but that hasn't stopped me from taking my time and doing my own thing.  Nothing says you have to rush from objective to objective.  You can explore, go find easter eggs and secrets, and just learn how to craft the world before doing much more than the first few objectives.

All in all, I'm impressed, even if my playtime Is small (again, I'm farting around here, not working hard on objectives yet).  Now wish me luck, some stupid Aphid actually taunted a wolf spider into the middle of my current zone :|

EDIT: 
I've played now for 51 hours as of this review, I'm updating from my first review when I was only 11 hours in. I'm still enjoying the game. I still would recommend the game but there are some issues which I ran into which were very annoying and so I now recommend the game with a disclaimer. I can get in and enjoy the game for what it is but there are some issues which are really annoying and I would love to hear feedback from the devs on these issues. Let me list a few things:
1. The door locked at the Oaktree lab -  (there's a work around, though not an easy one, you can go in the back way through the Anthill).
2. So after the lab door closes and you can't access the lab anymore, as a work around, you can restart the game. After restarting I realized that all the locations that I had initially found that had 500 science points, these locations do not have the 500 points anymore so restarting kind of sucks b/c now you will have to work really hard to get all those points back, and this is due to the bug from #1. 
3. I'm fairly patient, so I decided to push forward and attempt to keep going with the first game, just accessing the lab via the anthill. Now I ran into, the worst bug so far for me, time has stopped at 6am. Everything in the game is time-based so nothing grows, you can't analyze anything, you will eventually run out of water since there is no more dew, etc. 

You can always create another game, but you get less science for some reason and that is a barrier for me b/c I love games like this but grinding again and again is not fun and definitely not my thing. The other obvious thing is that the game is in early access so there isn't much story, and so I assume the bugs will be fixed eventually. The game is playable,  and can be fun at times, I will come back to it after they fix some bugs myself.

The map does not change, from something I read it will always be the same, probably to keep the story points in place but having either more maps or a procedurally generated map may help keep folks interested in the game for a longer amount of time.

This is definitely an early access game, but it's a hell of a lot of fun. If you like survival games this might be the game for you!

The Good: Art direction, feel of scale, crafting, research system.
The Should-be-improved: Backpack space, amount of held items even with ant armor is really low (though it could be made better by giving us mounts), logging out while on a platform causes you to fall through the world (multiplayer), arachnophobia mode is still really weird
The Obviously-will-be-improved: Story length isn't very long, but this is an early access game. Definitely will have more items to craft and bugs to fight.

Overall, this is a very good investment if you are willing to accept the early access quirks. The fighting feels satisfying, especially when you kill your first wolf spider. 

Also speaking of spiders... I have been screaming a lot. If you have any phobia of spiders, stay away from this game. Even arachnophobia mode doesn't really help. I have heard they're planning on doing something about this but until then, this will not be the survival game for you.

[h1] Best Small Game Out There [/h1]

[b] Discount Playtime, Listen To Review [/b]

This game is AMAZING! 
Have you ever wanted to enjoy [i] The Forest [/i] with your family, but you didn't want all the blood, gore and inappropriate body parts flailing about? Well, this is DEFINITELY [i] THE GAME [/i] for you!

I just got off of this game with my best friend, which I had bought because he had it on Xbox Game Pass. I saw this game all over YouTube, with all the gaming channels playing demos or the full game and showing off how amazing it is. I desperately wanted to try this game out and my best friend gave me the greatest excuse to.

Here are something I'm going to talk about:
a.) Gameplay
b.) Graphics
c.) Story
and...
d.) Technical

[b] Game play: [/b]
The game play for this game is extremely simple, build, survive and explore. Kill bugs, craft armor, and find new designs for upgraded weapons or the such. It's like [i] The Forest [/i] but it is simple and not very scary. you can go anywhere and do whatever you want, as long as you stay hydrated and eat. Also, defend yourself from mean bugs. Again, the world is free to explore in this game, you're only held back by the boundaries and possibly big scary bugs.You can also craft little furniture or stuffed animals. it's pretty cool!

[b] Graphics: [/b]
The graphics in this game are beautiful! The grass, soil, and bugs are very cartoon-y. Nothing is the game is too realistic, with exceptions, but most things are caricatures of their real life counter parts. The lighting and distant landmarks are beautiful, especially at night time, but the slight blur makes the game feel weird on the eyes. All the graphic settings are easy to adjust, but there aren't that many to play around with. Hopefully, more stuff will come to Steam Players.

[b] Story: [/b]
The story for this game is already more interesting than most survival games. You're 4 kids who are shrunken by a weird machine. You have no idea how you ended up there or who did it to you, but you can collect little tapes that help you understand the story a little better. It's a lot like [i] Honey I Shrunk The Kids [/i] but with more action. The story, at this time, is still incomplete and there are plans to continue the story at a later date. Knowing Xbox, they'll have more parts of the story out quickly, but i wouldn't put too much hope into that just yet.

[b] Technical [/b]
Firstly, I wanna talk about the Multiplayer, You have to have an Xbox Account to play Online, but that isn't too bad, if you already have an account. But, it's free to play online, if you're using Steam. very simple, not much to complain about. 
The map, it's big but not that big. There are very interesting landmarks outside of the map that seem a tad bit more interesting, hopefully they become levels for us to play. Some bits of the map have nothing interesting except for a land mark, but that is about it.
The glitches are small, not game breaking, but they can be a hindrance on fun! 
The voice acting is on point and I can't wait to see what more lines they add. 
The arachnophobia setting is genius, it's extremely helpful.
Lastly, crafting better items can be a bit of a head turner, if you don't know what you're doing.

[b] Overall: [/b]
This game is AMAZING! It's fun and exciting, it has all that it really needs to be a great multiplayer game, but the small things can make a big difference. I hope that Xbox Game Studios continues to pour a lot of time and effort into this game, because it truly deserves all the love from it's community and developers. I really hope that Xbox and Microsoft continue forward with this game, because it has so much potential. Hopefully this doesn't get popular and then they just ditch the project, like a lot of other great titles.

I highly recommend playing/buying this game, but I would also give it time, it's still taking its baby steps. But, I wouldn't put too much hope into it, who knows what'll happen when Next Gen consoles release.

Be Warned:
I don't leave reviews very often. Today Grounded is getting a review because I love the this game so far. My friend loves survival games and I typically get tired of them. This is the first we have both been able to enjoy long term. I may not have the patience for this game if I weren't playing with a friend.
There are cons... the phrase that sums this up for me is "this feels like Wolcen..."(sloppy). The only saving grace is that is it's early access status. In Grounded's case I think it is fair for this game to have occasional bugs.
The problem is they are often game breaking bugs.
*So far all play time is with 2 players in a world*
Game crashes to desktop
*When I respawn after death, so far these have happened*
camera tilts about 15 degrees to the right
I lose all my inventory
In bleedout state I cannot give up I have to wait out the timer
*workaround*
The work around to most of these  is to revert to an autosave and switch characters.

I am loving this game as a casual survival game please don't be plagued by bugs out of launch.
Please don't end up like Wolcen.. good news is it's Obsidian behind the game.

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
The game has about 10 hours of content in this version if your not rushing into the story and you are trying to build a base to store your collectables.
I have pros and cons about this game but I do believe it has potential, it has performance issues and glitches, cross platform compatibility needs clearing up as you need to follow a process to join friends games for which no one outlined a very important step that was not listed in the articles.
IF you have a Microsoft Live account, add people on it as friends you want to play with otherwise don't expect being on steam to allow you to see friends in this version of the game.

For pros and Cons.

[h2]Pros[/h2] 
- It's fun to find new strategies to fight different insects, this adds a level of thinking to the game.
- Spider's are fun to have to try and avoid from time to time, in open areas and getting on top of high places.
- Climbing the logs for tree sap is cool, it gives you a reason to climb and then your just amazed by the environment and the ability to help your team mates navigate around spiders. Their is also a Demonic head in the game :O
- I am constantly trying to improve out builds and layouts while also obtaining better gear. It's fun to get something a bit better that makes fighting easy! (Not Wolf Spider's though. Still quite a challenge.)


[h2]Cons[/h2]
- The early game feels unbalanced. I am constantly trying to build a base while either having my stuff taken away from me by ants or destroyed by Larva who keep spawning in my base. It's frustrating The doors were shut, their were spike traps at the doors... They were just a cluster inside the base. Starting off as 2 and then 3 then 5.
- Spider's are way to dangerous to the player early game, they can see you from way further away seemingly at night suggesting their vision is better at night than in the day. They are way to fast for the player and it's almost impossible to survive an encounter unless you have a base or hide in a building.
- Water resources from the grass leafs are far too sparse to find and don't always respawn. Early game killing bugs for food to which satisfy hunger while Slurping from a lake is the only way to really survive in a team effectively as the bugs hunger overcomes your loss from slurping lakes and murky waters.
- I have no ways to place markers on the map to help me locate where I want to go and where I am going. I want to place custom markers because my base maybe in a weird spot, and their is no navigational equipment without opening a map. It worked well for me but other players are a little annoyed to not have a mini-map or compass to navigate with.
- Crafting items feels a bit too slow and tedious to wait to hit a button and craft.
- Dropping items is annoying and slow.
- Transferring items between containers is also tedious and slow. I want to shift click straight over on PC. On a controller holding a button and clicking the stack would be cool as well!
- Armor equips and weapon equips feel weird as they don't go into the slots. It reminds me of older games like Champions or Norrath where you equip an item yet it's highlighted and still in your inventory. It would be good if when I pickup my bag those items also auto equipped instead of just my hot bar. I don't know if my armor is on or not otherwise.

[h2]Bugs and Glitches[/h2]
Bug- When the game crashes in multiplayer it's possible other players will spawn as if they had no gear at the start of the level, frustrated and angry about their hard earned gear being lost over a game crash.
Bug- It's frustrating to try and save a player only to be Holding E and then suddenly it stops trying to help them. Also in combat situations when your fighting it sometimes trys to heal a player mid air. IDK why that happened. So I can't include it as it's own bug.
Bug- Between players in Multiplayer some items appear visible, not collectable and you may not collect those items.
Bug- If your inventory is full and you kill something only to attempt to collect items, it seems to destroy everything. This was horrible in two occasions after beating a Lady Bug and our Wolf Spider friend.
Bug- Bug's keep spawning in my bases and sometimes even walk through walls. IT'S ANNOYING! Especially Larva who destroy everything! Ant's... I watched them walk through a wall... Open doors and okay... They can open doors? Okay. give me a padlock or something!
Bug- When I healed someone they were able to get up and back into the fight while I was still in the state of trying to heal them, my game broke and I got knocked out and we died as a result.

Glitch- Jumping on walls will teleport you up and down a foot sometimes.
Glitch- walking on Grass planks while looking around twists out the camera like crazy!
Glitch- You can break spider AI by getting it to attack into a place it can not move from I've cheesed multiple spiders into this situation and it's easy to now kill them in a set of certain circumstances.
Glitch - When transferring items into a container it can sometimes destroy items, overriding that item in the chest potentially in the process. This was from MP, each game mode may have different results and scenarios.

[h2]End notes:[/h2]
The game may seem like it has a lot of bugs and issues, regardless I think the pros are enough of a reason to play the game and the cons are things the developers need to look into and try to work out!

If the developer's are Interested in having some [b]QA[/b] done they may [u]get in touch with me professionally[/u] and each issue will be better documented and produced. From game balancing to the bugs. 
This game has potential regardless of some hiccups of being early access with bugs, it's price point seems a bit high and people in the community criticising the developers who are making a game they don't seem to be experts in making. I disagree, The developers have some fun experiences and the game does in someways seem to try and cater to a younger audience in it's child like appearance and bug like environments. But it also tries to cater to an older audience with it's difficulty and different ways of challenging a player to fight with strategy.

Also I watched Markiplier's video (Part 2) on this and it seems their maybe some mature seeming jokes that Adult's may read between the lines on which kids will not.

This game is pretty great for being early access.. you can finish the early access story pretty quick.. but there's still quite a bit you can do afterwards still.. I mean.. you're a tiny person with so much to explore in a GORGEOUSLY made world! 
Since it is such early access.. there are a few glitches here and there.. but nothing to deter me from still wanting to play.. 
I'm not sure if this can just happen.. or if it's an actual bug [haha.. unintentional pun].. but I built up and enclosed a base.. yet ants are still getting into the base and stealing all my snacks in storage.. [which I know stealing snacks is a thing they do.. they're ants after all!].. I have no idea how they are getting in either.. they just show up out of nowhere!
A glitch I love is when a spider gets stuck in one of the places you can go to to analyze stuff.. and then it's just an analyzing pod thingy with spider legs.. [Seems to be the only way I can kill a spider.. so I am perfectly okay with that!]

Something I also found before even starting to play.. was when I tried to login to my Xbox Live account.. every time I tried to type 'A' it would take me to the game options.. so I ended up having to copy and paste an 'A' every time I needed to type it to login.. So that needs to get fixed.. 

I also find the whole in-game menu a little weird.. just so many different buttons you have to use.. or have to click.. I wish 'TAB' could just take you to inventory and then all the other options.. I tried changing stuff around.. but.. OOF.. that was just ridiculous.. [I know it's not fair to compare a brand new early access game to ones that have been out for a while.. but something like how 7 Days to Die is laid out would be nice.. that'd be perfect honestly!].. 

Any who.. I love forward to see this game develop more and more.. I know there will be bugs and glitches here and there through it all.. but I'm excited to see the progress.. It's already a beautiful looking game.. the graphics are AMAZING! And it has ENORMOUS potential!

I'm gonna go play some more Grounded now!

Ps.. Y'all.. love the arachnophobia settings.. it's amazing!
