So when I wrote this, I had already completed both of the main story objectives. However, there was still plenty to do. There are a lot of field labs and landmarks to discover around the yard and many enemies to see and fight. Something special that this game manages to do for me is that every death doesn't feel cheap. Each time I die i'll realize what I did wrong and what I can do to fix that. Leveling up your armors and weapons feels very rewarding, and each time I unlock something new i'm excited to find out what it can do. The base building is fun and allows you to build almost anywhere. Gathering resources is fun and each time I find something I'll be so excited to analyze and figure out what I can make with it. Altogether, Grounded is a very fun game, and I'm excited to see what comes next after early access!

Some say the open world survival genre has been overdone. My question is, was it ever done right?

I have been a survival game fanatic since the first week Ark was posted on steam. This game takes all of the good things survival has done and shaves off all of the bad. It simplifies everything down and focuses on what a survival game really about, and what makes it fun. There are definitely early access bugs, but I'm sure they will be ironed out soon.

Pros:
- fun enemies
- great combat (I mean you can hurl literally anything in your hand)
- seems pretty balanced even this early. ex: even with the strongest armor enemies are still fun and challenging to fight. not to challenging though:)
- lots of armor variety (hopefully more to come)
- beautiful scenery
- game plays super smoothly
- lots of exploration and discovery
- even though the art is stylized and cartoony, there's still thrilling jump scares and a sense of danger

Cons (hard to say any of these because it's early access but):
- enemies sometimes clip into or spawn in your base
- enemy ai need some work

Not really Pro or Con... just neutral thoughts I guess:
- weapons have great variety in play style but not many variants which I would love to see (also better uniques)
- price. I'm fine with paying the $30 to support a good game with tons of potential. i'd rather pay more now so the studio has the funds to keep updating it than not pay enough and the studio gives up on it before it can really blossom.

In conclusion, it's been a long time since I've seen a game that has excited me as much as this one. If you are a fan of the open world survival genre I highly recommend you try this game out and support the studio. My hopes are big for this game and I hope others enjoy it too.

Grounded is easily the most polished Early Access game I've ever played. Normally Early Access games come with a slew of issues that make the game almost unplayable, but the state Grounded is in is already really nice. With that being said there are a few issues but none of them keep you from playing the game or enjoying your time. The worst issue my friends and I have encountered is sometimes when you die and drop your bag it'll fall through the world. However, after you reboot the game the bag will reappear at spawn so it's an easy work around. Very excited to see where this game goes, can't wait for that August 27th update!

I purchased several copies of grounded for my friends and I and started playing the moment it came out.
I am no at all disappointed. 
Only in Alpha, I already feel like I got my $29.99 back.
The game's overall vibe/feel is amazing. It is just like Honey I Shrunk the Kids in a Pixar movie.
The game has survival, exploration, combat, and base building. When you add it all together it creates a really engaging experience. I play grounded on Steam and it ports perfectly from X box to pc. You can tell (for the most part) that they were thinking of the PC when developing the game.
One of the best aspects of this game is that unlike "most" games out there, this one is a family friendly game. 
OK, so now for suggestions for Microsoft (should they accidentally click on this review and read this):
1. Server stability/crashes and saving progression. This is the only game breaker. The host has virtually no problems, but friends joining into the game might have difficulties such as: Game Sync errors: not seeing the blueberries in the same spot as the host (or not at all). Complete server issues: Extreme lag, and or loss of inventory. Falling through bases etc.
2. Quality of life, mainly around inventory management. I realize this is developed primarily for the X-box. The GREAT news is that the controls and movement feel perfect on the PC. The problem is that some quality of life problems exist. If one looks at just about any MMO or games with heavy inventory management such as Tarkov, then there are shortcuts such as ctrl + left lick or shift + left lick to move whole stacks of items from a container to the inventory. I realize there aren't as many options on a controller but there probably should be some "alternative" toggle or control to allow ease of inventory management.
3. Players and the community are eager for more content. HOWEVER, I would love to see fixes to the above issues and making what is already there, better before adding in new stuff.
Thank you for a great game!

Grounded is a very down to earth survival game (Pun intended). Easily one of the most polished Early Access titles to hit the Steam Store. It's similar to The Forest, yet infinitely scarier. With identical building/gathering mechanics, and even an underlying story. Grounded stands on its own though, with fun gameplay, a beautiful atmosphere, and interesting enemies. From regular worker ants to ladybugs, and even Wolf Spiders. Not everything is wonderful though, the hunger/thirst system is a hindrance. Forcing you to stop very often to eat and drink. Only offering realism it's a dated mechanic that can make survival games a chore, in my opinion.

Fortunately the game succeeds everywhere else. It's a fun and exciting game. Vastly better with friends. Despite the small story, it's well worth the $30 price tag right now. There is so much more content to be added. With a full release planned next year. Easily an 8/10 for me.

This game sets the standard for Early Access.

The big question “Is it worth 30 bucks??”    Ask yourself:

1)	Do you like exploration?

2)	Do you like discovering new and exciting items to craft?  These items can be weapons, apparel, building materials, home décor, food, smoothies!

3)	Do you like being scared out of your wits sometimes?

4)	Do you like looking out over the landscape in a game and wonder…is it safe to go that way?

5)	Are you afraid of spiders?

6)	Do you like building your own safe base?  (then get it off the ground!!!)

7)	Do you like thinking for yourself trying to figure out how to survive in the cruel world of insects? Let’s face it, the insect world is cruel.

8)	Would you kill a ladybug?  (please say NO! although they will scare the pants off of you because they are like a bulldozer coming through the grass!)

If you answered yes to these questions (except killing a ladybug!) then you may want to try this game.

This game is being created by 2 of the biggest software houses in the world and the possibilities of this game are as endless as the insect world itself.

Some people complain about content.  Seriously, it’s a survival game and surviving IS the content.  That being said, I have yet to find and end to the quests being given to me.  Story line?  It is still being developed but again, what type of story are you really wanting in a survival game?

Biggest tips I can give anyone is Do the quests and DON'T BUILD ON THE GROUND!  Learn how to build scaffolds and build on top of those.
If you store food in a container on the ground then you can be assured it will be raided by ants and larvae and they will destroy your stuff to get the food.  Think about it.  Food on the ground…ants…yeah nuff said.  Good bait tho if you are hunting for ants.
I have almost 20 hours in and now have a 3 story house (on stilts) and still have quests to do.  As far as tier 1 items to craft, I have not discovered them all yet and have not even started on tier 2.

One of my favorite experiences was when I first saw a spider web.  Hmmm nothing around it.  I wonder if the programmers made the web sticky…so snuck up and I touched it.  Hey I’m stuck..Stuck..STUCK!!  OMG, grab the pebble axe and start chopping…wait..is .. is that grass moving…is it moving, and my way!  OMG IT IS…Chop Chop…it’s still coming my way…AAAH! IT’S A SPIDER!!! CHOP CHOP CHOP!!  Right before the spider got me the web broke and I was free.  IM FREE RUN FOREST RUN!  And I ran like a scared little boy.  If you zig zag through the tall grass the spider can not keep up and you can out run it.  Whew!  Then to my surprise I realized I had been collecting the silk from the web and learned how to make my first dew catcher!  YUM Fresh water!

Yeah, I like the game and feel it is well worth the $30 bucks I spent.

Obsidian did a great job with this game, and I'm enjoying it thoroughly so far. Initially, I was only planning to make my first world a 'breaking it in' world, and I ended up accidentally playing for 6 hours straight. Systems feel intuitive, spiders are terrifying every single time. So far I've only had one crash, and that was when I tried to cook food. Hasn't happened again since, though, so I'm not worried.
Base building, though. Yikes. While it's great to build a base, it's a very clunky system that's in desperate need of refining.

Overall, for an early access game it's very well polished. Can't wait to see it after a few updates.

A new favorite survival game for my collection! 

HOWEVER

downsides:
* Serious crashes daily, can make you a bit annoyed.
* Lack of content, very little of the story is completed.
* bugs can be buggy and get stuck in various places (under rocks and terrain)
* Spawns of enemies are unbalanced.

What I like about the game:
* Daily quests with a point system allows you to buy uppgrades for tools and other stuff
* Building is very easy to understand and decent amount of "puzzle pieces" (hope to see more added)
* combat feels satisfying.

Keep in mind this is very early access and I hope the devs fix a lot of the bugs really soon!

Probably closer related to The Forest than any other survival sandbox, Grounded is a fairly streamlined affair without being overly simple. Story-focused with pre-made characters, whilst there is plenty of sandboxing to be done, there is a definitive goal to guide you along and give you something to aim for.

Compared to The Forest, Grounded has a lot more content going for it, at least in terms of crafting and base-building. But at the same time, it lacks the complicated gameplay of games like Ark. Thus, the game is both accessible and challenging. And boy, do the hostile bugs pose a challenge. I've never actually found a wolf spider to be scary before this game, and dang are those things terrifying when you're shrunk down to ant-like proportions.

There's certainly no shortage of humour either, nor polish or - certainly compared to the norm with these sorts of games - decent graphics. However, the game could do with some optimisation, as I personally find random stuttery spikes for seemingly no noticeable reason, that last for a good few seconds before subsiding.

In essence, Grounded is probably what you'd expect from a not-quite AAA attempt at a survival sandbox (as the game is developed, as I understand it, by a small team within Obsidian rather than the full force of the entire company). Decent and fun from the offset of early access status (certainly a lot better than most of the more well-known indie titles were at this stage of development).

As of now I have had a blast with Grounded. I do think 30$ is a bit too much with where the game stands, bc overall you can maybe get a good 20 hours out of the game if you REALLY stretch it, however the time that I've put into it feels well spent and rewarding. The atmosphere in the game is fantastic and the fact that there hasn't been a game with this idea yet surprises. Some people say that the difficulty is too hard, but i completely disagree. I feel that the natural progression of gear is fair and that its feasible to beat all enemies if you have the right strategy. Also I don't think some people realize there's a lower difficulty setting that they can play if its too challenging. Currently I'm sitting at about 12 hours into the game and I've had a lot of fun so far, however I have hit a bit of a wall. At this point there's not really much to do anymore. The story will only occupy about 30 minutes to an hour of your time and the rest of your time will most likely be spent on base building and getting better gear. As entertaining as that is there are some bugs that should be addressed. The building is a bit confusing but if you commit to learning it you eventually figure out. One other bug is that sometimes you'll crash and come back in through an autosave, however you'll have a different inventory from earlier but still the same progression in terms of your base and whatever is in your chests. Not a major bug, will lose you maybe 45 minutes in the long run. Can't wait to see where Obsidian takes this game, I think they already have a really good base.

P.S. Don't Rely on Any Reviews from people with less than 3 hours in the game. These people haven't properly played it through and have only looked at the small bit of story in the game rn and maybe wandered around a lil bit.

There is no story or campaign at the moment so unless you enjoy figuring things out or googling constantly it can be annoying. I am not familiar with this Dev company so i am unsure of their reputation with pre-release/Betas. If they are going to sit on this for a few years like the rest of the industry does it will be very unfortunate. But if they listen to reports and fix things rapidly this has potential to be a pretty great game.  But those are my thoughts. You should watch streams or gameplay to see what you think though.

The majority of negative reviews for the this game follow the lines of "This early access game doesn't have a story!" or "why are giant spiders continually killing me?". There are a considerable amount of reviews saying the game has little content in it, with people who have played it for 2 hours, and people who state it's broken and have 30+. It seems people want to be angry at an early access game, for issues that are part of the parcel with it being in early access. 

Please don't be stupid. Please don't cry about spiders. 

This game does suffer from a few glitches that need ironing out. The game's survival aspects are a bit too easy, with water and food being plentiful. However, most other resources are well placed out and require you to venture, fight and plan your way to acquire them. This is where the game is. The game allows you to handle enemies in a variety of ways. Using the  environment to your advantage when dealing with larger bugs, setting up traps to bait enemies in small tunnels, making the right armour or weapons to nudge the odds in your favour. A genuine issue is that the game has sacrificed difficulty for accessibility. With that, the game is extraordinarily easy to pick up, the learning curve is as smooth as a lot of the negative reviewer's brains are. 

It hurts my head to see people whining about story and glitches in a early-access survival game that is still wet behind the ears.

Honey I Shrunk The Kids Simulator. Love it.

This game is amazing, its  little short on story for the minute but there is room to play after, you can only build bases after you finish the story. You can finish the story with barebone resources such as a spear, and armor and thats really it. Heres a pro/con list of The Honey I Shrunk the Kids Game, "Grounded"

Pros: 
#1. Good base building mechanics and you dont need the exact resources at the time you place it.
#2. The little robot you meet after you finish the story is SOOO cute and the way you can buy things from him to make an after game is really nice, although i expect it to not be permanent.
#3. The way (most) ants aren't hostile towards you is really nice, and the fact they will attack "Weevils" at any cost really adds personality to the ants.
Cons.
#1. Hostile and passive creatures will often get stuck in walls and can make combat incredibly easy.
#2. The building is incredibly buggy making it hard to actually build a huge base, but not game breaking.
#3. It has a lack of REAL story content, yet this will be expanded upon soon. 

A little nitpick, but not a con, is the fact you have to fight a practical boss to get the spider armor, yet the ladybug armor is better???? Why? Its more of a flex than a "good" armor set.
Overall rating 7/10. Its incredibly addictive however, so take that rating with a grain of salt.
Its a good survival basebuilding sandbox game, but not one the best; although it has the potential to be one.
Its not a "Minecraft" or "Terraria" ripoff either, all of them are there own games and needed to be treated like one.
My hour count may not sound impressive (19 hours) But thats amassed of 2 days. 9 and a 1/2 hours a day, so buy it if you have the money to spend. It will only get more expensive, (in early access.) so buy it while you can.
Again, a 7/10 game, with potential to be a 9/10 or even 10/10 game. Go see if you agree with me and buy the game!

There is a spawn area near some rocks (cannot recall where) where ants spawn excessively and get stuck below ground.

This is my first ever review for a game in a long time and after playing this a while i thought it wouldnt hurt to leave one here.

I really love the art and concept of this game, the honey i shrunk the kids mixed with a bugs life story is a unique twist for a survival game. and would love to see this game progress more and more in its development. there are a few flaws I like to point out..

While I love the game and the sense of difficulty i feel that the difficulty is way too much for new players that are trying to unlock items to deal with bugs. so far my only problems are with spiders in the game. they appear way too common and near the early part of the game. 

i know there needs to be a challenge and spiders are meant to be tough but it basically discourages me to keep going at times. killed 1 wolf spider by luck when it got stuck with bow and arrows then jumped on immediately by another, and on mild which i assume is the easy difficulty? now i know the game is early access but i feel spiders should be a rare spawn in my opinion due to how much of a threat they are. it gives the player a chance to be prepared. I haven't had a chance to build my base due to them which i hope gets tweaked in the future. i would hide in a machine near the starting area or the lab but it seems to glitch itself through to hit me enough to kill me. even if i hide inside something where it is unable to reach me the spider will stay until I am dead but will return once i go back for my items.. 

I would love to recommend this game cause I can see potential in this but I would recommend waiting and see what comes in updates cause for a game that's 30$ is steep for a game riddled with a few bugs and insane difficulty. 

I chose recommended only because I can see this game be really good later on and i hate to give it a not recommendation status... but its up to you to decide if its worth getting for yourself

if your getting grounded in early access just to let you know your not getting it for the story you are getting it for the survival. the story in grounded is like 8 minutes long rn sadly but the survival aspect of the game is great having the forest vibes while building a base and if you have friends the game is alot more fun

This game is great!! Especially for someone who loved the "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" movies!! The only thing i would change, would be to allow more players in the multiplayer. 4 is very limiting for large groups of friends who want to play together.
Very polished game-play and unit interactions. Only 20% of story line is released, rest in upcoming major patches.
Great Game!

Pros: This game is a simple survival game but has a lot of fun aspects to it. The research function for finding new blueprints is nice since it means you don't get have to have a team of people to build a whole base. I like how you obtain resources by carrying the stuff too large to fit in your inventory and the equipment tiers, armor sets, and various tools are all neat, well crafted, and thought out. The combat feels well balanced.

Cons: Buildings are way too brittle. Even the smallest creature seems to be destroying parts of my house in three hits or less with larger creatures one and two shotting the walls leaving me wondering why even bother building a base. This needs to be improved drastically. There is also currently a bug in the game that allows monsters to spawn inside of your house and or inside of your walls so hopefully that gets fixed. There also seems to be a bug when wielding the 2 handed ant axe that makes mobs unable to attack you at all, allowing me to run into a pack of four or five orb weavers and kill them all without taking any damage.
Super fun and deadly nerve wrecking... when you see a spider just run
Well i have over 200 hrs in ark and have played almost all survival games and i must say this one best them all even with so little content

Personally I like this game but the price it to high considering there is no public mode for the multiplayer.

This short review is from someone that does not play survival games, so for me this was a culpusive buy. Plus I normally play fps games, and mainly full on action games to. 

When Grounded got released I watched many live streams on here and videos off YouTube, and to be honest I was intruiged with the game so much that I just had to give it a go. 

First off the graphics are gorgeous to say the least, the unreal engine is put to great use in this game. 
Sound is good and music for what there is just sets the overall atmosphere around you. But the main title music is just dam awsome, and reminds me of Stranger things series in many ways. 

Gameplay, so as iam sure you already know this is a survival crafting game which takes place in your garden. But something went wrong and you were shrunk to a tiny size, so the game world around you is massive in size. 

Now coming from someone who normaly is not good at these sort of games, well I found the crafting very easy to do, and believe me that's saying something for me lol. 

So your main threat is the creepy crawlys in the garden, which can and will give you a bad day.
So you can craft weapons and find new resources to anylise from the research tents dotted around the garden. 
But you can also craft and build a house or fortress to protect you to, well from gathering resources from around the garden. 

As being a early access game there's lots more which will be added down the game development root. 
So from the information I know, there will be a bigger expansions to the main game size map. Also more creepy crawlys are on there way, and weather conditions to like rain I heard which would be amazing. But the game has day and night cycles which you can speed up when you sleep to make it day time again quicker. But you need to build a basic shelter or a house ect. 

A special mention must go to the graphics as they are outstanding, and the bugs are just awsome to look at like the rest of the game world. 
But oh boy, if you don't like spiders in the real world like me, well you won't like them  in this game. They creep me out so much, and I remember passing a leaf which underneath it was a very big spider hundled in there sleeping, which gave me nightmares that night sleeping lol. 

So I guess from my review I can honestly say  buy this game if you like survival crafting games, it's just a awsome game so far even at this stage of early access. 
So far there's a bit of the story content added, but much more will be added through the games development. 
But to be honest just the free roaming aspect of the game makes it a instant buy anyway. As that part of the game will tell your own story weather it be on your own or Co op with other people. 

It's been a strange year for me for gaming, and 3 titles so far by smaller development teams have just shocked me for quality games. 
Those 3 are Deep Rock galactic, Hyper Charged unboxed and of course Grounded. 

So I whole heartedly recommend this, and what have you got to loose. As there's always the refund option, but iam sure you won't take that option though. 

Thanks for reading my review, and please read others as I know I have missed alot of the finer details. 😊

Things I liked:
-enjoy the concept, think it has a lot of potential. Minus the immense about of glitches and set backs.
Things I disliked:
-no point in attempting to build a base. Just ends up getting greifed by the bugs. They genuinely wont stop attacking the base until it is entirely demolished, even with no food or anything of value in it. It just doesn't make sense, seems like the bugs are programmed to destroy whatever you've attempted to build. 
-no access to items that actually give you a chance against the bugs. I wouldn't be worried about it, but from the looks of it, there is no scale of where you are (in the game's progression) versus what bugs come attacking your base. Had two hoards of 10+ larvae come and spawn camp me/destroy my base, one after the other. No room to breathe or progress when you can't even have a place to call home or store what little progress is made in between fending off armies of bugs.
-weird paradox of not being able to sleep because there are threats, yet the more you stay up the more bugs come. 
-I dislike the bugs not having a sense of "victory". You'd imagine after killing the player 6+ times in a row and then destroying the base, they'd move on. Yet, seems to me the only way to get the bugs away is to kill them. 
and how am I supposed to kill anything when I constantly feel in a one versus thirty situation with tools that do absolutely no damage. 
$30 for a bug fest both in terms of playability and actual content.
if you like open world, crafting, survival, then this game is for you! its stupid fun!
amazing !!!

An interesting and refreshing take on the survival genre. As a 1000hr Ark player, I was slightly skeptical going into that that it would just be Ark with insects instead of dinos. But this is not at all true. Of course some of the key stables that you would expect are in place. Hacking, smashing up or collecting whatever resources you need to craft, build or survive. But this game also includes the true inclusion of story and purpose, and although so far in this early access we only get a micro view of this, I have to say it I was quite excited at where this could go. Of course this is entirely up to Obsidian now, if the story elements don't get fleshed out and added in fully - then this game will likely struggle to make its mark in the sea of survival/crafting games. However if the story elements do really get built and there is a clear and interesting purpose added in, then this game could achieve what Ark never did, not matter how hard Wildcard tried. As for early access bugs (ahem no pun intended :) ), not too many to be fair, has been running pretty stable for both me and my son whom I am playing this with. Definitely a thumbs up for now.

I cannot recommend the game as it is right now. While the premise is very much to my liking and what little I was able to play I did enjoy, there are currently a multitude of issues that have to be addressed first.
We faced bugs like teleporting mobs or clipping through surfaces, but we also experienced savegame corruption+CTD and issues with xbox live.
We were able to fix the xbox live issue after reinstalling all default win10 apps and making sure the system is up to date (only one of us had this problem), but the savegame corruption requires the person to reinstall the game before it even allows said person to host a new game.
We probably only actually played 1-2h total. For now we have decided to wait until some patches have been released and development has progressed before trying to play again.

Overall: (7/10) (For now)

Game-Play:
Very interesting game with seemingly endless ways to improve. The story is currently very short but there are so many ways it could go from here. The open world aspect of the game is fantastic, the map does not feel small at all. The way the mobs interact with the player and each other is interesting and enjoyable.
 
Graphics: 
The graphics are smooth and have a perfect balance between realism and the cartoon look. Some aspects are done better than others. For example the ray tracing is gorgeous. Waking up in the morning actually feels like a morning with the sun just peeking over the grass.  Some of the animations however are not quite as stellar. Specifically the tool animations feel clunky and uncomfortable- especially the shovel. Something about digging with one hand and stabbing the shovel like a spear just doesn't feel right. 

Recommendations:
-It would be nice to see some sort of other life in the future of the game- aside from different insects. Maybe occasionally a dog/cat could walk through the yard, if not to interact with then just for the aesthetic. Lizards/snakes/etc. would be a nice addition as well, the atmosphere feels like there should be life other than bugs.
-There are tons of different locations on the map, but nearly all of them are purely aesthetic. The majority of the locations consist of a single piece of trash that you are often able to enter or climb on top of, but these landmarks serve nothing as far as game-play goes. Being able to interact with these landmarks in a certain way or at least being able to build items on/inside of these things is something I would consider an imperative addition.
-The addition of some sort of sled or cart to transport materials is much needed. To construct decently sized bases costs a ton of materials, some of which are sparsely scattered across the map (specifically Dandelions) and can be extremely tedious to gather only carrying 5 at a time.

Bugs I have encountered:
-The way steam determines if the app is running seems to be bugged. Steam thinks this app is always running- even after force quitting the program steam seems unable to register that it has closed.
-Stuck in spider web even after destroying it. 
-Unable to resurface from underwater.
-Jumping with something blocking above you causes the character to be launched backwards a fair distance. This most frequently happens to me underneath clovers.

I give the game an overall 7/10 for these reasons but remember, this game is still early-access so it could very well be on its way to a 10/10. It has tons of potential.  Needless to say I am excited to see the path the developers choose.

(THERE IS RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE DEVS IN THIS REVIEW DEVS PLEASE READ)

Grounded is easily one of the most fun experiences I've had with survival games and it's just in early access. The devs are enthusiastically responsive and right now the only way to go is up for this game in terms of content. There are a few bugs I've encountered(pun intended) but nothing game breaking. YMMV though! 

Expect from this game a simple yet creatively beautiful map. You'd also quickly find that resource gathering, crafting, base building, are all very simple, yet satisfying to do. The enemies offer a legitimate threat and you'll have to think about where to place your camps. Armor set abilities make you want to complete different armor sets for their different effects, as they can be helpful in different combat and exploring scenarios. Speaking of exploring, it's a blast to do in this game. You can go explore the lush garden and be wowed by the visuals, or go underground and see how sophisticated the AI is in the ant colony. Warning to adventurers though, this yard is your unreasonable fear of Australia turned real...with you really really small.

The really cool thing is the game's ability to transform everyday objects into something amazing; an empty soda can provides a reprieve from a swarm of spiders, a discarded juicebox is a source of endless juice, an anthill is an exciting, yet spooky cave system to explore.

Well, what to say?

I have been playing these survival builders pretty much for as long as they have existed.

I tend to be forgiving for their shortcomings, they almost always start as early access, and stay that way.

But, beggars can not be chosers, and the availability of AAA titles is limited, if not non existent in this genre.

Hopefully that is about to end!

Does grounded have issues?

For sure, plenty even, there are game braking bugs, annoying bugs, and, well just bugs everywhere, both literally and methaphorically!

It is a game about bugs after all.

But, I soldiered trough it.

Why?

Because this have the potential to be the best of them all.

The setting and premise is imaginative and exciting, to a point were my mind takes this game to places it can never go with todays technology, and barely could with a holo-deck.

I am well aware I am setting myself up for dissapointment, but I just do not care.

Story took me a couple of in game days, ( if that ), I had discvoered mostly everything this version have to offer by day 20.

It is now day 70, and I am still logging in!

Because underneath the buggy, and limited, version we are playing there is a polish we, or at least I, have yet to see in a survival title.

That being said, if you are easily furstrated, new to the genre, or early access games in general?

Perhaps stay away from this one for now.

If you enjoy survival games even a little bit though, or think you might get it later, I encourage you to to do so now, doubt it will get cheaper.

I do not think this will be abandoned in a half finished state, as is often the case.

This is Obsidian, ( allthough I know nothing about the group making this so take that for what it is worth ), they are pretty well known for quality.

And Microsoft, perhaps not known for the same things as Obsidian, but they tend to have perseverence. ( More so then lets say EA or Activision ).

And considering the hype, I very much doubt they are willing to lose face on this one by making it a half-assed product.

Sadly I do think they will keep it a PC/XBOX game though, seeing the popularity and the console makers affinity for "exclusives", they will probably milk this for all it is worth.

Also means I am fairly sure there will be DLC's and skin packs and whatnot in a steady stream.

Ambivalent about that, want it to both be true and not be true! ;)

Regardless, I have not had this much in a game in a long time, and I have played mostly solo, in multiplayer it is like crack glazed with sugar on Christina Aguileras behind!

/Umbrood

WARNING: You will develop Arachnophobia from playing this game.

[h1] WAIT FOR CONTENT UPDATE...UNLESS...... [/h1] 

An early-access game, made from a passionate team of 12 developers, from one of the greats Obsidian. The game is beautifully designed with an appeal that grabs you from the start. Spiders, Ladybugs and Stinkbugs seem impossible at first and overwhelming at first, but as you learn and grow, the backyard becomes yours. 

However, the story and a lot of the content of the game is yet to be out. They plan monthly updates, so if you want a more polished, story driven survivor game I'd give it some time. I personally enjoy the state of the game where it is now, I found it fun. Adapting to your new environment, building and discovering secrets and hidden places. The potential of this game is through the roof, I proudly bought this and played and look forward to the new content. I like the idea of having an established foothold in the world as it grows around me. 


[u] Thank you for reading and enjoy your playtime [/u]

So only 5 hours in and I have enjoyed every minute of this game. This is such an awesome concept for a survival craft game and I have not been disappointed with this game at all. It's brutal but It has so many great mechanics and It has a base building/crafting system similar to The Forest as it allows you to lay out a blueprint for your base so you get a feel for what you're building then you go find the materials needed to complete your structures. The graphics and art style are beautiful, the characters have their own personalities and I can't stress enough how awesome this game is and how it is well worth the 30 bucks It's at even in early access. I have to say, I'm not scared of spiders, but this game might change that because those orb weavers and wolf spiders are nightmare fuel. Buy the game, give it a shot, support the devs and If you don't like it, refund it. I'm sure you won't because this one is worth the money and time you invest in learning how to play.

Notes:

I love this game to death. It really makes you feel small in your own backyard. I love the survival aspects of this game like being able to farm resources. I can't comment on the story, since It doesn't have one yet. Overall a very enjoyable game, albeit heart-racing at times.

Of course, the game is in early access, so there are some bugs (no pun intended)
Bugs Include:
-Insects getting stuck in objects/falling through the ground
-(one instance) blocking freezing my screen and studdering for a second (scared the sh!t outta me lol)
-An Orb Weaver stuck on bushes, thought it would jump down to eat me (concept?)

Some Critiques:
*Make the stack size bigger than 10. I find myself running out of space a lot whenever I go exploring.
*Let me be able to build on structures! That'd be sick!

Other than that, go buy the game! Is fun!

**Right after I wrote this review and tried to play, it kept crashing as I attempted to load any save. Please factor its very early development into your judgement.**

(TL;DR) It's great if you are super into the theme/idea of the game and willing to support its development with the current price tag, but it can be frustrating otherwise.

I almost didn't buy it because I felt the price was way too high for early access. I still believe that. The reason I did buy it despite my better judgement is because I really want to see a game like this succeed; this is my childhood dream come true. I'm not very picky besides with graphics, and this game has really beautiful ones. Also, I just got my tax returns.

Otherwise, I still would have bought it eventually; but I would have waited a year until it was on sale, and even then the devs say the price will be higher so who knows if that would be below $30. Scare tactics, man.

Besides waiting for new features, here's some problems I've seen in the game:
Some inventory UI glitches
Repair tools not working
Spiders/other big bois being way too hard to kill (easy mode is just for survival stats like hunger)
Big scarcity of weed planks, which could be solved if I could kill bugs easier to get a lvl 2 axe, but even in some places weeds are hard to find. Dang this thorough gardener...

So they're not really game breaking, and likely to be balanced and fleshed out as development continues. As most people are saying, this is basically Alpha gameplay.

I loved building a base on a leaf though, and gliding with dandelion seeds. Made me feel like a fairy. That's really all I wanted from this game, and it works. But if you aren't 100% on board with the idea of the game, I'd say maybe wait until it's more fleshed out.

Edit: You can also make little plushies of the small bugs you kill, and head mounts of big ones. I made a gnat and it hooks onto the ceiling by a string so you can wack it around. Also Aphid slippers that grant you "The Quickness"
10/10 creativity

It's just alright. I can't recommend it right now as it's no where finished and doesn't have the content to keep someone entertained in a building/survival game. 

The first issue is balance. Spiders feel spammed across the map and not really properly placed. I mean they can out right rape you and one hit K/O and with no real effective way to fight them without CHEESING the AI is frustrating. The enemies start to repeat heavily.

Next big issue is AI path finding. It's also broken. If you head into the bushes you'll be greeted with 1 million orb weavers and spiderlings where if you are on the ground you're fucked, but if you simply just climp up into the bush branches the AI just lets you shoot them to death as they can't figure it out even with you 10 ft away. The Ants in the nest can't path find worth a damn. They clump up into huge balls and don't bother attacking. (**Also there is no queen, what a freaking massive disappointment there holy shit**)

The next issue is the combat. It feels... fine? But not really on point. Rather clunky. Especially when fighting spiders. As the hit detection just doesn't feel right. Don't try to melee spiders. Just don't.

The amount of weapons is also very limited and they make you feel under powered and not a lot of fun... The most effective weapon against spiders if you can land it would be the Bomb, But it's a thrown weapon with rolling physics... Also the bomb blows up half of the grass to so it creates even more of a mess and things to get in your way while you're trying to fight since you collide with grass stalks. 

The game does look stunning and runs perfectly at least for me. So no issues there.

The game desperately needs more content and balancing if it's going to get any better in the future.
Even for early access, there is nothing to this game.  It might have potential someday, but it isn't worth paying for at the moment.

I've been playing this game a lot.  I LOVE it, as a disabled person, I often find myself just plane locked out of games I want to play.  I can't do anything makes you rely on sound cues, I can't do quick time events and there's a dozen other reasons why I've not been able to play some games.  The accessibility options are amazing.  And appreciated.  I'm kinda sick of being  forgotten about by game devs as a whole.  A dev taking the time to add accessibility options is so very appreciated.  And nearly un-heard of in early access games.

Oh...the the arachnophobe mode...lifesaver.  And the reason I decided to but on release day instead of waiting.

I'm kind of dissapointed on how little this game really had. There was a lot, don't get me wrong, but 30 bucks for whats here right now is a little steep. I know the Developers will add more into the game, which I'll be totally stoked about it when it happens, but to see what there was in the trailer, and then hop into the game to literally see everything this game is with just a trailer was kind of a bummer. This game just needs more stuff to do. I started playing today, and I already feel like i've completed this game, and for 5 hours of play with a 30 dollar price.. not good in my book. There are a couple of glitches here and there that aren't game breaking, but annoying. I would just say to whoever wants this game: buy it if you plan on waiting for more content to come out and play with what there is, or don't and wait for more stuff. I still like this game, but this feels more of like a demo with a price tag on it than anything atm.

Game is f***ing beautiful.

Had to get that out of the way. It runs surprisingly smooth and the sound design both deserve honorable mentions, but jumpin' jesus on a pogo stick this is visually glorious.

The only real drawbacks are hallmarks of most Early Access titles. Needs more content for sure. In the first 7 hours we've done everything we can quest-wise, and only stopped short of attacking the big spider nest. On the note of spiders, a dodge roll is desperately needed. Map is actually a lot smaller than you think. If you dead sprint from one side to the other, you can make it to the other side in about 3-4 minutes. Again, chalk this up to "more content" needed.

My only personal pet PEEVE is the coding of the spiders. They won't fight each other, or hunt other insects. The ants will eat other bugs, the ladybugs will charge and devour aphids. The spiders? They only have a taste for HUMAN FLASH and nothing else will do. This is doubly weird because Wolf Spiders are territorial by nature. But they will gladly team up with three or four other spiders (including Orb Weavers) to corner you in a research shelter.

Even the friggin' Ladybug I got to hit a group of ants started fighting with each other. Spiders need a behavior coding overhaul.

Other than that, 9/10.

Great survival fun, especially with a friend!! Don't be fooled by the childish look, this game is scarier than 99% of the horror videogames I have played. These spiders are nuts!

Positives:
- It actually looks really good!
- Very Fun basebuilding with a ton of depth (Best in the genre)
- Awesome atmosphere
- Brings back memories of honey I shrunk the kids :)
- Very fun base gameplay for them to build on (very important for Early Access)
- Pretty polished gameplay so far!
- This game can be the scariest game in years, those dang spiders! :)
- The AI is fantastic, they have things they must do and they react to whats going on

Stuff that needs improving: 

- Some issues with the coop sometimes
- Random bugs that need to be fixed (but nothing gamebreaking)

Played the demo previously and now the Early Access game, color me impressed! For a game made by 12 people this is fantastic! Playing with a friend is so fun!

Did I mention it is scary as hell!? At night time with the big spiders around, me and my buddy Mathew both screamed like young kids lol

The game has unlimited potential for future content. New Biomes to explore, Adding more Insects/Danger (Snakes! Lawnmower! Dogs!), Charming insects (The devs said they want to add this), more story elements, more stuff to craft and build, (there is already so much to build and craft its crazy!), new weapons,etc.. the game is already amazing, Obsidian has done great ground work for a special game and I cannot wait to see what they come up with next! 

Not a ton of story stuff in the game yet, BUT there is so much more to do like amazing basebuilding (try building somewhere up high and experimenting), exploring the wonderful map,etc..  I have already played 26 hours on the game, solo and with friends and I am still itching to get back on the game.

Keep it up Obsidian!

*27 hours I have in the game now and I am still learning new stuff, you can REALLY get creative with the basebuilding!*

Played the game for just under 4 hours, completed the game in 40 minutes, fully believe that if you tried you could complete this game is 3 minutes, that is 180 seconds to finish the game in its entirety, unless you feel like grinding to build a wooden house. played solo while waiting for my friend to come online, (multiplayer doesn't exist) tried to play co-op but it was a buggy mess (no pun intended) Attempted a refund that was quickly declined, tried 7 refunds in total that was all declined all under different categories with all valid and standing points, all 7 refunds declined all for the same reason "more than 2 hours played" easily half of this time was spent trying to get the game to work, I have seen reviews for people with 4+ hours whom have gotten a refund. In all honesty do not purchase this game right now unless you don't mind it sitting in your library for 6+ months waiting for content updates to come out.
Super fun! Runs smooth, only a few minor adjustments needed - removable bag finding icons and the ability to drop full stacks instead of one at a time would be very nice :)

Frankly, the game in its current state is a novelty. I have no doubt this will be a fun game when/if completed, but there is only about 2 hours of gameplay as it sits. At the price of half a Triple A game, I would have hoped for a developed story-line longer than 20 minutes. 

Not enough money to be saved by buying this one in its infant state.

I would wait until there is more content and then buy it.


The positive things:

If you want to explore the pretty big world and build a base, you can spend several hours
The game has only a few bugs and is very easy to control.

The negative things:


The game runs at 60 fps even though I have lifted the limit and played it on a top PC with 1080ti and i7-8700k.
The game has very little content so far. If you want to play through the story right from the beginning, you need about 20 minutes. The tutorial is very short and hardly explains how to optain important things and how to find the necessary things. To be able to craft anything at all you have to go with every item into a laboratory and research it there. But you can only research 3 things and then you have to wait 16 minutes.
If you can build something then it is very limited. To build a house you only have a roof, walls and a door. But the whole thing doesn't make sense yet because you are not attacked in the night and you can just sleep and skip the whole night. There is no goal to work towards. You have to eat and drink every 5 minutes or you will starve or die of thirst. Finding something to drink is not the problem, but finding food is very difficult. The fighting system is bad and pointless, the only really dangerous enemies are spiders which are almost impossible to fight alone.

Don't listen to the idiots complaining about a pay wall for online. There isn't one.

XBL is free on Windows and always has been. You don't need XBL Gold to play online on Windows.

If you already have a Microsoft account, you just need to make an XBL user name. If you have Outlook, Onedrive, or Office, you already have a Microsoft account.

Obsidian is owned my Microsoft and the game is published by Microsoft. Of course it uses XBL, and complaining about it is like asking ActiBlizz, EA, and Ubisoft to get rid of Battle.net, Uplay, and Origin. It's not going to happen.

If you buy and play games through Steam for any of them, you still have to log in to their respective online services for MP. XBL is no different.

The same could be said of the many, many other games that require an account login, like say, pretty much any major MMO, Elite Dangerous, or whatever else requires a game specific login.

The game is decent for what it is, and is a perfectly fine Early Access survival game with an interesting premise. It's clearly unfinished and not balanced well, but it's early access and that's what early access is for fixing.

Obsidian has a good track record and the game has a lot of potential. Really no chance of this being abandoned in eternal early access, and the chances of it turning out badly are lower than most early access titles.
I haven't had as much fun in a crafting survival game since the early days of ARK. I can't wait to see what this game becomes.

DO NOT BUY. It may seem that this game has a lot to offer, but trust me it doesn't. First of all the actual "story" is incomplete and the part that can be finished, is easily done in under half an hour. Im not even kidding, because all you have to do is repair a machine which takes about 15 minutes and then go to the giant oak tree, enter a hidden labatory and boom. done. This game then has the audacity to tell the player that there will be extra story related content coming in the future, as if we shouldn't expect a complete game for 30 dollars. Apart from the content, the gameplay is decent at most. The only enemies that will give you trouble are the spiders which super annoying if you play alone and a pain in the a** if you play with a friend. the crafting system is accessed by a time restricted research system which forces you to wait in order to make progress making it feel more like a mobile game than anything. The combat system feels very rushed and not responsive at all probably to due to the HORRIBLE hit detection. OH AND DID I MENTION THAT THE PERFORMANCE IS AN ABSOLUTE JOKE. On medium settings mind you, i had 60 fps with an amd radeon 5700 XT. For comparison, i have about 170 -200 fps on Star wars battlefront 2 which looks 10 times better with the same setup on ultra settings. Lastly, the game is buggy. Not fallout 76 buggy but still buggy. mostly visual glitches with enemies or objects phasing through other things or things spazzing around. I defenitely cannot recommend this game to anyone who doesnt absolutely love survival games.

This game is amazing so far! Between the super crisp, cute graphics, to the intuitive crafting system to what has started as a really amazing and engaging story line this game has it all. Looking forward to seeing what lies ahead.

But honestly this game has some serious potential to one day become awesome. Needless to say it's a great investment. Becuase as soon as the devs fix its bugs this game is gonna become legendary. I have put enough hours into this game, I think, to give my 2 cents. 
Tl;Dr: Good game with lots of potential. Lot's of bugs (the bad kind) however.

Gameplay: Grounded has a very cool concept. Basically Honey I Shrunk The Kids the game. The survival mechanics are what you'd expect, just with the twist of being tiny. Water is dew drops, food is bug meat and shrooms, etc. 

Characters: The characters are young teenagers and, while the voice acting is fine, I had to turn down the dialogue volume to 0% due to the repetitive voice lines. Being anywhere near ants causes the characters to machine gun out the same stupid line of "Oh hey look an ant" over and over and over. 

Spiders: A lot of people complain about spiders being "op" and, at first, I was inclined to agree. However, once you learn to fight, especially when it comes to using the perfect block, they quickly lose most of their terror factor. My only remaining complaint regarding spiders, specifically the wolf spider, is that their attack hitbox is obscenely generous in their favor. I died several times to wolf spiders (albeit while still learning to block) due to them being able to attack from a distance despite clearly doing a melee attack. 

Bugs: Bugs often get stuck in walls or stuck on each other, the ai is super easy to exploit, ants can rob your chests even if the chest is inches (several meters by comparison) off the ground. 

Overall I would say wait if you don't want to deal with bugs and frustration over the lack of polish to mechanics. If you're like me and are used to EA titles being unfinished and just want to help support the devs so they can finish the game then by all means go ahead.

My wife and I were looking for a Coop game that moments of "chill" and "stress." We have played quite a few survival builders and what sets this a part for us is a few things. (My experience is primarily based on 5-8 hours of initial play).

The Good:
- The world is "relatable." Obviously this is due to the ant size backyard appeal. This makes the exploration a real treat and families young and old can get behind it.
- It has quests compared to other survival builders. This is great because for myself I like directed goals to complete, rather than just being left to my own ideas to keep me interested.
- Simplistic. The crafting system shows you what you need and not only that, you are able to set out "pre-builds" of what you want to do. Then you can estimate how many materials you need! It also has an easy tutorial to follow in the beginning. Note: Be careful on going dave the barbarian on ants in the beginning ;) you have been warned! lol.
- Combat system isn't "dull," and is pretty straight forward. Nothing too hardcore.
- I'm sure I have other things to note but this is just my initial review lol.

Improvements (hope Devs see this):
- When depositing in a storage container, it looks like there isn't a "deposit all stacks" of one item. You have to deposit one at a time. (please correct me if I'm wrong)
- Armor equipped takes up bag space. It would be understandable if you weren't wearing the item, but it doesn't make sense to me that it takes up bag space when you are wearing the item?
- Minor: Could we get a quick-turn-around function? If this exists and I'm unaware please let me know.
- Could we get a "loot all" in a small vicinity? Sometimes items roll after killing, and it would be great if there was a faster loot option.
- More graphics alterations/editing would be cool. My wife and I don't have the best graphics card, and normally I turn shadows down to low to help this without butchering the rest of the game world too much.

The game works.  There is nothing to do.  After about one hour's worth of story, you just run around and get killed by spiders.  There is very little content here, save your money until it's further along in development.

If you are the type of player that needs the game to give you something to do, pass on this.  Right now, it's just a sandbox.

It's a console port, so if terrible console controls frustrate you as a PC player, this will annoy you.

There are plenty of issues with the EA build.  The UI is particularly frustrating.  The armor that you wear is still in your backpack, which is very tiny.  Repairing items is usually harder than crafting the same item again, until you figure out quartzite.  There are several things that will cause a CTD, like interacting with the spit when it has items already cooked on it and many other things.

There is always a delicate balance in a survival game between challenging and really annoying.  Right now, it's super annoying to have to constantly eat and drink so often.  Food will also spoil faster than you can eat it.  Much faster.  You can craft a jerky rack to dry out meat that won't spoil, but until then the early game is a real pain.  There needs to be a much better transition between tiers so it isn't so punishing for new players.  There is no fun in getting one-shot by spiders and constantly dying of hunger and thirst!

It almost feels like the early game is tuned for a group of 4 working closely together, and when you tech up to the next tier you are finally strong enough to combat the bigger bugs and spiders solo.

Everything I mentioned until now can be changed and improved.  Unfortunately what I see as the biggest issue for this game is the static hand crafted map.  Re-playability is going to be very low.  It's only fun and interesting to discover the back yard once.  Even the resources spawn in the same place, so you find yourself just running in a circuit collecting things where you know they are.  In 2020 procedurally generated maps is a must have for mature players that want to play more than 10 hours for a full price game.

Lastly, some are comparing this to ARK.  It's only similiar in some of the lower level survival concepts.  In terms of the amount of content in ARK compared to Grounded, it's apples and oranges.  ARK's map, tech tree, mob variety, gear tiers, etc. is about 100x more rich.  It would take Grounded a decade to catch up to that.  Anyone that says "it's like ARK" must not have ever played ARK for longer than a day.

Players tolerance for these things will be low at the very high price tag of this EA game.  At this stage in development, it would be fair to charge about $4.99.

PRO TIPS:

For players that want the challenge, and like survival in a sandbox here are a few tips:

Get a 3 piece acorn set (super easy), and beat a few soldier ants to death.  Then make the ant club, and beat a few spiders to death.  Now you have the spider bow, and you can kill a bunch more spiders for the spider set.  With this, you can solo everything, and go collect the other tier 2 resources you want to base build and gather science from the quests.

Plant fiber and sap are literally everywhere, and they make a bandage that is a HoT (heal over time).  You should have 10 of these on your hotbar at all times, and a hotkey to use.

To begin, I want to say that this game cranked my whimsy factor to an 11. As uncomplicated as it seems, there is such a rich potential for growth in any direction, and I am looking forward to further updates to the game. That said, I would have to say that the graphics are both a blessing and a curse. If you're like me, and have a basic windows 10 laptop that you picked up from Staples, you may have to adjust some setting with your graphic card in addition to turning the settings down in game. Even so, the low end graphic version still looks great, and theres no latency with the screen attempting to keep up with the scenery, which is vast (Ironically in a game where youve been shrunk.) The craft system is both very simple, with room to grow into many different things. If you're a fan of The Forrest or any similar survival-crafting game, then this is right up your alley, and you should either pick this up or keep a close eye on the developments.

I NEVER usually but Early Access games, or games for full price for that matter. More-so if I do then I spend time watching gameplay, reading reviews for ages etc. But there was something about Grounded that just made me skip all that. I'm not sure what exactly. 
  
As soon as I got in to the playable game I was just awestruck by how beautiful it is and how polished the completed sections of the yard are. The atmosphere is incredible. I just explored and explored. I played single player, so I can't comment on the Multiplayer issues.

The main enemies are honestly the scariest I've faced in any game bar none. Expressionless, almost unstoppable assassins just waiting for you to make the wrong move. 

The base building, resource gathering, hunger/stamina/thirst could use some polishing, sure. But hey, Early Access.

I'm so excited to see what the future bring for this game!!

I've played this game for a few days now, and my experience has been that this is definitely a fun and refreshing take on the other survival and base building games out there. I never saw any advertisement for this and just stumbled upon it myself, though it's fairly new I would have expected to hear about it earlier, with it being such a visually attractive and interesting themed game.

 There are still some bugs (Ha!) but nothing that is game breaking by any means, a little annoying when they first happen but they can be worked around. The main ones I've dealt with have been the game crashing a lot the first day I played, once or twice an hour but the autosave feature was a big relief when that happened. Sometimes while crafting several of something, the crafting window will not update showing the quantity you currently have and just starts dropping the new ones all over the ground around you. Other than those, it has been doing wonderfully. 

I love base building games and it's fun to run around slicing down blades of grass and watching ladybugs go into a blind frenzy when you knock down an aphid. The little noises the insects make are sometimes adorable, sometimes startling, I would love to see more of a variety of insects added later on.

 I am still figuring things out and learning from mistakes, but the lack of permadeath and the autosave feature make your failures more easily forgivable. A couple suggestions I have so far, some way to preserve food would he a huge help instead of having meat rot after one day, a spoilage timer would be great. Equipped armor shouldn't continue to take up bag space, it's an odd thing to see that happening and that bit does seem unnecessary. Maybe I haven't discovered how to make it yet, but some way to catch water other than collecting droplets or sipping from puddles would be awesome! I love hopping on the backs of the lady bugs and letting them wander around like I'm taking a ride, have you considered making an actual taming or riding system for any of the insects? Maybe a fishing pole with a little aphid dangling off to lure your Ladybug steed to your destination?

 Overall I'm enjoying the game and I would suggest any survival fans to check it out! It might also be a nice introduction for older children interested in the genre as it's not as intense as some of the other popular ones. There's also an arachnophobia adjusting slider in the options to make the spiders look less scary if that's something that puts you off of trying it out. I'm excited to see what new content will be added in the future.

Obviously we're in the beginning stages of this thing, but so far it is pretty great. I'm sure there are a lot of those people who run out of things to do but I'm definitely not one of them. The story so far is short due to it being in Early Access , but you can feel that something great is coming. 

The graphics and gameplay is amazing and smooth. My friends and I took 6 hours to explore the whole map and it is still under construction. 

This game does cause Anxiety with all the bugs crawling around. 

Characters have their own personality and easily lovable.

While I've only played 12.4 hours of it, i can say for a game that came into early access like 6 days ago or so, i can really see the potential in the game. I've fought everything aside from the spiders and each can be a different enemy type.

While currently lacking in the story content, they've setup an interesting world and it's definitely one i kept exploring.

The Base Building is incredible for such an early build of the game, it was interesting because of it's scale harder materials were numerous in other areas, and at times i really felt like an ant, moving across the map, which for being entirely localised in a backyard, does still provide areas to explore and i haven't even seen everything the map has yet.

I would say that Grounded is worth getting and giving it a try, 
While there are bugs and well Bugs it is still a game that i can boot up when i want to relax and just build, and when the story content gets fleshed out and we have some different areas to explore i'd be up to play this game for hours.

The Fact the game has multiplayer means that it's got a one up on other survival games like Subnautica (which i also adore) because it allows players to come together to explore, survive and face threats.

(Warning: At this time the non-intentional bugs are numerous, and my main save locked me outta some areas related to the minuscule story content.)

Really fun game! Pretty polished for an early access game. The combat is pretty unique. Genuine jump scares if you're not paying attention. Unique crafting system that includes physically carrying planks, for example. Feels very rewarding when you kill a big bug, with really satisfying animations. I didn't experience anything game breaking in the four hours i've played. The cross-play works flawlessly between Steam/Xbox One, little to no connection issues and saved our progress.

Overall, it has many of the survival game elements! The theme of being small and fighting bugs is really cool, and it's exciting to see where they take the game. Many new creatures to possibly encounter, and what if it expands into the house!? Who doesn't want to slay cock roaches and giant rats?!

Some people might be turned off by the price tag, but grab a friend or 3 and it will be worth it for everyone involved!

Probably going to draw quite a bit of flak for this "not recommended" review but hear me out.. 

Scores (at its current state):
Atmosphere: 9/10
Graphics: 9/10
Content: 3/10
Replayability: 2/10

The good:
Concept is unique and one that surprisingly hasn't been explored by any dev so far despite its obvious entertainment value (Honey I Shrunk The Kids meets ever-increasingly popular gaming genre of survival). Realistically brutal, as it would be in a bug's life (in this case yours, in their size). The lack of handholding pushes the player to think on their feet, which fits well into the mystery of this situation you are thrown into (unnecessary handholding would've taken away from immersion otherwise).

The bad:
The release of this game at this price point is a little unjustified. Survival games that had an early access (for e.g. The Long Dark) usually come with a decently fleshed out sandbox with the promise of an eventual story, or a decently fleshed out story with a promise of an eventual sandbox. In grounded, we have little of either. The story comes to a very quick end as it is still being created (perfectly understandable). However, there is not much content in the sandbox department as the ceiling of craftables are quite quickly reached (which the exception of tier 2 tools). With a very familiar and simple trope of only having to manage hunger and thirst, there is little to do in the sandbox other than basic base building. Most survival games so far (even on early access release) have had decent enough distractions for your character to manage (Cold, Thirst, Hunger, Fatigue in The Long Dark) or endless base building possibilities (Minecraft). 

Many would argue that this is still early access, and there's much more to come. I agree, and I would expect no less from a dedicated dev like Obsidian. However, this release should've been either:

(1) A larger story on release at this current price
(2) A better sandbox on release at this current price
(3) Based on the current content, at half its price

On some closing thoughts, my "not recommended" review is specifically on a cost benefit analysis of getting this game in its current state at this price. My position will change (knowing Obsidian, highly likely for the better) based on price of the game after some of its more larger content updates are released.

Wow another early access survival game, aren't there enough of those already? Well at least that is what I thought before playing this game. At the request of a friend I begrudgingly purchased this title. I also really like Obsidian and don't mind supporting them but I have to stress I am really weary of early access releases.


For an early access title there is a surprising amount of content, it is much more polished than most of the 'early access' titles that are on the market. In fact many games that are early access take years to get to where the current state of this game is and would declare the title a full release.

 The game is pleasantly unique for the fact that the premise is instead of your normal zombies, being marooned on an island, or the end of the world, you get shrunk down to comical proportions. You chose from 1 of 4 kids to play as and you have to some how manage to survive in your new horrific predicament. A different spin on the survival crafting genre of games. 

 The art style is very whimsical, initially giving me the impression that this was going to be a casual kids game. The moment I ran into a Wolf Spider I realized this is very much not the case. I have to really stress that the art style of the game is a breath of fresh air, this isn't a reskin of DayZ, or a voxel Minecraft survival clone, this is it's own unique thing.

Grounded being a survival game is similar to titles such as The Forest, Ark, and Subnautica. The crafting system is nothing special, gather the right resources build the things. However what I like is that the game isn't as much of a grind, building your base and crafting resources does not take a ridiculous amount of time and energy. Collect the parts, analyze them, build cool stuff. 

Combat in it's current state is pretty unforgiving and you will find yourself using strategy more often than brute forcing your way through the environment. I am playing with one other person and even dealing with lower enemies is sort of a hassle. That said, if you die (you will a bunch) the game doesn't punish you. All of your belongings will drop where you died so you can go and collect your things and not lose any progress. (I personally really like this).

Currently the selection of insects/animals in the environment is pretty small. Then again for early access it is a decent amount and I have been having a pretty good time. I am really looking forward to the future updates and what new critters they will add.

Unfortunately if you are looking for a rich story driven game, that is simply not there at this time. To Obsidians credit they are very forthcoming with that fact so I wasn't blind sided by the currently shallow story (they are working on it).

As for performance, this game runs really well on my system. I have not experienced lag or many bugs for that matter. Occasionally insects will clip through the environment making them impossible to get to.

Another thing I noticed is that objects in Grounded are persistent, meaning what ever you drop, or what ever things the world generates remains in the world. I currently have not ran into any issues with this but I have the creeping suspicion that eventually this will become a major problem in more mature games.

Overall if you enjoyed titles like Subnautica and Ark I am confident you will like this game. It is very fun in single or multiplayer. If you want a story hold off on this title. If you are looking for a survival game to play with friends that doesn't involve zombies I would highly recommend this game.

3. Items fall through ground and you will not be able to retrive them

8. There are no instruction in the games that can guide you

Please understand that this is an Early Release - but I have to say I am quite impressed. So much so I have it on both my XBox console and on my PC. This is based upon my experience on both units. Visually this is just stunning. Seriously just stunning. I do have to say that i experience something like a splash/ multi-color blur effect  on the edges of my screen (but this only occurred on the console not the PC version). That has seemed to have been corrected as of me writing this - been playing since day 1.

Sound is now good but upon initial launch it was a bit off at certain areas of the game - entering the Oak tree  or speaking with BURGL. I've noticed that the support has been very good with corrections so far.

Controls are good on the console but I had to get this on the PC because for me I had to "feel" what it was like to run through the grass; as it's seems to me the WASD input method is far superior, when compared to a console controller. This game "feels" good on a console but WOW on a PC. From building, to combat and exploration this is good.  

Not going to make this too long as I am going back into this game to find out what I can discover - REALLY looking forward to how they flesh this out.

This game now being 14 hours in playing both solo and co-op has been a blast. Its really fun building the base you want it to be and alot of the creatures behave like the would in real life. Mess with an ant and all the ant in the area come after you for awhile. I own spiders and dont have a problem with you until you are smaller then them and they chase for long distances in the grass. Building a fort early on really is smart and helps out, just get ready to defend it at night if the spider gang or larve gang show up LOL. i typically dont play survival games but this one is fun and the grind for nutrition and water isnt bad after you build some of the basics. getting a dew collector early on in the game makes it much easier as you dont have to hunt for dew droplets anymore. im glad i got this early access and cannot wait to see all the extra features and hopefully even more bugs that are to come.

I must admit, coming into this game knowing it was in early access had me not expecting much, but even now this game is absolutely incredible. Its still haves bugs and issues but the game is very entertaining and fun to play. Friend of mine really wanted to give it a try with me so I agreed to get it so we could play together. The overall look of the game is nice.

Issues I noticed was getting DCd a lot when connecting with my friends game. I have Fiber so I know my internet speed is not the issue and his wifi is at the highest. I play several online and rarely have connection issues. But during our 8.9 hours of play I got DCd from his game about 15 times.

Bugs in the game besides the actual ones were items that said E for collecting that would not work. I ran into some bubbles of juice forming below the juice box near the tree and for some odd reason one of my backpacks spawned out of it, several tapes, 2 granola bars and some stones. Backpack had my name on it, with the E symbol which would mean you could interact with it, but still could not. It was as if it spawned one of my backpacks I lost from a death in that spot and it made me lose a decent amount of tools and items because where the backpack was before, disappeared from the map after that. Spiders glitching into areas, like the science building hallway that is under one side of the tree. Spiders being able to hit you through landscape items that should otherwise keep them from hurting you. Ants and random other bugs glitching into large stones. We built on one of the large flat stones near the largest body of water on the map and an ant ended up stuck under that large stone. We ended up attacking another ant that was trying to get into a storage chest on the edge of our foundation, that we were trying to build walls around but hadnt gotten all the materials, and the one stuck in the rock, was able to hit us through the rock and through our clay foundation. Was a big pain but we put down a few spoiled meat around the edge of the large stone and got his head partially out enough to hit him a few times and kill him, but again a big pain.

I know the game is still being worked on, and even this that I would still recommend it. The disconnection is a bit irritating along with a few of the bugs but the over all time I have played it I enjoyed it.
I had to return this game, heads up to people with Radeon R series graphics cards, this game is freezes constantly and is super buggy with this series of cards.

I'm having fun with Grounded so far and I'm glad I took a chance on it.
It's deeper than I expected in EA. Lots of exploring to do. 
It's cute, fun, and engaging. The world is extremely dangerous, but the cost of death doesn't seem too high.
Struggled at first to find safe water to drink, but you figure that out soon enough.
I love that if you die (and drop your backpack), then die again on the way to pick it up, you can still go get it. Other games would despawn the original one permanently if that happened. 
I'm happy to play and explore while they add more to the game over time. I know some aren't happy with the price in EA, but I have a feeling it's going to be worth it, especially if they jack the price up closer to full launch.

It's a solid survival game, somewhat identical to The Forest in terms of controls and environmental animations, but with the Honey I Shrunk the Kids theme (I know it's been said 1000 times but it's true.) There are a few bugs such as insects phasing through tier 1 grass walls and sometimes getting stuck behind or in random objects but it's not a game breaking issue and will be fixed down the road. The map will eventually be expanded but for what it has now, it's a diverse and gorgeous landscape with different insects and spiders in each areas. Enemy's aren't too overpowered (except for wolf spiders) so if you practice, you will be able to hunt down and harvest better tier weapons and building pieces pretty early on which will save you from random larva swarms, or spider attacks to your base. The good in the game significantly outweighs the minor negatives, and it is a game I'm looking forward to the updates the developers have planned and if you like survival games, for sure get this one.
