Grounded is easily one of the best EA games I have personally played, and that's quite a few through the years. It also happens to be one of the most fun and original survival builders that I have played, and those are one of my favorite genres. 

There are some bugs(no pun intended). There are some crashes, but for me, at least, they have been VERY minimal and unobtrusive. I also have confidence that Obsidian will deliver a fully fleshed out product in the end. Hell, I have already put enough time in to make the price/hours played factor negligible, and I am still finding enjoyment, even with the game in this early state.

The game does not hold you by the hand, AT ALL, but I mean, it's a survival game so...I dunno...survive? Once you progress your tech tiers most things become so trivial, but Wolf Spiders are always scary, even if they do get melted by the 3rd Tier weapon that is mildly hidden.

Overall, good game as is, has potential to be great!

Short and Skinny review

Still in development but has a basic and unique twist to the survival genre. Make sure to use the auto save feature as saves do corrupt occasionally. If you are afraid of spiders there is a mode to change them out to something stranger looking and less spider like. If you are a fan of the genre or honey i shrunk the kids you will probably like it. If you want a lot of content I suggest waiting until they have done more. Over all I suggest the game, its quirky and fun. $30 dollars is a good price point but I feel it should have been closer to $20 at this stage of the game.

The Full review

I decided to pick this game up due to it being a survival game and I like the movie honey I shrunk the kids. It's been combined into a unique experience that has tons of bugs, pun intended. Seriously though there are a ton of programming bugs and some can be frustrating especially for new players. If you are not a fan of spiders, the game does have separate mode to disable them. If you are color blind the game does come a colorblind mode however it is still a work in progress. Future updates will also include language translations. A feature I have come to love in Grounded is the auto save. It is set by default to save every 5 minutes and up to 3 auto saves. It can be turned up higher or lower 5 minutes intervals to 20 minute intervals. The auto save slots you'll use go from 0 to 5. This feature can save some frustration which I will address in my not favorable section further below.

The game itself is still in development but the shell of what we currently have seem to be good building blocks for future updates. The graphics for the game are good, it to me captures exactly what the devs are going after. The textures and details of the grass, ground, caves and objects sitting on the map are all well done.   Small normal everyday items like mint container, soda can, juice box are all now gigantic points of interest with different uses. Thee mint container can be opened and mints harvested. You even have the chance to run into a giant hot dog that you can cut up and eat.

The crafting and gathering of items is a lot like other survival games where it can be a grind but as you go things get easier. To be able to craft some items you'll need to analyze items using a research center. Once an item is analyzed you may unlock something like the insect bow or bandages. In a multiplayer game things analyzed are shared with all players. You'll have to fight some bugs several times in order for them to drop parts so if RN-jesus is not being kind to you it may take a bit of time to get what you need.  Another neat mechanic they have is that you will find water droplets on blades of grass and knock them down by throwing a rock.  Just know you're going to end up eating bug a bug at some point as you play the game.  

The Insects and arachnids  are interesting to say the l east. There are several passive mobs that are good for food like aphids, weevils and grubs. Then you the neutral mobs such as worker ants and lady bugs, you leave them alone they leave you alone. Then you have your aggressive mobs which range from gnats to spiders. The gnats do no damage but much like in real life they are just there as irritants, but they also drop meat to cook and eat. There are mites that will attack you but can be handled with bare fists. Other aggressive mobs include infected weevils, and mites.  There are also stinkbugs, larva, soldier ants bombardier beetles and the dreaded spiders. There are also neat mechanics such as an aphid running up a blade of grass to avoid being attacked or ants raiding your base because you have food stored.

Base building is pretty simple with the pieces snapping to each other. Some places cannot be built upon which can hinder you so make sure you check the area as some places that look like you could place something down will not allow you. The building can be fun and is about the same as any other survival genre there is just with a unique spin. You'll need grass plants of weed stems as your main items for building.  There are side quests that will allow you earn science to trade in for plans for other building options such as sturdy walls or a floor. 

Multiplayer is also a fun way to play. You can have up to 3 others join your game and play. Take note a Microsoft account is needed to play online. Once your friends are in you can enjoy teaming up as a group or even splitting off from the group. 

The story of the game is largely unfinished and could be completed in less than 30 minutes if you just focus on it. This is still a work in progress so I do not hold this against them.  Once you complete the main quest then there are the side quests that unlock. These vary from analyzing quest, fetch quest, location marking or even killing certain amount of bugs.

Now we went through the good, leaving us only with only the less than favorable aspects of the game. 

Less Than Favorable

Now above I mentioned the great feature of auto saving. I will tell you now to use it as several of these issues below can be fixed by save scumming.

Now know I suggest auto saves for a couple reasons. I at first was not saving as when you go to exit the game will create and exit auto save. Regular saving is something I suggest doing regularly before you exit the game. My first play through auto exit save was corrupted and would not load. I was able to use an auto save from earlier to recover. Now the save game issue here can happen on a normal save as well. Again the more saves/auto saves the better for this early stage game.

Right off the bat on of the most frustrating things are the worker ants. IF they feel you have too much food they will attack your base and start pulling things out of your chests. This is a unique feature that i enjoy but what makes it bad is the fact the ant's reach is seemingly unlimited as they could reach up and take things out of a chest 6 stories up.


Another point of frustration is that there is a chance for items when in chest and being moved to glitch and change to something else. I had spider silk turn into ant heads and grub hide turn into gnat fuzz. A friend playing with me even had his screen show spider silk but on mine something else. Save scumming and going back to my save 5 minutes prior allowed us to recover the proper items.

Players may also randomly get kicked and I have seen it go 1 of 2 ways when a player rejoins. First they come back with all their gear on and all of their inventory. The second way is after reconnecting they come back with nothing, no gear, no inventory as if they were a fresh player. Save scumming at that point will allow them to recover anything which may be more beneficial than just making everything over again.
ff

Very fun and quirky survival game with hints of the systems used in games like "The forest" However due to it being early access and just recently released i find myself wondering around with not alot to do. Obviously the issues of lack on content Variety will be solved in time as they develop this game. Overall Gud Game moar bugs plz

I just felt the need to finally write my first review, guess why? I don't stand those bad reviews. 10hrs on early access seems fair enough to me as most ppl 've only played it for barely 2 hrs, to review and refund it. Seriously folks?

A RL friend of mine and I decided to buy this game right after release, and boy oh boy. 

Even though the game only has a very small amount of story (max 1hr), we ended up exploring the garden and uncovering different biomes. Doing so gave me chills and loads of goosebumps. I mean my stream viewing mates were laughing so hard at the multiple bug encounters we had, that at a certain time even I couldn't hold it back. Didn't know any more whether I should laugh or shit my pants encountering those nasty spiders. When it comes to base building, you'll soon realise that your housing location is of importance. The building system itself seems quite nice although, you'll most likely experience some major bugs, which didn't take away the fun but made us solve the issue in a creative way.

Now after spending 2 evenings in "Grounded", I've decided to go back outside into our lovely garden. Man, I don't know what happened but when I'm playing games with my kids in the garden I check on everything, hahahah. Like: 

"Woaaaaahhhh, there's an ant, lets follow it"
"What might have created this hole?"
...

I wish you'd see the look of my eldest when doing so.

First let me start off by saying I love this game =) its great and a lot of fun. As someone who is definitely terrified of spiders I am appreciative of the arachnophobic option. Thank you to the devs that implemented it. I in all truth havent turned it on, because I want to experience the game as it was intended... -.- Terrifying as they are lol. Every time I am running the hairs on the back of my neck stand up ( not even kidding )

Anyway, back to the game.. I love the artwork... Its incredible, Yes its a cross between Honey I shrunk the kids, and your building/survival game. Currently I have spent 22 Hours in this game and yes, there are bugs but in the same token this is Early Access and I can see those issues addressed before launch. I love that in the morning you can look up through the blades of grass and find dew drops to drink as "clean water" lol because the mucky puddles make you ill and hungry ( for a short time ). The nights are disgustingly dark lol and you cant see not an inch in front of your face. 

You are forced to think on your feet... Before you venture out, have the supplies you would need to get far from your base to explore and find certain items. I appreciate the torches and "never leave home without one" lol, just in case! 

Combat: Combat seems okay imo? You can block, you can also use a bow and shoot from relatively far. However be prepared to be stunned by some bugs, poisoned by others, and damn those spiders they are SUPER fast. If you are playing alone they present a challenge for sure. But I find that in the game where I am playing with a friend they are more manageable. Teaming up against a ladybug seems oh so wrong, but it becomes easier. You can also acquire weapons that stun them in turn, they help A LOT. 

Food: There is food everywhere.. my favorite has to be acorns. You can utilize the whole acorn, the tops, shells and meat from inside. Aphids are one of the first critters you encounter, their meat is great to cook fills you right up =) they are simple to kill, if they climb up a blade of grass, whack it and they will fall to their death lol. There are many things you can "cook" to feed yourself along with a plethora of mushrooms all over the map. 



Here are some of the things that currently are what I feel needs looking at =) 


Voice chat is not working properly, settings I have PTT on and its always on, I check the never option and its still ON lol. You have to toggle it for it to read the setting per se. 

Analyze menu escape doesnt close it ( a few menus do not close when hitting escape or space as instructed ) 

Items disappear at times when putting them in storage, or pulling them out of storage, putting items to cook. 

Maybe not have "gear" that we wear take up space in the inventory? Or maybe add in a backpack of sorts for it and the tools?

Also I dont know if this is possible, however it absolutely drives me bonkers that once the game settings are set as we want them.. The volume of the main start up screens are ear splittingly loud -.- If this could be a thing? Where whatever volume the game itself is set at, it carries over to everything in the game? Especially the start up screen  ( you would have my eternal thanks heh )

Edit: for the first time yesterday I kept crashing, only when recycling though. ( might be an issue here ) 

Also, another suggestion... I think its sort of unfair that when you play multiplayer, the other "non host" people dont get a save of their own. We were playing the other day and my friend died, but I was stuck in a web, so I had to restart the game ( the web had been broken btw, I was just kinda hanging there in mid air lol ) and he lost all his stuff =(

This brings me to my next bug, seems that even if you chop down a spider web, you still stay stuck there regardless of how long you wait etc. Only a relog will help free you. 

Another thing we were speaking about, is maybe if it were possible to make multiple of certain items? Like the fibers and such? 

One last idea I had, because its driving me mad that there grass cuttings EVERYWHERE around my base lol. Would it be possible to maybe make a compost bin of sorts? Was thinking that it could maybe be like the grass pallet, but we could put grass/weeds there to eventually delete and maybe become a dirt, or fertilizer... or even a clay? That once a day it would empty and maybe give something in return =) hell, lol tbh I would be happy that it just trash those items once a day with no reward hehe

Will update as we go along, or after final copy is out.. But for now IMO a definite must pick up =) Even with the small inconveniences its still a fun game!
GG

Grounded is a survival game with a brilliant game concept and a lot of potential!

I have already spent some time in Grounded and would like to share a couple of ideas in order to improve the game: 

Inventory - The size of the basic inventory is too small.
Especially considering, that your Armor, and other equiped items also takes up space in the inventory. There should definitely be a Tier 2 Backpack.
The player should also be able to drag and drop 10x stacks of items from their inventory to a chest/basket. 

Bow and Arrow - Especially early in the game the Bow will be the weapon of choice against bigger and stronger enemies. Maybe add a Quiver so the Player won't have to carry about 40-50 arrows with him all the time, because that's about the amount of arrows it takes to kill a Ladybug. Please buff the bow! 

Food - Raw meat spoils too fast! If you leave your base in the morning and go for an adventure, the meat you hunted earlier that day will be spoiled when you get back to the base.  

Base building - This one is kind of obvious, building something can be quite frustrating. Please improve! 

Reviving Teammates - Takes up to 5 tries, in order to work. 
30 secs isn't enough time to revive a teammate. Also concidering, that enemies tend to patrol their prey for a long period of time after they killed them. 


Things that could be added later on:
At some point the Grounded world will have to increase it's size. 
So either create more and deeper Dungeons/Ant nests, or take it into the house. 
Maybe create a world inside the tree, add a water world. (Add a Swimming suit, diving bootle)

Ants that can be tamed with food, and then be used as mode of transportation, like a horse with armor and a saddle. 
Or use the same principle on a butterfly, that can get you up to the treetop of the acorn tree.

Using new material found in the lasers or the lab to create some form of a advanced weapon.


Problems I have faced whilst playing Grounded:
- Enemies health randomly recharging during combat. 
- Spiders bugging through Defensive Walls.
- Groups of Larvaes and Ants spawning inside the base.
- Water drops dissappearing after hitting the grass they where clinging on.
- Swimming mechanics feel kind of odd.
- Only about 50 FPS when playing Grounded, even though I have a strong hardware and my CPU and GPU drivers are up to date. Haven't quite found the root of this problem. 
Maybe it lies within my Hardware/Software or in the game.

So I feel I've pretty much done all available content in the game at the moment. In my 22 hours, I've built a decent sized base, crafted T2 weapons and armour and killed a few of everything except the Wolf spider.

The game is beautifully presented. I didn't see any graphics glitches. I'm a fan of stylised art anyway, but they've done a terrific job of every aspect; mobs, landscape, resources and buidlings. The only glitches I noticed in the game were mobs spawning in stuff occasionally, and the fact that the Unload action (used for dropping planks and stems) is hardcoded to G and cannot be changed. It's a really smooth package already.

The available story is very limited at the moment, clearly lots still to come. The game does a reasonable job of intro and guiding you through the basics, but you're left to wander and explore on your own fairly quickly. That suited me, and the exploration has been fun. There is no minimap and compass on the HUD, although you can see the direction you're facing and key features on the main map. This creates a terrific sense of being lost, without actually ever becoming completely lost (because you can check the map). I hope they keep this, as it makes the world seem bigger than it is.

The combat is relatively simple. You have block and hit. Combat is a balance of strafing and/or blocking to avoid attacks and striking the mob while managing your stamina bar (running and striking use stamina). I feel the game could use a dodge, but that might make combat too easy. Still, it took me a while to master the combat, and even with a T2 armour set, I'll sometimes kill an Orb Weaver cleanly, and sometimes drop to less than 1/2 health in a fight. Combat definitely generates a sense of peril!

I'm very much looking forward to the updates as they get released.

Is it worth buying now? IMO, if you're looking for something new to play, then yes. If you're anything like me, you'll get at least 10-20 hours in its current form just learning it. I expect there will be a lot of updates before it's 'released', so there's clearly loads of content to come. Very much worth it in my opinion, but everyone has a different sized games budget, so YMMV.

This game might be the next Subnatica when it comes to survival-crafting games, only more stable and less glitches. Lots bugs though, just not ones related to computers. And an aracnhophobia mode? Even if I'm fine with it I know a friend who hates spiders, and a mode like that is great when you want to focus on everything else. 

The charm is mostly in the perspective, othewise it's very sumilar to other survival-crafting games when it comes to the moment-to-moment gameplay loop. Surprisingly stable for an early access game, more stable than a lot of AAA games at least. 

It is lacking in content, like only the central part of the world is finished and mostly polished, the story is barely there (arguably the best part about Subnautica was the inclusion of an actual story), the enemy vareity feels a little lacking etc. However. In time, as long as the developers doesn't just abandon ship, this game will be a gem among the garbage that steam spews out. 

Maybe not buy it now if old school gameplay and a fresh perspective is not enough for your entertainment but this is definitively worth a follow and adding it to your wishlist if you like survival-crafting games in general.

As a side note, I've only encountered one game breaking bug yet, but restarting the game ended up fixing it as I found out after rage quitting when it first happened, then a day or so later starting it up again.
I cannot do the spiders in this game, the arachnophobia slider doesn't do anything for me because i still know they r spiders and i just can't.

Climbing my way out of an "abandoned" ant hill that was not nearly as abandoned as I was lead to believe, my torch burnt out and thrown at a hostile soldier ant long before. My health is low, but slowly recovering, thanks to my last bandage freshly applied. The ants skitter and chitter in their search for me below as I look up, out through the only exit to the golden light of day above me, the sky a pleasing and calming blue, and my steps quicken from the promise of salvation...

Only to freeze in abject terror as eight long, hairy limbs silhouette over the exit, as a hulking wolf spider crawls it's way in. I have nowhere to run. I have no time. The wolf spider looms large over me, eyes red with malice, and ends my life in one swift stroke.

10/10 would soil myself again.

I am not a game reviewer, simply a player.

Grounded is compatible only to The Forest and Green hell it shows yet again that not all survival games are alike. It directly takes unique elements from The Forest such as its building, progression, and exploration but with better (yet goofier) graphics. It also has some elements from Green Hell.

Even with the cartoon graphics, it’s terrifying to run into a nasty beetle or giant spider. So it still has strong horror elements despite the youthful feel. It seems like the best game to get your kids into the survival horror genre, which I think is genuinely fantastic. It follows Minecraft in that.

The game has a lot of new features, like all good games should. Researching crafting materials unlocks more content. You’re limited to only three items per day per computer, but there are many computers and many days to play.

I’ve only played it for 6 hours, and it’s still in early access with many frustrating bugs, some of which just kill you. It’s clear it’s not finished, but it’s the most polished early access game I have ever played. The animations are smooth, the combat is fluid and it just feels amazing to play.

It’s such a pity it’s only four players, though I’m so grateful it’s multiplayer at all. This would be so much more fun with a bunch of friends all screaming and running from spiders together.

I always hate it when games don’t let you create your own character or least customise them. But at least this game has male, female and different races. It’s nice to play a Forest like game where I am a female for the first time. I wish I didn’t have to play a child, but I understand the homage and the young theme and I think it’s one of the game’s biggest strengths.

I expect to play it for many hours, and expect to pick it up again each time new content comes out. It’s fantastic already, with a lot of content but still need more. I am most excited to see it have more content than it’s only two comparable games, which are both now complete but still lack content.

Having first seen the game and its unique concept a few months before their early access release, I had no other choice than to get it. After playing this game for a good amount of hours, I can look back and safely say that it was indeed a fun experience. Both the singleplayer and multiplayer of this game were equally great, though I still highly recommend getting at least up to 3 players on your first run. With singleplayer, it's a horror survival game, yet, with multiplayer, it's still a horror survival but comedy included! The game looks really nice even with the lowest settings as well as the immersive experience to complement it. However, I never said this game was flawless. I'm going to be listing them so that they can be acknowledged, but I can say for certain that this game has a vast amount of potential that it can achieve as well as how much it can fix. Me and my friends, in the hours we have played, have encountered quite a deal of problems during our playtime. Firstly, a lot of disconnection issues occurred in addition to the game crashing a few times. Due to disconnections and crashes, some of us would find our stuff to be missing completely. Secondly, the frames would drop all of a sudden and never pick up, causing the immersion and overall ability to play well to decrease significantly. What I do and what I see do not line up, therefore making it impossible to smack a soldier ant with the ant club at full velocity to stun it. Thirdly, this is something only I encountered out of my 4 friends (separate occasions), the angle in which I hold my items, such as the bow and arrow, become slanted as well as the third person point of view. This slight angle messed up the aiming of the bow, making it more difficult to see what you're aiming at. Finally, sometimes when you log back into a game, you spawn underneath the world and fall down into the endless void. Those are some of the dilemmas we faced throughout our play of the game and we hope to see those fixed some time in the near future. All in all, me and my friends thoroughly enjoyed the game and are looking forward to what Grounded has to offer next. On a side note, I found the building system to be quite rebellious and weird. It may just be me but I think it needs to be improved upon just a bit. All in all, the game was an absolutely beautiful experience and I am supporting Grounded all the way. What makes this more is that you can experience this with friends. To end it off, a fifth player would be nice, and spiders are absolutely terrifying!!!
hell yeah.this is a super fun game, great open world and great graphics, its a super fun game to play with friends.i totally recommend buying this game

While seemingly expensive for an early access game, it has a lot of promise. The general idea is very unique, and the way that Obsidian are executing it suggests that this will become the new Subnautica; an early access game that was heavily improved by the community playing it. 

The story can currently easily be completed in one hour, but so far it's promising. The building is confusing at first, but once you get the hang of it, it becomes addicting. The world is very cleverly made, with the ability to run along blades of grass and be trampled on by giant spiders, ants, crickets and ladybugs, to be able to drink from droplets of water, and to build a base out of blades of grass. 

This game is unique and definitely has lots of promise.

Regardless of the fact that this game is in early access (beta), it is still super fun, and worth the $30 price tag.

- The graphics are endearing and well done.  The lighting in the game is beautiful.  The environment is interesting, fun to explore, exciting. You FEEL small because the scale is spot on and the distance is blurred, giving the impression that everything around you is even bigger.

- The sound is amazing.  Scary things in the game REALLY scare, even just with the noises that they make.  Anything significantly larger than you that is running through the grass after you barrels through the stalks, hitting each one aside terrifyingly as you hear it getting closer and closer, and it's so well done.  The background ambient noises remind you once in a while that you're still JUST in a back yard, even if you've been focusing on surviving as an ant.  A car bumping music in the street passes by.  A dog barks in the distance.  A loud engine drives on the next street over.  All the while, you've been running for your life from a stinkbug.  It's excellent.

- The base building is enjoyable, and can be difficult in single player.  I think the difficulty is a positive, because it gives you something to do and look forward to.  If you are given everything too easily, the game doesn't feel worth it because you have had nothing to adventure for.  If you are playing single player, getting the materials to create a sturdy base can be time consuming!  I enjoy every minute of it anyway.  The bases look adorable when they are done.  The textures of the materials make sense for the world that you live in - a lantern is a sprig with a single tiny flame atop a burning piece of sap.  And it's believable!

-  THE GAME NEEDS WORK but I still believe it is worth its price point, even at this stage.  This is the type of game, like Conan Exiles, or ARK, or No Man's Sky, where I don't expect to be playing it 100% of the time all the way up to its release date.  I'll play it for a couple of weeks, get bored and run out of things to do, and I'll come back for the updates.  I'm 100% ok with that.  I expect it.  I don't love any of the other games I mentioned any less because of it.

- THERE ARE BUGS (not just the 8 legged kind).  Some of them are very annoying.  I encountered a bug where when I attempted to exit the building hotmenu the game crashed. 6 times in a row. It was annoying. My game crashes when playing with friends at least once or twice a night.  The building UI is a bit skitzy and sometimes rapidly switches snapping positions.  Your worn items and the items in your hotbar still exist in your bag, which is confusing and not standard for survival games.  The storyline is very, very unfinished (I'm talking about 3 major missions, then "dailies").  There are plenty of things that need working on. Things that could possibly put a frown on your face when you play.  I still think this game is worth it.  I've played for 45 hours so far, and I'm not finished.  I will be coming back to see what's new with every update.  If I stopped playing today, and payed less than a dollar for every hour that I've enjoyed this game, it would be worth it.

Bottom line: Grounded is engaging, beautiful, unique, fun, and at times can be quite difficult.  I love it.  If you love survival games, and the idea of being the size of an ant exploring a back yard, don't hesitate to give it a try. I can't wait to see what's coming next.

I enjoyed the game, but the buildings are so fragile.  Even clay foundations get destroyed so easily by bugs.  I lost my whole base to a swarm of larvae.  They went directly toward my base and started attacking it and destroying all of it.  What a waste 10 hours of game play.  Well, guess I got to start over and look for a new base location.

The building strength of buildings need a bit more adjustments.  There is no point in building a base just for it to get demolished by a swarm.  They pretty much bulldoze through your whole base.  Bases are meant to built for shelter and security from outside elements.

I am caught in the middle right now.  As it is now, it is very difficult for a player to build and keep their base.  It's the constant grind for materials that puts me in the middle between recommend and not recommend.  Getting your base constantly destroyed and having to find the raw materials to rebuild is a bit of a grind and boring.

Fun game for early access release.  Definitely expect that they will expand the map and quests.  Quest line to this point (as of 8/2) was easily accomplished in 6 hours of playing.  There was still plenty to do with base building and building up the weapons and armor to fight harder bugs.  I think this would be even more fun in multiplayer.

The concept is great and I think it's going to be a fantastic game when fully polished. The exploring, crafting, and survival part of it is fun... BUT there are some definite downsides at this point. 

My friend and I just alt F4 ed because the larva swarms just keep coming at our base and tearing everything down. The larva respawn so quickly, do insane damage, and have what seems like unlimited health. The larva issue seems to stem from having food at the base, so if you don't have food there it should go away. But what is the point of collecting food then? The spiders also seem to have very high aggro. If you come anywhere near them they come at you so quickly and then wont leave you alone so if you're in your base you're just trapped. 

The devs definitely need to work on the bugs (literally) so you aren't so screwed at the beginning of the game. Another thing is that they should also make the armor you are wearing not count as inventory slots used.

Wouldn't recommend at the point - especially for the price ($30). Hope to change this review to a recommend at some point.

I like survival games, not I'm not that heavy into them. That being said, I launched this game last night and wow, I did not expect to be hooked 13 hours straight. I only had to reset once and that was because I was breaching past caution tape into a development zone. The amount of freedom they give you early access is pretty neat in my opinion. The combat isn't incredible, but very similar to a lot of other games you would play, though I do like the perfect guard addition. The crafting system is very interesting, I like that there are layers, and I'm sure they'll expand even more when the game is fully released. I like the direction of the story, very eager to see what they do with this, usually games like this are very lack luster in this department, but I have high hopes. Aside from basic early development bugs, this game has been amazing, I highly recommend it, especially at it's current price.

Just a quick note this game is in early access and has been for not very long. These things could change at any moment and most cons are small and not very important. I think this game is fantastic. 

Cons
- Save bugged out to where the time stopped completely, making it so we can't progress. 
- Dandelion puffs will spas out on occasion. 
- You can't loot other players backpacks.
- If you fall in water while holding something you can't pick it back up.
- I have had multiple wolf spiders outside of the main spawn.
- Armor stays in your inventory even when equipped.
- You can only drop one item at a time.
- Sometimes mobs health will reset too quickly (around a minute) after you stop attacking or when they lose aggro. 
- You can only craft one item at a time. 
- A visual glitch when joining friends that resets your weapon durability until you hit something with it. 
- Story is very short and unfinished, although that's to be expected for right now.
- A bit pricey for an early access game.

Pros
- Runs as smooth as butter, even for my partner that has a 970. 
- Looks absolutely stunning visually.
- Music is beautiful and matches the game well. 
- Very unique concept for a survival game.
- Has taken a lot of mechanics from The Forest (like wood cutting). 
- Multiplayer works with no issues what so ever. 
- Story thus far is very interesting (what do you expect from obsidian). 
- Map is a decent size. 

Negative Reviews
Do not listen to most of the negative reviews! They're from people that don't know how to read descriptions (I've seen lots of people complain about logging into Microsoft even though it says it on the steam page), don't know how to use Microsoft's app to play multiplayer, and have no idea what early access is supposed to mean (or sometimes even dog on it just because Microsoft is a 3x A company).

My Thoughts
This is an early access game and it was released in this way only a few days ago. This is something you should really think about before spending $30 on a game. All in all I would say if you don't mind waiting for future story updates, don't mind there not being a ton of content, and enjoy the genre then go for it. I do think its a bit pricey so if you're short on money or are still on the fence wait for a sale. Its definitely a great game and I can't wait to see whats to come.
The game is really fun if you like survival games that are similar to the forest, but the game just needs a little more content

A great example of what a Triple A developer can accomplish through an Early Access release.

Enemies are buggy, pun intended, but they work to an extent, pathfinding needs refinement as enemies can glitch into places they shouldn't be, or they just won't find their way around your house. Enemies are also attracted to your base and will come to destroy it, so build high off the ground if you want it to last.
Base building works but could use refinement, some floor and wall placements don't magnetise to where they're needed and sometimes you'll have to glitch out a placement just to get it to fit and walking over a wall where you have placed roof makes you glitch out. 
Water droplets in multiplayer, especially those from juice boxes can make your Co-op partners crash due to latency and really large "water clouds" can happen which act like a small explosion and cause these crashes.

The Story is lacking pretty much everything currently, yet the area you can explore is massive, and interesting things are hidden away enough so that finding them is a small story of its own. Certain parts of the map, like other research rooms hidden in trees and underground are currently locked and seem inaccessible because the content will come at a later date.

The core mechanics of hunger and thirst are a little troublesome at first but you can survive 4/5ths of a day with filled meters and finding clean water isn't necessary as most food fills you right up, you can just drink dirty water and have a snack to be fine from then on.

The art style is refreshing, character commentary is cute while being slightly repetitive, the gliding and jumping mechanics are just okay, they work but can get stuck on objects here and there. Character and Item hit-boxes need to be refined and walking into objects with physics can make them fling off into orbit.

Overall it's worth the price seeing as I've dipped my hand into lots of Early Access titles before and they never had the depth this one has right out of the gate. Obsidian has done a good job and considering their record with games, I doubt this one will be forgotten by the Dev team. 
If you enjoy The Forest, this is a very similar type of game but for a different kind of experience.

The base building is a bit basic and has some graphical quirks (clay foundations passing through grass walls, for example) and it isn't 100% reliable (spiders, bombardier beetles, gnats teleporting through the walls, for example) but it is pretty fun to find the best designs and the work that is put into them is a good challenge without being too tedious (except finding enough dandelions before you have the T2 axe.)

I have 25 hours on record at this time.  I do not usually write a review but due to initial release, sometimes the rating gets dragged down by early adapters and initial launch issues.  What I will say, is this game is beautiful.  It is a blast for us to go from nothing to seeking out Wolf Spiders on purpose (and still getting decimated quite frequently, HA).  It is a game much more enjoyable with a team, in which we have 3-4 players on at most times.  
I play almost solely survival games and can say that this game will be one of my favorites as long as content is released regularly.  I have had the occasional crashes, glitches (most frustrating is the chest glitch where if there is only one spot left open in the chest it regularly deletes whatever item you try to put in that spot), and other random frustrating events; but all-in-all this is a great start. 
This game definitely needs some refinement and content but you are still only limited to your imagination and combat is great with teamwork.  If you're looking for a visually stunning game with great potential for the future, this could be the one.  I think the price is decent considering we all want to get that additional content and content requires devs which requires money...

So far the game has been quite enjoyable. I love the style of it (The ants are absolutely adorable) and I believe the game certainly has a lot of potential. If you're interested in getting an early start in base building and learning the survival side of things, by all means get the game. However, it's not without its issues.

The story is done within 20 minutes of starting a game -- kind of to be expected honestly, as the game is in early access. I don't generally play these kinds of games for the story and lore though, but rather the creative aspect of it. 

It's fun choosing a base location and finding where might be ideal. Some areas, which I found out the hard way, are going to face bug infestation no matter how well you try to fortify it. I personally like this factor though.

There's various bugs that make the game a bit difficult to play.
- Getting caught in a web can force you to kill yourself, as it'll sometimes trap the player in the web even after it's destroyed. 
- Backpack issue. While I haven't personally dealt with it, my friend who I share a server with has had his backpack fall through the map, making it completely inaccessible. 
- Crashes. It feels like once you spend so much time in a world (multiplayer), the game will frequently crash for no reason, making it impossible to play. 

Overall, I would recommend the game if you're interested in coming into it for the survival aspect of it. Even then, play with caution -- there's numerous issues that need to be addressed. I personally didn't mind paying the $30 price point, and even paid for a game and a half for friends. However, others might say the game isn't worth that price point yet, and I can totally agree.

Grounded is an utterly fantastic game, Obsidian once again showing off their skill and talent with creating a game that's just plain fun.

While the game is still not 100% complete, the story of the game as it stands can be completed in under 20 minutes, the $30 price tag is still more than fair when you're given an entire backyard to roam around in, challenging enemies to fight, and an atmosphere dripping with so much vibrancy and life that it feels like you're actually living in this tiny tiny world.

Over all, I'd give this game a rock solid 6/10. It would be a 9, but because the story isn't finished, the odd game bug (lol) here and there, and the fact that some areas of the game LITERALLY have "Under Construction" signs on them, I can't grade it much higher. The developers are apparently going to have monthly updates though, and if the wasps on the box art are any indication of what the future of this game has in story, that 6 is going to shoot up higher and higher before you know it!

Maybe keep them more bug-like but replace the scary spidery parts - eyes and fangs mostly - with something like a pair of googly eyes and a goofy mouth.

3) The physics are still a bit wonky. I keep accidentally launching materials and smaller bugs into the stratosphere.

BEWARE SERIOUS SPIDERS - Arachnophobia alert here folks, jump scare at least for sure!
[Detailed Review]
With over 100 hours on xbox pc game pass before buying it outright on steam I have a lot of respect and love for this game. As a streamer who plays and streams a variety of games for 10-16 hrs a day 7 days a week I have to say this game took me by surprise. It was on my radar the second it was announced on xbox game pass. I am a Gen X baby folks so I grew up to the Honey I shrunk the Kids movies and was all for a game featuring that universe. I was to be honest worried the dev's might mess this up as many have before with so many other games recently. While there are a number of issues and minor glitches here and there as in any game still in development, this game is from the start addicting.

Small size about 4 GB total download, that is crazy small for this great game!
Not only do you get to run around the back yard as kids shrunk down encountering all manor of bugs and life as you would expect, but you get added to that a surprising great and well thought out base building feature!
The initial game at the time of this review has a small main story side that you can go through in not too long if you put your mind to doing that and little else in your life...<looks around innocently>
There is tons of replay ability here though folks there really is. From easter egg hunting [4 leaf clover cave anyone?] to building up a fun large base for you and your friends to use when playing together to farming up all the components to make all the gear you and your friends will be needing too!
I can easily say I have already over 100 hours in and more to come as I work on my base now and look for solutions to the thieving ants! Little buggers will sneak into your place in search of loot [food] from your storage, even through walls!
100% recommend this title to any and all ages!

Problems:
---------------
Minor clipping issues with playable characters.
Graphical glitches some times with items in your hands [only happened twice for me] Spear overlapping the canteen
Ants able to loot through walls even from ground to higher levels of your base into even the acorn chests. Nothing is safe from them thieves I tell ya!
Inability to pick up items in the water or really manipulate them..example berries that fall and you need or building materials that you lose because you suddenly need to leap in the water to avoid a huge spooder from hell ripping your face off.
Wolf spiders in single player need rebalance.
Things I would like to see added
------------------------------------
fencing 
railings/banisters for the stairs and other things we build like patio's etc
queen ant, bee's, wasps, hornets, mantis, slug, snail, frog, mole, rat, mouse, raccoon, cat, dog, humming bird, crow, butterfly, moth, mosquito, dragon fly, fire fly, earth worm, centipede, caterpillar, different ant types, bat, venus fly trap, edible berry's, carts, bikes, siege weapons to use as base defence, able to go into other houses near by yards, able to dig underground bases/ditches, ability to tame creatures like in ark and even breed them? ride some? Maybe explore inside a house? Ability to add text names to chests, markers and more please!

There is room for improvement in the combat and building systems but so much potential, also a surprisingly scary game, like its cartoonish but I had to fight a Wolf Spider during night next to my fire and it was like something out of a movie. So far I love this game, it has a wonderful aspect of exploring, thrill, and survival. It has nice tier progression thus far, I'm hoping the tier progression grows further than tier 2 (idk if it does, if it does I haven't gotten there yet). The graphics look awesome in this game. I am hoping for some sort of ability to increase backpack size since your weapons and armor take up slots in your inventory, and your inventory is fairly limited since the meat of the insects don't stack unless it's jerky and everything else only goes up to stacks of 10. I do enjoy building in this game, however, with the limited amount of weeds/dandelions around you and with no way to carry more than 5 at a time (unless ant armor), it is a bit of a pain to run back and forth 20 times just to build a small base.

There are pros and cons in this game, but overall it's a really fun game. I can't wait to see all the other implementations when it rolls in. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival, building, exploring, and doing little mini quests.

Its early access so I expected falling through the map and multiplayer desync but some parts were a bit much, especially berries (endgame material) never being in sync is really annoying and getting stuck in spider webs after removing them is just pepega, you are beta testing their game for free. If they'd paid a child to test their game they would find all these obvious issues in an hour...

For the actual gameplay you'll spend 10 to 30 minutes on the story before completing it. Then the only thing left is going through the whole map beating up enemies, specifically with a weapon made from ants, as later weapons are literally all worse. There is no better weapon past what you can make from ants; enemies you can slap down with your bare hands. Once you have full ant, you can probably take on Wolf Spiders, which are currently the hardest enemy. Beside equipment there's other content, and it isn't finished, they probably started working on it last tuesday by the looks of it. We found probably well over 6 lab entrances which were locked off and a bunch of "under construction" tape where there's literally nothing there.

We cleared everything & made the highest tier endgame equipment and it took about 7 or 8 hours to get to that point at a casual pace and made our base pretty and have an endless suply of food, water and healing potions (drinks). If that's worth 30 bucks, go ahead and buy it.

Warning: At the time of writing, it is *clearly* early access (as advertised). If you get annoyed by missing content, bugs, and crashes, then you might want to wait for a more complete experience.

It's the well-known genre of basebuilding/survival, where you can build a base, explore, and gradually get better resources and equipment. It works well. Both alone and with friends.

What I think makes it stand out is the visuals. It is a unique setting – and it also looks great!

Pros:
* Looks great
* Plays well
* Original setting
* Fun both alone and with friends
* A ton of potential here. There is so much fun things they can easily implement and build on this.
* Scary spiders, but they have an arachnophobia-setting you can use to dial back their appearance to something less scary!

Cons:
* Very Early Access. It just released. This means there is a chance you will run into frequent crashes or gamebreaking bugs requiring you to start over or reload an older save – although it has not been a major issue for me.
* A LOT of content still missing. It is clear more is planned. There are locked doors to several bases/labs that you can't enter, and several areas are literally marked in-game as "under construction".
* Bad pathfinding for the Ai enemies. It is often trivial to make them get stuck somewhere silly so you can just slowly take them down with a ton of weak arrows from a safe distance. I hope they improve this, as it makes some things a bit easier than it should be.

My recommendation is based on the assumption that they will actively keep building and improving on the game; especially adding more content and story.

The short version is that this is a great game well worth the money, the fact that its EA simply means that they are going to continue to develop this game with adding more content and fixing bugs for free.

I have seen many games that are more jank and with the same level of content or less for the same price being sold as a finished product.

If I were to compare this game to another I would have to compare it to The Forest, which even today still feels like an early access game that people genuinely enjoy. Grounded has more polish and more depth than the Forest in its current state and there is plenty more to come for this game.

If you enjoy exploration, survival and sandbox base building style of games but wished there was one with more of a challenge, this is the game for you, the combat in this game takes skill in timing with blocking and attacking and learning enemy attack animations much like dark souls and is about as punishing where you have to return to your death spot to retrieve what was lost.

The Good:

- The graphics are great.

- The combat although a bit plain is challenging, rewarding and satisfying to watch the bug guts fly.

- The exploration is decent, the map is not overly large at least as of yet, but it is beautifully crafted and I believe they plan to expand it.

- The base building is simple and clean, the blueprints snap together with ease and minimal restriction.

- The crafting is simple and intuitive in its current form and from what I have heard directly from the Devs is that they plan to add QOL improvements such as proximity crafting from materials stored in chests that are close enough to the crafting station.

- The Story for now is extremely short but this does not go into the Bad list since the story albeit short is also great for what is already in and there is plenty more to come and if they continue with the same quality I am excited to see what they come up with.

- The replay value of the game so far is great, depending on where you build determines how difficult your life will be and there are plenty of different places to build, plenty of different resources to gather, plenty of upgrades to craft, with more still yet to come and last but not least the reactive environment keeps things fresh and challenging as bugs wander through your base to ether steal your things or to settle a beef they have with you from earlier.

- Good for facing your fears... anyone with a fear of spiders or other insects may possibly benefit from being able to face their fears head on.

The Bad:

-There is not much to put in here that is considered a long term issue as most of these things will be ironed out over the course of Early Access but I figured I would post them anyway since they are current issues and need something to put here.

-Outclassed, some enemies feel a bit overpowered and I have not got far enough into the game yet to know how many tiers of gear there currently are and how much easier it makes taking on the tougher bugs but I suspect that in the future we will get higher tier gear to help out a bit more than what we have now making the game feel a bit less tedious and still offer a challenge which like the rest of the things in the bad list will probably all be sorted out at some point in development.

-In General the UI is a bit buggy, The UI and controls with keyboard and mouse are bit janky when it comes to backing out of some menue screens like crafting or radial wheel. Sometimes the escape key does not back you out of the window and you have to click the button with your mouse. I rebound my inventory to Tab instead of I and Tab will open the Inventory fine but will not close it again and instead shifts the current highlighted UI slot.

-The bugs are bit buggy, sometimes they spawn in overwhelming numbers, and can clip through your walls or even spawn in your base if its big enough.

-The lack of one specific graphical option Depth of Field, what this option does is changes the focus of the player camera so that distant objects and terrain are either blurred or crisp and clear as things right in front of you, and on one hand I can see why the devs left this option out, it is very much apart of the atmosphere of the entire concept of the game, the feeling of being shrunk down and the world being much larger than what it should be and the blurry distance is apart of what makes that feeling come to life. However I still feel that option should be left up to the player to decide.

On The Fence:

- I am a bit half and half on how I feel about the Price of this title at least in its current state. I paid $40 CAD and feel it is far more than a fair price for the final product once it releases with all the content they plan to add and all the issues ironed out. I also feel it is a bit over priced for its current state by about $10 CAD but after a few updates I expect that the price I paid will be right on par with what I expect to get for my money.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys being creative with building and exploring in a hostile and challenging environment. Or anyone who just wants to smash some bugs!

We need more character choices, ones that aren't super campy and annoying would be nice. I want a 'bad ass' and a 'goth' kid. 
The building is very janky right now.  Hard to build walls, as any hill of leaf gets in the way, and critters WILL come right through the slightest gap.  I want to be able to build into and around the environment better.  Currently you're better off with a square base on a flat open patch. 
I really really want some character progression, some level ups, some perks, some stats that increase.  Want more personalization in the characters too, different outfits and things.
Needs more crafting, building, gear, variety. But that is to be expected in early access.
I encountered a program bug or 2, but in general things went very smoothly, including multiplayer which was so easy to jump in and out of. 
Lastly, they need to figure out leaf physics better, specifically the Clovers.  You should be able to walk through small plants, pushing the clover leaf out of the way.  I found myself getting stuck on small plants and clovers pretty regularly.  

Awesome game!  If survival crafting is your jam, this is the AAA version you might have been wishing for!  Bravo Obsidian!  Keep up the good work!

The graphics are amazing and I love the concept, I've wanted a game like this for a long time. For an early access there's a lot of content and plays really well.

It's quite early access at the moment however the game looks stunning and runs okay, I would give it a chance if you don't mind the price point at the moment. Once some more features for the story get added it will be insane and definitely worth picking up.

As for the survival aspects, you build bases, gather resources and make armour. It's similar to the forest but instead of cannibals it's insects. Which in my opinion makes it a lot scarier and a lot more fun. The spiders look amazing and because you're tiny they really do scare you half to death. Not many games scare me, but this one in particular causes me to have full on panic attacks when I'm playing just because of how threatening everything looks. It definitely feels like an atmospheric horror survival game. I might have some deep seeded arachnophobia but it definitely gives off those vibes which I'm loving.

Love the game, if you really like survival games (think of Ark, Rust, etc) this game is really for you then, featuring insects of course, plenty of map to explore, things to collect and you can even go underground into an ants nest, super cool.

So far no weird game bugs or glitches (except for the actual bugs that are in the game of course, many insects), although building system could be a little polished as the placement sometimes goes a bit crazy at certain angles and positions.

Game runs super smooth, doesn't require a very powerful PC at all, can easily run it at maximum graphics while still having decent FPS on a laptop with a GTX 1050 without starting a fire.

I have no regret instantly buying this game after only seeing a tiny bit of gameplay, I wanted to see the rest for myself and I love it so far.

I have never feared spiders, including the big ones like tarantulas and such but this game is teaching me to fear them like a arachnophobe, I still refuse to use the arachnophobia-safe mode because the hella scary looking spiders make night time and certain places a whole lot scarier and more interesting at the same time.

Some spider species like the wolf-spider and such will wander around at night, very hard to kill, certainly scared me multiple times and will certainly prevent you from staying at the same spot outside for too long if you don't have a base yet.

9.2/10 game, can't wait for more content, early access already is very fun to play and worth your spending!

The story isn't anywhere near complete and you reach the end of the story within fifteen minutes of playing the game. If you don't build a base, then it just leaves exploration, and that itself is limited as there is about an hour worth of exploration and then you've pretty much seen the entire area within this release. All in all, for those that have a game pass, great, give it a try as you are already paying for it, but for those of us who payed the full price for it... what a sham!!!!!!  Microsoft, if you are going to use us as your debuggers, at least give us the f'ing game for free as you are getting us to do your own work for you!!!! After playing it for roughly 4 hours , I can honestly say that this game has  potential to be the next "Minecraft" or "ARK Survival Evolved".

Grounded is developed by Obsidian games who are known for their superb RPG games and great storytelling and narrative experiences. Obsidian touches are clearly present in this game, especially with the narrative ,the environmental story telling, and art style that they're aiming to add to this game. While most of these features are still under-developed, this is still a solid survival game by itself. 

Pros (+)
- Unique setting 
- Art Style and Graphics are impressive 
- Great Base Building Mechanic 
- Great Stability for an Early Access Game 
- Tutorial does a good job at introducing the basics 
- Cross play with Xbox and PC

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Cons (-) 
- Game world feels small
- Few enemy types (Spiders , Solider Ants , and  Robots are probably the only hostile species in this game ) 
- Underdeveloped story features, with the story content leaving you wanting more


The game is no where near finished  it still needs more updates and features to make it worth your money, however, in its current state the game is fun and the survival loop would satisfy fans of this genre.

Review: 7/10

Probably one of the best survival games out there. Yes it does currently have bugs, crashes etcetera. But I really do believe that this game will get better and better, it has a lot of potential! I have played it solo so far, and I can say that it was a very fun and learning experience. I can recommend building a base that is positioned up high, because your base could otherwise get attacked by soldier ants, larvaes or spiders and that could get really annoying. If you need to kill a spider or a stink bug, standing on top of a lady bug and shooting them with arrows could make them fight each other and you could just run back and watch them kill each other. 

Another tip is using a bow and arrow to shoot down the droplets on the leaves instead of using an axe (it's just way faster and your arrow doesn't go to waste)
If you easily get scared then I would recommend playing with friends, that may boost your confident. 

Is it worth buying the game? Definitely! There are a lot of bad reviews but I would just ignore them. The game will be updated monthly and I'm excited!
Game is more terrifying than you'd think. As long as they keep working on the game, it's going to be fantastic. I can't wait to play it co-op.

Alright so, i like games like terraria, minecraft, subnautica and the forest.  ( I also like multiplayer games but this is the most relevant)
And now for the review from my POV

PROS:

- Great and interesting theme of "honey i shrunk the kids"
- Cool art style of the game
- First and third person
- Good mechanics ( you can jump on leaves and stuff + way more ) 
- scary big spooder and ladybug and stuff
- Epic to play with friends 
- Nice terrain
- Good building mechanics

CONS:

- Not the best optimized game ( however this is understandable as it has just came out ) 
- Very short story ( will discuss more at the end)
- Limited armor and weapons
- Not the easiest to play alone

Overall this game has incredible potential, I really recommend playing this game in early access and joining their discord to give feedback to the devs. With a complete story, this game will be one of the best. The exact same thing happened with subnautica. It was an ok game but with all the feedback it became really good. Lets just hope that obsidian entertainment really work hard on this game and give frequent updates!

Do bare in mind this game is early access: I find the game mechanics easy to use, the play itself and interactions between characters (in multiplayer) a delight to hear and see. there are some teething problems as all early access have them but I feel the developers are passionate about this game and these along with monthly updates will fix some of the issues. I saw a bug posted that games overwrite themselves but I have not found this, The newest save may be taken as the single player save, even when you've hosted a server ... just scroll and your singular saves should be at the bottom. Hope this helps! I highly recommend, very nice concept and well thought out characters, looking forward to the next update 27/08/2020

Take note, this game is very early in early access.

3hours may be a short time to give a positive review in , but that's because there isn't a lot of content here. The game is still very bare bones but is still awesome to say the least. It's early access, you're buying into the future of the game, and ultimately that future is looking bright.

Story wise, there's about an hour of story if you focus on that, but i found myself just wanting to explore and reach the edges of the map because the wow factor is what makes this awesome. Running from terrifying giant(atleast to you) spiders and jumping off of high places, using dandelions as a glider are some of the things that make this super cool. It has a really vibrant look and the building is quite simple and enjoyable. It's awesome to find the normal sized tech in the garden since you're like the size of a button on it, and it's just awesome. 

The game has a lot of potential, it's just really early in development. You'll have a good few hours of fun and then it's back to waiting on the next update which the devs have promised will introduce more story, creatures and just overall additions to game.

As of now, I do NOT recommend buying the game as it is at 30$, August 1st 2020.

I know for a fact that the Devs did not even bother trying out this game, is this game fun? Yes, absolutely... when it works, 70% of the game does not work properly though.

- Enemies fall thorough the floor and can hurt you or inside rocks
- Enemies WHEN YOU FIGHT THEM, will instead ignore you and attack your base instead (If you are near or defending your home) Im talking about, you smack an ant in the head, and he turns around and rather hit your base

- Enemies can hit your chest and items, through walls, doors, height differences. It does not matter if you put a chest in the middle of a room, or if the enemy is close. If they sense a chest, they cant just hit it no matter what. No ands, ifs, or buts

- You will get stick mid-air, with no way to escape except for re-loading or killing yourself via menuing, when something you're standing on gets destroyed.

- Traps in general don't work, the log traps DO NOT damage enemies, but they damage YOU, how convenient...

- The only NPC that is pretty important since they give you blueprints for more recipes, bugs out and disappears, or the door to him is locked MEANING. That if you played in a world for 10 hours or more, you just lost potential crafting recipes.

- Equipping Armor, does not remove it from your inventory space, so it just clogs up inventory space. In what world? Every game literally doesn't have this issue, so how-- whatever

- I understand its in early access, but 30$? Really? I GUARANTEE, if you buy this game, you will experience everything I listed without even trying to look for them. 

- If you die, you drop your backpack full of stuff. Pretty normal, no problem you can just pick it up. But sometimes, the game will make your bag completely disappear and you just lost all your weapons, armor, and whatever else was inside

- Tier 2 gear is 95% USELESS, there is only 2 items that is Tier 2 that is better than a standard weapon, That is the Insect Bow and the Insect axe, a tier 1 sword is better than the tier 2. An axe (which is primarily used to  collect mats) is better than most of the actual fighting weapons meant for combat.

- Enemy who aren't suppose to be near the beginning area, will spawn in HORDES within the 1st day (sometimes) and when this happens it keeps on happening, its impossible to defend yourself at this part of the day

If you made it this far thank you for reading, I know I just listed negatives, but I honestly enjoy the game, but with this many issues I cannot in good heart recommend such lazy development, you dont even need to be a dev to see the obvious issues, at 30$ no less. If you really want to play the game, just wait until they actually fix the game and save yourself the money. There isn't much to do anyways besides base building

and even then, good luck when enemies rather fight your base than you. Peace out

Okay so, i'm going to give you my honest opinion on the CURRENT state of the game.

Pros.
1. For an early access game, it's extremely well polished, a lot of content as far as I can tell.
2. Major company, expect continued updates without abandonment, safe purchase.
3. Fun. Base building and mechanics offer a lot of things some games just DON'T have, that i wish they did.
4. Co-Op/Multiplayer
5. A new take on the survival genre. I would say "oh my lord this has never been done before" but it has, just not like THIS.
6. Optimized, sort of. It runs incredibly well on single player. I have words for multi-player, but that's for later.
7. Fantastic, cartoonish graphics. 
8. Entertaining jokes and character dialogue.
9. Interesting, dynamic environment.
10. There's more, but i can't think of it all lol.

Cons.
1. 30 dollar price tag per copy, while technically early access. Big oof. 
2. Extremely convoluted microsoft/xbox login requirement to play multiplayer, especially for those who don't already have it
3. Multiplayer ping is terrible, since it uses xbox/microsoft servers instead of steam
4. adding friends is unnecessarily hard, and again requires them to have an xbox/microsoft account too
5. Arachnophobia mode doesn't quite make the spiders any less fear inducing, but it's not as bad as you think
6. some game progression hiccups and minor lack of clarity, but it's early access so it's no big deal


SUMMERY 
So basically, the game is really fun and has a ton of pros and it's clearly professionally done.
I had issues when the Demo came out and couldn't really play it, but i don't really mind now that i'm here and i can play it NOW. I was super looking forward to it.
Granted, there was NO warning on the steam page or otherwise that a microsoft/xbox account is required, and i wouldn't have known since I don't typically play their games since they don't fit my genre preferences most the time- but the game is fun enough to make up for it and I wouldn't consider refunding or not playing it over something so trivial.

However, i'd really love it if they would include local co-op or some way to get around having to use their servers to play with friends/family/loved ones. As it stands, i expect there to be issues, but I don't honestly care for xbox, microsoft or their stuff/programs/whatever. I'm literally never going to use the xbox/microsoft account for anything beyond this and i don't really want to be forced to have it just to play with some pals. 

Again it's not a huge deal, just annoying. 
If i had to give it's CURRENT, UNFINISHED state a number rating out of 10, it'd be a 7/10. I'll bump it up to 9 if they make local co-op and 10 if they either make it cheaper and add local co-op or fix the requirements for multiplayer. 

If you're a foam at the mouth, void your pants, 360 kill shot xbox fan and you want to tear me limb from limb feel free to comment and make it known idk, i'm just some random on steam. 
But if you have some info i'm unprivy to that might change my mind, i'd love to know tbh.

I have never had an audio issue with any game in early versions or full releases in my time PC gaming until this game. Being on the title screen was fine but as soon as I got into online play it would take over my entire computers audio and make it sound like trash. Refunded after 15 minutes of game play.
i like it

4/10 currently (this will most likely change as the game progresses), with what's available in the game. The game should probably be around about 15 bucks (usd) with what's currently in the game. Took me 8 hours to do almost everything. This game is similar to The Forest/Subnautica, and less like Ark/Rust. If you like the former games you might like this one. It's less of a full time job than the latter. 

2070 super
9700k
32gb ram
installed on an m2 ssd

The Good
Sound/Audio - The tracks I've heard are decent and all of the sound effects are decent quality (insects, weapons, water, and etc).
The game runs perfectly fine for me. I had one crash and I think it's something to do with the auto-save feature. * I should also mention I played the game entirely offline and don't use cloud saving for any games (this has caused issues in the past too).
I think the tiered system and base building is fine for what it is now, but could use some improvements (I'll talk about that in the bad).
The animations are pretty good. Though there's not very many overall per insect.
The models are pretty good and all of the equipment (structures and environment too) that you can craft is detailed pretty darn well. So, props to the artists of that portion of the game. 
The game looks pretty good, fits the theme it's going for. However, I think the map is pretty small. The whole yard is only like 30 feet by 30 feet....so that's a really small house. Just think 500 cm is like 16 feet. That's like from the pond to the oak branch. 

The Bad
"Reactive World" - "Explore this immersive and persistent world, where the insect life reacts to your actions.". This is such a reach it's really not even funny. They react to you moving, attacking them, using a lure, or lose aggro if you get far enough away. That pretty much applies to every game...ever. There's nothing unique or innovative about anything the AI does or how it reacts.  Honestly, it's bare bones and pretty bad. 

Tons of insects get caught under large rocks, roots, or the ground. They can clip through this and attack you. They spawn in your base while you're away. They barely react to each other at all. Sure some of them will fight occasionally. If they can path to each other correctly. Otherwise it just looks like they're dancing. Orb Weavers don't attack ants, but will fight lady bugs, which will in turn fight ants. So rock, paper, scissors of reactive insects/arachnids I guess. Their pathing is overall terrible.

Base building placement is awkward and really needs perfectly flat ground. It's functional, but looks terrible. 

The UI is very simple, and looks like something a first timer made with UE and put up as a demo on Itchio. 

That wraps up the good and bad, but I'd like to mention a few gripes I have outside of this review. Anyone giving this a 10/10 or a 0/10 is pretty much useless as a human being. And I'm surprised at some of the positive reviews for this game. This game does nothing new or innovative over games we've seen a dozen times over the past decade. The only thing different about this and it's clones is the aesthetic. 

The crafting is bare bones and just functional. There's nothing unique or special about it over it's competitors. 

The combat is equally bare bones and just functional. Attack (some weapons have a power attack), block (timed blocks negate all damage and stagger), and uhhh...that's it. 

Anyway, that's about it from me. I'll update this review as updates come out. I can't tell you if you'll like this game or not. I'd  suggest watching some video's or streams of it, but I honestly found those pretty boring. And had to try it myself to see what all the fuss was about (it's over-hyped right now in my opinion). I hope things improve quite a bit, but if we go off the experience of it's predecessors. It's going to have the same core element flaws even after release.

Watched Markiplier on youtube play this game and was very intrigued. Its a super cool concept! Its not just another clone copy of a survival game like minecraft or astroneer. The environment is super cool to be in, between looking up at the tall grass, or the house out in the distance. Graphically beautiful, the sounds have a nice ring to them. Its entertaining to just walk around and explore and see whats around you. All the dancing bugs, the giant baseball, the big oak tree in the middle of the yard, THE FUCKING SPIDERS. I have never jumped so far out of my seat than when a wolf spider jumped down on top of me from a rock above me. Campaign is short, yes, but its said throughout the missions and multiple menus that the game is still in beta and that there is more to come. If this game continues on the path, and continues to add more quality content to it, this game could be up with the greats of survival genre games. If you arent playing it, and are going off the slim bad reviews, I promise that you are missing out on a very entertaining game. 10/10 would recommend.

I hope to see ALOT of improvements, but for this early stage in the game its everything i expected.

As a dev myself I CANNOT support this game.

Sure i guess it looks promising, but really selling a game 40$ for an outstanding 23 minutes of content is a huge NO-NO. It looks pretty but really the story was just ridiculously too quick to complete (even tho more will be coming...maybe in a year or two...), the building was clonky yet it was one of the selling points, I encountered multiple bugs from the random DC to for example opening a container and finding my controls inverted... Bugs that should not be present... not even in an early access title.

This is A CASH GRAB and they only want people to throw money at them hoping they can eventually make something decent... Just another game released in a beta state asking you to pay full price. Again, i understand the early access concept being a dev myself,

This game in clearly in a testing phase, and as such a big studio such as Obsidian should PAY to get decent QA and not ask potential buyers to PAY to... Test?! a game... They will only push people away like they did for me.

All in all,
Building = clunky,
Combat = clunky and unbalanced,
Story = boring (and only 20min of content?)

Not a SINGLE working mechanic attached to a 40$ piece of trash.
