Long time fan of survival crafting games, and this one is really interesting to me. The concept of a survival crafting game set as a shrunken kid in your back yard is pretty novel. 

The visuals are pretty good. Though it is not well optimized as having it on ultra puts my 2070 super up to an average of %65 usage when running 1080/60fps, but that's to be expected at a fresh early access release. 
Gameplay is pretty basic, you explore, gather resources, craft tools and homes, research new items, and work to find food and clean water. It does have a story which makes it more interesting. Also there is a tutorial and optional difficulty setting for the non hardcore gamers.

The only reason I don't recommend it at this point is due to a high latency issue a lot of people are having when trying to play with their friends online. If all you're interested in is single player then you shouldn't have any issues. As soon as the "high ping" issue is taken care of I'll change my review to a recommend.

The ants have become my beloved buddies :-)

While taking the game for a test drive via the demo, I was a bit jumpy and I made the mistake of attacking one of the ants (because I assumed the ant intended to attack me), at which point, I was quickly mobbed by the other ants and died... total playtime: about 3 minutes. 

Despite my short life in the demo version, I was hooked and I bought the game as soon as it became available. 

This time, I decided to try and implement a more passive strategy regarding the ants and, by using that strategy, I've learned a valuable lesson... don't judge an insect by its exoskeleton. I've survived for about a week so far and the ants have become my curious and comforting companions :-) I mean, it gets kinda lonely playing single player, but the constant curious clicking noises of my ant friends has kept me company (unlike the buzzing of the not-so-nice knats lol).

This kind of surprisingly complex and entirely unexpected relationship feature is just one of the many amazing aspects of the game. The graphics are BEAUTIFUL! The controls are easy to use and make logical sense. The entire premise of this game is an absolute dream come true for those of us who grew up watching the "Honey I shrunk the kids" movies. I personally don't care about the multiplayer aspect, so I can't speak to the issues people have brought up about that part of the game, it doesn't impact my opinion in the slightest. Overall, this game is AMAZING and I definitely recommend it!
Fun game it's a must buy if you like games like this. A honey I shrunk the kids vibe.

This is still in early access so there are some things you have to understand when it comes to polish and amount of content. With that said, a buy-in of $30 should mean there is a good chunk of content here. I would say right now there is enough here to justify the price tag. I would like to say that it is very fun and has a lot going for it. Lots of quirky humor in Obsidian's style, lots of really fun and challenging game play, and over all a really pleasant experience. 

Actual game play is really solid. There are some fresh mechanics in play with the crafting and building system and a lot of familiar mechanics for folks who are used to survival games. 

Base building is pretty great right now. I would say there are a few recipes that are low tier that feel too expensive, but other than that the risk/reward balance is pretty good. A couple of nit picks I had is that my first base I started next to a plant I thought I could chop down later, I can't. So I had to adapt my base around it and eventually move it. The other is that no matter how well and tough you build your base, bugs will just get in. I have a solid clay foundation and the ants just spawn inside of it. 

Survival is fairly easy once you find a good spot. Food is pretty easy to find and gather once you know where to get it. Hydration is also pretty easy and doesn't feel like a terrible chore.Which is nice because the hostile bugs in this game are way OP for how often you find them. When I first started I was taken out by a wolf spider in the spawn area. Finally found what I thought would be a good location only to find another wolf spider den very close by. I then moved to another area and found yet again another wolf spider den. I think they either need to dial down the amount of bugs, spread them out a bit more, or make them not as tough.  

Over all though, great game and has a lot to look forward to. I am really excited to see where this goes, and to see more stuff get added.

The gameplay is very entertaining, especially if you're a fan of the genre. It's always great to overcome that next hurdle and discover new stuff to create, and how you can implement into your base or game. 

I was more than happy to put the money down for this game as Obsidian has a great track record and I'm sure it will only get more engrossing and complex as time goes on. 

Also, you can parkour on top of the grass so that's a big win in my book.

I had been interested in Grounded since the previous demo release. I had watched a couple people play and was pretty impressed by the overall feel, the attention to detail and of course, another crafting system to work through.

Having invested a few hours now, about 6, I can say I am massively impressed with how much is here already in the base foundation of this game. It's beautiful, the crafting system is rewarding in sometimes challenging ways, the areas you can stumble upon and sights are creative - I seriously cannot wait for more to be added. 

Between being stuck in a ramshackle house I made from clovers as a orb weaver corners me into submission, or riding lady bugs into glorious battle against stinkbugs, I am thrilled with the little details that are already here that make the game great.

While I can't sing praises loud enough for this game, I will be honest in that there are a couple bugs here and there. No, not the ants or gnats. Sometimes the game will crash but if you're patient, they generally resolve and overall this game is undoubtedly worth it. If you ever wanted to have that child like sense of wonder about your own backyard again, go for it. You will not regret your decision to support an absolutely impressive game on it's first steps to becoming an all time favorite.

The graphics are good, the 2 hours worth of story mission I did was cool, but overall this game is just not worth 30$ and I'll walk through why.

This game has time-gated progression, which I hate when my progression is time-gated. When you discover a new resource, such as grass, dry grass, clay, etc., you need to research it at the science base to figure out what you can craft with it, you can do this 3 times every like 20-30 minutes or so.

This game on "medium" difficulty has enemies that can only be beaten by cheesing the environment. Large enemies like spiders can kill you in a single hit and some enemies (wolf spider) can also run a lot faster than you so if you get aggro you are just dead. Only way to beat a lot of these large enemies is to get up high on a rock or something and shoot them with bow and arrow. Its like how you can cheese kill dinos in ARK.

I've played mobile games with more content. It's sad to say, but you can pretty much do everything you want to do in this game within 3 hours. The story mission is fun, but it's also ridiculously short. Building a base is fun, but I've noticed that after building my base, bugs will spawn near it (Larvae, ants) and come try to wreck it. It's pretty stupid that they can destroy your base so fast, and that they spawn in so often. Within like 3 hours Larvae tried to wreck my base 3 times. Enemies should not spawn on my base, nor right next to it. I could understand if I was running from enemies and dragged them back to my base, then it would be my fault if my base got wrecked.

My final point is that while the map is cool, it is currently super small and the points of interest really aren't that interesting. A lot of the map is labeled "under construction" and all you can really explore is a small portion of the entire map. I think that they really need to work on the points of interest as well. While it's really cool to find a large hotdog, or a large cassette tape, or a large action figure, or a large soda can, thats really all it is. You get a feeling of "oh that looks cool!" but that fades in like 15 seconds and then you realize that was all there was to that point of interest. These points of interest need to have a little bit more to them, it's hard to explain, but I feel as like MOST points of interest should feel more exciting or rewarding or should just have more to them to explore/do.

Finally, in closing I want to state that this game "could" be really fun. I like the graphics, I like that there is only food/hunger, and overall the building is not terrible. The map is cool, the characters have good voice acting, the music is good, but overall it is just not worth 30 bucks. There is not enough content here to keep most people engages for longer than a few hours.

Did not expect much going into this game, very weary of early access titles now days and honestly if it wasn't for a couple of my friends wanting to coop the game with me I would not have bothered, however colour me surprised! 

The game is a blast, and you can tell a hell of a lot of love has gone into crafting it, as well as the ai and their habits (I hear ant hills are basically fully simulated little worlds). Any fans of the Forest will feel its very familiar but also completely different at the same time, and not in a bad way. The gameplay loop is very well thought out and even though we reached the end of the intro story in our first play through (It being EA doesn't surprise us that much, the forest was the same at the start) we could tell the game will have a lot more to offer eventually. And for now its a really fun little survival sandbox which none of us thought we needed but anyone who grew up in the 90s will 100% appreciate the setting. 

Overall, great start to a game that has much promise. Gameplay is fun currently and the mechanics are really well thought out. Its also just crazy to experience the world at the scale you are in this game, honestly interesting for anyone whether they are an avid survival game player like myself or if you are just interested in biology or ecosystems, or if you just like cute insects, beware of the spiders though!
So far it is great game, and there is still so much more to come. looking forward to seeing were it all go's.

Really fun game! Definitely worth playing! The premise is great, visuals are amazing and music/ambience is really good.

I usually don't enjoy survival games because of a lack of storyline and the propensity for them being a killfest with other player killing on sight, making them a tedious version of a PVP shooter since you still have to manage things like eating, drinking, sleeping and whatnot only to kill or to be killed by someone else with zero purpose and then repeat. Boring.

However, Grounded is not like that! It is a really fresh take on the premise similar to "Honey I Shrunk the Kids!" with an interesting mystery to solve (though I have to admit, I have yet to fully play out the story) and this means there are actually objectives and purposes to work towards.

Also, spiders..damn..those spiders are scary. Really smooth controls too. So far, not a single bug was encountered.

Definitely worth playing!

Early Access Review. Grounded is effectively a survival game version of "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids". It's well optimised, the building system is polished and it's really immersive to play in, with tons of potential. If you enjoy base building and Crafting, there's probably 10-20 hours of that to do, although I'll admit that the story content is painfully short right now (can be done in less than an hour). I'm excited to see what the game will add over time because my brain is full of ideas for this little world. One of the best games of the year so far and it's only been out for 2 days.

Additional
The other important point is to ignore most of the negative reviews saying either it doesn't have enough content or that the multiplayer doesn't work. 1, it's Early Access - you're not paying for a finished game; you're paying to be part of a development process. If you expect it to be finished, have more content, or it's too expensive, wait for it to be released. Leaving a negative review is worthless. 2, The multiplayer works perfectly, we played for 5 hours in a group of 4 the day after release. It's one of the most polished Early Access games I've played.

[Pros]
+ Gorgeous, especially the lighting
+ The design of the game world is impeccable. You can climb tall things to get a better view, landmarks are easy to spot, creatures move and interact with each other
+ Blueprint system for planning in advance
+ When you throw a spear at a creature, it gets stuck in it
+ Mysteries
+ There are landmarks scattered around the garden which are great to explore as a tiny person.
+ can craft armour out of bugs
+ multiplayer works (but it uses microsoft instead of steam, which is shit and confusing)

[Cons]
- Even on medium, spiders are way too hard. Best armour and weapons before spider tier, still only got one to 25%. If a spider decides to walk through the base it will just kill everyone. That's fine for early game, but they need to be beatable later
- The 'leave feedback' section is literally just an icon system for happy/sad face and a location. There's nowhere to type actual feedback
- It uses Microsoft instead of Steam for multiplayer, which is a genuinely shitty interface for playing together. Once you eventually manage to add each other as friends (which, unintuitively you do by 'following' each other), it took us a while to work out how to stop hearing everyone twice.
- Pathing could be better. Creatures regularly get stuck in large objects or underneath bases

[Wishlist]
- Renewable materials. Looks like dandelions, clay and quartzite don't come back yet
- Bigger inventory through crafting bag upgrades
- Weather. Rain would be awesome
- Some kind of building to explore. I guess the house is ambitious, but there's a shed in the garden
- More weapons and items to craft, with longer production chains
- Some kind of leaf boat you can sail on the pond
- More story
- Custom characters and clothing customisation
- When you wear armour, it shouldn't take an inventory slot
- Fish
- Subnautica bases
- Multiplayer bosses
- More kinds of bugs. Bees, frogs, snails, worms
- Some sort of power system for lighting using a battery for power
- More traps (think Fortnite PVE)
- More points of interest that aren't trash. Garden ornaments?
- Craftable paragliders
- I'd love the landmarks to have more things to explore, like more complicated rubbish rather than just cans

Solid sandbox game. There are a lot of things this game still needs, and it could probably be $10 cheaper in it's current state, but it is a solid title. Co-op, at the time of writing, requires at least a free XBox Live account and uses that friend's list. Story is over very quickly on release, so most of the loop right now is exploration and upgrades. Many quality of life features other survival games lack. We'll see how this plays out, but I think this is worth a play, even in it's current state.

Grounded is a mixture of The Forest's survival mechanics and backyard-childwonder. You can build bases made up of weeds and grass with your friends, fight bugs n spiders alike, explore, explore, explore! The game is fun at first but, definitely repetitive with the crafting and going out to find things. It loses my interest pretty quickly but, it is in EA so I guess we'll wait and see. I don't recommend getting this title thinking it's going to be smooth experience with setup. You need to have an Xbox Live account in order to play with friends online, which for me personally wasn't a big issue but, after witnessing my friend having a lot of problems with it puts me on the same boat with people donking on this game for the integration. I'd give this game a month or so before really investing into it since right now there isn't much to be had, even with friends. I look forward to the story developing with future updates to keep me invested or whatever else these guys might throw in. My review is tentative.

Great game, but incredibly short so far, not sure its worth $30 at the moment. If you really get into the building and craft progression then you can probably get 10hrs? But updates will come free, so I can see it being worth $30 in the future and would like to support the developers.

As for bugs:
 - Day night cycle completely breaks later in the game. Night never occurs anymore.
 - All cooking stations (dew catcher etc) break and become un-useeable later in the game making food tricky. Probably has something to do with my broken day/night cycle.
 - Lots of inventory bugs with items, straight up, getting deleted.
 - It seems as though the soda/juice boxes run out? I don't know if that's a bug or intentional.
 - Attacks on your base aren't well distributed. Sometimes there will be 4 attacks of 8 or 9 larva each in a row. My base isn't even that big. I'm afraid it will be destroyed. There are no good defenses. You can't really attack them through walls without breaking them and they just destroy traps almost instantly. So there's no point in having walls or traps.

This game looks really cute, and I love it! I have only encountered 1 bug (error) so far: the game shut down on starting a new game on "Woah!" difficulty twice in a row. After I got it started, I've had no problems loading  into my saves.

The main story quests takes about 30 minutes, so for the time being this is an exploration/base building game. That being said, I got a new storyline quest by exploring. I have not yet found out where to get the information needed.

Playing on the hardest difficulty means that I die really fast in combat, but that's what I wanted. When I first started on normal difficulty, the enemies felt a little bit too squishy for my liking. I WANT to be killed by bugs and spiders many times larger than me. It makes it a lot more scary to play. If you really need a hard-to-get bug part, be smart. Get your enemies to kill each other, then swoop in to loot!

Base building is really good for early access, with a lot of buildable items. Gathering building mats is definitely a long process that involves travel and hard work. You also have to keep in mind that you're living in a place where every creature wants to kill you, destroy your stuff, and steal your food. My tip: build off the ground!

Pros:
>Excellent frame rate and very little, if any, stuttering or massive frame drops
>Beautiful and fun to look at and explore
>A fun take on being tiny in a normal world
>Solid crafting and survival system
>Lots of potential
>Ladybugs are helpful and cute
>Spiders, if you're into spiders

Cons:
>Spiders, if you are not into spiders
>Enemies randomly spawn in your base in numbers that you cannot defeat alone
--This wouldn't be a big deal, but you need Xbox Live to play with friends. Why?
--Enemies, such as soldier ants, are hyper aggressive and will cause unbeatable swarming
>Larger monsters can basically two or three shot you, even if you have good armor on
--Said enemies are almost always as fast or faster than you. Good lucky running away
>There's zero way that I have found to secure your base/building supplies
>Regular crashing, especially in regards to storage and cooking food
>Early story is incredibly short and the daily quests offered don't really inspire continued play

INTRO:
The game was put on steam a little early even for early access standards, and it suffers for it. The story is almost non-existant and playing it now is just kind of spoiler for whats going to be added. But it is a very interesting survival game, that takes a bit of direction from games like ARK and The Forest while still leaving plenty of room (small things joke.) to be a very different game.

THE GOOD:
AI behavior is very interesting and is unlike any other i have seen in a game like this. There is a lot to explore, and that means there is seemingly a lot to do. There is a lot more items then i expected there to be with how early in development this game seems to be.

THE BAD:
While there does seem to be a lot to explore it is much to the games detriment. As tho it seems like a huge world to explore and discover. Its just a standard backyard, and with as behind the game seems to be with most things you would expect from a game. Then i think it would be cheaper to just lay on your side in your own backyard if it does not pick up soon.

4.  Grub hunting is fun.
5.  You can climb up lawn lights.
6.  Being chased by spiders (which is actually very scary)
7.  Collecting and building in this game is so much more fun than most survival games.

10.  Hopping from clover leaf to blades of grass.

THIS IS AN AMAZING GAME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

as a few have already said *not a game for the faint of heart / bug phobic...! - don't let the *fortnite GFX* fool you

but if you can get beyond that - and if you love *Sandbox survival* with quests - and if you were raised with *Honey i shrunk the kids* - that film from the 80s... not the epic series that was spawned from it in the 90s... they even have one of the kids look like Nick  - the geek with glasses!
---------------------------------

Review:

For what it currently is  - an **EARLY ACCESS** game with a *limited* story (we only currently get the tutorial - but don't worry hopefully i will appease you below -)

- Ok so as i said - we only get the tutorial *Story Oppener* at the moment - which if you are smart, can be completed in 20 mins or less... **Don't forget it's early access!!** there is  still a TON more things to do!

Build/sruvive/craft

Analyse certain items to learn more recipes (for base/food/health/utility/etc)

fend off a storm of Mites  - squash Gnats (as big as your head) - ride a lady-bird (not a mount, you can just stand on it lol) - run from spiders (i do not mind spiders at all - or let's just say - i never used to... these critters WILL make you jump (at least the first time)

Build a multy floor base on/in/around a tree (or wherever you like)

If things get too hot, you can cool off in the pond and go for a dive.... Why not use you genius and repaire some tech?

---------------------------

other than the above it is just your *typically generic survival game* - but let me tell you this... its the best one i have ever purchased!!!

10/10 - i hope this get's completed - but it is Obsidian so i don't doubt it (KOTOR?)

----------------------------

And to expand upon the quests - once you reach that *certain point - where the tutorial ends and it becomes sandbox* - talk to the cute little guy who looks a lot like a *disco-tech* *Tik-tok* from Return to Oz - he has some quests for you - and you can unlock more things for your builds

What's the point of building walls when a never ending stream of hostile insects (that were't there for hours) can just randomly destroy chests from behind walls? I was constantly losing huge inventories of supplies, only to finally see a chest shaking  from inside my camp and realize it was being hit by something like 7 feet away. Whats even more fun is the incredible ease that the game will just have these never ending larva swarms break into your base and keep you in a death lock. They kill you, and no mater how damaged they are, the second you respawn, they get all their health back, and are still on your body. The very definition of fun and enjoyable design. Good job devs.

I have played Grounded for about 5 hours on and I have to say that I really like it. I like survival games, in general, but to be shrunk down to slightly smaller than an ant adds a whole new dimension to this genre. You research the items you find to unlock new recipes. Blades of grass and dandelion stems can become your shelter. Insect and arachnid parts become armor, food, and crafting ingredients to help make quality of life improvements and advancements. Since it is Early Access at this point, I am sure there will be a large number of additional features added, so I am really looking forward to where this title develops. There are small things that seem glitched here and there, but it isn't really anything major. I had a spider spawn inside my scaffolding one time, which made it really easy to kill. Sometimes when things fall, they seem a little erratic, but I think that stuff will likely be tweaked in the future. I could see some pretty fun multiplayer mini games being implemented into the game. I'd like to see something with a window box fan and the dandelion fuzzes that are used to slow fall from high places where you would compete for distance or something like that. There are a couple of quality of life improvements that I would like to see added to the game - a move stack option as a keyboard shortcut and/or right click menu option, being one, but it isn't all that inconvenient to click and drag from storage to inventory or vice versa. Again, it could be something implemented in the future. I hope so. Overall, though, I would say that this game is one of the top ones on my current list and I expect it to continue to get better. I'd say if you like survival games, building games, or are nostalgic for something similar in ways to "Honey I Shrunk the Kids," go for it and check this title out. I don't think you will be disappointed.

This game is amazing!  I love survival games, and played through the popular ones. (Subnautica, The Forest, Green Hell, ARK, 7days, ect.)  The gameplay isn't exactly unique, but the charm and concept is spectacular.  For how gorgeous the game is, I have had almost no issues.  I would love to see more insects in the game.  Just imagine how terrifying a dragonfly/centipede/Mantis would be?  It would be almost like a leviathan class creature from Subnautica.  The game does have its share of glitches, and I have had to start over again due to a bug, but this is an early access game, and that should be expected.  I really recommend this game if you love survival games, but go into this game knowing it is not complete.  The early reviews were mixed because the cost and glitches.  The cost is nothing considering how amazing the game looks and feels, and the glitches will be fixed as the community helps bring them to light.

So heres my input at 55 hours playtime (games only been out 2 days at this point). 

Graphics: Game Looks and runs beautifully. 

Bugs: Being early access I am surprised at only a very small amount of bugs. Runs great and bugs aren't that game breaking. My friends and I have been playing pretty non stop.

Content: Its EA. But there is a extreme lack of content. Within 2 hours of having the game, I beat the game. There are other things you can do after beating the 'storyline' though. Lots of tunnels / caves and things to explore, as well as science to unlock. But that only unlocks bigger / better bases and such. There are parts of the map that are under construction though which gives hope to alot more content. 

How much fun can you get? Id say you can enjoy this game for a solid week of hardcore playing before your burnt out. Or a month of playing a couple hours a day. This IS NOT something you will play non-stop because it does get very repetitive. After beating the strongest spiders out there right now, theres not a whole lot more to work for. The best armor in the game can simply be found. As well as the peppermint and you can obtain them immediatly upon joining a new game aswell. Ive put 55 hours in the game, and i feel like i've done all I can do.

I do stand behind this game because it has MUCH potential. And for a 29.99 price point, you'll get your moneys worth. Just praying the Dev's keep updating this!

Not recommended...yet

First - just beware the story line for this game ends very quickly. It's early access so that's okay with me, but just be aware of that. 

The good: Amazing concept. The world is very immersive and realistic. You really do feel like your 2mm tall in a back yard. 

Here's why I don't recommend though:
The problem with this game is how incredibly small it is. For example - to walk from the first major landmark you come to in the story (laser pad thing) to the second major landmark in the game (the tree, which is where the story currently ends) takes 94 seconds. 

If I assume that I am 2mm tall in the game (based on the size of the small ants that look like grease ants) and that the average person walks 1.5 meters per second, that converts to an in game distance of 15 centimeters (or about 141 meters of real life walking).

Looking at the in-game map, that is about 20-25% the distance of the entire map. In other words the entire map encompasses about a square meter. 

Granted this is an estimate, but even if my estimate is off by 100%, that's still a very, very small world. 

When I have fallen into other survival games - the first thing you get is a sense of scale and loneliness. In other games sometimes it's a long time before you come into contact with anything except trees and dirt but in this game you are interacting with bugs and objects within seconds. 

Maybe this game is intended for kids with short attention spans (all the characters are kids so maybe that's it) but if you're used to playing traditional survival games on the PC I don't think you will like this. 

I am definitely going to try it again in a few months to see where it is.

I have a library full of disappointing early access games but this one has really surprised me.

Pros:  - A great setting
          - Base Building that actually works on launch
          - Terrifying Spiders and Insects (nighttime has a great atmosphere)
          - Gorgeous art style and great voice acting
          - Tool and Science progression
          - A good core survival game to build a story mode on
          - Working Multiplayer which has (after 20 hours) only had a handful of crashes

Cons: - No Skill tree implemented yet (not sure if this is planned)
          - Difficulty may put some off initially (medium still has spiders who can 1 shot you if you're not careful, reccomend 
             easy mode!)
          - Not much penalty for death since there's no exp or skill system so it can take the edge off gameplay.
          - Solo gameplay can feel unbalanced compared to multiplayer as enemies are the same strength and outnumber you 
            quickly.
          - Some crashes and visual glitches (Giant Arrows and Frame eating Juice bombs!)

Overall: 8/10 Would love to see what they do with the story and skill/exp progression in the future.

TL/DR: 10/10; Gameplay is great, multiplayer stability is great, playing solo or with your friends is equally enjoyable. Really hit the nail on the head with this one, looking forward to countless hours in Grounded. 

While being in the same vein as ARK survival evolved or Conan: Exiles, Grounded is a breath of fresh air! A much more casual experience, with less severe death penalties than the aforementioned titles. The wonder of exploring a beautifully created world, that feels immersive and exciting. The ability to speed up time, and skip the night using a bed, makes the early game a bit more manageable, while giving the opportunity to increase the risk/reward when you gain the confidence to take on the night. 

connecting with my friends and playing co-op was a snap! And being able to join in on my friend's game, if they need help, or they can join mine if I do, really fantastic. Some folks will probably lament the lack of a PvP experience, but to me, it doesn't feel like I'm missing out on anything. And, while the Multiplayer is limited to 4 players, limiting the number of people you can play with, it certainly does seem to make it much more stable when playing online (A critical failing of certain other titles in a similar vein). 

The cycle of finding new resources, analyzing them, learning new recipes to build and be able to take on new challenges, for new resources...etc. Feels smooth. Learning the "tech tree" does not feel clunky, or overwhelming. I really can't say enough for how great this game is... and it's only in Early Access. I look forward to future content, and am particularly hoping to see a Frog introduced as a "boss" for taking on with your friends :)

The last year or two have felt bland for me when it comes to gaming. Obviously I've wondered if I'm just burnt out on games, or if gaming is in some truly dark times right now. 

This game has been 8 hours of straight up fun so far. Me and my buddy, we went down an ant hill to get quartzite. He held the torch and the hammer and went to work on the quartzite while I fought off a horde of ants. 10 minutes of fighting go by quick as we dive deeper and deeper into their lair. Finally we came to a dead end, but not just a simple dead end, we arrived at one of their food chambers.

I love, love, love details like that. A world that feels like it's completely realistic in it's layout. Obsidian rarely dissapoints and I've realised once again that it's not that I'm burnt out on gaming, it's just that most games have been completely souldead for the past 5-10 years.

There is a good start here however the map needs to be made bigger. Something I hate insects target structures they have no strategic reason to its just mindless destruction of your stuff and it feels like a sad attempt at creating a challenge where there wouldnt be. Spiders should maneuver thru the grass and climb over things not rampage thru like an elephant. They should be scary cause they move like a spider and are the size of an elephant, however that aspect is not here. We should have small spider that descend from webs and sneak up on you. Larva should burrow a bit. None of that is the case right now. 
I have seen better Early Access and I have seen worse. buy it if you cant wait. If you can wait put it on your wish list and wait until this time next year. Times like these I wish there was Yes, No, and Watch as rating. I would give this a solid Watch.

This is a beautiful game. Everything from exploration to combat feels satisfying. At the time of this review, the game was early access, so there were a lot of... BUGS!

“It made me feel tiny, like Thumbelina!” - Deandra Reynolds

I had a blast playing this in the first few hours. This game has so much potential and I hope the devs know what they are doing and take all the feedback to good use. The story cant really be called a story and its just really short yet so dont except to much. The concept, graphics and sounddesign is really beautiful. I already imagine an online multiplayer with pvp elements, taiming mechanics and even ways to move through air, more creatures like snakes, bees, moles, mosquitos, worms of which some are introduced as bossfights, an immersive coop storyline that you can just enjoy together with friends. Alot of things need to be fixed like: inventory improvements (making it transparent so you are more aware of your surroundings), creatures glitching into various places, better building and snapping mechanics, sound effect glitches with no volume, general movement and AI of the creatures need better pathfinding and behaviour. Obviously its early access and these things will hopefully be worked on in the future and the game will well be worth its pricetag. If you want to support this game sure buy it but if you want a great story coop game I would surely grab something else.

Early Access--So, bugs and glitches are most definitely to be expected. It's a beautiful game that makes something as typical as the common backyard feel like an epic adventure in some distant, unexplored land. Fun in single player mode, but a real blast while playing with friends. My only primary gripe is that the base-building mechanic is in dire need of repair. Seeing as how this is a Survival game wherein base-building is a primary mechanic and necessary for long-term survival, I feel as though THIS is what needs the most immediate attention. Otherwise, I can't wait to see what new adversaries get added into the mix. Mantises? Hornets/Wasps? Snakes? Rats? Can we befriend the neighborhood squirrels and forge uneasy alliances with the Ants and other such insects that are tired of the Spiders' reign of terror and other OP BS? I'm sincerely looking forward to it. Just...please polish up that base-building mechanic before anything else.

TL;DR: The best way to get arachnophobia or prasinophobia, or both!

The game itself is actually fairly stable, and I have found few bugs (HA HA BUGS, BECAUSE THERE ARE BUGS IN THE GAME HA HA) that seem to ruin. There has been only one CTD in 20 hours of play at the time of this writing, and so far I haven't seen anything that does not appear to be working as designed. A few balance issues could stand to be addressed, and the game desperately needs to recognize player bases to avoid enemies spawning inside compounds, but I do not know if this can actually be fixed. 

I honestly can't tell if the dynamic ecosystem promised actually exists. Respawn times for spiders and so forth seem a bit fast, but this could still be working as they intended. 

If you're here for Obsidian's story-telling chops, I have to say you're out of luck right now. The story quests take less than 25 minutes to complete if you follow them directly. There are radiant quests you can follow to accumulate the currency used to buy items from the one NPC there is. Other than that, you'll find the most fun right now through base building, survival, and exploration.

The last thing I will add here is that this should be qualified as a survival horror/open world game, not just open world. The spiders move quickly, quietly, and are nearly instant death when they show up. Nothing is more terrifying than seeing blades of grass move in the distance, wondering if an eight legged menace is about to show up and make you scream like a little girl. Honestly, I don't think the arachnophobia setting makes it any better, as the floating bobs are way creepier to me. Still, I don't think I've ever seen more realistic spider movement portrayed in a video game. Thank god they can't currently climb.

This is expensive for Early Access, but I believe there is more than enough content to justify the $30 price at launch. Seeing as though it's clear that they already have more content lined up, likely in short order, I think this is a solid investment of your time and money.

Recommending ONLY on the condition of frequent, heavy updates, and soon.

The aesthetic and characters are cute and charming. The core loop of hunting/foraging, crafting, exploring, in the context of "you are tiny" is novel and fun. But this is an early access game to its core - it's unoptimized and chugs hard for how it looks, and the "story" can be finished in less than half an hour. Me and my coop partner have thus far averaged 1 crash an hour between us.

I bought the game for an afternoon of entertainment, and it provides. I'm looking forward to playing the finished version in another year or two.

This is a fantastic survival/crafting game. The graphics are superb as is the gameplay thus far. It is going to be even more fun as the game is completed, but even the Early Access is so much fun to play.

As it stands as of writing this, it is without question a game designed for 3-4 players. It is a social game. I have played thus far only solo, and I can say that it is a challenge to go it alone. It is still a great deal of fun playing solo, but certain challenges (such as spider defense) is highly improbable. With a team... I can see it.
As of now, multiplayer is via XBox Live only, with more expansion to come.

All in all a very fun game, and brief bits of comical dialog to boot. If you are of the survival/crafting type, get this now and enjoy it as it unfolds.

highly polished early access game.  I was hesitant initially due to the first reviews having a lot of negativity but then realized a lot of them were due to the idea that you have to have xbox live to play with friends.  The second login is seamless once you connect and set it up the first time and xbox live is free for pc.  So that out of the way..  

the graphics are very polished, the optimization, at least for me, seem well done as i can't recall having any kind of lag or problems with jitter etc during my first hours of playing.  it's a whimsical, cartoon style take on the survival genre but be warned, as cute as the graphics are, it is, indeed a survival game.  you can and will die in early game - the spiders are as deadly as they look and as of yet i  have not found an effective defense or offense against them.  I'm sure that's because I haven't progressed far enough.  i will be honest, if i was not a veteran of survival games i would be far more frustrated with the difficulty of spiders and some other enemies.  

The building is interesting and though I haven't progressed far enough for any advanced building (if there is any in game yet idk) but I like this aspect and it's very important to my gaming needs to be able to create bases/buildings and craft items.  The mechanics of it, seem to take a cue from the forest or games like it, you place a ghosted "plan" for a piece, be it wall, door or window etc then build by adding the needed materials for that.  i feel like it's so much like the forest in this aspect that some of the devs must have played that game but that's just speculation on my part.  this isn't a bad thing whatsoever as I love the building in the forest  too.  

Story is standard fare for survival games, and personally I do like story in games but for a survival crafting game it's not entirely essential to have it.  The story is short simply because it's incomplete so that's mostly all I can say about it at this point.

Things that I think can and hope will change: 
Difficulty even on "mild " only adjusts hunger and thirst, seems that the enemies are still just as deadly.  I expected this to be adjusted also but if it is lowered, it's not by any noticeable amount.  The number of characters and/or character customizer would be nice.  I'd like to either have a better choice of characters or be able to make one myself.  I hope they add something along those lines later, as  i don't think there are major reasons to make a limited set of characters since it doesn't seem like their personalities or uniqueness is much more than aesthetic if you play in 3rd person view.    

Even the qualms i have about this game are pretty minor,  so this comes highly recommended.

So far this is a great game. Shame only like 20% of the story was released for it, but after exploring the map in it's entirety I can tell they are going to be adding quite a few more biomes to the 'backyard'. The only issue I have thus far with the game is that you do not have the freedom to build 'wherever' you'd like. Specific building pieces will not attach to assets already in the game and you are forced to build in places where you'd not really desire to. Another drawback is that the only way to carry 8 things is with a full set of Ant Armor. I would like to see some form of cart that you can bring with you and load things in or on to, much they did with The Forest. This would help if the location you built in wasn't near other specific resources like weeds and such that weren't close by. I've also been wondering if Weeds actually respawn after some time because the ones I have chopped down so far for my base have not come back. 

But overall this game is great so far and I know many more things will be implemented in the future. I look forward to seeing more of the story itself and what new biomes are added with new insects and items.

Interesting premise. I like the world but right now the game is exceedingly punishing. Your enemies are relentless and some of them institute an instant kill. I think this game has a lot of potential but needs tweaking. Food spoils far too quickly. Water can be a challenge to find easily depending on the area. I do have faith that some of these complaints will get ironed out. I look forward to future updates. Pausing playing this until it's less frustrating. For full context, my friends and I built a base near a research station. We were bombarded by spider after spider, cockroaches, etc for 45 minutes straight. We literally couldn't secure the base. I finally gave up and logged off. Your mileage may vary. Right now I'm going to give it a thumbs up because it's the environment is incredible and it has a lot of potential. Will revisit and change my recommendation based on changes made.

This game is amazing. I'm a huge fan of a good survival game and this provides everything I like including multiplayer. I understand that many are complaining about multiplayer not working however I was able to get it to work first try with very little issues. I played with 3 other people all in my own household so that might be why it worked without hiccup. Although it should still be going through the internet before it gets to my hosted game. We all play on PC though so maybe that's why. We also had a friend join in from across the country and he joined just fine. Everyone has to ensure they are logged in to a valid microsoft account. Needless to say this game is EARLY ACCESS which means it's not ready. It drives me crazy to see someone complain about a game and it's bugs when the game isn't even finished yet. If you buy this game you should fully expect to run in to random things that don't work. Maybe your location, ISP, connection, or PC build are preventing you from connecting to or hosting a multiplayer game. Maybe your game will randomly crash on you or something really weird will happen in game. Again, THESE ARE TO BE EXPECTED!!! IT'S EARLY ACCESS!!! But if you can accept that and enjoy the game for what it's current state is then you will have a blast. The amount of content the game already has is awesome. I don't like spiders but I don't fear them. This game, however, makes you fear them. I absolutely love that they can instill fear without resorting to zombies or some other overly used tactic. This is also a game that I would be totally fine starting all over again if need be because of a crash or patch. Although that hasn't happened yet. So far 5 of my friends and family have purchased this game and absolutely love it. For an early access game the Devs did an amazing job prepping it before releasing it for us to test out. And knowing that it will only get better with more content makes me even more excited to keep playing.
Great game, super nice concept. Need content badly - Me and my buddy ran out of objectives in 4 hours :)

The game is very polished for being early access. There is enough to do right now to keep me occupied for a while. It has its glitches (the most frustrating is when bugs get their health back) but its worth supporting.

Multiplayer is riddled with bugs. While this game has an incredible amount of potential I want to recommend this game but can not. 

There isnt much relaying of information leaving you to wonder what to do and figure out. Seeing tons of items that can be harvested with a level 2 axe is quite frustrating when you have zero clue how to get that axe. Not to mention base building is completely pointless since worker ants and larva come around and destroy your base before you can even finish building it. The weapons are no better than punching with your fist except weapons swing slower than your fist. There is a button designed just to preview your hot bar, what a worthless idea that was seeing as you cant move your items when you press v but you can view and change it all in your inventory. 

Now multiplayer, dear god what a disaster this turned out to be, well its constantly crashing with half of my friends group were not even able to play. And lets talk about the lag somehow this game has a high ping when youre playing with 1 other person in the same country? Yea thats not acceptable, not for any game.

You can listen to the people who say its early access, but to me that just gives companies like microsoft who have the capital to put out a completed game reasons to not complete a game because they know the cash will flow in regardless.

 I feel completely duped by purchasing this game even after trying the demo and anticipated its release. With the state its in it is not worth 30. Its not even worth 10. Hi so far I have played for 9 hours that is 9 hours Non-Stop. i love this game already. if you like survival games more then likely you will to.

Played a bit more / Solo only.

- Regular working coop mode unavailable.
- Very good game optimization.
- Incomplete and average story line (because of EA)
- Textures glitching required polishing (because of EA)
- Ants/Bugs attacking/walking through walls (because of EA)
- Spiders able to kill you through walls while you are hiding in aluminium can (because of EA)
- Food/Water consumption required small balance but more or less ok (because of EA)
- Lady Bug can pass through all you base walls and kill you in 2 hits. Base walls remain undamaged (because of EA)
- Backpack falls in texture after death (happens 3 times in different map spots) (because of EA)
- Weapon damage / Mob HP - kinda joke. Looks like all this figures scripted in game randomly without any sense. (Most probably because of EA)

- No character creation available. You have to choose between 4 available teens.
- Base structures/modules glitching after game restart (because of EA).
- Combat with mobs is annoying. If you take a break for 2-3 seconds just to take better spot for fighting Lady bug is out of combat with fully regenerated HP (because of EA? hope so)

Overall: Average stuff for 30 Euro. Not recommending at that stage - because of EA.

A great core game and fun for hours and hours. Other reviews bash the game for lack of content, but in all honesty it's already more game than I've gotten for $30 elsewhere. The team has a solid game design and the Unreal engine will make anything we imagine doable. Want to ride ants or ladybugs? I can see that happening, as well as a slurry of mods for building everything we can imagine. The game has huge potential and is already a great deal of fun. A patch or two will sort most of the minor issues and give the content criers some tissue.
Spiders

Don't buy into the review bombing because "The story is only 20 minutes long", this is a survival game, go survive. There's a good bit to do even in these early stages and everything feels hand crafted with love and attention to detail. Everything that is in the game is gorgeous and well thought out. 
I have crafted a number of "tiers" of armor each one as awesome as the next. I was still finding new materials to craft with 10 hours in. If you take the time to explore you can see how big a play area the devs plan this to be. Some areas are taped off, but the yard is going to be much bigger than it is now. There are story elements scattered around and I look forward to that part of the game being expanded. Until then I'm off to finish crafting my lady bug armor, expanding my base, and look forward to putting in many more hours. The future of this game is bright.

PSA: Don't store too many things that could attract bugs because it will!

Amazing game so far, super fun concept and a mysterious story, so many hidden secrets.

This game is probably one of the best early access games I have played. The game itself runs great on my 1060 and is stable and smooth. The menus are a little clunky, but once you get used to you find some hidden intuitive features. The main reason I wanted to play this game was the cross-platform coop with my Xbox friends. The coop itself is a blast, working together to defend your base from larvae attacks is exhilarating. As some have mentioned the story mode is only about an hour max, but that does not mean there is nothing to do because as with most survival games the focus is on surviving and upgrading your items.

Pros:
Great Coop fun
Crossplay with Xbox 
Awesome environments that make you feel like you are in Bugs Life or Honey I Shrunk the Kids\
Cool 80's style music.
Good Voice acting
Very small game, not a 180GB install like Ark.

Cons: 
Menus are clunky at times
Co-op is a host-based game, so if the host is not online you can't play. (Would like to see a No Mans Sky approach to Co-op)
Some base building glitches

Overall this is a pretty solid early access game, there is always going to be room for improvements and I hope over time we get small updates adding more gear, items, and story. 

Score: 8/10

Grounded starts out as most survival games do: You’re plopped into an unfamiliar, unfriendly environment and must gather resources to survive, scrounging for food and materials, fending off the occasional enemy or two. But what sets Grounded apart from other games of its ilk are its setting, premise, and design subtleties that make it a distinctly approachable and enchanting entry in the survival genre.
Rick Moranis

Even though it is in early access, it's a graphically beautiful game. And for those familiar with the "Honey I shrunk the Kids" series of films, it'll be nostalgic. I've only played in survival so these comments are purely from that perspective.
PROS: Immersive setting and scenery. A lot of polish for an early access game. Relatively easy to get started and the initial quests lead you along.
CONS: The weapon balance seems a little off compared to the enemies you face. Especially ranged weapons against larger enemies.
I very much look forward to what they have in store as they bring the game to fruition. If you enjoy survival games and base building, it's worth checking out.

Good time with even just one friend, even better with three. Short story for now while its in early access but there is more coming soon in theory. Still lots to do for now with exploring and base building. I think its worth the $30 now and when the updates start coming it will be a steal.

While it isn't worth the $30 it is right now, this game has loads of potential.  There's a story, albeit seemingly short, with some lengthening and bug fixes this game will be AMAZING! Obsidian has lost it.  You don't bring a game to Steam and then NOT use Steam COOP.  It doesn't really matter that the game has good game mechanics and graphics, when you've crashed to desktop three times in the last 90 minutes of game play.  Crashing also locks up Steam causing the game to appear to be endlessly running so that it can't be restarted.  You expect rough game play in an Alpha, but the game needs to work...and it doesn't.

If Obsidian is smart, they will get the game stable for play instantly, followed immediately by getting Steam COOP enabled.  If they don't, this game is going to fail HARD.  I'll take another look at this in a few months to see if they've made any progress, but until then I've had the game refunded and rate it at 0/10.  If you cant PLAY the game, that's the best rating it's going to get.

It is still very fun to play and a unique take on the survival genre that I highly recommend giving a shot.

*Early Access*
Beautiful game that really nailed the “you being tiny in the world” feeling. It mixes a bit of humor, exploration and survival with a touch of horror, especially if you are uneasy around bugs. The building system is well made, and the resource grinding is more about exploration than grinding the resources.
It runs very smoothly but I had a few hard crashes. The autosaves makes it not so bad to catch up on your loss (suspecting the autosaves to crash the game but it will surely get fixed at some point). At this stage of the game, there is very little story to follow, just enough to layout the intro but there is much to explore and many area offer a good challenge (the feeling when you kill your first spider …. Awesome).
So, if you are looking for a story driven game, I would wait a bit before you get it. If you want to encourage the devs, explore that new sandbox and not (too much) afraid of insects, I would recommend it.

So far, the game has been great! It has a few bugs here and there, and I am not talking about insects, cause those are everywhere :D. Anyway, it is still in early access so I am sure those bugs will be fixed! 

Bugs that I am talking about:
- Sometimes insects get through walls! Way I got through it is to create a fence around my building for extra layers.
- Planks and other building materials can alter your movement and cause you to turn. They also fly all over the place when a giant insect walks over them. Not sure if intended!
- Some insects, alike the big spider ones, can slap you through walls. Again, not sure if intended!
- Item drops and arrows can get stuck under clay structures, making you have to recycle them to get to the goodies.
- Drinking water(specifically) from the "Canteen" item, does decrease thirst. Works for juices, however.

That are all the bugs I have experienced so far.

Suggestions to the devs:
- Would be nice to be able to easily see above water when swimming atop of it.
- Not sure what some of the base buildings can be used for (scaffold, inner corner roof)
- Add more triangular shaped walls as rotating the existing one cannot fit in all triangular shaped holes.
- No rush, your game is already amazing!

I have to write this review for all those bad reviews that are not true. 

Firstly anyone who says they completed the story is lying. The first initial quest does take maybe 30 mins if you focus on it but that is NOT the complete story and just the tutorial. You have to collect better resources and kill stronger bugs to be able to unlock more areas where you will find more quests and learn more about the story. This all requires better tier tools that requires time to get.

Secondly those who are saying multiplayer does not work is also lying. Currently there is no way to join other servers but you can join your friends who host a multiplayer game. You must do this through Xbox friend list which is free to make an account and join them that way. This Is not ideal and with time I see it being fixed however being an early access we are lucky we have multiplayer. Also note there is in game voice chat which again is lucky to have for a early access game. 

If either of those reasons are holding you back from getting the game, don't let it. There is a lot of game play for being a early access game. I have 7 hours on the game and have yet to scratch the surface it seems with so many hidden quests and mysterious doors that you need to find a way to open. Also remember this is a early access game so the game will not run as a full released game and there will be more content added guaranteed. If you can get a couple of friends to play the game with you then it will be even better and much more enjoyable.

Had to change it to a thumbs down, simply can't recommend this game in it's current state.

I love these kind of survival and base building games.
The game already does a lot of things right. The setting is insanely creative and fresh BUT there are still a lot of bugs... lmao
The Spiders and worker ants feel incredibly punishing if not outright unbeatable if they don't bug.
Correction, Spiders are currently pretty unfun. Sure they should be punishing dangerous juggernauts, but the aggro resets feel bad sometimes.
Base destruction might be too punishing, enemies literally destroy EVERYTHING you can built.
I played The Forest with base destruction turned off because it was just too frustrating and i spent too much time investing in creative ways to build an amazing base.

The story that is in the game so far took us 80 minutes with base building, it can probably be done in like 10-20 minutes and is more of an intro if anything. You can get an idea of what the game is supposed to be. But not knowing that was a BIG slap in the face when you see the popup telling you the story is already done for the moment.

My biggest concern so far is the crafting interface though, it feels very clunky and annoying to use, you have to go full screen and click through menus. The crafting itself feels slow and unintuitive.

This game has amazing potential, but 30 bucks is 20 too much at the moment if you ask me.

fun sandbox type game

Ok, so after about 15 hours or so in the game i can say that the foundation for this game is very strong. As a survival game fan, have enjoyed most my time in game. The idea is brilliant. Like Ark, it sets itself apart from competitors by not going the zombie route wich is AWESOME. 

Grounded has the same problem all survival games has with AI, which is that they are easily exploitable. Big scary spider? No problem, find a nice rock to stand on and blast it with arrows while it stares at you. this works with any enemy and leaves alittle to be desired as the game almost forces you to take this route due to the simple fact that aggressive insects do ALOT of damage. A combat roll would do wonders here. 

A good survival game has a crafting system too match and Gounded does excellent in this area. Akin to Monster Hunter, you craft almost all your armor and weapons out of the parts of insects you have slain. This leads to cool looking gear and each set of gear gives you perks that can increase health, stamina, block, hauling capacity and ability to wander in the Haze area. its this aspect wich also breeds excitement to what future insects they might add like grasshopper (increased jump height?), mosquitos, bees/wasps (wich have lootable armor already), Mantis ect. this lends itslef with the opportunity for cool weapons, armor and other crafting goods, wich is one of the key corner stones for a good survival game.

The map is somewhat interesting, offering a whole new perspective and scale to the average back yard and making it feel like a entirely new world. there arnt many biomes as of now and some feel a bit underwhelming, the hedge area is really cool with a sprawling upper section of branches to explore, while the floor level is a bit...meh. The haze area did not feel as dangerous as i think it could be. and pretty barren overall except for 1 enemy type that was kind of just an afterthought compared to all the other insects. there is a big oak tree wich players will need to travel to in order to progress the small bit of story that is avialable and this area feels really cool and populated but various insects. Then there is some nice marshy areas that were created by leaky sprinklers wich was a very nice touch. there are also a few areas wich are marked as "under construction", fairly large in size and hope to see some new things that are not already present on the map be added. 

Things you used to walk on and swat away are now all (mostly) predators. From the fierce warrior ants, annoying gnats that constantly bump into you, to huge spiders you can see swaying the tops of grass forest in from a distance as they search for their next unlucky victim. there are a few others that i wont completely spoil with new ones in the works aswell, so i look foward to those. 

Overall, if you are a survival fan that doesnt mind there not being any pvp, i would say give it a try. if you dont like it in the first 2hrs just get your refund. but i think this game holds a huge amount of potential, aswell as having a damn good solid base to build off of. there not much story as of yet so im not going to make any remarks on that front, but it is an Obsidian game, so i trust they will have something good in store on that front.

Even when i am in my base the adds seem to just teleport through my walls and wreak havoc on everything i took a long time to farm up and build inside. If the rate at which my base is attacked is true then playing this game solo is gonna be a nightmare in the later quests like it is for me. [h1] Grounded [/h1]

[u] ** Early Access Review ** [/u]

Grounded is a unique gaming idea that follows up-to four teenagers as they survive, and explore the backyard of a house. They have been shrunk down to "Ant" size randomly and there seems to be some scientific explanation as to why this has happened. This is where the story mode comes in, and you must keep in mind that this game is Early Access as the story stops [spoiler] after you speak to the robot in the laboratory [/spoiler].  This realistically took me 45 minutes to figure out and get to as it's not that far into the game. 

The game prides itself on survival; meaning crafting, building and fighting to survive your common insects (Ladybugs, Spiders, Nats etc). Other than the concept of the game (which is what pulls you into the game) it is very similar to The Forest when comparing survival aspects. Find water, food and craft structures to make your survival easier, and more comfortable while avoiding specific insects. 

Pros: 
+Concept
+Graphically enticing 
+Smooth gameplay (so far)
+Arachnophobia Mode (If you have this you will be glad this setting was implemented)
+Text to Speech (Accessibility option for users that utilize Narrator)
+Story has promise and potential
+Survival aspects were thought out (Drinking water from droplets and drinking dirty water is bad for you etc)
+Crafting abilities are easy and straightforward
+Need to discover uses for things using Science
+Developers seem to be very open to criticism and direction for the game


Cons:
-Voice acting is atrocious, and are cringe
-Character depth is lacking
-Other than the story the game is extremely shallow (at the moment)
-The price of $29.99 (This game is Early Access, yes) This game is easily $14.99 or [i] maybe [/i] $19.99
-No Skill Tree 
-Larger insects are insanely difficult 


It's hard to place a recommendation on this game as it's not finished but the game shows promise. I will place it down as Recommended because you're paying of the development of the game and it has tremendous potential. It's tough with a price of $29.99 but at this moment the game is [b] not [/b] worth the asking price.

It's like that movie 'Honey, I Shrunk the Kids!' but if the kids got viciously mauled by spiders, beetles, and mites.

The 'story' as it is right now is pretty non-existent, and you can 'beat' the main story in like ten or twenty minutes if you know what to look for/where to go. The yard, however, is sprawling and there's a ton of other stuff to see and do, plenty of bugs to fight, and enough grubs to make Timon and Pumbaa swoon.

There's also an 'arachnophobia' slider, and while I don't use it I do think it's worth noting for those of you who don't like our eight legged friends. You also need an X-Box Live account to access the multiplayer aspect of the game, but signing up for that is free and really isn't that much of a big deal, and if you're like me and are only really interested in the single-player, you don't need to worry about X-Box Live at all.

Do keep in mind that the game IS early access, and that stuff is going to be added or changed as the game develops. As it is right now, I highly recommend it if you want to play a survival game with a unique setting.

This differs to its competitors by having no PVP I'm aware of at this stage, but it's the only game I can recall that made me scream out loud. If your arachniphobic (and an adult) just roll with the game as it's designed, even with its seemingly childish art style it is genuinely terrifying, and full of flavour, and after 10 mins the design manages to walk the fine line and come across as rather endearing. This game is a survival game. Think of "Honey I Shrunk the kids in an Ark/Forest (no cannibals just big ass spiders) style way of surviving.  The one con I have is Grounded has very little to offer in the way of a story at the moment.  However, it does give promises of expanding and learning more of a story line in the future.

Now the survival aspect. 
This game is a survival game.  If you want to build, survive, and explore with very few 'quests' then this is it!
The art in the game is beautiful.  It truly makes you feel TINY and in a backyard while looking up at grass blades that have water droplets on them for you to drink from. The detail of the game is amazing.  
You wake up to have been shrunk somehow and have to figure out why.  
You collect resources on the ground just like Ark and Forest.  Instead of cutting down trees, you cut down blades of grass.  You collect everything and analyze it at least once.  One item analyzed can learn you one or more recipes.   A few analyzing stations are scattered on the map (the map is huge).   You build your base with leaves, and weed stems from dandelions to name a few.   You can jump from grass blade to grass blade exploring, but watch out for the moving grass in the distance or near by.  Seriously!  Orb weavers and Wolf spiders galore.  If you have arachnophobia, the game has a sliding switch for that. It allows you to have the spiders not be so.....spidery. Staring up at a wolf spider while running under leaves in a backyard is a bit unsettling for my household when I screamed not once, but twice.  
Grounded is family friendly. If you are wanting to play with your children there isn't any need to worry other than the spiders could be a bit scary.  The wolf spider lurching out in the dark tunnels with you holding a torch is no fun! holy crap! I literally almost crapped!  

Advice for just starting:
The ants are friendly until you attack one.  Attack them in pairs or less if you are by yourself.   
Set markers up as you go until you memorize your surrounding, 
craft lean to's or hit escape and save VERY FREQUENTLY, 
ants will steal your food.
Have fun!  PTSD from spiders engaged.

Enemies are mostly insects (at least for now), and spiders (the biggest threat at the moment) are really terryfing, you instantly get a huge sense of danger upon seeing one in the distance. Even worse when it's suddenly close!

Overall a game with great potential that's very fun to play. Can't wait to see what's coming in future updates.

- Awesome Concept

Cons
- Currently, the story is incredibly short, and only offers a few hours of play-time

- Graphics seem to be poorly optimized, there is no ability to finely tune individual settings, and the preset graphics settings don't seem to make much of a difference in terms of FPS.

I cannot give this a positive review since it currently costs $30 for only a few hours of meaningful playtime. Overall, I still think the game has potential, and I have high hopes for its future.

So! Fourteen hours in so far, and I'm loving the game! To be fair, I'll include some gripes, but overall I am highly satisfied with the current game and what stuff I have yet to see!

* Naturally, this is an EA game, and like it/hate it, that's how some games are made today. Do I wish I had loads more stuff to play with? You bet! Yet I've also played (and enjoyed!) games like Escape from Tarkov and Rust, just to name some 'EA' games. I like the feeling of knowing more new stuff will come in, but that's me!

* Again, EA game, so expect bugs and issues. And issues with the bugs, if you'll pardon a pun. Yet that's what you're supposed to do as you play: Call out the issues and get them fixed! Again, like it/hate it, part of an EA game, get with it.

* Content? LOADS of stuff. Sure, you could make the argument 'but there's like not enough to warrant full price', and you may have a point! But I've been working on finding just ONE Point-of-Interest for the last two days, and I'm excited to both find it, and find ever more stuff: because there is FAR more than what meets the eye here.

* Keep in mind, all of my words are just from a solo player: I highly expect this game to be even better with people! Sure, you may not like the 'Microsoft Account' detail needed from MP, and I can agree, I'd like some more Steam love. Yet if your PC has Windows, chances are you have a MicroAccount, so hush! Sign in, just like if you were booting up a browser.

All in all? I'm very pleased with the game, pleased with what I have seen, and excited for the future. I'm well and truly 'grounded' in this experience!

Launch impressions: This game is neat, but it's what I think of as a "polished early access." What's included is good: the core gameplay seems to be mostly there with a large number of craftables and materials, and the visuals and art are very nice, but there basically is no story at this time (half characters don't even seem to have any dialog recorded yet) and it has a fair number of bugs and balance issues and could use some work on interface.  The survival aspects of the game are fairly light on medium difficulty, with food and water being pretty much everywhere and the only death penalty being a dropped inventory which you can run back to and pick up. Basically right now you can explore the map and build a nice base, but have no particular gameplay reason or story motivation given to do so. 

I don't have any reason not to recommend it with the caveat that the $30  price tag is pretty high for what's on offer right now. That said, it seems about right for what I'd expect the game to become when it's nearer to completion, so be aware that if you're not going to wait for a sale or the game to be ready then you're basically paying extra to get an early look.

Wow, I'm impressed!  The graphics and smooth gameplay would not indicate this is an Early Access title.  My laptop isn't a high-end gaming rig but it's handling everything well, and even the lowest graphical settings look really, REALLY good.  In my 5+ hours of play I have had zero crashes and zero glitches, at least not anything I would notice as a glitch.  

There is very little story so far, but the devs have said that will be implemented later.  Honestly I think tht's a good idea, because I'd hate to get involved with a story so riddled with errors and crashes that I couldn't play. Right now after you make a huge discovery, the story ends and there are only a series of daily missions.  I'm using the dailies to familiarize myself with the landscape and the wildlife, and gathering resources to build a base.  The world itself is very fully fleshed out with a variety of insects already, and more to come.  There are several distinct biomes within a single back yard, and as an entomology nerd I'm really enjoying seeing the diversity and actions of the various bugs.  I haven't heard anything on the subject, but being able to tame some of the neutral insects would be really fun in the future.  

Crafting is fairly intuitive, and a lot of the things you can make area really creative, like the acorn armor pieces. Every new resource opens up even more crafting options, and there are a LOT of resources!  

It's also worth noting that the devs have taken the very real fear of spiders into account and have included a sliding scale of graphical options to make them go from full spider to a series of round blobs, so that the game is more accessible to more people.

I bought the product with a friend to see if it was a good/functioning EA (early access) game. and for an EA game this game is great!
Pros - 
Well made and satisfying mechanics like perfect blocking and armor that has unique effects
great accessibility options (especially for arachnophobia, and even though I have very bad arachnophobia I enjoy the spiders in this game)
A forest like system for logs/building, so you can plan out buildings and your friends can also do it with you
Enjoyable in multiplayer and doesn't feel unfair when it comes to PvE

Cons - which are inevitable but this is also a list of things that either I don't like for a game or bugs that I would love to see gone when the game gets more updated
Xbox multiplayer only. My friends and I all have microsoft accounts, we just launched from steam and he saw my host available to join, no problems there
one very annoying problem is that everytime we reload the world we have to reset our settings (notable ones being motion blur, mics being disable ingame, and subtitles size) 
can't think of anything majorly irritating or any problems besides that, will update review if I find new stuff I like/don't like, bugs, etc.

tl;dr you're getting what you pay for as an early access game with loads of potential and even pretty functional gameplay, but with some bugs and a short storyline for the time being

Updating this review. Initially, I didn't recommend this game, because I felt the issues with the game would turn away the average player. After spending some more time in the game, I still feel that the average gamer may get frustrated with some of the issues, but I'd still recommend players to pick it up and try it out. Just bear in mind that the game is very much an early access game.

Pros:
-The Base Building aspect of the game is fun. I'd like more customization, but the community has already made some really cool designs with what they've been given.
-Co-op worked fine (I know others were having issues). I've had a few errors with friends being able to connect to my game, but they were able to get in eventually
-The concept is EXTREMELY fun. It's like "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" meets "A Bugs Life".
-The graphics feel very polished and the art style matches the theme of the game well.
-The bugs are absolutely terrifying. I've jumped out of my chair no less than 5 times playing this so far
-The crafting system is incredibly in depth already

Cons:
-A Microsoft account is required to play
-The walls and doors often have a hard time aligning or being placed on certain terrain, unless they're attached to a floor. If you didn't have to spend raw science to research the floors, it wouldn't be as much of an issue, but I also don't want to have to build floors to be able to reliable place walls.
-The bugs (especially soldier ants) are way overtuned. The soldier ants will go on a rampage at night and destroy EVERYTHING you've built, even on the medium difficulty.
-There's a noticeable lack of content in the game. The "main story" took me all of 15 minutes to complete. While this is a sandbox game and the creative aspects give you plenty to do, the story could have been fleshed out A LOT more (even for early access).
-Character selection seemed to make no difference, other than which voice lines you are forced to hear over and over throughout your play through. Having the characters make a choice would have been a nice touch
-There's no character progression. Having some skills would give you some agency, which would feel much better from a role playing perspective.
