This is the first review I have ever made and I'm only leaving it due to reading so many hate comments about this game and the small things they complain about. First off, the game is "Early Access", meaning... well...it's not finished. It's going to have some bugs (ha pun not intended) and obviously not all of the content is there yet. Yeah the story only takes about 20 min to complete up to the point the content is over but it's only just begun. Hell, for one, it has a story. "7 Days to Die", although I love this game as well, has absolutely no story to speak of because it doesn't really need it. I would still play Grounded without a story so I'm just happy it has one.  The thrill of exploring is immense in my opinion as you have to be constantly aware of your surroundings. I've also never had a game scare me worse in my entire life, and I've played plenty of horror games. Having a wolf spider the size of a tank charging at me at full speed will haunt me for the rest of my life, and I love it. I love the sense of scale and how small you feel, hell gnat's are the size of your head. The gameplay and crafting mechanics reminds me of "The Forest" which I'm all about. I also appreciate how fresh this game feels, your enemies aren't zombies or cannibals like most survival craft games are.  So far I absolutely love this game and look forward to playing it for a long time.
im really enjoying this game. you can build bases and its like fortnite meets a bugs life but as people.

I love the setting and art style of this game but I can't recommend it, as the combat is just complete garbage. its a spam fest with "timed" blocking and stamina management, which is fine until you run into the enemy types that will kill you in 2-3 hits regardless of armor that will tank 20+ hits from you. this might lead you to think that its best to plink them to death from range, but there is a leashing mechanic where if the enemy cannot path to you it simply forgets your location and instant heals back to max hp.

I want to start this review by saying IT IS EARLY ACCESS. In all honesty, don't buy this game until there is more content. I would wait maybe 6 months, i'm sure (hoping) there will be more content by then. With that being said let's move on. The graphics for this game are absolutely stunning. I find myself frequently climbing to high places just to look around and enjoy the view. This game is gorgeous. The sound design is amazing and I am surprised to not see many people talking about it. You can tell, what enemy is nearby just based on the sounds alone. That mixed with really good ambient noises that really make the world seem alive. From dogs barking, to cars driving by. Heck, even the sound of someone mowing their lawn. The sound design of this game is amazing, and I cannot stress that enough. The story for this game is well... horribly unfinished. Which is to be expected of course. However, what we do have is a REALLY cool concept and something very interesting to be sure. Think of The Forest, which is probably the game closest to this one. The Forest has you surviving until you're prepared enough to uncover the secrets of the island. This game is practically the exact same thing. The creature design in this game is pretty good. I think in terms of enemies where this game REALLY shines is the large spiders. Spiders walk around and move the "giant" blades of grass that don't even jiggle if you walk on them. They give away their position with this detail but also blend in very well into the environment. This is the perfect mix of ominous, terrifying, and downright exciting. Seeing large enemies is always fun and gets my heart pumping. Overall this game has the most potential I've seen in a video game of this style in quite some time. I give this game a solid 7/10 and I am very sure Obsidian will not let me down once they have a more finished product. I look forward to exploring this game more and more with each update. As a final note, there is a ton of world for you to explore and enjoy the scenery. Just because the story of the game ends quickly without much content doesn't mean you can't run around and enjoy what there is to see and find. There's more to the game than the negative reviews would have you believe.

Slightly rough around the edges, but a really enjoyable core experience and pleasing aesthetics. I am personally happy paying 30 to support the future of this game. The story is very short right now, and that is mentioned pretty clearly in the early access details. For a team of what we were told is 13 people, this game is promising. I feel like complaining about an early access title not having answers to all the issues a day after launch is really just a sign that you should not pay for early access. I got 5 hours out of my first play session with friends, and expect to sink at least another 20-30 hours on what is offered currently. You do need an Xbox live account, but you do not pay for any membership (seen this mentioned too many times) and setting up multiplayer is as easy as being friends on those accounts and joining your friends lobby once it is up. Server stability was overall mostly fine, but we did have to remake our first lobby to stop random disconnects. Content is there, but a good portion will be added in over time and that is reason to wait for some. I do not normally post serious reviews, but feel like this game is getting more negativity than needed. Hopefully this clears a few things up for people looking to buy.

it's crazy good fun (especially with friends) and will be more so if [spoiler]spider aggro is tuned down and[/spoiler] the volume of content is increased.  

Neither I nor my friends have experienced any kind of connectivity issues so I can't speak to other's experiences. For us, the networking has been rock solid with the party easily able to find the host.  The world is amazing. The sound design is great.  The depth of field, textures, mechanics all spot on. There's fun little things here and there that make perfect sense and add a delightful bit of whimsy -- things that you'd expect of a [i]complete[/i] game, but sadly it is not.  If you seek out the video "How Obsidian Created Grounded" it concludes with their desire to work with the community to build it out and if that's legitimate... ok. My fear, however, is that the team that built it will be re-tasked now that art assets, game mechanics, sound, etc. appear to be in the bag.

Now for the less good things.  Buying what amounts to a ported XBox game through Steam does require that you log into your XBox live account within the game in a fairly clumsy way (web iframe in the middle of the game menu).  It's especially painful if you use a password manager (lastpass, 1password, dashlane, etc.) and have to transcribe a password.  The game can get into this weird state where if you type an "a" as part of your credentials, it opens audio options. I'll admit that had me seeing red.  Once you bind it to your XBox live account it seems to remember it and it's not an on-going hassle, but it's not as clean as you'd like.  Therefore, it [i]may[/i] -- and I hesitate to suggest it -- be better buying the game through the Microsoft Xbox app thingy than Steam.  Personally, I'm glad I and the majority of my friends bought through Steam because you get a centralized view of their activity, achievements, etc. but you can decide how important that is to you.   

There's also a lack of content.  The game world is much larger than I have explored, so I'm sure there are things to find and enemies to encounter and areas of the world to experience, etc.  That is all "content" but that's not the content I'm referring to.  There's some guided tasks that you are [i]suggested[/i] to do to understand the larger plot and if you do that it'll end fairly quickly/abruptly.  You can continue to open world it, but it's jarring to be invested in a story, making what feels like progress and have it conclude as it does. If you were an early purchaser of Sea of Thieves you'll be familiar with a similar experience.  That's an unfair comparison because SoT was sold as a complete game and commanded a complete game's price and after about an hour you realized you'd seen and done everything that was on offer.  The experience with Grounded isn't that and yet it kind of is...  

Grounded is not sold as SoT was sold nor is it marketed as SoT was marketed nor are you charged for a complete game -- so keep reminding yourself of that.  The problem with both titles is that they're stable and beautiful and immersive and care has been put into what you'd think should be finishing touches and yet neither title was in a finished state and when you discover that it's deflating.  You have my attention [b]now[/b]!  In 3 months or in 6 months when the content gets expanded I don't know that I'll be able to convince people to give it a second look or to re-grind aspects of the story.  

In the end, that "negative" leads to the highest compliment I can give it... I want to be a consumer of the final product and that's not what they're offering.

I knew this game had potential as soon as i saw early game play of it. I don't want to go over the top and write a whole essay so to sum it up this game is amazing and has so much potential to be even more.
Here is a list of things i hope to see in the future:
-All bugs drop meat (for consistency because it doesn't make sense for some bugs to drop meat and some to not)
-More creatures (ex. Bees, Butterflies, Dragonflies, Wasps, Grasshoppers, Crickets, Black Widows, Mosquitoes etc.)
Weather:
-Rain (collectible and drinkable)
-Snow
-Thunderstorm
-Drought
Seasons:
-Spring (Plants start growing back and bugs start coming back from winter, rain is more common, dewdrops on grass are more common)
-Summer (Number of bugs peak and they are at their strongest, crops/plants grow faster, longer days, shorter nights)
-Fall (Tree leaves start changing colors, grass starts dying and changing colors, long nights short days)
-Winter (Water freezes and snow can be used as a water source but must be melted down over a fire, All bugs are more scarce and less active except spiders and crickets, most grass and plants are dead or frozen and can be found easier underground, food is overall hard to find and must be stored and saved in preparation for winter, longer nights shorter days)
-A temperature mechanic
-More caves
-Sand
-Most resources convertible into raw science
-Technological advancements bought from BURG.L (Vehicles, Concrete (or some type of durable building material), Saddles which can be used to ride flying passive insects like butterflies, etc.)
All these suggestions would be perfect future additions. The more realistic a survival game is, the better.

I'll get right to the point:

This game is adorable and crazy fun. Discovering the different insects, friendly or not, and learning the ecosystem "rules" and the consequences you face for disturbing them is amazing and different. The fact that you can go from "wow this game is beautiful" to "HOLY $&!# THERES A SPIDER BEHIND ME OMG I JUST PISSED MY SELF" in less the 0.1 seconds is exactly what I want from this game. This game is like Raft and The Forest had a baby. There's story based objectives with a cute art style like Raft, and scary enemies with difficult survival like The Forest. I HIGHLY recommend this game.

If you've been reading negative reviews for this game, here's a few things I want to say about them:

-Most of them played less than an hour and gave up. 
-They hold the Obsidian name up too high- this is a passion project for them, not another fallout series. They wont be the same game, so accept that.
-This game is early access, and WILL have bugs, issues, and limited content. That's just part of buying an early access game, and if you felt upset by that you never should've bought an early access game.
-All bugs I had while playing 9 hours of CoOp were easily fixed with disconnecting and reconnecting. Nothing was game breaking. I only crashed twice in 9 hours and reconnected easily with no progress lost. So I'm happy with that
-You need a Microsoft account to play NOT A XBOX LIVE ACCOUNT. It's quick and easy and FREE to make one, and I feel like most people have one already.
-They rushed the story in 20 minutes and then quit the game. If you only play a game for objectives, and not for exploring and creating a unique experience for yourself, I feel sorry for you. It's so much more fun that just following a dot on the screen.

I highly recommend this game, and I recommend you buy it now. It's $30 and I can see how amazing this game is going to become as it grows and expands with feedback. The story is already so interesting and mysterious, the environment and insects are unique, beautiful and terrifying. I'm happy with the time I spent already and plan on playing more tonight with my friends. This game will easily become $60 on full release so I'm happy with paying $30 now with a few bugs and a short story in exchange for the excitement for every new update until full release and saving money with it.

Take negative reviews with a grain of salt because if they steer you away from this amazing game, you'll be missing out.
Think, Honey I Shrunk the Kids meets a Bugs Life. I'm very excited to see where this game leads, especially since it is from such an incredible developer.

Great visuals. Obviously it doesn't have a huge story so far and I know it's a work in progress but it's a good survival game so far. The only problem I have is when I was trying to make a base. I would place wall blueprints and when I got to certain parts of the terrain, the walls were too high off the ground and looked bad. Some parts I could place the walls a little lower in the ground but some places I couldn't. And I couldn't see other games when I looked. Keep up the great work!
Fun so far.. smooth movement, great graphics keeps you on your toes !

I really want to like this game. I've never enjoyed survival games, but from what I've played so far this seems to be right up my alley. The cartoonish look sells it as a much more casual game than it ends up being. You will spend a large amount of your first few days running from the spiders that, for some reason, live right next to the starting area. They can spot you from a long ways away, run faster than you, and will kill you in one hit. That kind of challenge is fine if you're up for it, but I definitely am not, and these guys are just as dangerous on the easiest difficulty. The (very thoughtful) arachnophobia slider is a really neat tool to make them less scary, but it does absolutely nothing to make them less dangerous, so I'm just as afraid of them as before.

After a couple of tries on easy mode, I just switched to creative mode to explore through the story without constant threats. Unfortunately, everything about the story seems to be disabled in creative mode, so if I want to actually experience this game, I have no choice but to confront those horrible, horrible spiders. If you think you can do that, definitely give this one a go. But if you don't like bugs... well, you probably knew this one wasn't for you anyway.
Super fun solo :D Can't wait for more updates to the game, love the concept. Reminds me of the forest running around murdering with my bow xD

I have Arachnophobia and this triggers it and I refuse to lower the accessibility slider. This is the first time I feel true horror when I play a game. There is a lot that needs improved and I look forward to seeing it.
Fun game, can't wait for the updates.

I haven't been startled in a looong time but dang that got me good. 

Game is packed with detail from the crafting to the animations when bugs are moving through the grass. The ants are little thieves, the research and decorative items are a nice touch. The spiders and other big bugs give you quite a bit of sudden danger depending on the area, seeing aphids scurrying around and running up leaves is a joy too.

It took me a good bit to get multiplayer working which seemed to be a combination of the xbox services on pc, my antivirus and some registry key that was stuck. They have a discord setup and are trying to sort out bugs effectively. I've been hearing the game is short but it seems solid compared to some other early access and its high quality, i haven't been blazing through the story just building a base and exploring so far and i think its worth it for some fun or scares and hopefully continues to get content.

Early access is early access. 
The game itself runs smooth and gameplay is fun. Menus are well designed and POIs are fun to uncover their purpose. There is a strong focus on multi-player and teamwork. With all the framework laid out and a cast of brilliantly voiced characters. Its strange to see larger companies like obsidian (being published by xbox) still claiming EA. That being said...

Unlike the advertisements and youtube promo-plays, some very important key features are missing or hard to navigate and access. For $30 and no EA discount, there is no steam multiplayer implemented at the moment, it must all be done through xbox friend list, which is a pain for many PC steam gamers who may have expected the ease of steam connect. You NEED an xbox/microsoft account if you wish to play multiplayer. This obstacle keeps customers from 'the time that they could be playing the product' with friends (aka. additional customers) Hopefully this changes and hopefully we see another map or additional story quests.

Spider hit-boxes, snap-lock grid building, speed vs flat damage balancing and pathing AI are all things that can, and likely will be, improved as the game is updated. If you are on the fence and wondering if purchasing the game is a good idea, hold off until they have an update or two.

My game crashed once or twice, but the auto-save feature rescued the problem, so it was no sweat.  Other than that, Grounded is a game that seems like it will grow into its potential through the dev process.  It already looks great and plays smoothly.  I would sooner compare this one to Subnautica than to Ark.  Ark was over-hyped rubbish that never managed to deliver on its promise.  Subnautica started out a bit rough, but eventually the underlying brilliance of its design shone through.  Hopefully, once they iron out a few kinks and fill in the story content, Grounded will be more like that.  I think it's already super fun, and I'm looking forward to jumping into a new playthrough soon.

Note:  I played single-player, offline.  I have no comments about the multiplayer, which seems to be the main source of bad reviews so far.  I think that's unfortunate, because Grounded is getting a mixed welcome, even though the problem doesn't really have anything to do with gameplay or design decisions pertaining to the experience itself.  Oh well, I guess that's how it goes sometimes.

Long story short, if this game looks interesting to you but you're a little wary because of the number of down-votes, I'm happy to report you're probably safe to give it a go anyway.

This game has a great theme. Really original. There is a truly enjoyable 80s vibe to it as well. Do not expect the game to help you out too much. You gotta figure out how to survive on your own. I really like games that do that. I only have about 3 hours on it, and have not encountered any problems with glitches. Can not wait for the full version!

Microsoft had all the resources in the world to conduct internal testing to support Obsidian. All this looks like is them cheaping out and making you pay to test. There's aboslutely no reason Microsoft/Obsidian couldn't have left this in the oven longer to release a finished product as opposed to Early Access.

In it's current state, Grounded is just another unfinished survival crafting game. It was barely advertised as such, and many people are validly disappointed. As of right now the dev's claim 20% of the story is in game, that amounts to a short, near uneventful tutorial that ends abruptly, leaving you with nothing but building and generic generated quests.

What's here is entirely dependent on how much you like building and doing "kill x bug x times" quests over and over. A coop experience might help curb the boredom but that isn't enough to validate the current price. They even plan to increase the price so it makes the expectations even higher. 

Do not forget this is not some indie dev, this is Microsoft and Obsidian, both entities have been producing/developing games for decades which makes the current state of this game inexcusable. They literally tell you in the trailer "if you want a real game, wait for Cyberpunk" and it screams they have no confidence in this.

I  have sympathy for those who are upset about the short story, it seems rushed even from an early access title. I honestly didn't even start with the story, I just kinda started exploring and setting up camp. I don't expect the story to be the strongest part of this game even when it's finished. However, I don't think anything else seems that rushed. Maybe I'm lucky but I've yet to run into any bugs so far (lol) and my game just generally runs well. The soundtrack is simple but effective and creates the right mood. The sound FX are satisfying. I'm not a fan the whole multiplayer requiring an xbox live account, I feel lucky I already had one I could sign into easily. 

There are a couple mechanics which have bothered me. Having to wait to analyze a new resource after 3 uses is just lame. I read this in another review but it absolutely gives off a free mobile app kind of vibe. I like that worker ants can steal your supplies from storage containers, but I REALLY DON'T like that the ants can clip through my walls and steal my stuff. I have a feeling this was just an oversight or something, but seriously, the ant should have to bust my wall down before it can stick its head in my container. Other than that, I've been having a pretty good time just exploring and building my base up. I think there's a lot of potential here.
Cant wait to see what the game become's.

Man, I absolutely love this game. Everyday things we have in our yard take on a whole new meaning when you are reduced down to such a small size. To think I love spiders IRL, I run like hell from them in this game.

For an early access title, this game runs and looks great on my system, which is an older one. (About 4 years old on avg, hardware)

Characters are likeable so far as well, I haven't noticed any glaring issues with animations or sound effects. But it may be too early to tell.

Crafting is OK, and I still really do not have the hang of lining up walls. I also feel the inventory system will need polishing.

[spoiler]BURG-L is awesome too! His lines crack me up. I still wish it was Failsafe's voice  tho from Destiny 2 ;(   [/spoiler]

Overall, early access notwithstanding, I give this game a solid 7/10, and it seems it will only get better.

People who complain about early access games really need to quit buying them.

My experience in the game is exactly what I expected after reading the big blue early access box, and I am loving it.

I can't wait till the next update.

Keep up the good work devs!

First and foremost, I can say that I do recommend this title.  It's got some nice polish to it, and it's themeing is very cute.  Obvious comparison is the "Honey, I shrunk the kids" franchise, and it works very nicely.

Yes, it's Early Access, so expect this to be developed slowly over time as is the theme with this Genre of games, but that's also my gripe... it's TOO early access.  There's maybe about 25 minutes worth of content in a $40 title.  This should have been a free demo in it's current form, if I'm honest.  
Am I upset I adopted this early?  Maybe a little?  If it was sloppier, I would have happily refunded this within Steam's time limit, but I can see the potential, so I guess it will sit in my library over the next year while I keep a side-glanced eye on it's development.  

Soooo, yeah.  If you want a fleshed out survival base builder?  Wait for this one to be further along in it's development and THEN check it out, since it's rocking that $40 price tag.   But if you are super interested in following along, then I'd say go for it.   This game feels like it's going to be a lot of fun.  ...eventually.

This vital information was added to the store page AFTER the initial backlash of surprised users who bought the game on release day and expected to be able to play with other steam users directly, as suggested by the store page and trailer material. 

The game looks promising and I will keep it on my watch list to return to at a later time should the situation regarding the accounts be handled in a more inclusive way. I dont mind having the option to use other store accounts to get more connectivity but having to use one mandatory (for Steam only MP), which is not the one of this plattform, is rather alienating.

Once I can play with other Steam users (without 3rd party accounts) I will be back.
The demo was cool and I looked forward to the EarlyAccess release but I will have to wait for the unforeseeable future.

Its the second day of early access and multiplayer is broken and the campaign only reveals 2 missions so far.  With that out of the way, even single player is fantasticly fun.  

The building is intuitive with snap together pieces however flexible enough to have some creative designs.  

The survival aspect is ever present but its not an annoying meter managing game where you must be constantly eating and drinking.  

The crafting is an interesting process where finding new materials and analyzing them leads to new designs.  

The game's atmosphere is wonderful.  A lot of effort was put into the world to give it a sense of danger, adventure, and exploration.  The landscapes do not feel generic and much attention to detail was added into the world.  

Over all, the game is fun.  I'm having a blast playing it by my self and cant wait for multiplayer to work.

After inputting my Xbox Live credentials, it attempted to login, and hung for a few moments before it crashed.
Launching the game again, after pressing any button to continue, it tries to login automatically, hangs, then crashes. Doesn't even throw a crash report through steam. I've tried all the fixes listed in forums and such for windows 7, but nothing has worked.

[b] Grounded [/b]

This game is something you'd except more from, but don't get yet.. Imo it's really still the skeleton of the game and the way it feels, the way it's played etc. which is very logical since it's still in Early Access. 

[b] Building - Meh[/b]
While it seems really simple, it is really not. They throw recipes your way like walls, windows and roofs pretty early in the game. You've probably seen it a lot in the discussion tab or even in the bug report [b] I can't make floors [/b] even though it's there.. You just have to unlock it by finishing the 20 minute story and unlocking it by spending knowledge points.
Which imo... Is a really weird take.. Why would you be ablle to make a straight sturdy wall and not a FLOOR that's litterally 4 leaves laying on a FLAT surface..

[b] Hunger, Water Mechanics - Yeah, i'm down [/b]
A pretty solid system not to shabby maybe a bit bare-boned, but still solid enough for an early access.

[b] Enemies - I hate them, but i also like them [/b]
While they're dumb as rocks, they pack a punch. The spiders are horrific, apparently lady bugs too and don't get me started on the weird hoppy things that spit acid all of you.
All in all.. Pretty solid would give it a 10/10 heart attack now a then..
(Spiders also like to sneak towards you... Very fun)

Been having a blast with the game! If you enjoy survival games like ARK or RAFT this game is right up your alley. You do all the same things, craft, build up a base, manage your health, stamina and food/thirst, all the while protecting yourself from all the dangerous enemies out there. The spin on this game is that it's all insects because you're the size of an ant, and honestly, that premise alone is an amazing foundation for a game. 

There isn't a ton to do yet, but even with the little that is there the admission price is totally reasonable, even if you buy it play it for a little taste, and then have to shelve it for a while until future updates come out. There is something viscerally terrifying about being hunted by a spider while the sun sets and your hunger/thirst are low - it preys on the fear of insects that a lot of people have and it totally works.

Microsoft has been quite the letdown lately with their offerings. This one is "The Forest" meets "Honey I Shrunk The Kids" with a clunky controller-based interface and no real story. There's only about 20 minutes of actual content that's just boring. It's a survival game for small children. Definitely not worth $30 (not at this point anyway). Feels more like a free game or something that should be in the $5 bin. Might give it another go for an hour, but I don't see this growing on me in that time and will probably end up refunding it.

Brilliant game - well done Obsidian.

The game is in desperate need of a skill tree or something to drive progression forward. Let me spend points on things like carrying capacity, backpack space etc. We need something that makes us feel like we are progresssing out character. There are some very strange bugs happening. Ever base I build I end up having 10 larvea spawn inside the foundation and they just tear it up from the inside out. Same with ants I come back to the base to see 4 of them glitched into the floor. Locations have no purpose and the world while filled with things feels empty. I will be happy to change my review once updates give us more content.

There should be an option for us when starting a world to decide what gets dropped on death I.E. Hot bar, Backpack, or both. 3. Game is definitely early access, so lets give some feedback. 

First, I love the environment, I'm getting mad nostalgic for my Pikmin days. So exploring is really fun.

After that stuff starts to really need work. I'm playing on normal and base defense is not fun at all. I keep getting attacked by like 5 or 6 larva at once, which is way more than two people can handle for 2 reasons. Reason 1, the main way you make your base more sturdy is with weed stems. There really aren't enough of these around, so building is a massive chore, unless you want to build out of grass, and the grass is basically useless as a fortification. The game keeps reminding me to block, but that isn't the issue when I'm being attacked by four larva from four different angles now is it? So I gave up on base building entirely and put all the necessary base items on top of a rock plateau and now that part of the game doesn't suck. 

Part of what makes base defense so bad is how weak the weapons are, you basically must get a weapon better than the first tier of weapons before you make a base if you want any chance. Ontop of that, base building wouldn't be so bad if I could get a tier 2 ax so I could chop down the large weeds, but I have no idea how. I've scanned every single new item I've found after a day a playing and not one of them has given me the recipe for the next tier of ax. Game really struggles with conveyance in that regard. 

The final reason base defense sucks is the bow is unbelievably weak. If you are getting swarmed, naturally you want to take to high ground and use arrows to solve the problem. TOO BAD, its going to take around 8 arrows per larva and like I said there's 5 or 6 of them at once. If i wasn't getting hit by larva, I was getting hit by ants despite intentionally storing no food in the base, and the soldier ants are tanky as hell, even two of them is a real problem on normal, and remember I had help. All of this kept happening before I had even errected a 2x3 with spike traps on all the walls. BEFORE I WAS DONE BUILDING, and the cherry ontop, they would attack again before I was done repairing the damage, so it's just a cycle of not making any progress on your base, and my build was a totally modest size. 

Last thing I'll mention is that multiplayer is not 100% playable right now. Crashes, failed loads, infinite loads, you name it, but solo is a way more stable option rn, which kinda sucks because I got this game to play with friends, and of my 3 friends who got it, I could only play with 1. The rest gave up on trouble shooting. 

So to conclude. Game has great potential, but the base mechanics need to be reworked BADLY. I would say don't buy this game for at least a month.

I hate to see a game this good get so many negative reviews. Yes you HAVE to have an Xbox Live account, it sucks. I don't like it anymore than anyone else. However, the game plays wonderfully and the environment is  incredible. I'm blown away by how cool the backyard forest is to explore. Every time I see something new I'm hit with a wave of excitement and desire to explore more. I can not wait till they add more story content, the little that is already in the game is fantastic and I'm excited to learn more about the world. The controls and survival mechanics are implemented in a way that isn't too overbearing even on the harder difficulty.  The enemies are fun to fight and rewarding to defeat, the "boss" level enemies feel terrifying. Crafting also feels and functions great.

Other than requiring an outside account, I really don't have any knocks against this game. I wish it was cheaper given the Early Access nature of it, but I don't regret my purchase of it. If you enjoy survival games, this one is a perfectly refreshing twist on the genre that you must play. (Its also on the gamepass if you can stomach using the Xbox store)

Prior to reading this review, please remember this game is still in very early access, and is still registered as a "preview" title according to Microsoft. 

Pros: 

Environment; unique and pleasantly unsettling

Soundtrack: Fits the astethic of the 90's vibe the game is going for.

Gameplay: Combat is simple but efficient, crafting is easy and UI is easy to figure out. 

Story: Although brief at time of release, has a lot of potential!

Cons:

Just one really....

THE SPIDERS, OH THE SPIDERS. Listen, I am an arachnophobe by every account, and the game does indeed have options to essentially make the spiders as detailed or as non detailed (you literally can make the spider a floating grey blob with eyes), but after a few hours, although still terrifying, they are simply OP in my opinion. They are littered throughout the map, are tanks, and will detect you almost instantly. Love the idea, but as my friend said "If they're going to be this hard to kill and avoid, they should be like running into a death claw in Fallout. Rare, but challenging. 

All in all this game is super interesting, fun to play, and provides a unique survival co-op experience. 

Would recommend highly, but just be patient with the devs.

Probably don't get this game at it's current state. It's story time.

We tried to co-op this game with a friend and had fun for the first couple hours setting up camp and exploring, but on hour 3 our base was just flooded one night with two wolf spiders, an army of ants and a band of larvae. For the entire night and day they rapidly undid all our progress and refused to leave.

We couldn't leave camp due to the spiders standing guard right behind our walls. Once the ants came in hunting a weevil they destroyed our walls in the process letting the spiders into camp. We fled to higher ground and slept on some rocks which didn't despawn any of the bugs as we had hoped. Instead this now spawned a horde of larvae that demolished the rest of what was left of our base, destroying all storage units and scattering the physics objects within everywhere across the ground. Once we tried to kill these larvae, poking them from a distance with our spears, they would just quickly flee when they'd reach low health and another larva with full health would take it's place. By this time our characters were both dying of their wounds, hunger and thirst. At this point we just both quit the game with a disappointed sigh. This is what I imagine playing Rust on a public server is like, but now it was the game's AI doing the griefing.

Story over.

I've yet to see all the content the early access build has to offer. There is a story path you can follow, but on normal your hunger and thirst meters deplete so quickly and you die so easily that most of my focus had been on just surviving until I can craft good enough gear and gather enough resources to safely explore the next area where the game wants me to go. So far this has felt like a zero sum game where by the time you gather resources your armor breaks and once you have armor, you again lack food and drink, leaving little time to progress the story.

I've took more notes while playing to both include in this review and to use as feedback for Obsidian if anyone's reading this.

- Would've preferred Steamworks for multiplayer but the Xbox live works okay here, I guess

- The game needs more detailed graphics options, currently you can't even disable motion blur, otherwise the game runs pretty well even on an older computer

- When you wear/equip gear they still take inventory space in your backpack for some reason, Obsidian please fix

- The game's time gated recipe research station is a fun idea

- Inventory lacks a quick sort button, you can't drop stacks of one item for your friend and you can't quickly deposit items either

- You also can't "trash" grass planks and other large materials that aren't stored directly in your inventory so they just litter your game world once you upgrade to a better base building material

- [strike]The base building in this game is weird, you can't build a flat foundation floor for your base like in Satisfactory but walls will still forcibly snap to each other at set angles. This makes base building feel super clunky.[/strike] Turns out these are in the game, just kinda oddly communicated in the game as foundations and floors are built separately.

- There's also no global game world grid you could snap walls to so basically you can't build two separate walls for your base and have them meet up somewhere in the middle, they won't align correctly, building a base in this just feels like a weird commitment to whatever your starting point is

- You also can't build a wall if it even a little bit of it goes inside a rock or a hill, this makes it a headache to plan a base that has no holes in it for small bugs to get through.
- But it doesn't matter since your first two wall types, grass and weed, are so flimsy that any aggressive bug will go through them if they so much as sneeze at them, this makes any and all base building feel pointless since you're building a protection that doesn't do what it's supposed to do, you can even accidentally break these walls yourself for whatever reason

- Basically your base can be way too easily destroyed as described above and there isn't really a place on the map where the bugs don't travel through it daily

- You can build spike traps for the bugs that hurt them when they touch them but these can also hurt you for some reason and there's no way to tell how much damage these actually do the bugs if any

- Any building materials you aren't using will take up space, these are all poorly stacking physics objects that will be flung 500 meters into the air if so much as ant brushes them. To fix this you have to build a pallet that lets you stack them as static objects but these pallets take up a ton of space and don't actually hold many of these materials at all. It's a pain.

- The nights in this game also feel like they're way too long compared to how fast daytime goes by. You can make a bed that lets you skip nighttime but what Obsidian doesn't seem clued on is that nobody playing online sleeps during the night in any of these survival games because it takes too much coordination for everyone in game to do so.

- For a crafting survival game it feels at odds that there's zero character customization apart from crafting armor. You can express yourself with how you build and decorate your base but you can't do so with the character you play as. There's two black kids, one white kid and one Mexican(?) kid. These characters all have their own unique personalities based on 80's youth stereotypes. Ah yes, the glam rocker, the nerd, the tough kid and Mabel Pines from Gravity Falls. Once you're playing multiplayer these characters can have some unique but limited banter between each other and it's all well written. These are all fun characters, but they feel like they're written more based on their 80's character trope than really any sort of ethnicity so it would be cool to see them either A) create more characters or B) let people customize the characters' appearance but keeping the voice and character that they have. But right now this current system does feel like placeholder as each time you load a save or die the game asks if you want to switch characters, so it's not like the game expects you to have a huge attachment to your avatar.

But even with all these issues I constantly feel like going back to play some more of this game so the foundation is there. I can see this game becoming really good in a year or two with updates.

The review is from 7/28/2020:
Upon release this game feel more like an overpriced unbalanced tech demo from the depths of Marc Whitten's twisted idea of an xbox account requirement on PC. Come on guys. Get it together. After 20 years this shouldnt be hard by now. The game has a lot of potential but hopefully it does not get overshadowed by cheap gimmicks and slow development. From Obsidian and/or Microsoft, the idea of using EA seems sketch from such large studios. I really have high hopes for this game and really high expectations given the last 2 years of bad games from Microsoft and Obsidian not really doing much since New Vegas. I would say hold off  on getting this game until you know you are going to like it or they put out substantially more content. There are a ton of indie games that have more content for a fraction of the price.
this game is amazing

Such a great game. Visually, probably the best survival game out there. Combat is fun and can be scary when your dealing with spiders. Game seems to be running pretty smoothly, no crashes or any of that junk. Cant wait to see more from the game!

As it stands this game is in VERY early access. If you just want to mess around in the sandbox with a few friends, I'm sure it's a fun time, but there isn't much to do. The "story," or lackthereof more accurately, takes all of 10 minutes and isn't so much a plot as much as context for the setting. The map is terribly small and is severely lacking in verticality, and there isn't all that much to explore (and by explore I mean discover landmarks) so after you've built a base, there's nothing to do except build more, which isn't all that satisfying considering the relatively limited materials and the nasty depth of field effect (for the love of god, please add a setting to reduce or remove this) ruining any views you'd get from tall structures. There also needs to be more music; you will get sick of the main theme playing constantly, suggesting a sense of marvel and mystery every time you look at a new identical blade of grass.

The game does look nice, although there's plenty of room for improvement. The core mechanics and ideas are well done and enjoyable for the most part (combat and AI need the most work). There's a good amount of craftables and mobs present. I really like playing the game but its just too shallow. This is an absolute ripoff for $30, especially considering Subnautica is only $25 for a similar experience that's superior in every way (though lacking multiplayer). I'd recommend getting it with gamepass instead. 

So. I like the game and I hope for the best but it just needs more of everything. And I mean a lot more. And there needs to be something for "lategame" (a few hours in as of now) since the story isn't gonna cut it. Something like a PvP mode, long term objectives/bosses, or maybe scale insect raids a la 7 Days to Die to hit harder and have more threats as bases increase in size. 

In summary, this game is maybe a 7.5/10 survival game, but its only a 4/10 in content. The amount of bugs, landmarks, and just general environmental diversity that this game currently has is only a fraction of the amount that needs to be added. Pick it up if it scratches that childhood itch, or if you want to have some fun with coop, but you will have to make your own fun after the first few hours. Saying a game has potential means basically nothing, but I'll still say it. This game has potential.

>Playing Grounded.
>Exploring, things going fine.
>See little ant. How's it going little ant friend?
>Keep exploring.
>Find mushrooms. 
>Pretty Hungry. Eat mushrooms. Hope they arent poisonous.
>Mushrooms are safe. Gather more for later.
>Keep exploring.
>Find giant soda can.
>Drink soda. Tastes good. We're really out here.
>Keep exploring.
>See giant spider web. 
>Where's the spider?
>Sneaks in closer to try and harvest some spider web. 
>Wack, wack, wack. Gather some spider web. 
>Hear spoopy sound. Turn around.
>Giant Orb Weaver Spider staring me in the face.
>PANIC, FEAR, SCREAMING.
>Hit it in the face with my pebble axe.
>Laughs at my frivolous attempts to hurt it.
>PANIC MORE! SCREAM MORE!
>RUN FOR LIFE.
>SPIDER RUNS FASTER.

My first impression on the game:

Day 1: Where am I? I got shrunk down? How? Damn its a beatiful world out there. Lets go exploring. Ants starts observing me what im doing. 

Me: Go away, im on a mission.
Ants: What mission?
Me: Peace of our time.

Ants start attacking me constantly and their numbers increased and then I died. Good start.

I respawned back. I see something moving in dense grass far off. Untill I saw it I regret everything now. A giant ass spider roaming around. There wasn't one but dozens. And then it saw me and instantly came after me while alerting other spiders as well. 

Spider: Oi, I see a juicy human there. Lets go kill it.
Me: OH HELL NAH. *runs away asap*

Damn nature, you scary.

Day 2: I figured out how to craft. Genious. Also you can find a machine which will analyze the item you collect 3 times/per use and then it needs to recharge for a while. 

Conclusion: Great graphics, crafting, open world game but you need MS account to login to play CO-OP. Big downside imo. They should just let ous invite players or host public server.

SPIDERS

I work all day to build walls/foundation/traps to protect my chests. Then night/morning comes around and some worker ants or patrolling larvas teleports through all of my defenses. They steal all of my stuff and break my house. Rinse and repeat. Great game.....

Despite this the game is good, just not worth buying early access.

The story forces you to play as a pre-teen, which immediately made me feel like I will be playing a child's game. I guess I should have clearly seen that coming. I played single player only on the PC. Hot take: consoles are for kids (get over it you old console players), so the xbox integration was probably wise of the developers.

The game play is simple and solid. It's the usual basic survival skills and staples like health, stamina, food, and water. It's the usual survival foraging, like chopping weeds, foraging for fibers, sap, sticks and stones. It's the usual survival fights, against mites, ants, and terrifying spiders. It's the usual crafting of tools, weapons, armor and base building. It's a LOT of the usual. The only thing that sets this apart is that I really like the feeling of being ant-size, in the forest of someone's back yard. And, the game is intuitive. 

This very early release is more of a demo, as you could probably experience the available story in about 10 minutes of play, if the story quest was your focus. When the story is developed, it could be good: trying to figure out why and how you were miniaturized. That said, the story is often childishly narrated, clearly for kids, which works given that you're playing as a child. 

Seeing the backyard through the eyes of a child, is fun, but this places limits on the game too, including limiting your audience, and weapons (i doubt we'll ever see guns, but possibly an alien zapping disintegration gun? since that sounds PG even if it's the same thing as shooting any normal gun)

In all, I recommend the game as a great start, but I don't recommend buying it yet. It's currently lacking questing content, story, and advanced base building. Buy it if you want a spider to eat you. The spiders are actually terrifying and deadly.

THERE IS ABSOLUTELY ZERO STORY CONTENT IN THIS CURRENT BUILD AT RELEASE. SANDBOX ONLY WITH A LOT OF AREAS STILL "UNDER CONSTRUCTION", aka NOT CONTENT IN PROBABLY 3/4 OF THE FULL MAP.

Had a good first play-through on the day of release. Hit a few technical hiccups at the start, which is to be expected of a game that has just released, however, once they were resolved I had an easier experience running the game compared to some of my other well established games.
I sincerely hope the developers are invested in releasing more content throughout its development phase. I'm looking forward to seeing what else Grounded can do.

A friend of mine seemed to have a few issues with the building mechanics but I found it fairly easy, the rotation (via the mouse wheel) is quite sensitive when placing building parts. Might do well to develop a message that displays when a building piece can't be placed, explaining why, so the player can easily fix rather than having to guess. Just a thought.
Hope to see an easier 'Invite friends to game' option in the game soon too.

As of release day (2020-07-28) the game is apparently Early Access in the way that the story content is less than an hour long but showcases some of the visual design we could expect. Exploring and building is done right, but the animations of your tools interacting with the environment need some work. Combat and hit registration is pretty bad with the spiders. UI and tutorial could use some improvements too.

Since the world and graphics is so well presented I think there's a solid base for further development. I recommend following this game and buying if you're really into survival / crafting, but I hope the developers listen to the community and prove this project to be worth committing in the long run.

Worth a buy. Game is still in early access so don't expect a complete product. Game has been fun so far in the two hours I played co-op with my cousin and brother. Haven't experienced any bugs yet. Game looks polished but isn't very optimized as it is. Make sure your computer can run this game if you have an "older" system.

Let me just start this off by saying this is still an early access game, so anyone expecting a full, polished game should wait. With that out of the way, i think this game is a lot of fun and has a lot of potential. I played for a few hours with my friend  and it was a rollercoaster of emotions. One second you're exploring the map and the next thing you know, you've walked right into a spider nest.

There were a couple of problems that we encountered while playing. First off, you need an Xbox Live account to play multiplayer. I saw that some people had trouble logging in, but it worked great for us. What didn't work was hosting a game. Sometimes it would throw an error, but most of the time i would just get stuck in a loading screen and i had to restart the game.

The game itself however ran great. I didn't get any fps drops, even when we got swarmed by an army of larvae. The environment was beautiful and the creatures were terrifying. We had a couple of crashes, but they weren't too bad. Thanks to autosaves we didn't lose any progress.
At the moment there is basically 0 story, so if you want that, you'll have to wait. We finished the story in about 45 minutes and then we just went exploring, built a base and did some quests. If you like that, i recommend you give this game a try. I'm sure there is a lot more content coming as well and i'm very excited about the future of this game.

TL;DR - It's an early access game. It has some bugs (literally and figuratively), but it has a lot of potential. Don't expect to buy a full game right now.

Navigating map is simple because you only have to look at the sky, remember what's closer to the house/oak tree and go that way.

Day/Night cycle works fantastic. It's cool exploring in the daytime and can be scary at the night especially when you're on the high ground seing grass moving towards you. 

You can actually craft quite a lot of items and there's stuff to do for quite a while. I hope that devs will implement more night time objectives and creatures for that craft purposes like ladybugs and such. 

Well anyway I could talk too much so the base line is- The game has great potential and I'll keep on playing it :)

Grounded is a game I have been looking forward since I first heard of it on Youtube, the theme of the game is just so unique and is an awesome take for a survival game. 

When you start the game, you get to see how special it really when seeing yourself as a shrunken kid, it's just stunning visually, the atmosphere is incredible, by far the most beautiful survival game out there.  
Now gameplay-wise, it's just as good, a little bit more different from the other survival games we have all played, it definitely feels far more UNIQUE then the other survival games we have received this decade. Forest looks really muddy, 7 days looks bland. It really helps the gameplay feel impactful. Although, it is a bit buggy, and I'm not talking about the bugs in the game. Some times the objectives wouldn't play a scenario, so I and my friend would have to exit out and retry it again. Nothing to bad, but there were some crashes towards the end of the campaign. Which is sadly quite short, you could probably finish it in half an hour.
Some resources are pretty difficult to get, but it could easily be dealt with if they allowed the players to build a wagon of some sort that players could use on long journeys to bring back grass or weed panels. Please add Wagons in the game. 
Besides that  I can honestly say this game is pretty much worth getting, it's fun on your own and with a friend, 


I really hope updates will be fast and constant, I do feel like it will not be as replayability as most of the other survival game but it definitely has potential to tower amongst the best of survival games. 
Please Obsidian, continue your great work with Grounded.

First off I have to say this is my first review to date on a product, let alone a early access title. That said i believe this game has the foundation to take it to being one of the most ambitious and enjoyable survival co-op we've had in a long time. 

I would like to say that for the first 3-4 hours my friends and I had horrible connection issues, as well as the gaming freezing, glitching out and just flat out crash if anyone but the host was in the server. It make the experience truly unbearable to the point one of our friends completely raged quit turning off his console without any notice to us. (Mind you I am on PC while everyone else is currently on Xbox that was in the server.) After this we changed the host of the server to myself and from there is was smooth sailing for rest of our 7 hour session. I know many people are irritated by the fact that Steam friends are not currently integrated and you have to have an Xbox account for online. In my opinion it wasn't much of a hassle being as I already use Xbox game bar for CoD cross-platform, but given time i believe they will find a way to integrate Steam better.(Though what can you honestly expect from a 1st party Microsoft game.)

With all that out the way it was a blast. I have not had a good scare in a game or shivers/chills running down my spine since playing Subnautica. The spiders are ABSOLUTELY TERRIFYING, I do have arachnophobia(no i do not have arachnophobia mode enabled at all), one moment life is fine picking some plant fibers then you turn around and HOLY F**K you're screaming like a little kid who in their first haunted house. Very scary gets your adrenaline going so far. Doesn't seem repetitive yet combat wise though we have no unlocked everything so far for crafting and weapons present at the moment. 
Each encounter we had was different to an extent, the current variety of bugs can seem low but I believe this is just a stepping stone to more they plan on adding. When we finally we able to kill a spider it took all four of us with the Rank 2 weapon ganging up on it beating it down like it owed us money, it was hilarious then we went around killing spiders until we f**ked and took on too 2 instead of 1 and it didn't end well. Game showed us right away the boundaries of our limitations. 

Currently the crafting is a little clanking to an extent in my opinion especially when it comes to placing walls for your base. Once you get a good exterior for walls it works out alot easier to build vertically. I did have an issue to where we did not actually found the material to build to foundation of any base until after we had already built up a good beginning base, which is just a pet peeve of mine might not be an issue for others. I like the limitation implemented to make sure you cant unlock every single craftable blueprint within the first day cycle or so. Seeing as this is early access there's a decent bit of crafting to begin with which makes for a good foundation to build on.

For the main story well there isn't one. Honestly not a big deal to me, there's a few little quests in the game but no story. I have seen some people saying the beat the game in 30 min and it's not worth it. Honestly they probably just did the story(basically tutorial taking you to quest hub) which I could see taking that long, but to unlock every item, craft everything, build a base, enjoy the game, test is out like is usual for early access then HELL NO it didn't take 30 min. Like i point out earlier in my review we've played a good 7 hours on one solid server with the same host and still don't have everything unlocked. Albiet we did f**k around alot(which come on survival/coop best place for it). Now i believe they could make a mysterious story that is just as good as the narrative of Subnautica, I know many may say that's a stretch since there is no story, but that's the point. In the little tid-bit we get of the story we know nothing, leaving behind the mystery. When you first get into the game it begins basically like Subnautica. Sake up no knowing anything, then finding out everything you can through your surroundings and little "cassettes" left around by someone with information that doesn't really make sense without context. I feel they took a good bit from them as well as The Forest when it comes to Grounded.

Overall i believe this to be a game well worth the $30 price tag even if there is no story and it has some bag bugs at the moment. Yes the beginning was rather game breaking but once it stabled out and we could play was well worth the experience! If you want a story then definitely wait for it in future updates and keep this game followed/wishlisted. If you don't mind no story and basically an Alpha build for the game get it! I've bought many early access games recently and this is the one I know is worth it and i believe in Obsidian. They are a great company and produce amazing products.

A few thoughts...

Good:
Looks pretty
Seems well optimized considering it is in early access
Map is fairly large
You can throw weapons and rocks
You can murder your friends by "Hucking" grass at them

Bad:
No character customization. You get to pick your "teen" 2 males/2 females. They look and sound more like 10-12 year olds
Only 4 players per map.
The map is forced Co-Op but you can murder each other
Building is a bit buggy but it's day 1 of early access
Must use Microsoft/Xbox login which means you use that name rather than getting to pick one.

Overall, I like it. It does feel a bit restrictive though. The game feels as though it is specifically designed for you to play Co-Op only, can only have up to 4 players in the game at a time, and you can only pick pre-made characters and you can't pick one someone else already has. 

I am in the camp of creating your own character that you personally identify with. I am a female in my 30s with red hair blue eyes and pale as mayo. The only reason I am ok with this though is because as much as the game pretends to be Honey I Shrunk the Kids + Rust... it's actually a story driven game (just the story is not really there yet) that has survival and base building thrown into it.

Maybe they will have more game types, more characters to pick, etc. We will see.... All I can say is Heavens forbid this game go down the dirty rat hole of selling additional characters, maps, and cosmetics on a cash shop... 

For now, I give the game a thumbs down, I don't do this lightly and will change my review when more is put in. But right now the game is a sliver of content with a large sandbox to build in. I wish more people could be in my game at once, but I suppose this is fine...

Really fun just to explore the map as long as you don't have a thing against giant spiders that kill you within a hit or two (on highest difficulty). So if you enjoy games like mine-craft you will be at home.

[h1]well, the verdict is going to be hard. let me say it upfront[/h1]
The game has a fresh concept, beautiful artstyle, yet some poor decision making(s) here and there. i mean its an EA game, but come on..
For example, why would you need an Xbox account in order to play MP? Why would you only be able to invite friends from Xbox live friendlist? The fact that they claimed it to be a "crossplay" game, it just doesnt make any sense if you cannot hit up your Steam friends.
Also the 4-player cap could also be a huge dealbreaker to some people.

On the bright side though, apart from the overall idea slash concept i've mentioned earlier, this game is probably one of the prettiest survival games out there, ngl.
The combat, swinging animation, collateral destruction, hitboxes, you name it...everything just feels responsive as hell.
Ambience gets spookier the darker it goes, so dont let the artstyle fools you.

Story wise, during the first EA launch, only 20% is playable and will be added as the development goes further.
I completed mine in 30 minutes, so if you are here for the story then just go somewhere else and get back probably next year.
The universe is obv not too vast atm so you would probably get bored during 2-3h session.
They need to add more challenging features like natural disaster, weather system, and so on. 
I mean seriously, you'd literally be fine having a base without roofs xD

Final verdict: 7.5/10

This game is very buggy... However, the amount of interaction with items, crafting, and survivability weigh out the bad by far!

Currently cannot recommend the game, I am excluding the launch issues and my feelings regarding Xbox live as the sole way of playing online.

Building system is not in a state where it is remotely fun to have to do with. The insects don't give a shit if you have walls as they 1 or 2 shot your walls and just go ham in your base, ours was torn down to the bare bones like 5 times in 2 hours. (Even when we did not attack anything nearby)
AI is still really weird, we tried killing a spider but it keeps running away when it is on low health and then comes back with full, which feels unfair when it literally one shots you from really far away.
Story is at max maybe 20 minutes long unless you build an entire base before progressing the story. 
Progression in general is also really short, we analyzed most of everything in 2 hours.

Overall what you get right now in early access is a grind to make all the gear that's currently available and a "hide your base" simulator as walls do nothing to protect you or your stuff.

Will probably be a good game when it releases though, might revisit it then.

Great Game. The insects reacting to your reactions in the game make the AI a bit smarter, which gives the game a more realistic feeling, and can be a bit scary. As you never know what may show up knocking. Or Lurk your base until you leave just so it can eat all your food, but perhaps you may show up at the same time to catch it in action, and have no choice but to try and save your supplies even though death may come quick. As you change the environment it seems creatures can start to take notice and get more curious of what you are doing. Its hard to tell who you may piss of, and who may become your friend. Coop worked great for me. Recommend playing it coop. Single player could be fun too, but also maybe a bit daunting, and possibly scary at night.

Not gonna lie everyone I do not get why this game has mixed reviews. I know mixed isn't negative, but for an early access package. This has a lot of substance. There is so much more ahead, crazy huge spiders and nicer tier 2 gear, hard to obtain insect weapons and many more things to where I'll even be able to go farm spiders with my friend. They are HARD and hit like a truck, we have killed one fairly. The base building is extensive and I had just barely scratched the surface, still need to unlock/build walls, and build many more utilities around the house. If you played the forest at EA launch. This is 30x better/more complete than that and has a similar feel world building/survival type wise. Give it a try, I think it is a really fun game now and also has tons of potential to be even better if they added more late game armor and bigger, badder insects.

I have THOUSANDS of hours on survival games, and while this has potential, both he balance and the UI need some major overhauls before I can recommend. 

a) backpacks need to de-spawn after a period of time (if they do, it should be shorter) 
b) building capability is miserable. 
c) the game feels like you absolutely need more than 2 players... they should just come out and say so. 
d) ability to empty, exchange and transfer items needs to be made easier. 
e) balance of Aggro and health is a major pain point (large, high health insects are impossible to handle with fewer than 2 people)

Yes, it is early access, but I feel some user-testing should have uncovered some of these issues - and if they did, they would fix before release.

Honey i shrunk the kids by 
Obsidian Entertainment!
There are a few things that are buggy, but it's a fun concept and I know there's more to come.  If you are in it for more than just the "pvp" then you're in for some fun no doubt.

Side Note before Review
Obsidian Entertainment is one of my favorite remaining studios. I say remaining as most companies in the last decade have all gone after quick cash grabs. 

While Obsidian was developing Out Worlds they allowed 13 of their team members work on a different "passion project". This is a game made by people that wanted to experience this game world and play this game not a group looking to make a quick profit. As a gamer I love to support projects like this!  

Pro's

The creatures/AI's
 - Even in early access each bug has its own personality.
 - Interesting world
 - Fun crafting system... I made a helmet out of dismembered ants....
 - Crafting is really decent for a Early Access Game 

Con's (Addressing some other complaints I read from my perspective) 

Multiplayer- Have to use Xbox Live...
 - If you have a Microsoft Account really is not that big of a deal.

$30.00 Price Tag (Frequent complaint) 
 - You spend all your birthday money? 
 - If you love coop the game is worth it
  *Note* Issue I had was frequent crashes from multiplayer however, the game autosaves often. If this is a deal breaker wait a week and I am sure the developers will knock this issue out. 
- Going to possibly have a quick story line. Games great, I read that 20-25% of the story is out currently, I beat that in about two hours (focused on that goal not exploring). So imagining completed story would be around 6-8 hours? Time will tell. 


I always try and support passion projects and this game just came out. I want to give the developers Kudos and see where they go from here to improve this game. A passion project is always a risk, I hope Obsidian and Microsoft will stay this course over becoming like some of the other Triple A studios. 

With my rant over last thing to say is I am going to recommend this to my gaming crew, if they don't buy it then I will get it for them.

Lots of fun little surprises in this game. Definitely worth the $40. I've encountered some minor bugs which are to be expected but nothing game breaking after 8 hours of playtime. No crashes or anything just small things like not being able to press ESC to exit out of a menu or something, but can still use mouse to click exit.

The building system is a bit finicky also. 

Overall, lots of fun though. Would recommend!

This game is fantastic! I am having so much fun. it is just like other survival crafting games but in the best location possible! the bad bugs are fierce! spiders and other large creatures are massive threats that will kill you with ease! range weapons and melee weapons are both viable and bases  can be be upgraded with stronger wallas and traps/lures to protect you from attacks.   story is not complete/released so you dont go far past the demo in campaign but that is alright as it is a survival game and even if it had 0 story it would be fine; although I was enjoying the little story it had so I am eager for updates.  I hope they add more bugs, Events! (like mowing the lawn or watering the grass), more playable characters or a custom character with a pregen characters voice (voice over options from existing characters). I the concept/setting makes it worthy to play even though it isnt as fleshed out as the amazing "conan exiles" or similar; but what it has is great!

The game is in early access. The few things that are wonky are to be expected. Me and a friend played multiplayer, he hosted. There were occasional crashes. My game crashed 3-4 times when I was crafting doors for our base. The building is really, really, wonky. I am surprised that would be allowed in early access.
 Some of the creature also had issue moving, a spider got stuck in water just kinda rubber banding up and down on the surface. Another bug got stuck in a leaf and did the same thing, unable to attack.
 There are some ways to increase your movement speed in the game. When I had this effect, I was rubber banding as I ran. 
 Those are some bad things, obviously it IS in early access, issues are expected. There are, as far as I can tell, a nice variety of creatures to kill, and a cool crafting system to it. The survival aspect is difficult. It isn't so easy as to eat grass; requires more effort to get food than that. The combat, is well done. Smooth hit boxes on the enemies and the attacking weapon. It is very visually appealing. I'm on max setting, and the game looks really smooth.
 I'd say the game is worth $30 as is now, with exception to those few things I pointed out. The fact that it is early access isn't a bad thing at all. It just means that the game will see improvement in the future.

I have a few hours into the game and I am going to say it is a really fun game. I haven't done much of the story and from what people say there isn't a ton at the moment, but the mechanics from crafting, building and overall survival are really fun and enticing. Finding materials and learning new recipes from all of the bug parts, grass, weeds and other plants found in our backyards is exciting! I never knew I could be so pumped up to find an acorn! The game came out saying it will only be a small portion of the total game would be and I will say going into this expecting some triple A adventure, story and gameplay is not realistic. It is a good start to what will be an incredible journey much like the forest (it shares many similarities which is a good thing). I highly recommend throwing your hat in the ring, paying the price (it will increase upon release) and enjoy the journey this game is going on. You also as a consumer need to understand this game is developed by Obsidian Entertainment - legends in the game development field. They are going to provide amazing gameplay and truly deliver upon their promises if not surpass them. Give them faith, give them some funds, and enjoy this sweet roller coaster. There is plenty of content for everyone even at the basic start they have now. The spiders by the way ARE TERRIFYING. Nothing like seeing grass move in the distance and two seconds later a giant wolf spider descends up you. Instant death lol. Please give Obsidian your faith and I am sure it will pay off. There timeline shows they expect to be finished 2021, they are just giving us a taste of the beautiful product they plan. WORTH IT!

Here are my thoughts after 7 hours of gameplay.

- Base building is frustrating and bugged. making a roof was mind fumblingly difficult. you definitely need foundations.

- Spiders are cool, but there are way to many of them (especially given that they can one shot you) and they are super buggy. I also find that even if you dont engage them, they passively walk slowly towards your position for quite some time and for some distance. Spiders need an overhaul ASAP

- I would love more items to improve the single player experience. Like maybe a shield or maybe the ability to tame an ant to use as a distraction

- I was TERRIFIED to get to the robot section because it was near the spider filled tree. It adds integral gameplay and should be easier to get to (especially as a tutorial quest)

- Water and food deplete to quickly for me to reasonably explore. Same with food spoiling way to quickly.

- The base building section needs way more stuff to build. I found that once was base was large and done... it was super barren without building the same things over and over.

- The night portion of the game seems... not scary or different. Besides running into spiders I expected something to happen, but nothing did.

- Once I had everything analyzed the analyzing stations seemed pointless. they cant protect from spiders and most of them dont have any special goods. I loved finding the underground one with granola bars. Made it feel special and unique.

- Exploring certain sections definitely showed how much left is in the game. It feels a lot like Raft right now with the chapters coming out over time.

- Multiplayer is bad right now, but I will wait. Just get rid of the XBOX live garbage and let us connect via steam.

- Let us place or throw torches on the ground so we can fight in dark areas with 2 handed weapons. please.

- I really wish some of the quest stuff was slightly highlighted. I completely missed the first chip near the robot and also missed the button near the first machine. Even a small glow around them wouldve been useful. Or even an arrow at the top of the screen pointing to them.

These are the ones that were at the top of my head. All in all still had fun.

A lot of the negative feedback I've seen for this game revolves around the multiplayer and Xbox account issues. Personally, neither my friend nor I had any issues whatsoever with this, so I can only speak on the game's content. Please keep in mind this game is Early Access and will see multiple updates, likely quite a few early on.

[b]Pros[/b]
-The game is very pretty graphically and doesn't seem to have many of the optimization issues that other survival games have.
-There is very little of the story there, but seems as if it's going to be neat. There's very little of it so far but a pop-up eventually informs you that much more is to come.
-The food and water meters are fair in comparison to resources in the world. You won't be spending 80% of your time hunting them down.
-Combat actually feels incredibly fluid for a day one EA game. There is some major clipping but that will be mentioned in the cons area.
-Crafting is intuitive and fresh. The way you unlock recipes is unique and adds a fun element to game progression.

[b]Cons[/b]
-Base building. I know it's an EA game, but good lord. Good luck placing a valid door that isn't 5 feet in the air, or trying to build a roof in a tight corner. The snapping is terrible as it appears to struggle between placing in mid-air and actually latching onto an object.
-Enemies. Specifically spiders. They will literally come out of [i]nowhere[/i] no matter where you are on the map and mess your shit up DAY ONE. They are incredibly over tuned so good luck taking one down too. Larvae apparently roam in gangs and will rip your face off and then kill the ladybug friend you were kindly building your base next too.
-Ties into enemies, but the clipping is bad. Half of a spider will be protruding through the wall and you can manage to hit it, but it will immediately start smashing your base in anger (and likely destroy anything you have placed next to the wall).
-Gathering materials for the base. Cutting down and carrying grass/wood is tedious and very heavily limits where you can build a reasonable base, especially considering the pacing of the game.

That's all for now. I'll continue to update this as the game progress. As of right now, taking into considering it's EA status, I'd give the game a solid...

[h1]7/10[/h1]

There's a solid foundation here for a good game but it has a long way to go if it wants to rival some of the others out there. Thanks for reading!
