Not many hours ago I would've told anyone how great of a game dev Obsidian is. But I guess even the greatest will have their low moments sooner or later. This honestly felt worse than back when Konami decided to release Metal Gear Solid 5 unfinished, because at least that game still had fun gameplay and enough content to justify its price tag. Grounded on the other hand does not. 

In no way, shape or form is this worth 30,-€. Not only is the story content absurdly short, which is whatever, to be expected for it being Early Access, but on top of crafting recipes being all learned in a short amount of time aswell just makes this a regretful purchase. Co-Op connectivity is as messy as you'd expect it from an Indie developer, except this isn't an Indie developer. I wish Steam gave a larger refund window for Early Access games, but that'll never happen. 

Oh and as a bonus meme: They didn't put the "Requires 3rd-Party Account: Xbox Live" tag in until an hour or 2 after launch. I thought "Wait, I can play this on Steam without the MS shenanigans? Nice!" because honestly if it was made clear beforehand, I would've just tested it via the Game Pass first. We need some brave e-attorneys to file a class action lawsuit for false advertising.  [i]<- That bit right there was a joke, don't @ me with your bar exam quotes[/i]

The game is really fun. It is EA and day 1, so there are bound to be glitches and issues. During the first run through, the issues I noticed were:

[list]
[*]Hard time connecting to multiplayer (seems to be a known issue that is being worked on)
[*]Spiders do [b]way[/b] too much damage and show up out of nowhere, with no warning.  A nerf should happen
[*]Base building is so glitched out, I thought I was going to have a seizure with the extreme flashing of blueprint outlines
[*]Setting up the base and being attacked by larvae made it impossible to even build without dying at [i]least[/i] 4-5 times
[*]There doesn't seem to be a designation when spiders are active/not active. Are there certain times/areas?
[*]Sometimes worker ants just seemed to attack out of nowhere, or soldier ants would appear is [b]mass[/b] completely wiping your character out
[*]Building a door didn't let me align it with the ground and I had to build it raised up...even though the area was completely flat
[*]Trying to build the roof was almost impossible and the roof wasn't aligned with the wall.
[*]Snapping positions for building needs to be fixed (caused the issue of glitching all over the place)
[*]More to come...
[/list]

Overall, I am really enjoying the game. It's visually pleasing, there's lot to do and learn, crafting system is good, combat is fun. Aside from some minor issues, definitely a great game and am looking forward to fixes and updates!
noice game

First few hours in and I'm having fun. Game requires XBOX Live / Microsoft account to play multiplayer which is...I mean not great, but not the end of the world (I'm looking at you review bomb guy.)

Honey I Shrunk the Kids nostalgia is high here, and there is clearly a lot of development to go. Early Access is early access, so that shouldn't surprise anyone at this point. Gameplay wise its a fun, but not too hard survival/craft type of game as expected. I jumped right in with three friends to start and we had a good first evening. 

Stylistically the game looks good, and sounds okay. Seems like some dialog lines have yet to be recorded, because for some things I got subtitles but no audio to go with. Controls are snappy and the whole platform seems stable for a first day of EA. The spider movement in particular looks fantastic moving through the grass, but got a little weird trying to handle elevation. The first time you see those red eyes watching you from the dark though...man...

I'm looking forward to see what Obsidian does to iterate on this going forward!
Some enemies are too easy to defeat due to terrain & AI (bugs will sometimes get stuck), but the gathering, crafting, and questing in this game are really fun.
pretty good for an early access game, im excited for the full release
This is one of the best made survival/craft/building games. Also the content and concept are unique for this genre. No performance issues on 4k/ultra settings(2080 TI / i7 - 8086k).

There's alot that I love about this game.....okay, it's really 90% down to the insects, I'm an entomologist.  I also enjoy the familiar and intuitive survival mechanics....for the most part.   I do have to say, however, that for 30 dollars there are a bit too many roadblocks launching at EA for this price.   Most notably, as others have mentioned, the story is lopped off from progressing very rapidly.  We've seen small indies release into their EA with more depth to a story already and at fractions of this price point.   Also, I find it to be a bizarre design decision to hold the ability to build a basic floor behind a task.  It's unnecessarily arbitrary.   I think most folks want to be able to put in a floor as soon as they start buildin a base.

I am looking forward to this game's continued development (fixing spider species would be nice).  But I would not recommend many people pick it up at its current 30 dollar price point.

It is very short in the story department but with this being early access the focus should be more on how and if everything works and so far it is pretty good. I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys building and survival games. My only concern is with how much they decide to release with updates. Time will tell but I have high hopes.

Survival games are one of my favourite kind of games, and this seems to be living up to everything I had hoped it would be.

It’s [b]Early Access[/b], and so the story element is quite brief, but the game itself is [i]stunning[/i]l. There’s something so purely enjoyable running around in this gorgeous world, eating disgusting stuff and knocking dewdrops off blades of grass while listening to a ladybug the size of a rhino kill some ants. 

The building pieces for making a base are so wonderfully, whimsically designed that I kept going ooh and aah over tiny little details (like how the second tier of storage boxes have a lid that consists of a leaf, where they’ve actually kept the stem on the back end of the chest. It looks [i]so[/i]] lovely. Whoever is doing the designing of the building blocks and items deserves a raise). All the pieces have so much texture and personality. It’s also hugely enjoyable to work as a group to gather the materials and designing structures because of how you put down a blueprint and anyone can add the materials.

I played with two friends, and while we had some initial hiccups with connecting to one another, once we got it to work it worked just fine. However, I do feel the store page should make it clear that just using your steam account won’t allow you to play with your friends. There’s no added cost but a little bit of added hassle that caused some irritation.

If you want to play this for the story element, and don’t care about supporting and beta testing the game in early access, I advice that you wait until they’ve added more of it. As it is, you can run through the story very swiftly.

However, if you (like me) love to play and enjoy games during their development and enjoy waiting excitedly for every update, and you love survival games in general… it could certainly be the game for you. It’s a lot cuter and more playful than any other title I can think of (though perhaps a little reminiscent of Raft?), but it can still be a bit brutal in places.

The first time I ran into a wolf spider I just froze in sheer terror, so it's certainly not just cutsey fun.

Don't see why this costs 40$, needs way fewer bugs and more of everything else. Feels pretty copy/pasted from the survival genre, so if you go for that or just really like tiny stuff maybe you'll like it in it's current state. I refunded for now.
game is a ton of fun with a lot of potential. If your unsure about buying though check out on gamepass.

Requiring you to sign into xbox live, only to be greeted with 30 minutes of story and a non-functioning multiplayer/co-op system which doesn't even allow you to invite people to your lobby. Thank you for the quick refund

[h1]For an Early Access Game, I was impressed at the flow of the game[/h1]

One thing I noticed over some other early access games, was the smoothness. The game runs surprisingly smooth! I didn't do much of the story at all, basically the very initial tutorial quests, but this game has potential.

I plan on going through and finding everything to craft everything. So, even though the story is super short for the time being, the rest of the game should keep someone busy for some time until they add more.

Thought the crafting/menus were pretty intuitive. I didn't feel stumped at the start, where as other survival games seemed to make you work a bit more to figure out some recipes.

Haven't tried multiplayer yet, but the single player so far is nice.
This is an awesome game so far cant wait to see what they come up with in the future..

Good game for being early access, people are complaining with 10 minutes into the game. It's enjoyable, and co-op is fun too. There is a pretty ok story for as early as it is as well. easy 7/10

Great fun so far with friends, played smoothly with 3 other people, 2 on xbox 1 on pc and had no issues until it crashed and now we're having trouble getting back in together. Despite this it seems like a fantastic co-op game and people are over reacting as usual in the reviews. 

UPDATE: 

After some initial trouble rejoining each other, me and my friends had a good 5 hour session with no issues. Base building, fighting bugs, exploring etc. Seems like a great little game so far and very excited to keep finding new things! 

Although the current story isn't long at all, which did surprise us, there is still plenty to discover, long after you get to the current story "end" and you can really tell how good the story will be once more has been added. 

- Would highly recommend for people looking to have co-op fun. Still imagine it would be enjoyable in single player but definitely better with friends at least from my experience.

So far I love it. I've put roughly 7 hours into a single solo world, so here's what I think.  The game is really fun, and its beautiful.  It's worth $40 to me, because its different. It's something for me to play around in and gain technique before it's released.  I'm sure that most players aren't gonna put in the time and effort to just play the game to play the game. 
----As everyone else said there's only 45 minutes of campaign if you take your time. -----
Once I finished the story line i was kind of bummed out, but its very clear that this is only a fraction of the actual story. If you don't mind playing just to play then I say try it out, but i can't recommend this simply because of the price tag.

The negative reviews I'm seeing are disheartening, you should know what you're getting into with an Early Access game. Overall, this game is a lot of fun so far and I very much look forward to seeing what the devs do with this game.

The story is not complete, in fact there barely is a story. If you run through all of the quests without doing anything else, you can reach the end of the current story in 10-15 minutes. It's early access, this should be expected. 

The game play is very enjoyable. The building aspects are nearly identical to The Forest, for reference. You gather materials and analyze them at one of many research stations. You can find research credits scattered around the world at points of interest to turn in for extra useful blueprints at the end of the story. The world is beautiful and the game play is smooth so far. 

I haven't encountered any bugs yet, apart from the ones running around the world trying to murder you.

Support the devs and buy the game if this game interests you, I can see this game having a lot of potential.
it works for me and is fun

Think of this as a less expensive, more polished first release of Ark: Survival Evolved.
It's not complete, and there is basically no story, but man is it a fun base building game, with a cool premise and unique enemies. Overall, worth the $30 for the base builder type gamer (Minecraft, Rust, ARK, etc).

Pros:
Crafting, Base Building, Overall UI - Snappy and Intuitive
Great Accessibility Options
Combat - Difficult but fun!
Graphics - Gorgeous Game and well optimized for Day One.

Meh:
Inventory Management - Currently no way to organize your whole backpack at once. But it can still be done manually.

Cons:
Multiplayer - You are going to have to jump through some hoops to get it working. You and your friends will need XBox Live accounts to connect to each other.
Early Access "Bugs" - Not the insect kind. There are some progress stopping bugs, just be sure to report them so they get fixed!

The game is fun and interesting, but there 100% needs to be a map expansion and WAAAAAY more content if this game is going to be priced this high.

Still fun tho
10/10 for early access.

Solid game so far. Didn't rush through the story, built a small base in the time I played. Excellent mechanics and the only time I dropped below 60fps was when I (/spoiler) entered the lab under the oak tree (/end spoiler).

Also, anyone who has an activated copy of Windows 10 should already have a Windows and therefore an Xbox Live account, so I didn't have an issue with that.

A couple gripes:
-Damage balance. Everything does significantly more damage than the player can. Getting one-shot by wolf spiders whenever they appear isn't fun, nor is getting double-teamed by soldier ants. I have to do 10+ attacks to kill one soldier ant while they can get three hits in on me and I'm down. This is with the first tier of gear, and I don't have experience with the second tier at the time of writing.
-This one is small: lean-to's don't automatically set a spawn point when they're slept in. I either have to a) set spawn, then sleep, or b) sleep, then set spawn, both requiring two menus. Personally, I would prefer if both happened at once on first sleep, then any new lean-to's ask to keep the old spawn point or set a new one.

Other than that, I'm having fun so far! Very much looking forward to where things go.

Assuming more content is added on a regular basis then yes I can recommend it.

If you don't want to wait for new content then no do not buy this right now, there is very little content. The story so far can be completed in about 20-30 minutes, then you're just left crafting, building your base etc.

But assuming there is regular content this should be a great game.
The style is very charming, I love the Honey I Shrunk The Kids concept. 
So far I haven't encountered any issues and the game runs fine for me. 

I am disappointed that I paid £24.99 for next to no content, but it is day 1 early access so I'm expecting big things over time.
I... will... kill... wolf... spider...
Certainly has some rough edges to be worked out, but that's early access for you. The concept is interesting and so far I'm having a good time!

The only thing I don't like is the significant depth of field, however, as I played I got used to it and it does make you feel small.  You can focus on far objects and the blur partially decreases. I still kind of wish it was adjustable. There is basically no story yet but the gameplay is quite fun. Finding new crafting materials, landmarks, food, and bugs is cool. Exploring, fighting, and crafting as a tiny person is cool. Some are comparing it to ark which I get but to me it feels much closer to subnautica (on land). If the premise of a survival game as a tiny person doesn't excite you or you're waiting for the story then this isn't your game yet. I played subnautica in early access too and it changed so much over it's development. I'm looking forward to playing this game as it grows. As this gets more content I think it will be one of my favorite games.

Well the story mode so far is a bit short but for early access I wasn't expecting as much as is here. Depending on the frequency of updates this game might be great fun to keep up with. The gameplay is simple enough without being the same old boring trope and allows for tons of playtime already. They have basic building available (and even some stronger versions of the basic building) They have a variety of armors depending on what stat you want to increase (more carry weight, move faster, hunger drops slower) They have a bunch of weapons which is really fun to try each one out. The best thing about the game so far is the map. A lot of detail and tons of points to explore, each with a reason and certain resources nearby.If you want to see the gameplay including some of the story you can watch my gameplay of it here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=55thDkbr8nk Keep in mind this is at time of release and depending on updates is not fully up to date with the current state of the game

Played this game with my s/o an hour after it's release, we had fun but also some complaints. 
First and foremost, the game at it's current state is absolutely NOT worth $30. There is little to no content already and the game wants you to finish the story immediately. Even if you weren't trying to progress with the story right away, you would still do it by accident. It's incredibly easy to finish the story in 10 minutes, even without knowing much about what's going on. In BOTW you could go straight to the castle and finish the game technically, it's open from the start. However, the game encourages you NOT to do this as it's very dangerous and gives you a lot of other options to help you progress and learn how to play. Right after the incredibly short tutorial, Grounded sends you off to do the 20% of content immediately. [spoiler] I believe if you told the players to go explore and find the landmarks/stations or find the tapes BEFORE telling them to fix the wires, it would be a lot better. Or even making the players have to progress a lot more before they're able to fix the wires. Being able to fix everything almost instantly is pretty lame. [/spoiler] *potential game content spoiler

The only reason I'm giving this game a thumbs up is because it has a LOT of potential. This is very unique and refreshing and I quite enjoy it. I'm very excited to see the game improve and have more content. Even with the disappointment of the lack of content, I had a really fun time playing this game for the first time.

This is only an initial review as I think I'm at the three hour mark, but this game is a different bag of chip. I've been excited about it for months now, and waited with baited breath this morning for the game to hit the store, then download. I waited and didn't play the demo, because I wanted more than just the demo. To say I'm excited is an understatement, actually. 

To start off, I personally had to turn down the blurring motion and put myself in 3rd person because I'm easily motion sick from certain game and that fixed the only major problem I had. (Outside of the 5 year old that was sitting next to me asking when his turn was.) I'm playing a single player, offline game, so it feels pretty seamless at this point. 

My first hour was spent discovering random things, learning to find water, food, smack things. I'm finding the ants both creepy and adorable, the lady bugs are literally the size of a Fiat, and we won't even traipse into the wolf spiders. (Side  note! There is a setting for the spiders! Although, I honestly feel they need to size scale the photo that they show you of what they look like. The wolf spider may as well be a mini mansion.) Speaking of, my second hour was spent trying to beat lawn mites, make torches, before I got ate (not literally) by the above mentioned wolf spider and just about flipped my lid because all I saw was a leg come down over me before it nonchalantly traipsed past. No big thing, right? <_<

The third hour, after finding my bag of goodies where I'd had my face eaten, was when I dove into the building aspect of the game. So far, I really like the building. It's easy while still being a challenge. I'm still discovering things, and I also really like how you "haul" things. This isn't a game where you shove 90 planks in your pack; No, you're going to be carrying those on your shoulder or "hucking" them. 

My two somewhat dislikes are minor and I can get past those. The first being water, it's sort of both sides of the coin, ground water is drinkable, but even your character makes jokes about cholera, etc. The process of getting fresh water at first is a bit more difficult, doable, but difficult. (Not going to mention exactly how, don't want to spoil that for other.) My second thing on the con side, although, again minor, I'd like to see more of an opening to the game down the road. 

Overall first impressions, the game is fun. I can see it being a lot more fun the more fleshed out it gets. I'd love to try to co-op mode at some point as well to see how it functions. I'll be diving back in later!

You can really tell a lot about a person based on their description of games.  Kids these days will compare it to A Bug's Life.  To me, this is a great "Honey I Shrunk the Kids" style survival game with so much potential (imagine having to explore the house to continue the story!).  I'm not biased against Early Access games at all, and just imagining all the places (maybe even inside the house) that could be added, really appeals to me.

I would not recommend buying this in its current state if your plan is to play with your friends. Its very hit and miss for being able to join your friends games and sometimes it wont work at all. However if you want to buy it now to enjoy the solo experience id highly recommend it but we all know these types of games are mostly enjoyed with your friends and the multiplayer quite frankly does not work at the moment.

Fun game all I was looking for in a game based on a good movie from my childhood, main issue as a lot of people say is you need an xbox live to play multiplayer and I think that is ridiculous. The future is now and you should be able to play with whoever, however and not have it restricted to xbox because microsoft owns obsidian. Otherwise I think it's pretty fun and I understand it is still early access but a story mode should be expanded and better explained. Been looking forward to this game and was not upset.

First, I'd like to say that I had played the Demo for many hours, so most of my 'first impressions' are based on that.   The TL/DR  though:  "Recommend the game, but either wait for a sale, or wait for more progress to be made on it"


So.  The game.  "Is this game worth it right now?"  I'd say,  yes.  However, is it worth the $30 asking price?  That's harder to answer.  Since I loved the Demo I was ready to pay that much, but I do feel that it could have stood to have a "Launch Day Sale".  With that being said, I'd suggest either waiting for full release or for a sale.

Content?  As of right now, I'm still (slowly) making my way through the game and taking my time doing things.  This is where the $30 asking price is probably a turn-off for most people.  Unless you're okay with knowing RIGHT NOW it has a small amount of content,  I'd again suggest waiting until the game's filled up more and is better suited to the price it currently has. 


Another mixed thought I have is the bare-bones "Tutorial".  I'm no stranger to games like this having minimal or even no tutorial, expecting you to figure things out on your own.  Heck, Minecraft was a lot like that too.  It's not terribly hard to figure things out though, and the Research stations help with filling in the blanks. My suggestion, research those plant fibres right away.
Could it stand to have a better tutorial? Sure, it wouldn't hurt any - but I don't hold it against the game for not having an amazing one either.


So final thoughts?  Yeah, I could recommend the game.  Can I recommend it for $30? Probably not. I'd say "Wait a while, or get it on sale".

At launch this game is missing a lot but its still really fun and the graphics are very good, I have now progressed far enough to have gotten the ladybug armor. i can say that this game is lacking content but it still has very high potential with future updates.

First real review and I gotta say feels nerve wracking but lets get into it.
First lets talk about the narrative with the story feels like its going in a great direction where will it go not sure. what i could gather so far from playing it shows great promise with a interesting but slightly wacky mustache enthused scientist with an experiment going wrong. That within it self had sold me even with as little we got the tapes that discovered also brought me deeper into the lore and narrative.
For the game play it definitely has a good survival crafting element to it with more edible options I'd say. The drinking mechanic and that alone was unique to me with the small water globules getting smaller till its all gone or even left there make a canteen come back and save it because of the scale in which the world took place and that is very refreshing to me. 
So far I'm in love and I sunk a decent amount of time but I can't wait to go further into this world and uncover more of the story.

Mixed thoughts right now!

Im going to start with the bad point first and end on the good stuff!
Cons...
After 2 hours of play this game no longer lets me play...my first save for some reason as it was becoming day time on the second day the brightness got insane and everything went crazy bright green like neon, eventually the whole screen went pure white and now that is the after math on loading that save so i started a new game, but even worse now i click play on steam it starts to load and bam! straight back to steam, so i have currently wasted 25 bucks on a game i cannot even open, i have had 4 or 5 crashes closing the game with no freeze or warning mid play, to return and find my save was a few minutes back which in a survival game like so every second counts, re crafting things re collecting resources etc.

Pros...
The graphics are great, i have not had any graphical issues, lag or frame drops whilst playing, after 2 hours of game play running around trying to collect as much as everything like a hoarder to get a nice little base set up, i did not bother with following the tutorial i wanted to just explore and it was fun, i shall try multi-player tomorrow when a friend gets it and i feel it will be good. controls feel good and set out good. and the option of 1st and 3rd person makes the game even better.

Right now i do not recommend this game, its good for a short time but too many crashes and other issues and currently not that much content, at a later date indeed i would completely recommend when its larger in content, but not for the price now! avoid for a while and come back later, you will thank me!

So this game has a lot of potential, I enjoy the building and almost all of the aspects to the game. Yes multiplayer needs to be worked on a tad but that is to be expected. My only gripe so far is that after sleeping in my shelter the past couple nights, everytime I wake up there were about 10 larva bugs that swarmed my base as soon as I woke up, this is only a problem because I as a single player had no way to fight that many bugs and they destroyed my entire setup. I could understand maybe 1 or 2 to fight but 10 was a little overwhelming. So after 3 hours of playing and gathering it all went to waste after one night. Not sure if I am doing something wrong or not but just thought I would share.

ok so me and my friends had been waiting to get this game for about a month. so fast forward to today and it just has so so so little content like you can do the whole story in id say about 30 mins but after all it isnt all about the story but then the game is just so buggy like for example spiders stuck in rocks getting teleported around when walking thru clovers or just multiplayer not working as a whole. i think that the concept is super cool but there is just so little content that it is in no way worth 30 hard earned moneys

A very fun and pretty looking survival game.  As a lot of reviews will state, it took influence from the movie "Honey I shrunk the kids"  Funny movie BTW, only the first one.  lol,  I digress...  It's early access so there is A LOT more coming but what's here is GREAT!  Pick this up if you like survival games, very well done OBSIDIAN.  Didn't expect this.  Love it!

Me and my friends enjoyed this alot.
There is no Steam multiplayer, but thats ok.
No latancy problems.

EDIT: There is multiplayer, idk where these negative reviews are comming from..
Although you have to connect with your xbox account.

Game was a lot of fun. I played single player and the only bug i ran into was getting stuck and had to reload. Aside from that, not a single bug noticed. The gameplay is short however, as in almost 6 hours I had finished my large base and unlocked all of the crafting recipes. You can complete the story that is in the game in about 20 minutes if you wanted to. 

If you enjoy builders, this is a good choice but be weary that it is short as it just launched on early access. The foundation is very solid and as far as early access goes, this is probably the least buggy game i've played. The game is also on xbox gamepass so if you have that you can try it there. 

TLDR: Highly recommend, although short game. Best early access i've played, the only early access part is the lack of content despite being bug free.
Looks absolutly gorgeous, run smoothly, clean gameplay, clean interfance, it's a rare sight in Early Access. It also has a lot of potential in the future (currently lacks content)
very good survival mix of holy sh!t hard and paced progress

so...played the game a few hours...and so far its a lot of fun :)
played it solo and it runs pretty smooth on my 5-6 year old system, which is a big pro!
i followed the little main quest to the current end and for now, it seems there is "only" exploring the world, survive the environment and basebuilding left to do till the next content updates...which is totally fine for me.
obsidian delivered a beautiful and coherent world in an very polished state (for an early access-game)...and for 30 euro i have seen much worse. yeah, they did nothing groundbreaking new, but the atmosphere, gameplay and writing is more than decent and promising.
also, didn`t experienced any major bugs (beside the enemys ;)) or crashes.
i also read about the multiplayer and its problems, which the developers will hopefully fix soon respectivley make it easier to use. 
but, overall its a pretty good und promising foundation, thumbs up!

Despite all the mixed reviews, this is a great game.  Im sure we are all thinking it when we see the trailers,  Honey I Shrunk the Kids.  Its a great idea and it has some great potential.  Grounded takes the survival genre and turns it in a fun and clever way.  The fact that simple things like ants and dung beetles are now one of your biggest threats, not to mention spiders.  I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good survival game.
Nice Game make lots of fun.

I wanted to give this a positive review so I did, however it has issues with multiplayer, bugged bugs(A spider walking sideways), and a lack of story(don't even get me started on BURGL's so called "purpose". All in all this is a fun game for play by yourself if you have a beefy rig and can tolerate slow pacing lack of story and no good multilayer.

Fun game. Great looking. Nothing more fun then fighting off an ant invasion. The spiders are impressive, at least the wolf spider is. hope they develop it further, has a lot of promise and great graphics.

This is the most amazing and terrifyingly thrilling game I have played almost beating subnautica. It can be pretty hard in the beginning but take your time and use google and stuff. I would absouloutely recommend this game even though is only in early access.

I'm gonna throw my 2 cents in here. I'm giving it a good review. Too many people seem to be giving it a bad review because of a bug or a crash here or there, literally on day one, hours after launch. It's an Early Access title, it's in the description, bugs are to be expected, even on a full game that's not Early Access. 

Just from the little bit of game I put in with 3 other friends, I can tell this is going to be a game I'm going to enjoy. I would honestly recommend waiting for a week or so after launch. So devs can iron out the crashes/bugs some of us are encountering. Once that is out of the fixed though, I would recommend the game fully.

Also, the spiders are terrifying. There appears to be a severe lack of flamethrowers that I hope the devs can fix one day.
Grounded provides a refreshing take on a very overdone genre and manages to both look and play superbly, for an early-access title. (Refunded because I didn't realise it was on Xbox Game Pass)

Magical, Amazing!  I needed something uplifting today.  I love Destroy All Humans, but I downloaded this and found it to be amazingly what I expected and more.  Encountering some of the "lawnland critters" is enchanting.  I've read it compared to Ark, but this simply feels much more intuitive, survivable and fun.  Granted, I haven't gone too far yet but where I am now is enough to make me happy for hours.  I've been a long time fan of "shrunken people" stories and the world from bug's eye view, this is completely it.  I've encountered no flaws or glitches yet, there's no cumbersome tutorial but just the right help guides that come up when you need them.  If not, you have all the information you need in the menus as well.  I'm playing single player so I can't comment on co-op.  I love that the ants didn't attack me, yet.  Kind of felt welcome.  By all means if the screenshots and videos interest you, this game will too.  It feels very polished already.  Good work Obsidian!

Honestly a really good game so far. Already pretty polished for an early access game (if you ignore the crashes). Visually really good and a lot of fun with friends.

Ok, first of all this is an early access game. It came out 5 hours ago prior to this review. People who complain about it being "buggy" "cant connect" complaining about having to use xbox account, you guys are idiots especially writing a review with 0.5hours????

In my opinion the issues I have had is yes it does take a while to "host a game + get a friend to connect" but if you keep retrying it works after a while. Just be paitent. I didnt have any problems with starting the game, everything worked fine [might be your shitty pc's that is the problem].

To all of you who are thinking of buying/playing it. Here are the pro's + cons.

Pro's
> I love the cartoony/kiddy art style reminds me of Raft. So if you like that then by all means play it!
> I have encountered the spiders and man it is scary when they pop out of no where lol.
> The game runs smoothly and i had no issues with certain things.
> So far the story is pretty cool and exploring underground places is pretty fun especially on top as well.
> Building mechanics I really enjoy and crafting is simple.

Con's
> It lacks content at the moment as its early access. There is only so much you can do after progressing through the story.
> Tutorial is simple and not completely friendly but you do get used to it and figure it out. Just use your brain. lol

P.S i will be playing this game more as its very enjoyable xd

Visually this game is incredible and the sound is amazing. 
Story is very short right now but the potential of wonder is there and the bugs are a lot of fun. 
Spiders are horribly overpowered which makes you fear them 10x more than you normally would, makes for somewhat tedious gameplay but makes sense seeing as they're also 10x your size.

Overall, this game has a lot of potential. Obsidian has a great survival game on their hands if it's treated with love and care. 
Is it worth 30 dollars? Yes and no. 
Are you a hardcore survival game player expecting a game with content and gameplay value like ARK or something like DayZ or something? Then you might not enjoy this for 30 dollars. 
Are you looking for simply fun time with some friends, nothing mechanically challenging but visually enjoyable to just be in? It's worth it entirely. 

I'm enjoying the game highly and hope they continue with development on this title for a long time.
This game seems like it was very rushed. Doesn't seem very polished. Not worth the 30 dollars at all. The devs have some work to do before this game is ready to play to be honest.

At this point I allow myself a first review after almost 2 hours.

First for the good:
- I haven't had a single crash.
- I couldn't find any serious bugs
- Coop + online sessions work without problems
- The world is graphically beautiful and looks very lively
- The gameplay is easy to learn, yet challenging
- It's definitely a lot of fun, even solo! 
- I was able to stream without any problems, everything went smoothly

Unfortunately the game has a serious dark side:
- I can't seriously make an EA game (yes, I know, EA means "unfinished") that offers story content in about half an hour! Obsidian Entertainment, are you serious?

I would definitely not recommend the game at this point! My viewers and I looked really stupid when the story suddenly stopped!

the game just came out so the mp aspect is broken but the game runs well while solo, when you encounter spiders and other larger insects you will die until you figure out how to get better at the game its fun but i currently dont think its worth the price
I don't get why people give this game a negative rating. Co-op works just fine and this game looks amazing so it should be no surprise that it will be hard to run on low end computers.

In the Hour and a half o play time I've done so far its was pretty fun. While there is notably low FPS, running around 45 fps, its not unplayable. The tutorial is pretty confusing to start out, but you can get the hang of it pretty easy. SPOILERS: For those having a hard time. You need to go to the stations that are mention to research item you pick up to be able to craft more item, Plant Fiber and Sprigs are your friends and used to craft most items. so pick it up when you see it. Once you get those things I recommend making a basket to help store items. Ants are mostly non threatening but will steal items for your baskets, so make sure to also build a base. Exploration is also good as there are spots with resource rich areas.

NOT CO-OP YET! Avoid until they actually impliment CO-OP!

ALSO, NO STEAM MULTIPLAYER.

XBOX ACCOUNT REQUIRED.

I've seen many reviews commenting on the 'lack' of features, but hardly any seem to appreciate the quality of this title so far. Almost everything feels refined and well made which justifies the price for me, and there's definitely a lot to do in terms of crafting/building. I would sooner be drip fed small additions to a carefully made story, than be given 90% of a half cooked idea. There wouldn't be a reason to keep coming back if we already had everything, and I'm more than excited for the future of this game.

It's not a bad game overall, but as of right now the game doesn't worth it's price tag. The story is fairly short as expected since it's in early access after all. There aren't many bugs that I've experienced but the ai could use some improvements. They would constantly just run away when they are at low health and come back when they are full hp especially the spiders which is frustrating. My friend and I were able to trap the big spiders in the electric machine and were just able to kill it for free. Overall the game has a lot of potential. I enjoyed the time I've played so far and can't wait for future updates however I do not recommend buying this game as of right now.

This game in its "Preview" is absolutely beautiful. The map is gigantic. The crafting options is endless. The challenge is there based on areas you go like most survival games. 
Its basically the breath of fresh air that crafting/survival players have been looking for. 
The thing I can't stand is all the negative reviews for people who are having a hard time understanding what "preview" means....
This means its playable, you can have a great time. ITS NOT FINISHED. It's an xbox/windows game, do your research and read instead of just buying then complaining. EVERY screen before you start reminds you of this. Stop negative bombing this just because you fail to read and are spoiled on the concept of finished games. 
This game will be top of the list for a long time coming much like Ark and 7 Days. 
I look forward to all the devs are doing and thank them for creating such a beautiful environment.

as of writing there is little content to this game. enough to get a few hours of play out of but still bare. it is however VERY well polished and other than one time the A.I. got a bit confused I haven't seen any issues. the setting is just as fun to run around in as you would think. oh and if you have a fear of spiders there is a setting already in the game to make them less real.

Game starts with a warning right on the load screen...

"This title is pre-release software.  Platform features or the game itself may not work correctly, and may crash."

However running it at 1440p on epic settings no problem, I can say that it is a very pretty game that alot of work has gone into.  Yes only the intro of the story is in the game but lets be real, people don't play 7days2die, ARK, etc for the intro story.  They play for the sandbox, the customization freedom you have when building, the exploration to find different things.  Even though its just a back yard, there is plenty of stuff to run around and find.

I have been entertained so far in learning lots of recipes, having to venture and attack harder bugs to get better tiers of tools, weapons, armor (which have set bonus's), building defenses...

The bug AI is also kinda fun to mess with.  The little leaf eaters skitter away when you loot at them.  A ladybug kept following me around investigating me chopping down grass, dandelions, etc.  I even messed with the ants, crafted an unsecure pot and put food in it out by itself, was funny watching one worker ant sniff it out then abunch of worker ants come back and raid the food.

So far the game is just a baby getting started though I see alot of stuff that can easily make it turn into like 500 hours of fun messing around playing just like in 7days2die and ARK.

[H1]Great potential, yet [i]very[/i] limited Early Access launch. [/H1]

[olist]
[*] Firstly, to cover all the negative reviews for the co-op not working, I experienced this issue as well. I exited the game and reloaded it, and was able to connect with a friend, no problem.
[*] The crafting and modular building systems in the game are nice, compared to many other crafting/survival games I've played. (Although, I couldn't find floor pieces, so I was stuck using scaffolding, unfortunately)
[*] in its current state, I cannot see enough flushed out mechanics that would provide longevity or replayability. After messing around for 90 minutes, we built everything we could want to build, researched most of the craftables, and completed the story up to what's currently implemented. We didn't explore all the caves, because it felt pointless after we built everything and completed the current story.
[*] The game is gorgeous, and well optimized (just under 4 gigs for great looking textures, audio, lighting, subsurface scattering, etc.)
[*] Death seems to hold no real consequence. Subnautica had a similar issue in its early stages of development. Why bother drinking and eating if you can just die and respawn at a location you can create? Subnautica got passed this issue by having such a large map, the player was inconvenienced by being dragged away to their last spawn point while losing their means of travel. Hopefully Grounded gets updated to a similar, or perhaps better solution for hunger/thirst/death being more meaningful.
[/olist]

I can foresee Grounded taking one of 2 potential routes with their updates:
[olist]
[*] Create an immersive story that provides a few hours of entertainment, but little to no replayability.
[*] Focus more on the survival and building elements, with more diversified goals for the players to explore or seek out, like "The Forest" or "Ark: Survival Evolved". 
I'm hoping more for this option, so the game will be worth spending hours in, with friends. 
As it stands, everything is too easily achievable, even in the hardest difficulties of the game. This robs the players of a sense of accomplishment, when they can make everything in merely a couple hours, without the fear of dying causing set backs.
[/olist]

As for bugs (not the creepy crawly ones) I only ran into 1, so far. My buddy was stuck in a spider web, broke the web with a hatchet, but was still stuck in the air. He needed to log out and rejoin my game to fix it.

I will provide a positive rating, and recommend this game as it gets updated. Obsidian Entertainment has a solid list of games under their belt, so I do not believe they will abandon this game in it's early stages of development. 
I do hope they find a way to stretch out the game into something I can stay immersed in for many hours like [b]"Subnautica"[/b], [b]"The Forest"[/b], and [b]"Ark: Survival Evolved"[/b] did.
So far, so good.

So far the game is great! As a lot of the reviews say it is buggy, but I imagine the developers will be working to fix the bugs pretty quick. So far I have only crashed once and the game auto saves regularly so I didn't really loose that much progress. 

The story is a bit short for now, but there are still little missions you can do and there is a good amount to explore.

I have not tried Multiplayer yet but I do see comments about how the game is currently having problems with Multiplayer. Not only that but the game does require a Microsoft account to play Multiplayer. I don't mind this much as I already have a account but I can understand for people who don't how annoying it would be or inconvenient it would be.

Over all I think the game is fun and after a bit of bug fixing would be great to play with friends.

Requires an Xbox Live accounts and its associations of your account data to the Xbox live services in order to play coop multiplayer which as of todays date (Launch day 7/28/2020) has not been mentioned ANYWHERE in the games store page, or ANY of its advertising videos.

Played the game with a group of 4 friends for a bit. The only way to host a game with friends was to spam the "host" button until you create the lobby or else you would get a connection error. If you want to join a friend's game you need to spam the "Join" button until you see your friends game. You can definitely tell that it is a Day one Early Access game, there is a lot of bugs (no pun intended). The graphics are great looking but it is a little unoptimized, which is weird seeing that this game is made by Obsidian. As of this review, after the second mission a big message comes up saying there will be more missions to come in the future and that for the time being, we can do quests and build/explore. For a $30 game, it is hard to reccommend but i can see this game being great in the future with the right content and patches being made. This is definitely a game I will come back to in the future since I already own the game, but if you are finding yourself read the reviews right now thinking about buying it I would wait for a sale or wait until more content gets added and patches get made.
Kinda wack that for $30 you get a tech demo that has 15 minutes of content.

Only about 1 hour in so far but it was pretty cool and feels like i havent done nothing yet because im not rushing the main story ( Not very long so far apparently ) and just exploring and looking at the base building and other stuff and can easily see myself getting at least 10 - 15 hours out of this so far at this very early stage. I think people that are just going to rush the story and not do much else will be very disappointed. I think it has big potential though. Note im only playing solo but seems like the game is having problems so far with the co op so would wait for a bit until it gets sorted if you plan on playing with a mate.

Akin to playing other games of this genre have managed to spend 3 hours killing bugs and building a house rather than playing the campaign side of things. I have died to spiders many times (and screamed often) and enjoyed co-op play. The game is pretty and I haven't finished the story line yet. Gameplay is great so far with only small hitches which are clearly designed for consoles with more streamlined controls (such as gliding).

For an early access game at £25 that STATES the full story is not there and there are only 2 tiers etc etc I fully reccommend this game to casual players. Do not expect a multi hour story arc on early access or high fps, this is a test phase for optimisations and bug fixes not a finished game.

Down points:
Xbox account required
More graphically demanding than you expect (1080 getting 70fps avg 1440p@Med).

tl;dr Campaign not yet released (or there wouldn't be a final game), Bug smashing is fun, Spiders are terrifying. Play for fun and support of the devs.
The game looks beautiful, but is lacking in gameplay however it is early access. So it might eventually get great.

Although this game seems to be getting some negative reviews based on how co-op isn't working. As of me writing this the game has been out for only 4 hours. I haven't been able to try out the co-op as none of my friends have the game yet. When I try it I will update this.

As for now I highly recommend the game. It has the feel of the forest but is more lighthearted.  You're  immediately thrown into a world with no reason why you've been shrunk and what to do from there. While you leave the initial starting area the tutorial starts. As you follow the tutorial you should be following a path from where you've woken up from. Through this path you will find a mysterious device in which you will interact with. After you do everything it needs you meet a robot that explains some what of what happened and what to do next. 

[i]*** The game developers note that there isn't a lot of content in the initial release but they plan on adding more content as creatures, quests, and more. This is shown within the game after you complete the tutorial as a pop-up message. ***[/i]

Overall I think this game has potential to be a fun game if you like resource management, open world/sandbox games. If you enjoyed The Forest you will most likely enjoy this game. But as for now the game has some content but not a lot so If you want more content I would wait a while before purchasing if that is your concern.

Early Access, about an hour or so of story content.  Single Player is fun so far.  The environment is good, nice graphics, good sound.  The ladybugs sound...terrifying, grunting and groaning.  Played around a little with base building, seems intuitive, but too early to tell yet.  I don't understand the gameplay mechanic behind making you wait to analyze the things you find.  I think its to force you to find other stations, but exploration should be up to the player.  Not a fan of limiting options on a time delay.  Feels too "Mobile App-ish".  Overall, it's pretty good.  Open-world sandbox to fumble around in.  Excited for where this could lead.

Man, this game has a ton of "BUGS"! Joining my friend's games is difficult to get working as their are no game-invites yet and the server browser doesn't work very well since I have to spam the refresh button a lot. But it's pretty ok when you get it working. Game looks nice and the bugs are terrifying. But the hot-bar doesn't work half the time in multiplayer and I crash a lot. Crafting bases is super wonky; Placing walls and roofs is a nightmare, the placement tool is overly-sensitive and it takes a while to place things where you want them. But hey, IT"S DAY ONE in EARLY ACCESS!! It's fun, it really is. A lot to do; A lot to see. You'll need an Xbox Live account, which is no big deal. Not sure why people complain about that, IT"S AN XBOX GAME. I'm thankful Microsoft put it on Steam.

The game is really bad. The story is so short and the multiplayer barely scrapes it as functional. SO much work is needed to make the game good, probably won't play for a few months. Classic XBox game.

Well... i couldn't wait for this, i was so excited! i bought myself and my fella a copy and how disappointed i am, its such a shame! It looks great and we never had a problem getting into a game together. The problem is the story , i understand this is early access but to have 30-40 mins of story and then it just suddenly stopping is very disappointing. When the devs put more story in i will recommend it but as it stands right now i may as well play other survivals i have. I'm gutted but i will be keeping my eye on this game and as it develops more i may come back.

I see some mixed reviews here and some misunderstanding.

To clarify about Multiplayer - There is online multiplayer as of the release (Just played for 2 hours with my friend) however you do need to have a Microsoft account to sign in and use Xbox services. Players can not join lobbies at the moment but one person will need to start a game as the Host, and other players can join as long as they are friends on Xbox with you and then they can join the in-progress game.

The game itself is quite fun, and there are some annoying bits here and there as it is clear it is geared towards Xbox system.

The mechanics are pretty much the same as The Forest in the sense of chopping trees and building bases. Thirst and Hunger are not too difficult to deal with but it can be hard to get started. 

The graphics are pretty good and the story is okay so far (apparently it is short but I have not finished it 2 hours in since I focused my base walls). 

There are not to many bugs that I have ran across, some very minor things. The base building can be wonky since walls cannot go into world objects very much at all (say an adjacent rock) so it makes it hard at times to completely enclose an area while making use of the natural wall structures (dirt hills and rocks for example).

I would say $30 does seem a little pricey for the current content but the game is still a lot of fun and offers a good amount of content, even if its sandbox, for the time being. Overall I would recommend the game now assuming content and bug fixes will release fairly often.
Online coop is not functional through steam, until this gets fixed i recommend steering clear.

Don't you just love it when multiplayer doesn't work? Don't you also love it when you have to create a third party account to play a game for sale on steam? I sure do. I refunded this one faster than it took to install this game. Thanks Microsoft for fucking up a really fun looking title.

Okay, I can't believe this.. Where should I begin with this? Look, I don't know why people are complaining about the fact you have to log in with an Xbox Live account to play this online. If I recall right Sea Of Thieves and every other Xbox Steam release did the same thing, So that wasn't an issue for me..

Now, what is an issue is the optimization.. It's awful! I dropped down to 48 fps on High settings & my specs are an RTX 2070 Super, 16 Gb of DDR4 ram & an i7 9700k! There is no WAY that should be happening on my rig.

Honestly though what's worst than that, is the fact they are charging $29.99 for a demo.. This doesn't feel like early access at ALL, It's polished.. Gameplay & graphics wise but, I finished the "Story content" in just under an hour. The only thing left to do after that is just some daily's, base building & exploring.

Cool concept with great graphics & game play.. but, it's not worth the asking price right now. Charge your customers when you have a game.. Not a DEMO!

Its filled with vibrant colors and obviously reminds me of "Honey I shrunk the kids."  I haven't attempted multi-player but already can see a lot of fun potential with additional folks playing.  I'd recommend it now but with the caveat that the game is 100% complete.  It does play like a complete game though...  Price seemed reasonable at $29.99.   My guess is that it will be a $39.99 game when it goes gold.  The fact that it works on PC and Xbox is a plus as well.   Interesting title and worth the investment.

Pros:

Voice Acting much better than demo

Grounded looks and plays great for an early access game. Together with a mate we completed the main objectives in a co-op game and had no issues logging in or connecting. We both found crafting and base building intuitive and fun, especially being able to share the construction of the base. The spiders made for some intense game play!

I look forward to more exploring, crafting and base building while patiently waiting for more story driven content.

Disappointed to say the least. This is, like the trailer said, the second most anticipated game of 2020 for me. I played the demo and got excited for the game because the demo was just a little sneak peak right? Wrong. There are only a few more missions in the story therefore the story in the game currently is unfinished. I did all the story quests in an hour and then got told that I could do quests like analyze things, find certain areas, kill certain bugs, and build a base. Boring. They need more story in this game and more exciting things to do. As of now, before the story-line has been completed and on Early Access Day 1, I can say that this game is not ready to be enjoyed with friends and can barely be enjoyed alone...

So for those who leave the bad reviews, yes It's still Early access, treat it as such.
And yes, online co-op is available but it's tricky if you don't know how to do it. Since they haven't implemented it yet in-game, you'll need to manually join your friend via the microsoft/xbox "launcher".

So, now that that's out of the way...

Minor bugs here and there as expected. 
Graphics decent, well made, ladybugs are cute. (Spiders bad).

This game has potential and I wouldn't recommend this to all you "hype players" who only seem to hate at minor things. Game is overall cute, terrifying and enjoyable if you let it be. Perfect game for just some casual bug hunting (actual bugs) solo or with friends (recommended with friends tho).

Load times are good, no stuttering, after playing 2 hours straight. Why I think this game is in early access is because they're still adding in features, such as more bugs and more story. I think I've seen just about every insect you can come across, and yeah, those spiders are scary.

I think Grounded has alot of potential, and they have a TON of material to work with, so I can say that I am excited to see what comes next with this game.

I have a 7700k, 1080, and 16gb of RAM. On medium settings, this game struggles to maintain 60fps at 1440p. It will spike very frequently, hitting as low as ~20fps. It's a good-looking game, but this is no technical masterpiece that warrants that kind of performance.

The online requires an Xbox Live account. This would be fine, if you needed that for cross-platform play, but that is currently the only way to play online. As of 3pm EST on 7/28/2020, this is not mentioned on the store page for the game.

This game has a lot of potential, as the art style is very interesting and reminiscent of "A Bug's Life". Here's to hoping that Obsidian manages to optimize the game and provide meaningful content updates.

With caveat. The game is in early access and just released, so I expected some bugs. However it looks like this is going to be a Day 1 Patch (thanks Microsoft).

First, I wanna say that I only have this under Not Recommended, as I'd suggest holding off on buying it until people have had time to report bugs and issues.

So far this game looks promising. The UI is nice, the atmosphere is great, points to the VAs and character designs too!

On the flipside, Max's line "Imagine how that sounded when it hit the ground! BOOM!" is fitting here; the game has so far crashed on 3 different moments.

1) Building a lean-to, which is highly recommended by the game to keep yourself alive on your first night. Think that first house you made in Minecraft, just something to wait out the night, albeit an inventory item.

2) Saving. I'm not sure why, but manually saving crashes the game.

3) Quitting (oh the irony). Manually quitting from the pause menu also crashes the game.

I'll give this game a few weeks, maybe up until the refund period. The game has promise, let's hope it lives up to that.

So, after about an hour in this game, I'm already glad I bought it. Between the roaming packs of ants hunting down animals (and me) like wolves in that Liam Neeson movie and the wolf spider hunting me down like a giant sneaky assassin, I've already died a few times. I don't mind it though, you can respawn where you loaded into the world or if you've built a lean to (as far as I've gotten) you can set that as your respawn point. In my first 2 game days, I've made a workbench to craft more complicated stuff, some walls to protect my stuff, and a couple chests to store my stuff. I also made a roasting spit to cook bug meat (I assume it will be bug meat-I've only been eating mushrooms so far).

I like that there's a field station that provides somewhat decent protection from the nearby hostile bugs (stupid wolf spider couldn't get me in there, but I could hit it) and that you use the field station to "analyze" the various resources you pick up-and that's how you unlock the recipes to craft stuff. For example, analyzing sap unlocked the workbench recipe. There's a limit to how many things you can analyze at once (I assume it's to help with the pacing of the game) and once you've used your limit you have to wait 8-9 minutes before you can analyze something else.

I haven't tried out the multiplayer yet and I've only fixed the initial strange machine you find right after you walk down the path that led you from the spawn point to the field station. I'm as excited to reveal the story in this survival game as I am to build up a base and do the normal survival crafting game routine.

In short, I obviously haven't seen a ton of what the game has to offer so far, but for $30 and the knowledge that more content is on the way, it was an easy choice for me to get it. This already looks and feels more like a finished game than a lot of early access games.

Alright, After going through the full tutorial of learning the controls of the Game. I will say this is like Ark...but its Microsoft's touch on it with a "Honey, I shrunk the kids" movie theme. REALLY pretty game, but it will feel stiff every now on then on gameplay. To put it this way, the survival reminds me of ark (collect resources, everything has physics, raw/cooked (bug)meat can spoil, etc.). The map, Which is a backyard, looks great, it may feel small at first but considering its open world with physics, you can actually parkour from grass tip to tip (warning, flies are annoying bastards). So uh...before i like start like going "I RECOMMEND THIS GAME!", please be noted this IS ON EARLY ACCESS, expect updates. 2ND THING, spiders...there's a legit personal option on how goofy/terrifying a spider can look from your perspective in game, cause you know arachnophobia is NO JOKE. Last thing, I have not personally touched on the Multiplayer aspect of the game, its a microsoft game...which means you need a microsoft account to gain access to it. (plus I don't have any friends I know of that be willing to make a microsoft account to try it out with me anyways T3T)
